HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE QUEST;
His Early Promise Vanished, Bradley Plans to Quit Today

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO and NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

 BODY:
Magic was in the air as Bill Bradley returned to his hometown last September. Pundits and pollsters swooned, Vice President Al Gore's campaign was in disarray, and Mr. Bradley began his own presidential race with a speech as lofty as his plays as a high school basketball star in that very same gymnasium.
And then, of course, Mr. Bradley crashed back to earth. As one looks back to understand the collapse of his presidential bid, perhaps the most telling moment came not during Mr. Bradley's thoughtful speech that day in Crystal City, Mo., but rather in his encounter with Rita Thuesen. 
 Mrs. Thuesen, a slim, brown-haired woman who was Mr. Bradley's second-grade music teacher, went before the television cameras to describe the seed of a president in her old runny-nosed pupil. Then, as the crowd brimmed with emotion, she walked over to where Mr. Bradley and his wife, Ernestine, were sitting. If ever in the history of politics there was a hugging time, this was it.
"I stopped in front of them and told Ernestine that I hoped she would be dancing with Bill in the White House," Mrs. Thuesen recalled. "And Bill just sat and looked at us."
Eventually, Mr. Bradley's wife prodded him and he gave his teacher an awkward hug. But that emotional reserve, that profound detachment -- even shyness -- never left him, and his campaign faltered in part because he often failed to establish an emotional bond with voters.
Mr. Bradley will appear with his wife today in West Orange, N.J., to announce the inevitable -- that he is giving up a campaign that began with such promise, only to end without achieving a single primary victory.
The tale of how Mr. Bradley's campaign collapsed underscores a few lessons about American politics today.
First, as Gov. George W. Bush of Texas must be noticing, a sitting vice president with strong party backing is a formidable competitor and enjoys a huge advantage when the American economy is purring along in its longest expansion in history.
Second, voters may be angered by negative campaigning, but it works. In the fall, analysts bet that voters would be turned off by smarmy politicians fighting like wolverines, but in the end the public also seemed to want a candidate who could demonstrate that he was tough enough to defend himself.
Mr. Bradley's attempt to run a high-brow, high-minded campaign sometimes conveyed wimpiness, and one lesson may be that positive campaigners get torn apart by those wolverines.
Third, in the Democratic primaries, traditional constituencies like labor unions and members of minority groups still matter enormously.
In retrospect, one of the death blows to Mr. Bradley's campaign came just as it seemed to be taking off. The first primary, in a sense, came back in October when the A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsed Mr. Gore.
At the time, though, Mr. Bradley was still rising in the polls, staying even with Mr. Gore in raising money and attracting admiring publicity from the news media. Mr. Bradley inspired some people with the impression that he was above politics, running less as a 21st-century politician than as an Old Testament prophet, and he deliberately packaged himself as the package-less candidate, wearing scruffy suits and disdaining the hurly-burly of political attacks and counterattacks.
Mr. Bradley set the tone at the first of his debates with Mr. Gore, in Bedford, N.H., in October. A woman asked Mr. Bradley to comment "on the behavior of the '96 Clinton-Gore campaign as it relates to fund-raising." An easier question could not have been lobbed at the candidate, but Mr. Bradley refused to swing.
"I think there were obviously some irregularities that have been addressed," Mr. Bradley said mildly, and he then noted that both candidates agree on some ideas to improve the campaign finance system.
Why the reluctance of Mr. Bradley to employ his best weapon, indignation at Mr. Gore's aggressive fund-raising?
"There was an ongoing discussion in the campaign in early October about the level of response and how much the candidate should be involved in the negativity," recalled one of Mr. Bradley's top advisers. The conclusion was that Mr. Bradley should stay above the fray, apparently for two reasons. The first was tactical, that Mr. Bradley would sully his appeal if he engaged in typical political brawls, and that commentators and journalists would keep the issue alive instead. The second was an apparently genuine distaste on Mr. Bradley's part for attack politics and a feeling that it was beneath him.
The high-mindedness appealed to many Democrats who were sick of conventional politics. But it also left a huge opening for Mr. Gore, who throughout his career has been gentlemanly when possible and a street fighter when necessary.
Delicately at first, Mr. Gore began taking jabs at Mr. Bradley. The vice president warned that Mr. Bradley's health care plan -- an ambitious proposal that was intended to help the poor and members of minority groups -- was too ambitious and would cost too much. Mr. Bradley did not hit back.
In mid-November, Mr. Gore raised the stakes. It was a sunny day in Pasadena, Calif., and Mr. Gore was fiery as he stood in his shirt sleeves and offered a different critique of his rival's health plan. The vice president told a gathering sponsored by an African-American group that Mr. Bradley was trying to "dismantle Medicaid" in ways that would hurt blacks, Latinos and the poor.
"Any plan that tears down Medicaid leaves African-Americans and Latinos out in the cold," Mr. Gore declared. He added: "I would call on Senator Bradley to reconsider a program that has such a harsh impact on low-income and working families in this country."
Mr. Bradley and his aides were stunned.
"I'm waiting for them to say Bill Bradley will push disabled people out of their wheelchairs," fumed Anita Dunn, Mr. Bradley's communications director. (Sure enough, Mr. Gore did eventually assert that the Bradley plan would hurt the disabled.)
Privately, Mr. Bradley was steaming. But the campaign simply released a measured statement accusing Mr. Gore of "scare tactics and divisiveness."
The lesson, for the Gore campaign, was that Mr. Bradley would not hit back. And so in the coming weeks, Mr. Gore began battering Mr. Bradley from every direction.
An underlying problem was that Mr. Bradley was not terribly good at taking advice. In contrast to President Ronald Reagan, who recruited first-rate campaign advisers and happily stood on the spot they marked for him to get the best television angle, Mr. Bradley attracted advisers who were as scornful of political games as he was. And while he listened to suggestions, Mr. Bradley acted in effect as his own campaign manager.
"His advisers reinforced Bill's worst tendencies," grumbled one aide, who asked not to be named but who, like others, now believes that bad campaign strategy helped sink their candidate.
Another senior aide said of the inner circle: "These people were always concerned about what their relationship with Bill would be, as opposed to just doing what it takes to win. It should have been, 'I don't care what you think of me, I want to win.' "
As the 2000 campaign unfolded, there came to be growing doubts among Democrats that Mr. Bradley had what it took to win -- especially the ruthlessness and the furious, uncompromising, tenacious lust for power.
With Mr. Gore slamming blow after blow at Mr. Bradley, and often distorting his positions, many of Mr. Bradley's field organizers were eager to fight back. But the candidate and his closest advisers -- all of whom believed that they needed to take the high road -- kept reining them in.
In New Hampshire, Mr. Bradley's state director, Mark Longabaugh, was seething with frustration as he watched Mr. Gore attack Mr. Bradley's health care plan as both too costly and inadequate. One day, when Mr. Gore visited a series of New Hampshire pharmacies to attack Mr. Bradley's health plan, Mr. Longabaugh had had enough.
Using his desktop computer, Mr. Longabaugh created a satire of a prescription form that caustically mocked the vice president. The form prescribed medicine for "Gore-itis," whose symptoms include "uncontrollable lying."
"Take a healthy dose daily, especially when talking about the Bill Bradley health plan," the sheet said. "Failure to do so may result in uncontrollable negative campaigning."
In sharp contrast to Mr. Bradley's muted response to attacks, the vice president personally complained about the flier. He accused the Bradley forces of campaigning by "personal invective."
Senior Bradley aides were appalled by the flier and feared that it would conflict with his positive message. So they ordered Mr. Longabaugh to apologize, and Mr. Bradley's campaign chairman, Douglas C. Berman, issued an apology of his own.
"This flier is not characteristic of Bill Bradley nor the style in which he has run this campaign," Mr. Berman said in a statement.
The retraction was barely noticed at the time. But within both campaigns it became a symbol of how easy it was for the Gore campaign to shove Mr. Bradley without getting pushed back.
One of Mr. Bradley's mistakes, apparently unchallenged by his close aides, was the decision to devote huge resources to the Iowa caucuses. The caucuses have always treated insurgents poorly, and Mr. Gore had a huge advantage because of his A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsement and the resulting wave of labor organizers working for him.
Yet Mr. Bradley devoted much of January to campaigning in Iowa, and he spent more than $1.3 million on commercials there, believing that a strong showing would give him momentum going into the New Hampshire primary one week later. It became evident very quickly that the strategy was not working, but Mr. Bradley's campaign then underscored another of its fundamental weaknesses: it was not flexible.
Instead of changing plans and skipping Iowa, as John McCain did on the Republican side, Mr. Bradley slogged on. It was an approach that friends say had carried him through life. Each time he got in trouble, he buckled down and worked harder. That technique rescued him when he first arrived at Princeton University and found himself at sea academically, and it worked again when he first joined the New York Knicks and initially played poorly.
"He had his own view of how things were going to go, and I'd never seen him so confident as at the start," recalled an old friend. "He was so high on his expectations, and then he didn't act well when a couple of things went wrong. As a young man, he had a tendency to get moody when his performance wasn't perfect. In his early career in the pro's, he was like that."
Moodiness plays even worse in politics than in basketball, however. And his old techniques of improving himself no longer worked. After losing a game, Mr. Bradley would go out the next morning and drill with a ferocious discipline, sinking 25 baskets in a row first from one place on the court, then another and so on.
In Iowa, however, practice did not make perfect. And meanwhile, Mr. Gore was proving far more flexible a campaigner than anyone had imagined. Terrified by Mr. Bradley's successes, Mr. Gore revamped his campaign, honed his message and became a far more dynamic campaigner.
The two armies had a decisive clash in Iowa at a debate Jan. 9, where Mr. Gore used a remarkably effective technique: he called on a farmer in the audience, Chris Peterson, asked him to stand up, and then asked Mr. Bradley, "Why did you vote against the disaster relief for Chris Peterson when he and thousands of other farmers here in Iowa needed it after those '93 floods?"
The attack was deeply unfair, because Mr. Bradley had in fact voted in favor of the flood assistance. He had voted against an amendment for additional aid, but the Clinton administration had also opposed that amendment until the last minute. Instead of pointing this out, Mr. Bradley tried to change the subject.
There were times, however, when Mr. Bradley more than held his own in debates. On the NBC News program "Meet the Press" in December, Mr. Bradley showed uncharacteristic steeliness when he brushed aside Mr. Gore's handshake offer to stop using radio and television commercials.
And in a New Hampshire debate in early January, Mr. Bradley offered the more nuanced answer about gays in the military, saying he would not make the issue a "litmus test" in nominating members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Mr. Gore said that he would, a position he hastily backed away from amid criticism from military leaders.
Increasingly, Mr. Bradley -- after rapturous initial coverage in the news media -- began to be portrayed in print and on the airwaves as remote, out of touch and even arrogant and gruff. While other candidates went out of their way to win the hearts and minds of journalists, complimenting them on their questions with such conviction that one might almost think they were sincere, Mr. Bradley often greeted tough questions with scorn. And he seemed to think he could manage the news, even though it regularly upended him.
Mr. Bradley had never disclosed that he for the last few years he had suffered an irregular heart beat, a common condition known as atrial fibrillation. Aides said he had planned to release full medical information in January. But his heart interfered with that timing: he had to check into a hospital in December when his heart began thumping out of beat, and so the news poured out in a deluge that made him seem both feeble and secretive.
The Bradley campaign also held back potentially valuable cards even when it was in trouble. Michael Jordan, the basketball superstar, cut a commercial for Mr. Bradley in late December, but the campaign did not run it until February, when Mr. Bradley was already in a tailspin.
In the end, Mr. Gore won the Iowa caucuses on Jan. 24 by 63 percent to 35 percent. It was not particularly discreditable in a state like Iowa, but it came across as a major defeat.
In New Hampshire, Mr. Bradley found himself with another problem: the far more glamorous candidacy of John McCain. In what is now seen by his aides as a major error, Mr. Bradley had met with Mr. McCain in a joint appearance to demand campaign finance reform, giving Mr. McCain credibility at a time few were paying any attention to him.
Mr. McCain and Mr. Bradley were both running as insurgents against the political system, and both were running in part on biography. Mr. Bradley's Hall-of-Fame background had seemed about as amazing a past as a politician could have, but Mr. McCain was the one candidate who could trump him in that category.
In New Hampshire, with its open primary, voters became excited by Mr. McCain in a way that they did not with Mr. Bradley. Not only did Mr. McCain siphon off votes of independents from Mr. Bradley, he also siphoned away media attention. There might have been room for one rebel with a great biography in the campaign, but there was not room for two -- especially when the second sometimes had trouble working a crowd.
On the evening of the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Bradley addressed a raucous crowd of several hundred volunteers in a college gymnasium. The supporters repeatedly interrupted Mr. Bradley to cheer and chant their support, but each time he sternly waved his hands to hush them.
Finally Sheila Wellstone, wife of Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, tried to sustain that enthusiasm by doing an end run around Mr. Bradley. Each time Mr. Bradley motioned for the crowd to be quiet, she would raise her hands to urge fans to keep the applause coming.
In the end, Mr. Bradley lost the New Hampshire primary by four percentage points. Labor unions -- which had vigorously campaigned for Mr. Gore -- helped provide the vice president with the margin of victory.
"Bradley had floated above politics, and he thought he could float above the campaign," said Fred Siegel, a professor of history at the Cooper Union for Arts and Sciences. "Suppose he had run campaign ads with shots of the Buddhist temple" -- a reminder of the illegal campaign contributions raised when Mr. Gore visited with Chinese Buddhists in California. "He could have won New Hampshire."
Mr. Bradley's performance was still impressive for an outsider, better than Eugene McCarthy's in 1968 that forced President Lyndon B. Johnson to quit the race. But whereas Bill Clinton managed to lose New Hampshire in 1992 and "spin" it as a victory, proclaiming himself "the come-back kid," Mr. Bradley was simply cast as the loser.
Just as important, the news the next day -- and in the next few weeks -- was not about Mr. Bradley but about Mr. McCain's amazing 19-point victory in New Hampshire and his challenge to Mr. Bush. The Democratic race had a five-week lull after New Hampshire, and so all attention turned to the vicious battle on the Republican side. Mr. Bradley vanished from the airwaves.
As the campaign wore on, Mr. Bradley abandoned his focus on the positive and began blasting Mr. Gore for distorting Mr. Bradley's record as well as his own. But while Mr. Gore could knife an opponent with warmth, grace and apparent reluctance, the newly negative Mr. Bradley came across as petulant and strident, and his shift from one extreme to the other seemed to be desperation.
"When he felt things slipping away slightly, he did things like going negative," recalls an old friend. "But when he heard the words he was saying and saw himself on TV doing this, I think he got depressed. He hated himself."
The few photographers left covering Mr. Bradley became frustrated that their standard photos -- Mr. Bradley waving exultantly to a crowd, or shaking hands with a beaming supporter -- never saw light of print. One photographer said that he found that the best way to get newspapers to use his pictures was to transmit shots showing Mr. Bradley looking alone or dejected.
"They didn't want the rah-rah shots any more," the photographer said. "I realized I had to start sending shots that reflected the tone of the stories, which was negative."
Indeed, perhaps the most memorable photo of the Bradley campaign -- taken by a different photographer -- was a haunting shot of the candidate on a ferry in Washington State recently, surrounded by commuters but standing alone in his own world, gripping a cup of coffee.
In some respects, the collapse of Mr. Bradley's campaign obscures its accomplishments. Mr. Bradley contributed mightily to setting the Democratic agenda by pressing Mr. Gore to talk more than he had planned about health care, poverty, race relations, gay rights and gun control.
Mr. Bradley also mounted an unusually potent challenge against a sitting vice president in a time of economic plenty, briefly shaking the foundations of the Democratic establishment.
In the end, however, Mr. Bradley never managed to attract core constituencies. Labor remained behind Mr. Gore, and so did most black voters, in both cases repaying a sense of loyalty to the Clinton administration. And unlike Mr. Gore, who over the course of the campaign turned from wooden to flesh as surely as Pinocchio in the movie, Mr. Bradley never lost his reserve and rarely linked at an emotional level with voters.
In Tacoma, Wash., a few weeks ago, Mr. Bradley spoke to a group of children and began interviewing them, eliciting vivid tales of seeing people shot with guns. It was wrenching to listen to, but when they finished Mr. Bradley simply nodded, turned away and returned to his dry speech.
Mr. Bradley's oldest friends in Crystal City are saddened by this inability to connect with voters, but not particularly surprised. They describe him as a mix of his parents: Susan, vivacious and fun, is reflected in the humor and warmth that he shows among small groups of people, and Warren, the reserved, Victorian gentleman, emerges in more formal settings like with a larger audience or in a television appearance.
"This is how he was raised," said Carol Cunningham, Mr. Bradley's next-door neighbor in childhood. "Years of conditioning would make it very hard for him to change.
"Hugging your second-grade teacher? You've got to understand how we were raised. She's a person of respect. You wouldn't hug her. She's still Mrs. Thuesen."

HEADLINE: Greenspan In Warning About Loans

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, sounded his second warning note about the economy this week, cautioning bankers today to avoid making loans on the expectation that the record-breaking expansion would continue unabated.
The remarks to a bankers' group in San Antonio appeared to be the latest efforts by federal regulators to forestall a repeat of the savings and loan crisis of the late 1980's and early 1990's. In that debacle, lax lending, aggressive expansion into new lines of business and fraud at some savings and loans eventually cost the government hundreds of billions of dollars. 
 Mr. Greenspan said there was a "troubling trend" for many banks to take the strong economy for granted.
"Lending granted on that basis could have grave consequences for the industry's ability to weather weaker economic conditions," he said in a text of his speech to the Independent Community Bankers of America.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks came two days after he publicly expressed concern that the nation's record-breaking economic expansion could be ended by a resurgence of inflation unless growth slowed to a more sustainable level.
Private economists viewed Mr. Greenspan's comments on Monday, which were made in a speech at Boston College, as a clear signal that the central bank, which already increased interest rates four times since June, would do so again.
The Fed has pushed the federal funds rate, the interest that banks charge each other on overnight loans, up a full percentage point, to 5.75 percent, over the last eight months. That in turn has lifted commercial banks' prime lending rate, the benchmark for millions of business and consumer loans, a full percentage point, to 8.75 percent, its highest level in nearly five years.
Mr. Greenspan noted today that even with the strong economy, the federal deposit insurance funds had recently had some big losses caused by lenient lending standards and fraud at banks.
Eight United States banks failed last year.

HEADLINE: Germans Try A Second Run At I.M.F. Post

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
Defying warnings that history might repeat itself, Germany began a diplomatic offensive to install one of its nationals as head of the International Monetary Fund and received a generally lukewarm reception today in both Europe and the United States.
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder began lobbying European neighbors and the United States to support Horst Kohler, president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to head the I.M.F. But Mr. Schroder misjudged, if he expected that his nation's allies would quickly rally around the new German candidate after the first one he promoted was forced to give up a four-month quest to lead the monetary fund. 
 President Clinton pointedly declined to endorse Mr. Kohler in a telephone conversation with the German chancellor Tuesday. White House officials said the president had a friendly conversation with Mr. Schroder in which he took a neutral position on Mr. Kohler's qualifications for the job.
European officials also have not rushed to Germany's side. Italy's foreign minister, Lamberto Dini, delivered a frank public assessment in which he said that Mr. Kohler was "less than had been hoped for." A spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said Europe had not rallied behind Mr. Kohler, who once served as a close aide to Helmut Kohl, Mr. Schroder's longtime rival and predecessor as chancellor.
French and Portuguese officials made much more positive comments. But it seemed unlikely that Germany could forge an immediate Europewide consensus that Mr. Kohler ought to be the region's unified choice to lead the I.M.F.
It is possible that Germany's decision to throw its considerable political heft behind a new candidate and campaign publicly for him will work this time.
Some German allies, including the United States, are eager to avoid the impression that they are picking fights with Germany, and Mr. Kohler is widely considered a better choice than the previous candidate, Caio Koch-Weser, Germany's deputy finance minister.
But it also seemed possible that Germany, by choosing a person who does not top the lists of Europe's most qualified and politically prominent financial officials, had set itself up for another stinging defeat. That is especially true because both European and American officials have put a high priority on finding someone who can quickly command support and end the prolonged and divisive search for an I.M.F. managing director.
Late last week, the 182 member nations of the I.M.F. rebuffed Germany when they denied Mr. Koch-Weser, a close ally of Mr. Schroder, a majority of their votes in an informal poll. Mr. Koch-Weser had the backing of the 15-nation European Union, which has named every I.M.F. managing director since the financial institution was created just after World War II. But Europe's support was tepid, and Mr. Clinton went public with his vow to stop the German's candidacy after months of quiet diplomacy failed to dissuade Germany from promoting him.
The United States and other critics had argued that Mr. Koch-Weser, a 25-year veteran of the World Bank and a specialist in poverty relief, did not have the political stature or the financial expertise to head the I.M.F., which has been likened to a world central bank.
Mr. Koch-Weser's lack of experience in finance or monetary policy was considered glaring because the I.M.F. has been under pressure -- from Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, among others -- to focus primarily on its role as a crisis-manager for nations hit by temporary financial panic. Critics have urged that it get out of the business of providing long-term loans, development assistance and poverty relief, the sorts of programs that are the specialty of the World Bank.
Mr. Kohler has considerably more financial expertise than Mr. Koch-Weser and is better known around Europe. But like Mr. Koch-Weser he has also spent much of his career overseeing development and aid programs, suggesting that he does not have the ideal background to counter some of the criticisms aimed at his fellow German.
Mr. Kohler, 57, was long allied with the Christian Democratic Union, the party that Mr. Schroder defeated when he took power last year. He served as an economic assistant to Mr. Kohl.
In the early 1990's, Mr. Kohler served in the No. 2 position at Germany's finance ministry, the position Mr. Koch-Weser holds today. In that job, Mr. Kohler helped manage Germany's financial relations with Europe at a time when the region was working out the details of monetary union. But he was better known for helping to arrange the terms of unification with the formerly Communist East Germany, and then overseeing a huge injection of public funds aimed at rebuilding the region. He also had a stint in the private sector, managing Germany's federation of savings banks.
Mr. Kohler now heads the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, a mini-World Bank that backs development projects and businesses in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. He took the post just after the quasi-public bank wrote off tens of millions of dollars worth of loans when Russia, its leading client, defaulted on its debt in the summer of 1998.
Clinton administration officials have declined to comment on Mr. Kohler's candidacy. Moreover, they seem determined to avoid a repeat of their role in defeating Mr. Koch-Weser, when Mr. Clinton publicly played the heavy while some European countries hid their true feelings behind the veil of European solidarity.
But administration officials were also hoping that Europe would select a candidate who would obviate the need for extended debate. Among the several senior politicians in Europe talked about as potential candidates are the current and former British chancellors of the exchequer and the Italian finance minister.
"We support a European candidate, a candidate of maximum stature, who can generate a consensus in Europe and support from developing countries," the White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said today when asked about Germany's push for Mr. Kohler.

SECTION: Section A;Page 6;Column 3;Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 584 words

HEADLINE: Biden Joins G.O.P. in Call for Delay in Missile-Defense Plan

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
Adding weight to a growing bipartisan movement, a senior Democratic senator has warned President Clinton that he should leave the decision on deploying a national missile-defense system to the next administration.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democrat from Delaware who is the ranking minority member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, told an audience of scientists on Friday at Stanford University that he did not believe that the North Korean missile threat was sufficient to warrant a vastly expensive system that was not technically proven. 
 Further, Mr. Biden said deploying the system could not only severely upset relations with Russia, but also encourage China to increase sharply its warheads, prompting an arms race in Asia.
Mr. Clinton is scheduled to make a decision on a national missile-defense system in the summer. His top arms negotiators have been talking to the Russians over six months about deploying the system in a way that Moscow might find acceptable.
Mr. Biden stated his opposition after Chuck Hagel, a Republican from Nebraska on the Foreign Relations Committee, called for a delay until a new president took office.
Henry A. Kissinger recently wrote that an election year was not the time to proceed on national missile defense.
Mr. Biden, who amplified his comments on Monday in an interview, also cited election year politics as a reason for postponing a decision. Mr. Biden said that
 he disagreed with White House advisers who say Vice President Al Gore and the Democrats need to proceed with the system to inoculate themselves against Republican criticism of being weak on national defense and that the Democrats would be most successful by campaigning on the strength of the economy, and not allowing the Republicans to turn the focus to foreign policy.
"This is going to cost $30 billion, and there has been no national debate," Mr. Biden added. "This doesn't make sense absent public debate."
In explaining his opposition to Mr. Clinton's making a far-reaching foreign-policy decision under such time pressure, Mr. Biden said he was particularly uneasy with the missile-defense system because he thought that it would essentially mean withdrawal from the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.
That treaty, which its advocates regard as the cornerstone of arms control, forbids a missile-defense system that protects an entire nation. The administration has been trying to persuade acting President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to amend the ABM treaty so that Mr. Clinton could decide on a system without scrapping the pact. Russia has shown few signs of agreeing.
In his interview, Mr. Biden said he had an alternative idea to answer the threat from North Korea's Taepo Dong missiles, which are believed to be able to deliver strategic warheads to the United States.
Mr. Biden said an Aegis sea-based system with missiles based off the North Korean coast would let the United States intercept the missiles in their ascents. Such a system would not endanger the whole fabric of arms control or threaten nonproliferation safeguards in the way that a national missile defense would, Mr. Biden said.
When Mr. Biden spoke at Stanford, former Defense Secretary William S. Perry was in the audience. Mr. Perry has also expressed reservations about the system's being the best way to counter the threat of long-range missiles from North Korea and in Congressional testimony favored the sea-based system off North Korea.

HEADLINE: Mayor Says School Board's Base Is for Sale, Study or No

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city was aggressively seeking a buyer for 110 Livingston Street, the Board of Education's decrepit and maligned headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, and that he was not going to wait for the board's study exploring the possibility of a sale.
"Study!" Mr. Giuliani said derisively at a news briefing. "That's what the city used to be doing. It used to study itself to death." He added that although the board must approve the sale of the city-owned building, "we're going to push this process to the limit" and that the city "can put together a whole deal" for the board. Asked if he could go forward at this point without board approval, Mr. Giuliani said, "Damn right we can." 
 Board officials responded that the mayor was trying to pick a fight and get attention. One board member said that Mr. Giuliani was resentful that control of the city's education agenda had shifted to Harold O. Levy, the interim chancellor whose appointment the mayor opposed.
"We set up a process to take a look at the sale of the buildings, and we're going to stay with that process," said William C. Thompson Jr., the board president.
Mr. Levy, who telephoned the mayor shortly after his appointment in January but has yet to have his call returned, had little comment yesterday in the latest chapter of the continuous conflict between Mr. Giuliani and a board that the mayor regularly says should be abolished.
"I have been directed by the Board of Education to conduct a strategic review of both the board's facilities and its staffing, with a deadline of June 2000," Mr. Levy said in a two-sentence statement issued by his office. "Until that review is completed, it would be premature to comment on any efforts to sell the current board headquarters building."
Privately, board members said they were not going to let the situation escalate by biting at what they described as Mr. Giuliani's bait.
The mayor made his announcement at an elaborate City Hall news conference, complete with pictures and charts showing the three buildings that make up the board's headquarters in downtown Brooklyn: 110 Livingston Street, 131 Livingston Street and 65 Court Street. The three buildings are close to each other but not contiguous, and Mr. Giuliani gave no figures as to their worth.
The best known of the buildings is 110 Livingston Street, where Mr. Levy and the board members have offices. It is a former Elks lodge designed in the late 1920's by the legendary firm of McKim, Mead & White -- after the three famous architects who gave the firm its name were dead. The American Institute of Architects Guide to New York City describes the building as "pallid and boring."
Mr. Giuliani took on the tone of a real estate agent with an excellent deal to offer yesterday. "This is an area of the city that has gone through an amazing transformation over the last four or five years," the mayor said enthusiastically of downtown Brooklyn, adding that the city would extend tax breaks to buyers.
"So these are pieces of real estate that should have a great deal of interest," the mayor concluded.
Officially, the action of the mayor was an announcement that the city has issued a Request for Expressions of Interest, the first step in attracting bids from developers for the buildings. Michael G. Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said he hoped to have the buildings sold by the end of the year.
After the news conference, Mr. Carey said that it was possible that a buyer would acquire the property while Board of Education employees were still working in the buildings and that it would be up to the new landlord to decide how to proceed.
Mr. Giuliani first announced that he wanted to sell 110 Livingston Street during his State of the City speech in January, which people took as a joke. Yesterday Mr. Giuliani's critics said that the sale was a gimmick and not a solution. "The change of address is not enough," said Peter F. Vallone, the speaker of the City Council.
Hillary Rodham Clinton, Mr. Giuliani's opponent for United States Senate, responded with a three-page news release outlining what she described as the mayor's failures on education.

HEADLINE: Perils of an Asian War

 BODY:

To the Editor:
David Shambaugh, in "China Is All Bluster on Taiwan (for Now)" (Op-Ed, March 6), presents cogent arguments for why China is not well prepared to attack Taiwan. But he disregards the economic reality that the world has become highly dependent on electronic products produced in Taiwan and China, often by Chinese affiliates of Taiwanese companies.
China, Taiwan and the United States would suffer serious economic damage from a war. So would the rest of the world, with its ever-increasing use of electronic and computer technology. 
 It is to be hoped that cooler diplomatic heads will continue to prevail. A full-scale war in Asia would most certainly have heavy casualties.
It could also bring about a collapse of the computer industry, a return to the multi-thousand-dollar computer prices of 10 years ago and the possiblity of a worldwide economic depression.
 
BEN MYERS
Harvard, Mass., March 6, 2000

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Water's Edge

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
So I was starting to envy the political reporters, because there seemed to be no foreign policy in this year's presidential primary campaign. But then I realized that there was no policy in this campaign, let alone foreign policy, so there was really nothing to envy. So far, this has been a campaign about campaigning -- who has the best ad strategy for distorting the other guy's position and re-inventing his own in order to mislead voters. We had a primary in New York in which people actually discussed whether John McCain was for or against breast cancer, and George W. Bush, who presides over one of the most polluted states in the nation, ran as the candidate from Greenpeace.
I realize that distortion is part of campaigning, but when did it become campaigning? I guess the true measure of how little foreign policy figured in the primaries was the fact that none of the candidates felt impelled to even distort the other's foreign-policy positions. 
 The absence of foreign policy is due in part to the relative peace and prosperity America now enjoys, but there are other factors at play. To begin with, the substantive differences between the center of the Democratic and Republican parties on many key foreign-policy questions has narrowed. Face it, President Clinton has done to the Republicans on foreign policy exactly what he did to them on domestic policy: He took all their favorite issues and left them with the garbage. The Republicans wanted NATO expansion, so Mr. Clinton expanded NATO. The Republicans initiated Nafta, and Mr. Clinton got it ratified. The Republicans were in favor of ballistic-missile defense, so Mr. Clinton made it part of the Democratic plank too. There aren't a lot of global wedge issues left.
The differences have also narrowed because some of the key issues have become too complicated to distort. They are so complex they don't fit on a bumper sticker at all. You'd need the whole bumper to describe them.
America's obvious national interest today is sustainable globalization. Just that term is a mouthful. But the fact is, it's America's products, technologies, ideas, values, culture and style of capitalism that are being most globalized today. So surely our overriding interest is to keep that going -- by both stabilizing the world system militarily and democratizing it economically and politically, so that more people in more places benefit from this globalization.
That's the theory. The practice is even more complicated, particularly in an age when Americans are held responsible for everything in the world but don't want to die for anything. As such, the practice of sustainable globalization is a quirky combination of cruise missiles and Web servers. It means deploying classic deterrence against Iraq; pursuing arms control, I.M.F. aid and containment vis-a-vis Russia; combining gunboats, trade and Internet investment to move China along; and deterrence and potatoes to induce North Korea not to go nuclear. It is not heroic stuff, but so far it's kept the peace and globalization alive.
Finally, the differences have narrowed because for a lot of citizens the biggest foreign-policy issue is now the biggest domestic issue: education. Just as the Soviet launch of Sputnik elevated the importance of science education in the early cold war, the onset of globalization and intensified economic competition is elevating the importance of technology education today. In the cold war we thought we had to get smarter to survive in a world of walls, and in this era of globalization we think we need to get smarter to survive in a world without walls.
If you look at the center of both parties, argues Robert Pastor, an Emory University political scientist, what's left that really differentiates them is attitude -- "how they define American leadership" -- with the Democrats tending to believe that the best way to pursue our interests is by working with coalitions of allies, the U.N. and through international treaties, and the Republicans at least talking about more unilateral approaches and rejecting treaties, such as the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. But how much even those differences are real and how much they grow out of who's in office and who's not is unclear.
Bottom line: Both George W. Bush and Al Gore would drive with roughly the same foreign-policy map. It's really a question of who you'd trust with the car keys. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Hard to believe, but the direct marketer Draft Worldwide will acquire the iconoclastic AG.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
IN an odd coupling that makes Felix and Oscar seem almost like clones, Draft Worldwide, a giant direct marketing agency owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, is joining forces with AG Worldwide, the brand strategy and advertising agency owned by the iconoclastic creative executive Peter Arnell.
Draft, based in Chicago, is expected to announce formally today that it is acquiring a majority stake in AG, based in New York, for undisclosed terms. AG is known for developing and strengthening brand identities for advertisers like Banana Republic, Hanes hosiery, Tommy Hilfiger, Donna Karan, Ray-Ban and Samsung. Draft handles direct and promotional marketing accounts with estimated billings of $2.7 billion for clients like American Express, Compaq, General Motors, Stamps.com and the United States Postal Service. 
 The primary goal of the deal, which calls for AG to operate as an autonomous unit of Draft, is to improve client service offerings of both agencies. Draft, known for hard-working direct sales pitches, is hoping to benefit from AG's penchant for producing brand images perceived as chic and trendy.
"Over the last five years, direct and promotional marketers have been forced to become builders of brands," said Howard Draft, chairman and chief executive at Draft. "You've got to sell the product and build the brand at the same time.
"Where our clients are pushing us is more to Peter's model," he added, "powerful creative that drives results immediately."
Draft, which has made a skein of acquisitions since being bought by Interpublic in 1996, also seeks to capitalize on the Internet marketing experience of an AG subsidiary, Surge Interactive. Draft, which now handles interactive marketing in-house, is also acquiring a majority stake in Surge, where Chad Stoller, 28, will continue as president.
"We both recognize the shift to a digital economy," said Jordan H. Rednor, president and worldwide chief operating officer at Draft. "Direct marketing is where the Web is today, a one-to-one dialogue with consumers, and Surge will serve as a bridge between our cultures."
AG, for its part, is hoping to benefit from the Draft abilities to develop so-called direct response campaigns as well as access to the Draft worldwide network, composed of 3,200 employees in 25 countries.
"We have a lot of multinational clients," said Mr. Arnell, chairman and executive creative director at AG, which also has offices in London and Tokyo, "but there has been strong resistance to allowing us to manage brands globally.
"We really felt we had to get into the larger world," he added, which can now be accomplished by opening AG outposts in Draft offices overseas. Current AG clients, in addition to Samsung, include Consolidated Edison, Indulge.com, Playboy Enterprises, Polaroid, the Rockport division of Reebok International and the Universal Music Group unit of the Seagram Company.
As disparate as the new partners are, Messrs. Arnell, Draft and Rednor offered several explanations for their unexpected cohabitation.
"Howard understands who we are and wants us to be more of who we are," said Mr. Arnell, 40, who joins the Draft executive committee.
Mr. Arnell is known for his photography and design projects as well as iconic ad ideas. He listed among his and his agency's signature work the poster for Samsung showing "a beautiful boy holding a microwave oven"; a commercial for Chanel No. 5 "bringing Marilyn Monroe back from the dead" by inserting footage of her into contemporary settings; and print ads for fashion brands like DKNY photographed in black and white rather than color.
Mr. Arnell is also known as an independent-minded executive who is never shy about trying to get his way. His voluble disagreements with clients and employees are a staple of Madison Avenue gossip.
"I'm a brash, entrepreneurial spirit," Mr. Arnell said. So can he work for someone else, particularly someone owned by Interpublic, the behemoth agency company headed by the gruff, no-nonsense Philip H. Geier Jr.? "It's probably one of the most unusual marriages you've ever heard," Mr. Arnell said. "That's what's so hot about it."
Besides, he added, if the partnership fails, "in the next couple years you'll have a good story to write."
Mr. Draft, 46, laughed as he suggested a headline for this column: " 'Hard to believe,' " then added, "We at Draft are pretty independent guys, too. The last thing I'd want is not to have Peter come into the office every morning and feel he's in charge," Mr. Draft said, adding that Mr. Geier endorsed the deal by declaring " 'Go for it.' "
Mr. Rednor, 45, said he found more similarities between Draft and AG than might be evident at first glance.
Both agencies are about the same age, he said, Draft dating to 1978 and AG to 1979. And both have gone by many monikers. Previous Draft names include Kobs & Brady and Draft Direct. Previous AG names include Arnell Group Brand Consulting and Arnell/Bickford.
Mr. Arnell said he became acquainted with Draft through Mr. Rednor, a friend for 15 years.
In a previous career, Mr. Rednor was "in charge of the advertising group at Chemical Bank," Mr. Arnell recalled, "and when we didn't have a line of credit -- or a MasterCard or Visa -- we had Jordan."

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: A Good Trade Deal With China

 BODY:
Congress should quickly approve legislation needed to smooth China's admission to the World Trade Organization. By helping China into the W.T.O., lawmakers would not be endorsing Beijing's policies in other areas, like human rights and Taiwan. They would be speeding the opening and reform of China's economy and subordinating Beijing's arbitrary authority in trade matters to the rule of international law.
What President Clinton seeks from Congress is a change in China's trade status under American law. Currently, China's access to normal trading privileges in the American market is subject to annual Congressional review. Under the bill submitted this week, China, as a prospective member of the W.T.O., would be granted normal trading status on a permanent basis. 
 In years past, some members of Congress used the annual debates over China's trade privileges to challenge Beijing's human rights record and other offensive behavior. But linking these issues to trade made no obvious sense and produced scant results. More recently, the Clinton administration has wisely separated its efforts to open Chinese markets from other aspects of Washington's relations with Beijing. That has allowed the administration to support trade policies that serve American interests, while opposing Chinese actions that conflict with American values or threaten regional peace.
Last November the White House negotiated a highly favorable deal with China on W.T.O. admission terms. Beijing committed itself to end export subsidies and open its markets more fully to American farmers, telecommunications companies and financial institutions. By joining the trade organization, China will invite international scrutiny of its performance in keeping those pledges.
Senate approval of the needed changes in trade law seems likely. But the outlook in the House is less promising. At this point, only 50 to 60 House Democrats are willing to break ranks with organized labor, which strongly opposes the legislation because it wants continued annual review of China's harsh labor practices and denial of political freedoms. These are legitimate concerns, but best addressed outside the trade status legislation. At least 20 more Democratic votes are needed, since many Republicans who might otherwise have voted yes have been alienated by Beijing's recent noisy threats against Taiwan.
Unless Congress approves the China trade legislation by the end of this spring, the issue is likely to get caught up in campaign politics and delayed until next year. By then, China might back off from some of the market-opening concessions it is now offering. Neither the Taiwan issue nor labor's misplaced opposition should hold up an early, positive vote. The China trade bill serves broad American interests and deserves strong bipartisan support. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Nasdaq Market at 5,000: Volatility as Way of Life

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Seldom has an index risen as rapidly as the Nasdaq composite has done in leaping above the 5,000 mark, a hurdle it surmounted yesterday little more than four months after it first pushed past 3,000. Virtually never has an index done so with such huge volatility.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 149.60 points, or 3.1 percent, to 5,046.86 yesterday after having first traded over the mark on Tuesday, only to fall below 4,750 during trading Wednesday before it again began climbing. 
 That move has been largely concentrated in only a handful of sectors within the market -- biotechnology, computer technology and telecommunications. Other sectors have generally lost value during the period, as the decision of the Federal Reserve Board to push up interest rates has taken a toll.
Indexes of stocks that are not so concentrated in technology have done much worse. While the Nasdaq composite is up 67 percent since Nov. 3, 1999, the day it first closed over 3,000, the Dow Jones industrial average is down 6 percent over the same period, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks has risen just 3 percent.
While most stocks were falling, the enthusiasm for the "new economy," dominated by the Internet, has only increased among investors in recent months. And the performance of those stocks has not matched that of biotechnology issues, which have nothing to do with the Internet but which have suddenly come alive in their strongest performance since 1992, when biotechnology stocks dominated market speculation.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has made it clear that he expects to keep raising interest rates until the economy slows, and he has forecast that the stock market's surge will slow or reverse, thus dampening the wealth effect that has spurred consumer spending.
In a speech in Boston on Monday, Mr. Greenspan said the market was "groping for the appropriate valuation of these companies" and noted that "many analysts are now projecting that the rate of increase in stock market wealth may soon begin to slow." In fact, that has happened for most stocks, but the speculative fervor in favored stocks has continued unabated, and margin debt -- the money borrowed to buy stocks -- has begun to rise sharply.
As the number of shares that are rising has narrowed, pressure has grown on money managers to buy the stocks that are working and to shun the stocks that are not. That pressure has been intensified by mutual fund investors, who have pulled money out of many funds that have been poor performers while pouring cash into funds that have been rising.
"Right now, valuation measures are being thrown out the window," said Phillip Coburn, a strategist at Warburg Dillon Read. He said that the average price of technology stocks, using a measure that compares price-earnings multiples with earnings growth rates, is now twice what investors deemed reasonable only a couple of years ago.
Nonetheless, he said, money managers are only being prudent when they load up on technology stocks. "Given the fact that I don't see the end in sight, I don't think they are being foolish," he said. "They are being practical, and they are making money for their clients."
As the market has narrowed, even some of the large technology stocks that had been market leaders have begun to falter. Qualcomm, Dell Computer and Microsoft, all stars last year, are down in 2000.
Those losses have been made up for by many other stocks, however. "We've had this change to lower-quality growth," said Robert Farrell, a senior investment adviser at Merrill Lynch. "We do have a hierarchy of big tech stocks, but big tech is giving way to smaller tech, to anything that has a good story."
Among the winners, the Nasdaq computer index is up 26 percent and the Nasdaq telecommunications index has risen 19 percent since the end of 1999.
But those gains have paled next to those of the Nasdaq biotech index, which has risen 63 percent this year and has leaped 144 percent since last Nov. 3, the day the Nasdaq composite first topped 3,000. That is more than double the impressive move of the overall Nasdaq index.
But this week the Nasdaq biotech index has fallen 10 percent, without much in the way of news to explain the action. But then there was not that much news to explain the increase, other than growing investor enthusiasm for the potential profits from new drugs.
That volatility has beset the overall Nasdaq market as well. One way to measure such volatility is to look at the number of days when the Nasdaq index has closed with a gain or loss of at least 3 percent from the prior day, as it did yesterday. So far this year there have been 12 such days -- six up and six down, an average of more than one a week.
By contrast, during the eight years from 1988 through 1995, there were 10 such days, an average of slightly over one a year. Even last year, when Nasdaq's volatility was greater than at any time in the past, there were just 20 such days, an average of less than two a month.
That volatility has reflected the different forces competing for investor attention. Some days the hopes for exciting new technologies drive prices up. But on other days most Nasdaq stocks succumb to the same concerns, often about higher interest rates, that have bedeviled many other stocks.
The real losers have been stocks that are vulnerable to higher interest rates but have no competing technological allure. So far this year, the Nasdaq bank index is down 19 percent and the Nasdaq insurance index has lost 14 percent.
Data from AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund cash flows, shows that through March 8 funds specializing in the hot areas -- aggressive growth, technology, small cap and biotech -- had garnered 76 percent of the $93 billion investors have put into stock funds. At that rate, said Robert Adler, the president of AMG, the annual record for stock fund inflows will be broken by the end of this month. In 1999, those hot sectors took in 41 percent of the money invested in stock funds, up from 10 percent in 1998, he said.
"The massive inflows into the mutual funds are going into a narrow group of funds," said L. Keith Mullins, who specializes in small stocks as an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "Clearly, money is chasing performance."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1825 words

HEADLINE: Las Vegas Glitz Is Set to Go West;
Tribes in California Scramble to Expand Casinos After Vote

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: COACHELLA, Calif., March 9

 BODY:
The modest Indian gambling hall near a truck stop here in the California desert has little of the flamboyance of Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal in Atlantic City or of numerous Las Vegas resorts. About the only glitz is provided by illuminated star-shaped wall plaques autographed by Tom Jones, Crystal Gale, Shirley Bassey and other entertainers who have performed at the casino's combination theater-bingo hall.
"The Taj has incredible crystal chandeliers that will absolutely knock your eyes out," said Charles J. Irwin, general manager of the casino, the Spotlight 29, and a former vice chairman of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission. "The Vegas places have water effects and pirate ships and that kind of thing. This is just a small Indian casino." 
 But maybe not for long. On Wednesday, Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts announced that it had signed a letter of intent with the Twenty-Nine Palms Band of Mission Indians to take over the Spotlight's management. The tribe and Trump Hotels will raise up to $60 million to turn the betting parlor into more of a resort, which is expected to take on the Trump brand name and a dash of Mr. Trump's trademark extravagance.
The announcement came a day after California voters approved a measure to legalize Las Vegas-style casinos on Indian lands throughout the state, setting off a scramble by tribes to expand existing casinos or open new ones.
Casino companies from Nevada, New Jersey and elsewhere are angling to get in on what could become a huge gambling market. Three Las Vegas companies, Harrah's Entertainment, Anchor Gaming and Station Casinos, have already announced deals to build and manage tribal casinos, each costing roughly $100 million. Lakes Gaming, a Minnesota company that specializes in managing Indian casinos, says it has signed up two tribes. Other deals are expected soon.
Tribal gambling, of course, is already widespread. But the expansion of tribal casinos in California is noteworthy because the large population could allow the state to grow quickly into one of the largest gambling markets, perhaps rivaling New Jersey. Bear, Stearns has estimated that casino revenue in California will grow to $4.7 billion in 2004 from about $1 billion a year now. But Robertson Stephens estimates the California market will reach only $2.6 billion by then. By contrast, Nevada has about $9 billion in casino revenue and New Jersey $4 billion.
It is also noteworthy because California, next door to Nevada, supplies about a third of the visitors to Las Vegas and an even higher percentage to Laughlin, Reno and Lake Tahoe. California could thus pose a bigger threat than other states to Nevada's gambling-based economy.
"It's not a positive for Las Vegas, I can tell you that," said Mr. Trump, whose company runs three casinos in Atlantic City and one in Indiana but none in Las Vegas. One of the most attractive markets, he and others said, is this area around Palm Springs, already a sizable tourist spot. People from Los Angeles can drive here in about two hours, less than half the time needed to get to Las Vegas.
Nevada casinos spent more than $20 million to try to defeat a ballot measure in 1998 to legalize California tribal gambling. The bill was approved overwhelmingly, though it was later overturned in court. So this year the casinos did not oppose the measure, which got 65 percent of the vote, and instead are trying for a slice of the tribal revenues.
Even the master casino builder Stephen A. Wynn has been scouting, although the planned acquisition of his company Mirage Resorts by MGM Grand will take any decision out of his hands. The Cabazon Band of Mission Indians, which runs a casino a few minutes' drive from the Spotlight, has held talks with Mirage and other casino companies, said Brenda Soulliere, first vice chairman, who said no decision had been made yet.
There are already about 40 tribal casinos in California with about 19,000 slot machines. But the state constitution bans Nevada-style gambling, so officials had threatened to shut the casinos down.
Now, casinos will be able to put in full-fledged slot machines, not the so-called video lottery terminals they have now, which do not have arms to pull and print out winnings on a piece of paper. The tribes will also be able to have card games like blackjack in which players play against the house. (Now players pay 50 cents or a dollar a hand into a pool that is used to pay winners.) But craps and roulette will not be allowed.
All this could make gambling more attractive in California. And with the threat of shutdown eliminated, the tribes will find it easier to get financing to expand.
"I'm just so relieved," said Richard M. Milanovich, chairman of the Tribal Council of the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians, which spent millions of dollars to win approval of Indian-run gambling. The tribe's five-year-old Spa Casino is housed mainly in a huge canvas tent that stands somewhat incongruously in the middle of upscale Palm Springs.
Now the tribe is wasting little time. On Monday, the tribe is expected to announce plans to invest more than $100 million to build a permanent casino with an entertainment center and restaurants, and to replace the adjacent Spa hotel with a larger one. The tribe, one of California's wealthiest, is also expected to announce an investment of $80 million or more to build a second casino. The total number of slot machines is expected to grow to 2,000 from 1,150.
Some tribal officials dispute predictions of an explosion of gambling in California or a huge influx of Nevada companies. Some deals now being announced or proposed will not get financing or prove economically feasible. Some still require tribes to obtain land and could face local opposition. Many reservations in remote locations could not support a casino of any size.
"You're not going to have a lot of significant operations," said Howard L. Dickstein, a Sacramento lawyer who represents several tribes. He said more than half the existing casinos had fewer than 350 slot machines each.
For casino companies as well, the opportunity is somewhat limited. Under federal law, outside companies cannot own tribal casinos and management contracts last no more than seven years, and usually five.
"In a perfect world I would rather own 100 percent," said Glenn C. Christenson, chief financial officer of Station Casinos. Still, he said, such deals can be profitable. Station will get 22.5 percent of the net revenue of the casino it will build with the United Auburn Indian Community near Sacramento, a few miles from the highway that links San Francisco and Reno.
Still, some casino executives say it makes little sense to set up a competitor only to be kicked out after five or seven years. Some tribes, having already run their own casinos, do not need outside help and do not want to split the profits. Some tribes also have lingering resentment against the casinos that tried to defeat the 1998 ballot measure.
For slot machine makers the opportunity is less ambiguous. "It's probably one of the biggest markets that ever opened up all at one time," said Ed Rogich, vice president for marketing at International Game Technology, the largest manufacturer of slot machines.
Under an agreement between tribes and the state, the number of slot machines could more than double, to about 45,000 -- more than New Jersey's 36,000 but far behind Nevada's 200,000. And some analysts say the agreement could be interpreted to allow even more.
Each tribe will be allowed up to 2,000 machines; most big Las Vegas resorts, Mr. Rogich said, have 2,000 to 3,000.
Because of the shaky legal ground of the California casinos, the leading slot machine makers would not sell to them before for fear of losing their own licenses. The machines in use at the tribal casinos here, with names like Native American Gold or Native Nickels, are crude compared with the machines now available elsewhere, which have themes like Wheel of Fortune or Monopoly, and bonus rounds. And without clanging coins, these are no doubt some of the quietest casinos around.
Las Vegas itself is not expected to suffer much because its billion-dollar resorts offer entertainment beyond gambling. The city has continued to grow despite the advent of gambling in numerous other states. Indeed, there is some evidence that gambling elsewhere only whets people's appetite for Las Vegas.
"It's not like Las Vegas is going to be reproduced in Palm Springs," said Ellis Landau, chief financial officer of Boyd Gaming, which runs four hotels in Las Vegas. While there are five casinos in the Palm Springs area, they are spread apart.
But Reno and Laughlin, which have fewer nongambling amenities and are more dependent than Las Vegas on people driving from California, could be hit harder. Harry C. Curtis, an analyst at Robertson Stephens, estimates that casino earnings in those cities could drop 15 to 20 percent in 2001, but recover later.
Harry York, chief executive of the Reno-Sparks Chamber of Commerce, said the expanded California gambling was "definitely something we have to reckon with and deal with, but it's not going to kill us."
He said the city was renovating its downtown and advertising itself as a place for more than just gambling. And while 30 percent of the economy is directly dependent on gambling, that number has dropped as the city has diversified. For example, it has attracted a big Amazon.com distribution center.
But some people gambling here say they already visit Nevada less. "It's better than having to drive to Vegas," said Rita Recio, from near Los Angeles, who was playing a slot machine in the Palm Springs casino. The lack of clanging coins and the makeshift environment did not bother her. "I didn't even notice it was a tent," she said.
Many people interviewed said they supported the casinos, which they said had helped the economy and provided entertainment for the many retirees here. But there was some concern about casinos growing too rapidly or the area becoming too much like Las Vegas.
"I'd hate to see the smallness of it change," said Marjorie Young, who has lived in Palm Springs for 24 years and gambles at the Spa Casino twice a week.
The Palms Springs casino has drawn some local opposition, especially because of its garish electric sign, which some see as clashing with the city's more subdued ambience. But Mr. Milanovich, the tribal chairman, said the new casino would blend in.
As for Mr. Trump, some gamblers were puzzled about what a big developer could want with a little casino like this. "Compared to Mirage and MGM Grand it seems a rather small type of thing," said Joe Preece, a businessman.
Still, some said the money could help. Elaine Pandl, visiting from Wisconsin, said she found the casino a bit "tacky," but when she heard of Mr. Trump's involvement added, "Maybe he'll put in a new carpet."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Deutsche Bank Announces Merger Plans With Rival

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Mar. 9

 BODY:
Declaring the era of "Germany Inc." had ended, the chief executive of Deutsche Bank A.G. outlined a radical plan today to merge with the bank's main rival and spin off their retail businesses serving 10 million customers.
Though its main elements were already known, Deutsche Bank's planned combination with Dresdner Bank is one of the most far-reaching overhauls for Germany's huge banks since the end of World War II. 
 It would also unravel the labyrinthine cross-holdings that have bound together German banks and insurance companies, a move that could accelerate the pace of corporate change in Europe's biggest economy.
"The headline for this is disentanglement and thus another facet in the farewell from Germany Inc.," said Rolf-Ernst Breuer, Deutsche Bank's chief executive.
The merger could have an impact on Germany's other big private banks -- Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt and Hypovereinsbank A.G. in Munich. Both would be far overshadowed by the Deutsche-Dresdner colossus, and German newspapers were already carrying unconfirmed reports that Commerzbank had become a takeover target.
As expected, Deutsche will essentially acquire Dresdner in a stock exchange worth about $30 billion. With $1.2 trillion in assets and operations around the globe, the new Deutsche Bank would be second only to the forthcoming union between three of Japan's biggest banks.
Under a complex deal with the German insurance conglomerate Allianz A.G., which holds stakes in both banks, Deutsche will spin off both banks' retail branch networks in a new entity that will be called Bank 24. Allianz will then reduce its stake in the two banks but acquire 49 percent of Bank 24. Allianz will also acquire Deutsche's big mutual fund business, called DWS, as well as Deutsche's own insurance subsidiary, Deutsche Herold.
All told, Mr. Breuer told reporters and analysts today, the bank merger would make it possible to eliminate 16,000 jobs around the world. About 5,900 jobs would be cut by reducing the number of local branch offices in Germany, while most of the rest would come from combining investment banking businesses.
Industry analysts said the bank merger would have little impact on American banks, in part because Dresdner has little presence in the United States. But the merger goes a long way toward solving Deutsche's biggest problem, which is its huge and costly network of retail branch offices across Germany.
That network barely makes a profit, and analysts believe that Dresdner's local branch operations are running substantial losses. Both banks are suffering the same problem: a huge oversupply of branches and cut-throat price competition from Germany's savings banks.
The biggest surprise is Deutsche Bank's decision to jettison the entire retail business, only keeping enough control to be able to still sell its own financial products through them.
Industry executives have speculated at length on this kind of outcome, and Mr. Breuer himself has hinted strongly in recent weeks that the rise of electronic banking over the Internet makes it far less important now to serve customers through physical branch offices. Nevertheless, many analysts have been skeptical that Deutsche would give up such a big stake, because it means losing control over a distribution channel to millions of customers.
Today's merger is the latest in a wave of bank consolidations across Europe, from the merger of Banque National de Paris and Paribas in France to deals in Spain, Belgium, Italy and Scandinavia. Until today, Germany had been behind most other countries even though the banking market here is extremely overcrowded. Though experts and industry executives have agreed that mergers were the only possible source of relief, the four big private banks have spent years wrestling over who would cede control.
Officially, the deal is a merger of equals, but Deutsche Bank is clearly in charge. Though the exact ratio was not set, Deutsche shareholders will own 60 to 64 percent of the company and Dresdner shareholders will own the rest. The new bank will be called Deutsche Bank but will use Dresdner's green logo. Dresdner's chief executive, Bernhard Walter, will share the top post with Mr. Breuer.
Shares of both banks soared after news of the merger came out on Tuesday. But Dresdner shares fell 11 percent today and Deutsche shares fell almost 13 percent as investors assessed the cost-cutting plans.
Mr. Breuer predicted that the combined bank would be able to save about $2.9 billion a year, though that figure is considerably more optimistic than some investment analysts have calculated.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Led by Technology Issues, Main Gauges Rally Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Technology issues paced a strong stock market rally yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index soared through the 5,000 mark for the first time while the broadest market gauge of all, the Wilshire total market index, surged above 14,000, also a record.
After some early losses, prices climbed steadily without benefit of any obvious trigger as investors piling again into computer-related and other technology stocks were joined by those seeking bargains elsewhere. 
 "Tech had a great day and drugs had a great day," said Matthew W. Johnson, chief Nasdaq trader at Lehman Brothers. "There's money that wants to buy."
The Nasdaq market gained 149.60 points, or 3.05 percent, to finish at 5,046.86, surpassing the previous high, set last Friday, of 4,914.79, and solidly above the 5,000 benchmark it had briefly reached on Tuesday.
Other major gauges also surged, with the Dow Jones industrial average pulling out of an early 118-point hole to end with a gain of 154.20, or 1.56 percent, to finish back above the 10,000 mark. At 10,010.73, the blue chip average is now less than twice the Nasdaq composite compared with five times as much in early 1997.
The Standard & Poor's 500 advanced 34.99 points, or 2.56 percent, to end at 1,401.69. Of its components, 340 posted gains while 141 declined and 19 were unchanged. Cisco gained 615/16 , to 1395/16 ; Microsoft 47/16 , to 100; and America Online 6 3/8, to 61 1/4, to lead the way.
"It's the winners chasing the winners," said Ned Riley Jr., chief investment strategist at State Street Global Advisors in Boston. He predicted that investors would continue to favor high-flying technology issues for another three or four months until it became clear that the Federal Reserve was succeeding, as he said it inevitably would, in slowing down a white-hot economy.
Long-term investors, however, might want to start looking elsewhere for bargains, Mr. Riley said.
For a second day, it was the beaten-down drug sector that captured much of this attention. Bristol-Myers Squibb jumped 6, to 53 3/4, and Warner-Lambert 59/16 , to 91 3/8, with Lilly, Merck and American HomeProducts advancing more than four points each. Some analysts said the threat of government intervention to restrict price increases seems to have receded with the winnowing of the presidential field while others said that drug stocks had simply become too cheap to ignore.
"There's a perfect example of a group that was oversold," Mr. Johnson said of drug stocks, several of which have double-digit percentage losses this year. "People began to realize these things are valuable."
Aetna, whose stock reached 99 7/8 last spring and which an institutional holder wants to see auctioned off piecemeal, advanced 2 7/8, to 57.
On the other hand, Lehman Brothers recommended several producers of depressed specialty chemicals, but those stocks showed little response.
And PaineWebber found little enthusiasm despite a spurt in quarterly profits for H. J. Heinz, which traded as high as 54 last May but closed yesterday at 34 1/2, up 1/4. The brokerage firm cut its target price to 36 from 44.
Procter & Gamble, clobbered earlier in the week, was little changed.
The Wilshire 5000 index, which covers nearly every American stock, climbed into positive territory for the year, advancing 338.45 points, or 2.48 percent, to 14,006.37
On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,682 issues gained while 1,299 lost ground, but 52-week lows still far surpassed new highs, this time by 175 to 65. Volume edged down to 1.12 billion shares.
Overseas, major indexes rose about 2 percent in Sao Paulo and London but fell about one-half of 1 percent in Tokyo and Frankfurt. Hong Kong stocks fell 1.75 percent.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
Treasury Prices Rise
Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices increased slightly yesterday as the Treasury Department repurchased $1 billion of debt in the government's first buyback in seven decades.
The Treasury, which plans to buy back as much as $30 billion of debt this year, received $8.6 billion face value in offers of outstanding 30-year bonds.
"With inflation under control, combined with continued Treasury buybacks, you have a recipe" for bonds to outperform shorter-term securities, said Gary Pzegeo, an investment manager for Evergreen Asset Management in Boston.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 3/32 , to 10111/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.15 percent from 6.16 percent on Wednesday.
