HEADLINE: Mexico's Chief Justice Strives to Oil a Creaking System

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 9

 BODY:
Seated at his desk, Chief Justice Genaro Gongora Pimentel was partly hidden behind an 18-inch stack of judicial papers. With assembly line rhythm, a clerk was pulling writs and rulings from atop the pile, sliding scores of them, one after the other, under the chief justice's hand for his signature.
This clerical drudgery took much of an hour. And it is not uncharacteristic of routines at the Mexican Supreme Court, where the caseload is overwhelming. Last year Justice Gongora and his 10 colleagues issued 6,573 rulings. The United States Supreme Court issued 75. 
 The workload is one sign of the archaic state of the Mexican judiciary, the weak sister in the country's out-of-kilter system of checks and balances. The opposition-led Congress, though still dominated by an overwhelmingly powerful executive branch, is flexing new muscles. But the court system remains feeble.
That is what the chief justice says he is determined to change.
"I want to modernize our federal judiciary," he said during a recent 90-minute interview in his office. He believes that institutions must change for Mexico to compete economically.
Since he began a four-year term as chief justice last year, Justice Gongora has lobbied publicly for measures to reduce the court's workload and to strengthen its role as a referee between the executive and legislative powers. And he has endorsed Mexico's evolution toward democracy more forcefully than any previous chief justice.
"There's no reason to be upset," he told reporters as he left a tumultuous session of Congress last fall in which President Ernesto Zedillo had been heckled and raucous booing had drowned out the speech of an opposition member. "This was a display of pluralism. We Mexicans need to get used to new times."
His public candor has won him many admirers.
"The court was silent before," said Hector Fix Zamudio, a prominent Mexican constitutional scholar. "Justice Gongora has given it an active voice."
Some of his initiatives have drawn criticism, too. The court's appointment of about 50 new federal judges last fall under an expedited process that sidestepped requirements for a competitive examination aroused a furor in legal circles here. Many of the new judges have close professional ties to Supreme Court justices.
"He wants to confront the judiciary's problems, which is praiseworthy," said Jose Ramon Cossio Diaz, the law dean at Mexico City's Autonomous Technological Institute, whom Justice Gongora invited to serve on a judicial reform commission. "But the way he's gone about trying to strengthen the court is dangerous and could bring the judiciary into general discredit."
The Mexican judiciary has never enjoyed the prestige of the executive branch. A prominent lawyer returned from studies at Harvard University in 1972 convinced of the need to strengthen the Supreme Court, and urged a leader of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party to seek appointment as its chief justice.
"I wanted him to be Mexico's John Marshall," the lawyer said, referring to 19th-century America's pioneering chief justice. The party leader just laughed. "He said I didn't know how things worked, that to be on the Supreme Court was just to be in limbo," the lawyer recalled.
Three presidents in this century have simply dismissed Mexico's entire Supreme Court. One was Mr. Zedillo, who in his first month in office removed all 26 justices, installing a new 11-member court.
Justice Gongora, who is 62, was one of Mr. Zedillo's new appointments. He previously served as a judge, appellate magistrate and law professor. His colleagues voted him chief justice in January 1999.
Six weeks later, Justice Gongora urged constitutional amendments to increase the Supreme Court's power. Approved last June, they relieved the court of the obligation to rule on hundreds of arcane jurisdictional disputes that had clogged its agenda.
But its caseload remains extraordinary, and in response Justice Gongora has invited judges, lawyers and law professors to draft a simpler law governing the fundamental procedure by which Mexicans appeal sentences, file habeas corpus petitions, seek injunctions and contest the constitutionality of laws.
A curious feature of the system is that Supreme Court rulings declaring laws unconstitutional apply only to the victorious plaintiff. All other Mexicans must continue to obey the flawed law or file their own challenges. That can force the court to review the same law over and over.
Mexico's Supreme Court has issued several recent rulings that scholars say have moved it somewhat from the president's shadow.
But legal scholars could recall no ruling that had circumscribed presidential power significantly. "They wouldn't dare," said Elisur Arteaga Nava, the author of a standard text on Mexican constitutional law. "Our presidents are still far too powerful."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Luxury Housing by the Boardwalk

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
A condominium community that will eventually have 850 apartments in 16 midrise buildings is beginning to take root on 15 acres at the edge of the Atlantic Ocean in Brighton Beach.
The first two structures at the $325 million gated community, called Oceana, are under construction, and 81 of their 104 two- to four-bedroom apartments have been sold since October. This week the sales campaign expanded to 100 more units in two more buildings rising directly alongside the Boardwalk at the Brooklyn site. Once home to the Brighton Beach Baths, the site is bounded by Brighton Beach Avenue and the Boardwalk and Coney Island Avenue and Seacoast Terrace. 
 The units in the initial buildings range in size from 871 to 1,973 square feet and sold for $267,990 to $750,000, though a few units are still available in the $250,000 range. Prices for the oceanside apartments, which will be similar in size, will be 10 to 50 percent higher, with the penthouses costing more than $1.2 million, said Diana W. Jabber. She is a senior vice president at the Muss Development Company of Forest Hills, Queens, which is developing the project with the Carlyle Group of Washington, D.C.
Two acres at the core of the site are to be reserved for recreational use, including a one-acre park, a health club and indoor and outdoor pools. A 1,200-car parking garage also is planned.
Oceana is among the largest luxury housing projects to be developed in Brooklyn in decades. It will replace the collection of pools and lounges that made up the old bath complex, which, hurt by declining membership, closed in 1997 after more than 90 years.
"We're adding a community that is an alternative to the suburbs and that until now has been unavailable," said Joshua L. Muss, president of Muss Development. He acquired the site last year from his cousin, Stephen Muss, who tried unsuccessfully from 1986 through the early 1990's to develop 1,500 condos in four towers as high as 32 stories. Then the recession hit and the project never proceeded.
Joshua Muss said he and his partner modified the project to have fewer but larger units, because "it would be difficult to finance buildings as large as the ones proposed, and the market today is for spacious apartments." The buildings were restricted to heights of 5 to 12 stories to meet waterfront zoning regulations put in place in 1993. Mr. Muss said that while he is committed to building condominiums for the first four buildings, he has the flexibility to include housing for the elderly or rentals in the later phases.
Real estate brokers said the pace of sales at Oceana reflected the continuing strength of New York City's residential market, where demand still outstrips supply. "We are at a point of having buyers, but no inventory to sell," said Jeffrey J. Ferretti, who is the president of National Brokerage in Mill Basin, as well as of the Brooklyn Board of Realtors.
In neighborhoods in the central and south shore areas of Brooklyn, which includes Brighton Beach, prices over the last year for all housing types increased 10 to 20 percent on average, Mr. Ferretti said. His office put the average sales price for condominiums in and around Brighton Beach at about $250,000.
Buyers, he continued, include second-generation members of immigrant families, primarily from Russia, who want to invest in real estate, as well as empty nesters who want to sell their large houses and "reinvest in a home in the area with less upkeep." But, he said, the production of new luxury units in the area is limited.
Christopher D. Thomas, a senior vice president at the Brooklyn office of William B. May, a Manhattan-based brokerage, added that new developments that offer "services and a waterfront location can command a premium above the market." They can also attract buyers from outside the area, from Manhattan, for example, who are willing "to compromise a longer commute for amenities," he said. He added that "the farther out the development is the developer has to offer a better value."
Those are the buyers Muss Development has drawn or expects to draw. "We have the advantage of offering people the opportunity to stay in or move back to the area," Mr. Muss said. "With the housing market hot there is always a spillover from Manhattan."
Ms. Jabber added that the apartments, with nine-foot-high ceilings, cost "30 to 40 percent less than comparable size units on Manhattan's East Side."
Alex and Diana Klurfeld, who have two daughters, are trading their two-bedroom rental in a nearby Brooklyn neighborhood for a three-bedroom, fifth-floor unit with an ocean view they are buying for $426,000 at Oceana.
"We wanted to stay close to our parents yet be even closer to the ocean," said Mr. Klurfeld, a physical therapist in Williamsburg. "We think we are getting good value for the money and living there will be something like being on vacation all year round."
In addition to the planned recreational complex, other amenities at Oceana, designed in a classic style with gabled roofs and balconies, include 24-hour security and high-speed Internet connections. Monthly maintenance charges will range from $211 to $968 for the apartments and higher for the penthouses.
The development has also received a 15-year tax abatement, with taxes fully abated for the first 10 years and rising 20 percent a year for the next five years. With the abatement, monthly taxes on the apartments will range from $9 to $41; without the abatement they would be $207 to $946.
Occupancy of the initial four buildings is slated for this fall and winter. Mr. Muss said the entire project, depending on the pace of sales, could take three years to complete.

HEADLINE: House Panel Approves Aid to Bolster a Faltering Colombia

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
By a wide margin, the House Appropriations Committee approved an emergency aid package tonight of $1.7 billion to shore up Colombia's tottering democracy and enable its military to step up its war against narcotics traffickers.
The vote was 33 to 13, with opponents noting the abysmal human rights record of the Colombian Army, which will receive much of the money and equipment. 
 The House package, which was crafted by the Republican leadership and was an increase over the original request from President Clinton, included more money to help with human rights and judicial reform in Colombia and to help neighboring countries fight the narcotics trade.
"If we move the druggies out of Colombia we don't want them to land in another country in the region," said Representative C. W. Bill Young, Republican of Florida, chairman of the committee.
The president had asked for $1.2 billion for his two-year plan to support Colombia's tottering democracy and bolster its military efforts to fight the drug trade by reducing the booming production of cocaine and heroin in Colombia. The House panel today added $500 million to the program's budget.
Colombia is the source of 90 percent of the cocaine consumed in the United States.
But the country is embroiled in a three-sided civil war including rebels and paramilitary groups that are lavishly supported by the drug trade.
Democrats objected to what they said was the hastiness of today's action, arguing that the administration may believe it is only fighting a war against drugs in Colombia but could find itself unwittingly pulled into the civil war.
Calling on lessons learned from Vietnam, Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, said that while he didn't think the administration had any plans to send American troops to fight in Colombia, he worried that there "could be a confluence of events that could lead to that."
Mr. Obey failed to persuade the committee to withhold temporarily the $500 million of military aid earmarked for training and equipping two army counternarcotics battalions. He said Congress needed to know more about their mission to gain control over two cocaine-producing provinces in southern Colombia before approving the money.
The House package also includes money for 30 Blackhawk and 30 Huey helicopters for the Colombian Army and police forces and $115.5 million for the national police.
The entire $9 billion emergency spending bill -- which also includes aid for the Kosovo and East Timor peacekeeping missions, natural disaster assistance, and money to pay the Pentagon's rising fuel bill -- will go to the floor of the House within two weeks, according to committee aides.
Central to today's debate was the sense that Colombia's president, Andres Pastrana, may be running out of time to implement his "Plan Colombia" to strengthen democracy, a program that is also seeking money from Europe and international financial institutions.
Both Republicans and Democrats praised Mr. Pastrana today for placing human rights as a priority and for trying to negotiate peace with the guerrillas, even though he has failed to reach a cease-fire.
"He is in the middle, he is trying to lead Colombia into the modern world," said Representative James P. Moran, Republican of Virginia. "If we don't help him now it may be too late later."
But several Democratic opponents of the bills argued that it would be better to provide economic and humanitarian aid, and the Senate is likely to raise even greater concerns about human rights in Colombia when it considers the bill.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Drew Donations From 49 States Last Year

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Senate campaign received contributions last year from donors in every state except North Dakota, attracting an even broader geographic spectrum of financial support than his rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton, according to a report yesterday by a nonpartisan research group.
But the report, by the Center for Responsive Politics, criticized the Giuliani campaign sharply for failing to provide full disclosure of its largest donors, saying that 21 percent of those contributing $200 or more had not specified their occupations or employers in filings with the Federal Election Commission. 
 "Without that data, it is impossible to identify the donors' economic interests," said the report, which followed a separate report in late February by the same group on Mrs. Clinton's contributors. It found that the Clinton campaign had identified the occupations and employers of more than 90 percent of its donors who gave $200 or more.
The criticism provoked a sharp exchange between campaign advisers, with Mrs. Clinton's spokesman, Howard Wolfson, charging in a news release that the Giuliani camp was "evading campaign laws by refusing to tell the people of New York what his donors do for a living."
Although federal election guidelines require candidates to seek and disclose information on their donors' employment, there is a gray area in that donors are under no obligation to disclose what they do or where they work.
"Mrs. Clinton's press secretary either doesn't know what he is talking about or doesn't care," said John H. Gross, the Giuliani campaign treasurer. He said the mayor's campaign staff had "fully complied" with federal rules by asking for employment information in its direct mailings to potential donors and in follow-up letters to people who sent contributions.
The report found that Mayor Giuliani's campaign raised $11.8 million last year from donors in 49 states, compared with Mrs. Clinton's campaign contributions of $8.1 million from donors in 46 states.
It said that the largest source of financial support for the mayor came from people in the financial industry, based in Manhattan.
The earlier report on the Clinton campaign found its biggest source of support was among lawyers and people in the entertainment industry.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Life at the Corner of Journalism and Activism

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN

 BODY:
THERE was a time, back in the fiscally straitened 1970's, that the city was so desperate it turned to known members of the media for help. Thus did Osborn Elliott, departing editor of Newsweek, become a deputy mayor, largely on the strength of his side job as chairman of the Citizens Committee for New York City, which had recruited several thousand volunteers to fill city jobs left vacant by layoffs.
Mr. Elliott's tenure as deputy mayor for economic development lasted 14 months -- "I was among the rascals thrown out by the rascals who came in with Ed Koch" -- even though he only charged $1 a year for his services and the city stopped hemorrhaging jobs on his watch. 
 But the Citizens Committee has flourished, through Mr. Elliott's sometimes stormy eight-year tenure as dean of Columbia University's journalism school, through his hatching and leading a nationwide march on Washington in 1992 to demand more federal money for cities and various other episodes in a career spent exploring the boundary of journalism and activism.
The Citizens Committee, which has morphed into a teach-a-man-to-fish organization that has trained tens of thousands of people to be neighborhood activists and gives hundreds of grants a year to neighborhood groups, turned 25 a few weeks ago, not long after Mr. Elliott himself turned 75.
It was in the committee's offices in a former fur-industry stronghold on Seventh Avenue that Chairman Elliott was spotted this week, polka dot bowtie in place, old-money-New-York voice huskier and quieter after a successful battle with cancer of the larynx -- "They removed half of my voice box and there are those who say that was a 50 percent improvement right there" -- still arguing the merits of a more civic-minded press, government and citizenry.
Not only does the now-largely-solvent city need its volunteers more than ever, Mr. Elliott said -- to ease the transition from welfare to work, to help new immigrants navigate the winding corridors of city bureaucracy -- but much of the recent turnaround can be traced to them.
This is why a career big-picture guy, a big shot long past the traditional retirement age, continues to spend four days a week guiding an organization that counts among its proudest accomplishments of 1999 a $1,000 grant to the Garden of Happiness City Farms project in the Bronx, an $800 gift to a job-mentoring program in Queens and a $2,000 check to GLOBE -- Gays and Lesbians of Bushwick Empowered.
"When we started," he said, "there were about 3,000 block and neighborhood associations in the city. Now there are 12,000 groups, they're all on our mailing list, and we figure they enlist an army of about a million volunteers who are working in their neighborhoods, cleaning up the parks, indulging in community policing, running after-school programs for kids, taking care of the homeless and the homebound. It's almost like an underground movement that people don't really see."
Mr. Elliott, who with his high forehead and straight-line mouth closely resembles the portrait of Osborn-Elliott-as-George-Washington that hangs on his wall (not far from a subpoena he received in a libel suit from the vice president for the Newsweek article "The Scandals of '73: Enter Agnew"), does not seem the most natural of advocates for the newly arrived and the downtrodden.
A descendant of Steven Coerte van Voorhees, who came to New Amsterdam from Holland in the early 17th century, he grew up in the East 60's, the son of a Wall Street father and a mother who got her real estate license after Daddy lost a bundle in the Depression and became a powerhouse of the brownstone world. After the Navy and Harvard, he went to work at The Journal of Commerce, where he was, among other things, the nonferrous-metals reporter.
Mr. Elliott's resume as a neighborhood activist is, in fact, a bit spotty. "I don't think there even is a block association at 72nd and Madison," he said. After maintaining at least a pied-a-terre on the East Side for his entire life, Mr. Elliott, along with his wife, Inger McCabe Elliott, is preparing to move to Central Park West, or, as he refers to it, "Pittsburgh," but don't expect him to plant any trees.
"I think there are plenty of trees in Central Park," he said.
BUT at Newsweek, which he ran from 1961 to 1976, he kept a focus on the nation's underside, and he counts as the most interesting week of his life a 1970 field trip with other white journalists into the heart of America's black ghettos. "It was a tremendous eye opener," he said. "I got to know some people pretty well even though we were only spending a night or two in each place. It kind of changed my life in a way."
Nothing in Mr. Elliott's post-Newsweek life has matched the thrill of journalism, he said, but years of struggling to awaken the news media to the magic wrought by volunteers have soured him somewhat on his former colleagues.
"I've come to view journalism with a little bit less adoration than I used to have," he said. "I think it should be much more engaged, engage its readers more, engage them more in their community life." In big cities like New York, he said, newspapers, particularly this one, have an attitude that says: "We're journalists. We don't get involved."
All right, Mr. Elliott, if you were editor of this newspaper, what kinds of stories would you do?
"I'd say we want a real puff job on Elliott tomorrow."

HEADLINE: Mayor Says School Board's Base Is for Sale, Study or No

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city was aggressively seeking a buyer for 110 Livingston Street, the Board of Education's decrepit and maligned headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, and that he was not going to wait for the board's study exploring the possibility of a sale.
"Study!" Mr. Giuliani said derisively at a news briefing. "That's what the city used to be doing. It used to study itself to death." He added that although the board must approve the sale of the city-owned building, "we're going to push this process to the limit" and that the city "can put together a whole deal" for the board. Asked if he could go forward at this point without board approval, Mr. Giuliani said, "Damn right we can." 
 Board officials responded that the mayor was trying to pick a fight and get attention. One board member said that Mr. Giuliani was resentful that control of the city's education agenda had shifted to Harold O. Levy, the interim chancellor whose appointment the mayor opposed.
"We set up a process to take a look at the sale of the buildings, and we're going to stay with that process," said William C. Thompson Jr., the board president.
Mr. Levy, who telephoned the mayor shortly after his appointment in January but has yet to have his call returned, had little comment yesterday in the latest chapter of the continuous conflict between Mr. Giuliani and a board that the mayor regularly says should be abolished.
"I have been directed by the Board of Education to conduct a strategic review of both the board's facilities and its staffing, with a deadline of June 2000," Mr. Levy said in a two-sentence statement issued by his office. "Until that review is completed, it would be premature to comment on any efforts to sell the current board headquarters building."
Privately, board members said they were not going to let the situation escalate by biting at what they described as Mr. Giuliani's bait.
The mayor made his announcement at an elaborate City Hall news conference, complete with pictures and charts showing the three buildings that make up the board's headquarters in downtown Brooklyn: 110 Livingston Street, 131 Livingston Street and 65 Court Street. The three buildings are close to each other but not contiguous, and Mr. Giuliani gave no figures as to their worth.
The best known of the buildings is 110 Livingston Street, where Mr. Levy and the board members have offices. It is a former Elks lodge designed in the late 1920's by the legendary firm of McKim, Mead & White -- after the three famous architects who gave the firm its name were dead. The American Institute of Architects Guide to New York City describes the building as "pallid and boring."
Mr. Giuliani took on the tone of a real estate agent with an excellent deal to offer yesterday. "This is an area of the city that has gone through an amazing transformation over the last four or five years," the mayor said enthusiastically of downtown Brooklyn, adding that the city would extend tax breaks to buyers.
"So these are pieces of real estate that should have a great deal of interest," the mayor concluded.
Officially, the action of the mayor was an announcement that the city has issued a Request for Expressions of Interest, the first step in attracting bids from developers for the buildings. Michael G. Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said he hoped to have the buildings sold by the end of the year.
After the news conference, Mr. Carey said that it was possible that a buyer would acquire the property while Board of Education employees were still working in the buildings and that it would be up to the new landlord to decide how to proceed.
Mr. Giuliani first announced that he wanted to sell 110 Livingston Street during his State of the City speech in January, which people took as a joke. Yesterday Mr. Giuliani's critics said that the sale was a gimmick and not a solution. "The change of address is not enough," said Peter F. Vallone, the speaker of the City Council.
Hillary Rodham Clinton, Mr. Giuliani's opponent for United States Senate, responded with a three-page news release outlining what she described as the mayor's failures on education.

HEADLINE: Boat People Losing (Uneasy) Haven

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 6

 BODY:
Ask Nguyen Kim Lien about life inside the barbed-wire fence of the Pillar Point Vietnamese Refugee Camp here and she is remarkably stoic. Her family lives in squalor -- a couple of rooms in a dilapidated housing block, where rats prowl brazenly outside the door. Her husband, who is out of work and addicted to heroin, spends his days wandering the camp in a haze.
Yet Mrs. Lien, 36, has found dignity amid the debris. She runs a shop that sells Vietnamese noodles to the camp's 1,070 refugees. Her two children, who were born in Hong Kong and have never lived outside the camp, go to a nearby school, where they are learning to read and write Chinese. 
 If Mrs. Lien has a reason to despair, it is because in two months she and her family must leave Pillar Point and find a way to support themselves elsewhere in Hong Kong. Last month, this former British colony announced it was shutting down its only remaining refugee camp, ending a drama that began in May 1975, a month after the fall of Saigon, when the first boat laden with refugees came ashore here.
"I'm scared," said Mrs. Lien, who fled Vietnam in 1988 and has been in Pillar Point since 1991. "Inside the camp, I can support myself. But outside, I don't know. I'm scared that I won't get used to it."
People like Nguyen Kim Lien are the ebb tide of a vast diaspora. Of the more than 800,000 Vietnamese who passed through camps in Southeast Asian countries between 1975 and the late-1980's, about 224,000 came to Hong Kong. Most of these went on to settle in the United States, Canada and other countries. At its peak in 1979, there were 68,695 refugees crowded into camps throughout the colony.
Hong Kong says it treated the boat people better than other Asian countries, welcoming them sooner and taking care of them longer. But it granted residency to only a few ethnic Chinese refugees and by the mid-1990's it had put 94,700 people on planes back to Vietnam -- often dragging them up the ramp.
The 1,400 boat people left in Hong Kong have fallen through all the cracks. After more than a decade of filing applications, they cannot gain asylum anywhere else. And they either cannot or will not return to Vietnam.
At a time when Hong Kong has closed its doors to immigrants from mainland China, it is no longer willing to take care of these holdouts. In February, it agreed to consider them for legal status here, but also imposed a deadline: move into society by May 31. They can choose to remain refugees, but Hong Kong will no longer try to find them homes overseas. It will also stop paying for their housing.
"It's time for us to close this chapter of history," said Regina Ip, Hong Kong's secretary of security, who handles immigration policy. "It's been a problem for Hong Kong for a quarter of a century."
Although Hong Kong's ultimatum sounds abrupt, few people fault the government for imposing it. Even critics say the continued existence of Pillar Point has become an intractable hurdle to the efforts of the Vietnamese to get on with their lives. A grim, isolated compound in Hong Kong's New Territories, it is a breeding ground for drug abuse, petty crime and sporadic violence.
Unlike in the 1980's, when the camps were virtual prisons, Pillar Point is open, and residents are encouraged to find jobs outside. But the housing blocks were meant to be temporary structures, and they now look like abandoned army barracks. Even after more than a decade, life for the refugees still feels tenuous.
Last June, the police broke up a riot between Vietnamese and ethnic Chinese refugees, also from Vietnam, who live uneasily next to each other. Sixteen people were injured in the melee. A chain-link fence topped with barbed wire now slices through the camp to separate the two groups.
"The condition of the camp is appalling," said Pam Baker, a British lawyer who has represented boat people in cases against the government. "It really is a purpose-built den of iniquity."
Although the government has prodded the refugees to move into their own apartments, it refused until last month to grant them legal status, and the accompanying identification cards. That made it hard for them to find decent work. With rents in Hong Kong among the highest in Asia, the lure of free housing pulled many back into the camp. Along with residency, the refugees would get ID cards.
"This is a logical conclusion, but it's not a complete conclusion," Ms. Baker said. "What's going to happen to those people who are not accepted for residency? What's going to happen to those who are not allowed to apply?"
More than 130 people would seem to fall into one of those categories. Most have been classified as illegal immigrants or economic migrants rather than refugees. The Vietnamese government has refused to take many back because they have criminal records or health problems. Hong Kong insists it will continue trying to repatriate them, though it is vague about what it will do if that fails.
For those who gain residency, the biggest challenge may be shedding the attitudes developed in years of camp life. Diep Long Anh, 42, an ethnic Chinese who fled Ho Chi Minh City in 1990, said she thought about moving out several times. But the free housing allows her to stay home with her son while her husband works on a construction site. "It's not that we don't want to work," Mrs. Anh said. "We're not lazy. It's just that we worry about getting jobs. It's so expensive to live outside."
Other refugees still dream of moving to California or Canada. This despite the fact that Hong Kong resettled only 71 people in 1999 and a single person so far this year. The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which had helped process applications, is so beset with refugee problems in Africa and the Balkans that it no longer finances its program here.
Despite Hong Kong's financial outlays, the sense of futility among many refugees has mutated into bitterness toward their adopted home. Some blame their predicament on Hong Kong's return to China in 1997.
"We came here because we wanted freedom, but now Hong Kong is a Communist country," said Nguyen Van Thang, a wiry man with hollow eyes who looks older than his 28 years. Mr. Thang said he still hoped to move to Britain.
Not all the refugees regard their future with dread. Pham Thi Binh, 38, who arrived in Hong Kong in 1988, has bounced in and out of Pillar Point a few times as she and her husband have tried to make it outside. They both work on a construction site.
Mrs. Binh is determined to succeed. "After all these years in Hong Kong, we know we just have to work hard," she said. "If I save enough, I'll go back and invest in Vietnam," she added, with a smile so broad that it briefly lifted the camp's gloom.

HEADLINE: A Leap in the Dropout Rate Confounds School Officials

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

 BODY:
New York City school officials were struggling yesterday to explain a mysterious and worrisome 2-percentage-point increase in the high school dropout rate, after seven years of declines.
Some principals said students might be dropping out because they were intimidated by the approach of tough new state standards. Some guidance counselors at special schools for failing students said conventional high schools were encouraging their weakest students to leave so that the schools would not appear to be doing a bad job preparing students for the tougher state tests. 
 And some school officials, noting that a large proportion of the dropouts are foreign-born, speculated that an increasing number of immigrants were coming from countries with shabby educational systems and then dropping out.
But in its own report, released on Tuesday along with the annual school report cards, the Board of Education hinted at the most intriguing explanation of all: a crackdown on the longstanding practice of allowing phantom students to appear on high school attendance registers.
Two high-level Board of Education administrators, who spoke on the condition that they not be named, said they believed the dropout rate had been underreported for years, because many schools, hoping to increase state aid, continued to carry students on their rosters long after they had left school with no intention of returning.
The school board refused to comment on the results.
The dropout rate rose to 17.5 percent for the class of 1999 -- the class that was scheduled to graduate last June. That compares with 15.6 percent for the class of 1998. The disparity means about 1,200 more students from the class of 1999 dropped out than from the class of 1998.
The latest figures show the first rise in the dropout rate since 1991, when the rate stood at 20.5 percent.
But there was a paradox to the figures for the class of 1999, one giving credence to the notion that many students were never really there. While more students were dropping out, more were also graduating. The four-year graduation rate for the class of 1999 went up, to 50.1 percent, from 49.7 percent, the first time since 1994 that it had been above 50 percent. At the same time, fewer students stayed in school beyond four years, for as many as seven years. The number of students who attended a fifth year declined by 2.3 points, to 32.4 percent of the class of 1999, compared with 34.7 percent of the class of 1998.
Whatever the reason for the sudden reversal of dropouts, education advocates said yesterday that it was a wake-up call to a system that for many years has been too quick to interpret marginal gains as signs of progress.
"It's a pretty negative report," said Raymond J. Domanico, education adviser for the Metro Industrial Areas Foundation, a coalition of civic and church groups. "We have been told the last few years that things are improving. This is another piece of evidence that says that was not true. With the system under pressure by the standards to improve, there seems to be some indication that the improvement efforts are not taking root."
Much of the speculation yesterday focused on attendance. In part, the two high-level administrators said, the attendance records were sometimes inadvertently inflated, resulting from a lackadaisical approach to tracking truant and missing students. But sometimes the figures were deliberately overstated, they said, to increase state aid, which is partly based on attendance.
In January 1999, Gov. George E. Pataki formed a Moreland Act commission to investigate reports of phantom students at Brandeis and Martin Luther King Jr. High Schools in Manhattan, among other places. The commission's report, released in December, alleged "widespread, systemic abuse" in attendance-keeping but was attacked as flimsy by school officials because it did not specify any schools where such abuse had occurred.
Michael Marr, a spokesman for the commission, said the new dropout numbers confirmed the commission's findings. "Based on what we found here at the Moreland commission with regard to dropout numbers, the prior year's numbers are quite suspect," Mr. Marr said yesterday. "Sunshine is the best disinfectant, and we can only hope that the Board of Education has started to clean up its act."
The two officials said yesterday that the school system itself began cracking down on overstated attendance in the fall of 1997, long before Governor Pataki's commission was formed. That is why, one official said, Brandeis and Martin Luther King dropout rates remained stable from 1998 to 1999, because they were among the first schools that the Board of Education cracked down on.
Tony Hoffmann, assistant principal at Middle College High School in Queens, where the dropout rate declined, said he believed that the specter of tough new Regents graduation tests had scared many students and schools. Some students, he suggested, might have mistakenly believed that the new standards applied to them, and dropped out. In fact, the new tests took effect for the class of 2000 and were not required of the class of 1999.
Asked whether a hot economy might have prompted students to drop out to enter the work force, school officials were doubtful. Bridget N. O'Connor, associate professor of business education at New York University, said only the worst paying and lowest status jobs -- like working in a fast-food restaurant -- were available to students without high school diplomas.
"I sure wouldn't leave for one of those kinds of jobs," she said.
The overall 2-point increase disguised much more striking jumps in dropout rates at some schools. They included several small alternative Manhattan schools: the Coalition School for Social Change, to 17 percent from 2 percent, and Landmark High School, to 7.3 percent from 1.7 percent. In the Bronx, big jumps came at Sarah J. Hale, to 24.5 percent from 12.7 percent; Adlai Stevenson, to 31.8 percent from 26.6 percent; and Evander Childs, to 23.4 percent from 17.9 percent. In Brooklyn, the worst were Bushwick, to 30.1 percent from 19.6 percent, and John Dewey, to 14.5 percent from 9.6 percent. In Manhattan, Art and Design rose to 5.1 percent from 0.7 percent, and in Queens, Hillcrest rose to 16.1 percent from 9.6 percent.

HEADLINE: Vibrant Area of Newark Suffers With Success

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS

DATELINE: NEWARK, March 9

 BODY:
Soaring home prices. Sclerotic traffic. The maddening roar of new construction. Too many people, not enough room.
Ah, the woes of a booming economy. 
 But in an unlikely tale for flush times, the locale in question is not Manhattan or Westchester County, but a corner of Newark, a city left for dead after the 1967 riots, where almost a third of the residents still live in poverty. The Ironbound section, long a bastion of Portuguese immigrants and more recently a magnet for Brazilians and other Latin Americans, has become one of the hottest swaths of real estate in the region.
More than 900 homes have been built here in the last three years, real estate values have risen 30 to 40 percent and most houses are snapped up after just days on the market. "It's been out of this world," said Jack DaSilva, a local developer who recently sold 150 homes in the Ironbound before even a single foundation had been poured.
Now, many residents complain, this bustling neighborhood of about 45,000 people has become too popular for its own good. The cost of housing is forcing families to double and triple up, the rising population has made parking nightmarish and local schools are overwhelmed by the influx of students, many of them Latin American immigrants who speak little English.
"Our quality of life has gone down the tubes," said Mary Correia, 39, the daughter of Portuguese parents who works in the neighborhood but recently moved to the suburbs. "This is no place to raise a family."
Overdevelopment is also feeding tensions between the Portuguese, whom many credit with saving the neighborhood during Newark's darkest days, and the newly arrived Brazilians, who often get blamed for the crowded streets and steep housing prices.
The Rev. Moacir Weirich, a Lutheran minister who runs a storefront church here, said the problems associated with explosive growth had revived long-buried animosities between the faded imperial power and its former colony. "People are angry and they're just looking for someone to blame," said Mr. Weirich, who is Brazilian. "They make easy targets for each another."
A hodgepodge of vinyl-sided homes and 19th-century factories, the Ironbound has always been a gritty, working-class place, named for the railroad tracks that once surrounded it. Even after the riots, when Newark suffered decades of depopulation and disinvestment and a crippling loss of faith, the Ironbound, bolstered by Portuguese immigration, remained a pocket of stability.
Outsiders might find it hard to appreciate the lure of the Ironbound, a densely packed neighborhood where new $300,000 homes -- most without yards -- are raked by the whoosh of planes landing at nearby Newark International Airport.
There are few parks or playgrounds here, and highways, railroad tracks and derelict warehouses are among the area's more prominent features. A layer of concrete separates many of the new homes from toxic soil, a legacy of the area's industrial past.
Augusto Amador, the Ironbound's representative on the Newark City Council, said people were drawn here by easy access to jobs, proximity to the state's main roads and good public transportation. It also helps that immigrants can navigate daily life without worrying about their limited English, he said.
"If you're a hard-working immigrant and you want to settle down in a safe, secure neighborhood, there's no better place to be," said Mr. Amador, who came here from Portugal as a 17-year-old in 1966. "You don't find this kind of stability elsewhere in Newark."
That stability has been fostered by the neighborhood's physical separation from the rest of the city and by the Portuguese, who began arriving in the late 1960's, replacing the Italians, Poles and Irish who came before them.
Although downtown Newark has benefited from a new performing arts center, a minor league baseball stadium and the promise of a professional sports complex, New Jersey's largest city remains mired in poverty.
With its modest two- and three-family houses, many of them built on the sites of former factories, the Ironbound is house-proud but not fussy. Charles Cummings, Newark's official historian, calls it "our Greenwich Village, without the bohemians."
Its vibrant street life is striking as one passes beneath the elevated tracks separating the neighborhood from the downtown and its fenced-in parking lots, vacant office buildings and empty sidewalks. By contrast, the Ironbound's main commercial artery, Ferry Street, is lined with restaurants and bakeries, its sidewalks thick with pedestrians. "I defy you to find an empty storefront on Ferry Street," Mr. Cummings said.
On weekends, thousands of Brazilians, Portuguese and other visitors from the metropolitan area flock to Ferry Street, snarling traffic and double parking on side streets. On most afternoons, the desperate honking of blocked-in drivers fills the air.
For business owners like Jose Moreira, the throngs are good news. "On weekends you can't even walk around in here," Mr. Moreira said on a recent Sunday as he held court at his restaurant, Casa Nova. Brazilian families gathered at tables loaded with barbecued meats, known as churrasco, and men sat along the counter trading gossip and sipping coffee or Brazilian beer.
Mr. Moreira, 33, who arrived here in 1988 and spent years as a landscaper, has done well in the Ironbound. Last year he opened his third restaurant in the neighborhood and he is planning a fourth. "As long as the Brazilians keep coming, I'm going to do good," he said.
Back in his home state of Minas Gerais, Newark is something of a household name, known as a place that promises steady employment to those unintimidated by hard work. The men find jobs as construction workers, landscapers or bakers; the women are usually hired as baby sitters or housekeepers.
They come already knowing the name of Mr. Moreira. Almost daily, newly arrived Brazilians, dragging their luggage behind them, walk into Casa Nova seeking advice, apartments and the comfort of compatriots. Last week it was Elio Lana, 34, a truck driver from Ipatinga who came directly from Newark airport with questions about work. Asked why he came to Newark and not New York City, the celebrated landing pad for immigrants, he smiled. "Everyone knows Newark is much easier than New York," he said.
There are no figures on how many Brazilians live in the Ironbound, but real estate agents estimate that 60 percent of the homes on the market are bought by Brazilians; the remaining buyers are Portuguese, Ecuadorans, Peruvians and Mexicans.
Like many entrepreneurs, Kenneth Rocco has met the influx by hiring more Brazilians at his travel agency, Monica Travel, which also wires money and offers long-distance telephone services. Five of his six employees, he said, are from Brazil. "Brazilians are our future," he said.
Not that the Portuguese are becoming extinct. They remain the neighborhood's most prominent business leaders and are behind nearly all of the new construction. Jacinto Rodrigues, for example, one of the city's largest builders, is also an owner of Crown Bank, a local lending institution that provides many Ironbound homebuyers with mortgages. Some of the biggest employers in Newark are the Ironbound's Portuguese bakeries and restaurants.
But one thing is indisputable: as Brazilians continue to flow into the area, immigration from Portugal has all but dried up. At the same time, many Portuguese families are moving to the suburbs and a growing number of the elderly are retiring to homes they built in Portugal.
The shifting demographics have fostered discord between the two groups, although most everyone agrees that the conflict finds its worst expression in off-color jokes. "We basically make the same silly cracks about each other," said Alessandra Braganca, 27, a travel agent who moved to Newark from Rio de Janeiro six years ago. "They think we're stupid, we think they're snobs."
Some real estate brokers worry that many of those buying new homes are in over their heads. Much of the buying frenzy, they said, has been fueled by subsidized loan programs or mortgages that allow buyers to put down as little as 3 percent.
And because many of them work in construction, an industry notoriously susceptible to economic vagaries, a recession could hit the Ironbound especially hard. "If there's a downturn, there are going to be a lot of people defaulting on their mortgages," said Carlos Couto, the owner of Re/Max United, a real estate brokerage on Ferry Street.
The Ironbound's popularity is also evident in neighborhood schools, which have become the most crowded in the state, with many classes exceeding 40 students. Last month, hundreds of angry parents packed a series of town meetings and demanded that the city provide relief.
Officials said they would try to install trailers in the months ahead and build three schools within the decade, but some parents said they could not wait. "You can't have a community without good schools," said Nancy Zak, a longtime resident and a leader of the Ironbound Community Corporation, a nonprofit group. "We're turning into a transient place."
Even Mayor Sharpe James acknowledges that the pace of development has been a bit too heady. "The success of the Ironbound could be its downfall as well," he said. Some are calling for a moratorium on new housing, although that is unlikely.
In the meantime, many homeowners are bracing for a revaluation of property, the first reassessment since 1961. City officials say that some tax bills could double or triple, something that lifelong residents like Linda Rodrigues fear could bring disaster.
Ms. Rodrigues, 49, chairwoman of the foreign languages department at the New School University in Manhattan, said she and many other property owners might be driven out by rising taxes.
"I've stayed here through some of Newark's darkest moments," said Ms. Rodrigues, who serves on the boards of the Newark Museum, the performing arts center and the public library. "But between overdevelopment and the reassessment, I don't know if I can survive much longer."

HEADLINE: Poll of Working Women Finds Them Stressed

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
A survey released yesterday found that one-fourth of working women hold a job that requires them to work at night or on weekends, while nearly half of working women work shifts different from those of their spouses or partners.
The survey, sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., found that many working women felt stressed and overstretched, with many complaining that their employers did not offer flexible hours, paid sick leave or child-care benefits. 
 The survey of 765 working women over 18 years of age found that 60 percent of working women toiled 40 or more hours a week and that women with minor children were more likely than other women to work different shifts from their husbands. Fifty-one percent of women with children under 18 work different hours from their spouses or partners, while 46 percent of all working women do.
The survey was conducted to articulate what issues are important to women with an eye to pressuring politicians to heed their concerns. Many priorities expressed by the women surveyed dovetailed with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s legislative program, which calls for making quality health care more affordable and strengthening laws to provide benefits and better pay for part-time and temporary workers.
The survey, conducted by Lake Snell Perry & Associates, found that the No. 1 legislative priority for women was stronger equal pay laws, because many women were unhappy that women earn on average 73 cents for every dollar men earn. Eighty-seven percent of women surveyed said such laws were a priority, while 84 percent said quality, affordable health care was a priority and 83 percent stressed expanding the Family and Medical Leave Act to provide paid leave.
The survey also found that 34 percent of women said their employers did not provide them with flexible hours and 74 percent do not provide child-care benefits. The survey, conducted from Jan. 6 to 11, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
"One of the reasons for work-family pressures is that working women are having to work full and crazy schedules just to keep up with today's instant economy, " said Karen Nussbaum, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Working Women's Department.
A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials said they would seek to mobilize working women this November to vote for candidates who address women's concerns. Last October, the labor federation, which represents 13 million unionized workers, endorsed Vice President Al Gore's bid for the presidency.
Frank Coleman, communications director of the United States Chamber of Commerce, criticized the women's survey, saying it was a pretext to advance labor's political agenda.
Mr. Coleman said it was ironic that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was calling for more flexibility in the workplace when labor unions have repeatedly blocked business-backed legislation that would make it easier for corporations to offer more flexible hours.
Labor leaders say those laws are a subterfuge designed to deprive workers of overtime pay.

HEADLINE: MINIMUM WAGE RISE OF $1 IS APPROVED

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The House agreed today to increase the federal minimum wage by $1 to $6.15 an hour but coupled the measure to a $123 billion tax-cut package sponsored by the Republicans and subject of a threatened veto by President Clinton, imperiling the raise.
Republicans staged separate votes on the two measures, seeking to defuse a politically potent Democratic issue in the November election by promoting one of their own, tax cuts, and then merged the two measures into one bill. 
 The political effect, however, is that the measures negate each other.
"I will veto the bill Republicans in the House passed tonight if it comes to my desk," Mr. Clinton said in a statement tonight.
The final vote on the wage increase was 282 to 143. But the crucial vote, taken earlier on a Democratic amendment to spread the raise over two years instead of three, passed by a narrower margin, 246 to 179.
On that measure, which gives more money sooner to more than 10 million Americans toiling at the bottom of the economic ladder, 42 Republicans joined 203 Democrats and 1 independent in favor, while 173 Republicans, 5 Democrats and 1 independent opposed. When it became clear this would be the bill's final version, 36 Republicans switched their votes on final passage.
Proponents of the tax cuts said they would ease the impact of the wage increase on employers, pensioners and poor rural and urban communities. But Democrats denounced the cuts as largely benefiting the rich.
Two-thirds of the tax bill's 10-year cost comes from a gradual reduction in the estate tax, $78.6 billion over the decade, with Democrats calling the measure a giveaway to people with annual incomes over $319,000.
That tax measure passed, 257 to 169, with 41 Democrats joining 215 Republicans and 1 independent in favor, and 167 Democrats, 1 Republican and 1 independent voting against.
Last month, the Senate approved an overhaul of bankruptcy laws that included a $1 increase in the minimum wage over three years and $76 billion in tax breaks over 10 years. House and Senate negotiators must now reconcile the competing versions.
Looming over those talks was Mr. Clinton's threat to veto the overall bill because it repeals key overtime protections and provides tax breaks that gobble up too much of the projected budget surplus that could be used to shore up Medicare and Social Security.
"Congress should send me a bill I can sign: a clean straightforward bill that raises the minimum wage by a dollar over two years," Mr. Clinton said in the statement. Combined with the House's passage last month of a bill to cut taxes for married couples by $182 billion over the next decade, Republicans have now approved two pillars of their $792 billion, 10-year tax plan that Mr. Clinton vetoed last year.
This year, Republicans have adopted the strategy of breaking out important parts of that bill and ramming them through the House, knowing that the measure's prospects in the Senate are uncertain and that it is doomed at the White House.
But in an election year, House Republicans are willing to pocket the floor votes as legislative triumphs and portray the White House as out of step with public opinion.
"Once again, Democrats are fighting tax relief, all tax relief," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee.
The tax package would gradually increase the 401(k) contribution limit and make other pension changes. It would make health insurance premiums fully tax deductible for self-employed people sooner than under current law. As well, it would increase the amount of business meals that could be deducted and repeal accounting rules that require small business owners to pay capital gains immediately on the sale of their businesses, even if paid by the buyer in installments.
Republicans staged the dual votes tonight on the minimum wage and tax breaks to prevent Democrats from pushing through their own pay raise, which has support from moderate Republicans from the Northeast.
But instead of waging a contentious battle as they did in 1996, the last time Congress increased the minimum wage, Republican leaders acknowledged that a pay raise was an election-year inevitability. The only questions centered on when the increases would take effect and how large the tax cuts would be.
About 10 million full-time workers paid the minimum wage now earn about $10,700 a year. Raising their wages to $6.15 an hour would increase their annual earnings by $2,000, enough, supporters say, for a low-income family of four to buy groceries for seven months or pay rent for five months. Spreading the increase over three years would have cost workers $900.
Nearly 70 percent of workers earning the minimum wage are adults, and about 60 percent of them are women, according to a report by the White House's National Economic Council.
"In this era of prosperity, we should ensure that no workers are left behind," said Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert, a New York Republican who supported the increase over two years.
Critics of the wage increase said that the raise would kill jobs, particularly for younger workers. "We're cutting off the bottom rung," said Representative Roscoe G. Bartlett, a Maryland Republican.
Today's floor debate came after two days of negotiations between House Republicans leaders and a group of conservative Republicans, led by Representative Jim DeMint of South Carolina, who threatened to delay the overall bill unless it included their provision to allow states to choose whether to carry out the wage increases.
But the conservatives backed down after Speaker J. Dennis Hastert urged them to stick with their Republican colleagues and not hand Democrats a political coup by blocking the popular wage increase.

HEADLINE: Teaching Johnny Values Where Money Is King

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., March 9

 BODY:
Every day after school, 13-year-old Jeffrey Mendelman has a peanut butter and jelly sandwich with milk, finishes his homework -- and checks his stocks.
"My dad's stock was going up," Jeffrey says of his decision to plunge into the market, and he now follows stocks the way he collects autographs and baseball cards. "Most kids here are interested in the market. Because a lot of their dads have become pretty rich and that's why they get to live in a gigantic house." 
 A new sort of American childhood is being forged in the land where each day brings the dawn of an estimated 60 new millionaires. It is one in which C.E.O.'s are the super heroes, family banter is often likely to include talk of multiples and I.P.O.'s, and where a recent collision between two students in a high school parking lot involved a Toyota S.U.V. Forerunner and a Mercedes 500 SL.
But along with a new openness about money, and the good things it can bring, have come concerns about the effect of Silicon Valley's bountiful wealth on children, issues that are likely to escalate as the post-adolescent entrepreneurs, barely old enough themselves to have graduated from Ramen noodles on a hot plate, come of age.
The peculiar challenges of wealth, or what is now being referred to in the Valley as "the sudden wealth syndrome," have themselves spawned a variety of enterprises dedicated to helping the rich be rich, or what Judy G. Barber, a marriage and family counselor, calls "the unique issues that children of affluence face." Ms. Barber, with offices in Napa, San Francisco and Palo Alto, also publishes the newsletter, "Family Money: Commentary on the Unspoken Issues Related to Wealth."
Three years ago, Dr. Stephen Goldbart, a psychologist, co-founded the Money, Meaning and Choices Institute, a private practice in San Francisco, to "explore the psychological opportunities and emotional challenges of having and inheriting money." Dr. Goldbart calls the Bay Area "ground zero for the expanded upper class," foreshadowing the "largest intergenerational transfer of wealth in history."
Financial institutions are also responding. Merrill Lynch, for one, recently instituted a "financial parenting" program geared toward children to "heighten awareness of wealth's responsibilities," said Scott Cooper, a senior client relationship manager. It includes investment lessons for children as well as guidance on the so-called "affluenza syndrome," helping clients answer such questions as, "Daddy, why are we flying a private plane?"
Answer: "We've had a little luck but we've worked hard for it."
On El Camino Real, the Champs-Elysees of the new economy, Liz Gannes, a senior at Palo Alto Senior High, reflected on the unusual environment of her youth, of going to organized "schmooze fests" for techies and weddings where people "eat, talk and make deals."
"It's hard to ground ourselves sometimes," Ms. Gannes observed, echoing the feelings of many of her peers. "The things we hear on the news are happening all around us. We're living on top of this bubble and we're not able to see below us."
On jogging trails and bridle paths here, money and how it affects children -- a subject once more taboo than sex and death -- has become a major topic of parenting. One high-net-worth mother in Portola Valley, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: "My kids have absolutely no idea we have more money than other kids, but at ages 5 and 8 that's easy to enforce. Soon, all they'll have to do to find out their fathers' net worth is look on the Internet or read the paper. It's embarrassing. I'm nervous for my children."
The landscape of 17-year-old Alexa T.'s childhood in Atherton is one of swimming pools, guest houses and gardener-maintained property where full-grown trees are helicoptered in, and it brings this view: "In school you're learning as fast as you can so you can apply it as fast as you can so that you can become rich and successful by age 24, because that's what happens here."
Her mother, Elizabeth, complains: "It's the money that comes first. They're not talking about the Ph.D. They're talking about the $20 million and the house in Atherton."
The rapid pace of technological change, the long hours required of start-ups, the making of vast fortunes at an early age, have brought with them new challenges for families, said Paul Schervish, a professor of sociology at Boston College who is studying the effects nationally of the recent surge in family wealth.
"The material life of this period has accelerated way beyond our spiritual understanding of it," Professor Schervish said. "For the first time we can no longer use 'we can't afford it' as a cultural limit.
"Parents themselves are living a more intense life, working faster and harder. Part of the new economy is this notion that you either move forward or you'll fall back, and those pressures and values are getting passed on to children. Parents feel more of a connection between what their kids are doing now and their fortunes in the future."
To Kris Goodrich, a co-founder of the Child and Family Institute, a nonprofit center in Menlo Park, the fear "that you're the only one that can't keep up" has become pervasive. Her center offers stress classes for preteen children and family discussion programs about values. Ms. Goodrich said: "Children look at the middle class as poverty and going to Hawaii only once a year is considered the bottom rung.
"The loud voice, the Silicon voice, says, 'If you're not constantly updating and going the next jump every day you're replaceable. That puts a tremendous strain on parents. They look at the children and think, 'I've got to give them everything.' They overprovide, because they want them to keep up."
An 11-year-old boy she knows made a fervent wish last year: to simplify his overbooked life. "It's not so much the money as the life style they perceive they have to have," Ms. Goodrich said.
Dr. Gerald D. Bell, a consultant and professor at the graduate school of business at the University of North Carolina, spoke of a father here who recently took his three daughters for a ski vacation in Gstaad, Switzerland. The father told each daughter they could bring a friend. "They spent two weeks in luxury, with unlimited room service," Dr. Bell said. "When they came back to school, the friends were telling friends, and the girls suddenly started getting a lot of social invitations. Even the coaches on teams were being deferential.
"Other kids see the preferential treatment and get mad. So these kids get a double-whammy, asking themselves, 'Do they like me or do they just want to get invited to Gstaad?' "
The flip side of parents staking their claim to Silicon Valley gold can be desolate. Laura M., 17, spoke softly in recalling her mother's plunge into a start-up: "My mom said, 'I'm going to spend a lot of time at work. Is that O.K. with you?' I would have felt bad saying no. The big problem was I was used to having her around to say, 'Don't talk on the phone' and 'Don't watch TV.' "
Laura's grades plummeted, prompting her parents to pull back on their hours somewhat. "The thing I really hate is coming home to the dark," Laura said. "It's a big house."
An undercurrent of parental regret runs through the conversations of some teenagers whose parents feel they have somehow missed the boom. "My parents are doctors," Lisa M., 17, said. "But when they see tons of money, I think they feel sort of left out. Compared to the C.E.O. of Cisco Systems, my dad feels totally insignificant."
At Palo Alto Senior High, a school with robotics classes and electronic lockers, Esther Wojcicki, a revered teacher, has noticed a change in role models among her students. Rather than Michael Jordan and Michelle Kwan, Ms. Wojcicki said: "Their heros are the 20-year-olds with start-up companies who've made $20 million. It's made more intense, because they know them."
In a milieu that respects divergent thinking, even students themselves are becoming legends for their exploits. Among them is Hans Pang, 17, the son of a bank teller and an acupuncturist. Three years ago, a friend's father, Dominic Orr, the chief executive of Alteon Web Systems, in San Jose, offered Mr. Pang a summer job after hearing about his computer wizardry. Mr. Pang's performance during the summers was such that last year, the company, which was going public, offered him employee stock options in lieu of salary in recognition of his work.
"I said yes, since I'd heard about I.P.O.'s skyrocketing and had a good feeling about the company," Mr. Pang said. His shares are currently worth about $75,000, on paper.
"I was earning $10 an hour, which wasn't bad," said Mr. Pang, who has a buzz cut and doles out business cards. "I was happy. But obviously this has made me more happy."
Eric Bloom, an economics teacher at Paly, as the high school is known, realized the culture had shifted when he began noticing that some students were becoming bored when simulated stocks were introduced in class. "It turned out they already had their own real ones," Mr. Bloom said.
A positive side of all this, some of the parents and children say, is a feeling among young people that success is just a step away, rather than a climb up the ladder.
Yet as the dot-com millionaires come of age, parents, educators and mental health professionals worry that the sense of entitlement that has long characterized the proverbial indolent trust-funder will flourish. "It used to be, 'My daddy can beat up your daddy,' " said Mark Walsh, founder of VerticalNet Inc., a Web site company in suburban Philadelphia. "Now it's, 'My daddy can buy your daddy.' "
Joan Lonergan, head of the Castilleja School, a private school for girls here where community service is required for graduation, said wealth is one of the biggest issue facing parents. "People here aren't brain-dead," Ms. Lonergan said. "They're looking hard at values, because everything in the community is focused on money."
Some parents are using their wealth to reconfigure values. Richard Lowenthal, 47, for instance, retired three years ago after his telecommunications company, Stratacom, was bought by Cisco Systems. The father of two daughters, ages 15 and 11, he now spends half his time in community service and is mayor-elect of the Valley town of Cupertino.
Mr. Lowenthal, noting that there are no 12-step programs for workaholics, said: "I've been through that intensity. People whose own self-worth is measured by how much money they have are far more common here than people who can give it a rest. We need more people to set an example for being more whole."
Debra Engel, 47, a single mother of two, retired recently from the 3Com Corporation, which she joined as a start-up. Ms. Engel said she had set "a number I aspired to" that she felt would financially allow her to be at home full time with her children, now 10 and 13. "I'm a great believer that making your own way in the world is important to who you are and who you become," she said. "Many of us have come by this wealth serendipitously. How do my children develop a sense that that's unusual?"
One of Ms. Engel's strategies has been to involve her children in philanthropy, including helping make decisions on where the money goes and visiting inner-city nonprofit organizations she has helped finance through the Community Foundation of Silicon Valley, a private nonprofit group in San Jose.
Of having money, she observed: "It can make you think, 'How should I live?' You not only get tested in life when bad things happen, but when good things happen, too."
Young people like Minal Hasan, 17, daughter of an entrepreneur mother and a venture-capitalist father, seem acutely aware of the unusualness of their lives, of intense family discussions about first- and second-round financing, school lunch chatter about Bloomberg, of endlessly winding driveways with underground garages. "Some day," she observed, "this whole time period will be in the textbooks, like the Vietnam War."
