SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1625 words

HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SAYS VOTES ARE LACKING ON CHINESE TRADE

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The Clinton administration conceded today that it does not yet have the votes to approve a decisive China trade accord, as a lobbying battle was shaping up for the 130 or so uncommitted House members who will decide the fate of the president's most important remaining foreign policy goal.
The fight over whether to grant permanent normal trading privileges to China reveals fault lines in the nation's political and business communities that will surely grow by June, when the House will probably vote. Odd coalitions have sprung up in opposition, from liberal Democrats who abhor China's labor and environmental standards to conservative Republicans who criticize Beijing's human rights record and threats against Taiwan. 
 A day after Mr. Clinton formally called on lawmakers to approve the accord, the administration's point man on the measure, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, acknowledged that the outcome, particularly in the House, was too close to call.
"We probably don't have the votes right now," Mr. Daley told reporters today after briefing executives on the accord. "Members are still trying to grapple with this. They're still wondering whether it's going to happen. It's very fluid."
Organized labor, especially the Teamsters and United Auto Workers, has made defeating the agreement its top legislative priority this year, both to preserve jobs at home and to put pressure on China to raise its labor standards. Business groups, on the other hand, kicked off a $1.5 million advertising campaign last weekend to expound on the benefits of expanded trade with China.
"No one's pulled a gun on me yet, but the lobbying is significant," said Representative Bart Gordon of Tennessee, an uncommitted Democrat whose late switch in 1993 to support the North American Free Trade Agreement gave Mr. Clinton a crucial vote to pass that accord.
In another complication for Mr. Clinton, some conservatives are considering amending the bill to increase military ties between Taiwan and the United States, a move that China and the White House strongly oppose. Moreover, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, urged Mr. Clinton last week to act positively on Taiwan's request for advanced weaponry, including four warships equipped with sophisticated radar and antimissile systems, which are built in Pascagoula, Miss., and Bath, Me.
Last fall, the administration promised Beijing it would work to grant China permanent trade status as part of a larger package to bring China into the World Trade Organization. In the bilateral deal, China agreed to open a wide range of its markets, from agriculture to telecommunications, a potential boon to American farmers and companies.
"Bringing China into the rules-based trading system is a win-win-win for American workers, American businesses and American values," said Representative David Dreier, a California Republican.
To close the deal, Congress is being asked to give up its annual review of China's trade status and grant it the permanent trading privileges that the United States gives most other countries. Congress has always approved this status.
What would happen if Congress votes down normal trade relations is debated. China would probably still join the World Trade Organization. But the administration says that American companies would not enjoy the benefits of the agreement -- lower tariffs on their goods and greater access to China's markets -- while Europe and Japan would.
China, however, may decide it is economically unwise to anger the United States, and so might accept a continuation of the status quo for a time, keeping the trade status up for renewal but withholding the marketing-opening measures.
The timing of the votes on Capitol Hill is crucial. The administration is pushing for votes by the Memorial Day recess to avoid bumping up against the political parties' conventions this summer, and to reduce the chances that new provocations by China would undercut support for the legislation. But Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, has said the House would more likely take the bill up in June.
Mr. Clinton and his cabinet are meeting with lawmakers regularly to win support. Mr. Daley and Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman plan to take groups of wavering legislators to China next month.
Vice President Al Gore has sent mixed signals on the measure, telling labor leaders three weeks ago that he would negotiate something better if elected president, and later reiterating support for the deal. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the presumed Republican nominee, supports permanent normal trading status as a condition of bringing China into the World Trade Organization.
"It's clear the president believes that if he rushes this through before members can fully understand what's in the agreement, he can win," said Representative Peter A. DeFazio, an Oregon Democrat who opposes permanent trade status. "The longer this sits, the more probability we have of beating it."
Prospects for the bill's passage seem good in the Senate, which is typically more supportive of trade agreements than the House. In a test vote last July, the Senate rejected, 87 to 12, a nonbinding measure to end normal trading relations with China. No one expects the Senate to duplicate that margin for permanent trade status, but supporters now count at least 60 votes, the magic number needed to end a filibuster.
For that reason, the administration will probably try to get the Senate to vote first, with a vote in the pro-trade Finance Committee by late April, reversing the usual order of trade bills starting in the House.
"This will be well received in the Senate," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat who strongly supports permanent trade relations with China and who complained two weeks ago that the White House needed to act soon.
Both Senator Lott and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, predicted this week that the Senate would approve the measure after a spirited debate.
Senate opponents concede they face an uphill struggle, but said momentum has shifted in the past three months. "I don't say we have the votes to defeat this, but it's going to be a more intense fight than people thought," said Senator Paul Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat. Senator Wellstone is among those who oppose the bill because, he says, allowing China into the trade organization would cause the United States' trade deficit with China to balloon.
Handicapping the House right now is like herding cats. But according to vote-counters on both sides, the math looks like this:
For several years, about 150 Republicans and 110 Democrats have voted to grant China normal trading status as part of the annual review. A bill needs 218 votes to pass the House if all members vote.
Republican vote-counters say they can probably produce at least 140 votes for granting permanent normal trade status, barring any new provocations by China, although they are short of that now. Democratic supporters say they can count on about 50 to 60 firm "yes" votes now, but insist that aggressive lobbying by business groups, Mr. Clinton and his top aides will harvest dozens of uncommitted Democrats.
By the count of some pro-trade lobbyists, at least 60 House Democrats are uncommitted. Some House critics say that number is closer to 20 or 30, and that the rest are leaning toward "no." Republicans say perhaps 70 of their rank and file are also uncommitted. Mr. Daley said today that the administration is focusing its efforts on about 50 of those 130 uncommitted members.
Legislators in farm states and in high-tech districts in California are under particular pressure from local interests to approve the bill.
Republican leaders, who fought Mr. Clinton over impeachment last year, are well aware that they would be delivering the majority of votes needed to cement a foreign policy triumph for the president. So they are trying pressure the Democrats to share the burden, aides say. That way if the measure fails, Republicans can blame the White House for not turning out its party.
"If the president gets us 100 Democrats, we'll be fine," said Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, who supports the trade bill. Other supporters say that figure is unrealistic.
Last week, Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the second-ranking Democrat, said that 128 of 211 House Democrats were opposing the measure. He added that 30 of those opponents had supported China in annual reviews.
"We're in an early stage, but the momentum is with us," Mr. Bonior said today. "People are moving toward our position."
This may be true in some cases. Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, a senior liberal Democrat who has voted for giving China normal trade status on a yearly basis, said he would oppose permanent status because it would be a mistake to surrender the leverage of an annual vote. Representative Brad Sherman, a California Democrat who has favored the trade status for China year by year, said the same.
But in interviews with about one-third of the 30 representatives who Mr. Bonior said had switched to opposing permanent status, some said they had not made up their minds. "I'm undecided," said Representative Martin T. Meehan, a Massachusetts Democrat. "I'm willing to look at the administration's arguments."
Representative Ed Pastor, an Arizona Democrat, said he had heard from labor advocates who oppose the bill, as well as from orange growers, cotton farmers and executives from technology companies like Motorola and Honeywell in his district who support permanent trade status.
"I'm on the fence," he said.

HEADLINE: DESIGN REVIEW;
Ideazapoppin': Images Fly at Cooper-Hewitt

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
IS it too much to expect the National Design Museum to show a little design now and then? Finally Cooper-Hewitt has taken the plunge. With the first edition of its National Design Triennial the museum brings us real, living design. Not the history of design; not the sociology, anthropology, psychology, theory, politics or economics of design. Not Good Design, Green Design or Universal Design. Just Design, the whole field of American Design and nothing but Design.
The first in a series of survey exhibitions to be held every three years, it offers a bracing dunk in the present. Encompassing graphics, fashion, industrial products, architecture, interiors, furniture, toys, stage and movie sets, and computer animation, the show is not a Best of the Best contest. Projects by 83 designers and firms, all produced in the last three years, are not grouped by disciplines. Viewers may pick their own winners and losers. We expect survey shows to be irritating, and this one does not disappoint. Too often the ideas lose focus. There are vexing omissions and far-fetched connections. Still, this show makes design look like the most protean, fertile field this side of the Tigris and Euphrates. 
 It has been organized by Donald Albrecht and Ellen Lupton, two curators on Cooper-Hewitt's staff, along with Steven Skov Holt, a seasoned Silicon Valley denizen. Their synergy is infectious. They have taken what might be called the Josephine Baker approach to the bountiful subject. In concert performances Baker would toss peaches, apples, papayas and other fruits into the audience. At Cooper-Hewitt the curators pelt us with ideas. Color, light, form, image, movement, materials and technologies land in seemingly random arrangements of contemporary American style.
The Triennial is organized around eight themes, from Fluid to Unbelievable, with stops at Physical, Minimal, Reclaimed, Local, Branded and Narrative along the way. The logic behind these motifs is more intuitive than analytic. This is not to say that the curators lack discrimination. Their approach reflects the mercurial state of design today.
Fluid, the introductory theme, states the show's overarching message: dead or alive, natural or cultural, all things must morph. The section also documents a particular current circulating through architecture and design today. Greg Lynn's "Hydrogen House," created in 1996 for the Austrian Mineral Oil Company, exemplifies the movement toward "blob" architecture created with animation software. Frank O. Gehry's unbuilt project for 1 Times Square deploys folding fabric as an innovative building skin. The impact of both projects is rooted in the shifting, mutable nature of contemporary visual culture.
A second-floor gallery devoted to Branded design embraces without condescension Martha Stewart's antiseptically earthy gardening products. Seed packets and a remarkable poison-free bug killer are used to symbolize the power exercised by labels, logos and slogans in the world of mass consumption. But why include Ms. Stewart and not Ralph Lauren? Why ask why? We love Martha and we don't like Ralph. Go figure. Just do it. Whoosh.
The eight themes are themselves brands, meta-labels for objects whose existence hangs on their reception in the consumer marketplace. Although handbags by Kate Spade and a dress by Geoffrey Beene are displayed in a Minimal gallery, Spade and Beene are also outstanding brand names. So are Apple and, at this point, even Frank O. Gehry. Less established designers, like Stefan Sagmeister, shown in a photograph with his name carved into his naked torso, are labels in the making. Doesn't everyone want to be a trademark? Isn't that what's driving the explosion of all those FillInYourName.coms?
Many visitors will be impressed by the commercial aspect of this show. Some of the objects can actually be purchased at the Cooper-Hewitt gift shop. Others are available at fine stores everywhere, or online. Many of the objects have graced the covers and articles of that excellent trade magazine ID. An architect whose work is represented in the show told me that his first response on seeing it was to look around for a shopping cart. In short, it offers a field day for those who can't wait for another chance to whine about the breakdown of the cordon sanitaire between museum and marketplace.
In the case of museum design departments, however, such a boundary never existed. Since the 1930's the explicit purpose of design departments like that at the Museum of Modern Art was to encourage a rapprochement between art and industry. This had been the Bauhaus ideal. The Modern extended the ideal from production to consumption. The museum didn't design products. Instead it rewarded manufacturers for producing objects that Philip Johnson and subsequent curators found aesthetically pleasing. They Branded stuff with the Good Design label.
In the Good Design period, Branded and Minimal shared a similar, machine-based aesthetic. Today the two are complementary opposites. The Brand catapults more stuff into the world. Minimal design creates the illusion that stuff can be kept at bay. Michael Gambelli, who designed the Triennial, is an excellent illusionist. Using a Minimal palette of gray homisote panels, clear plexiglass containers, white fabric and empty space, he has kept the show from turning into Times Square. Mr. Gambelli has also achieved the remarkable feat of keeping the ornate interiors of Andrew Carnegie's mansion from undermining the entire idea of design.
Reclaimed, another Triennial theme, is the offspring of Branded and Minimal. Since stuff never really goes away, it might as well be made use of. Reclaimed is design's trash compactor. It shows what to do when Branded objects lose their value or aura. Don't throw away those webbed plastic straps that came wrapped around that shipment of clingy Diane von Furstenberg traveling pants suits. Make your own version of Constantin and Lorene Leon Boym's version of Breuer's Wassily chair! Breuer's aesthetic was based on industrial production. The Boym sensibility derives from the landfill end of the consumer system.
Images and ideas can be reclaimed along with physical castoffs. Peter Girardi, a retired graffiti writer based in Manhattan, collects old typefaces, printer's marks, candy wrappers and other signifiers cut loose from their signifieds. Then he posts them on a Web site: www.funnygarbage.com, a semiotic town dump. In contrast to the crisp, clean look of most computer graphics, Mr. Girardi and his associate, Chris Capuozzo, want Web pages to look like old newspapers blowing around the alley. Funny Garbage is working on "Pink Donkey and the Fly," a cartoon show on cable television.
Julie Bargmann's "Testing the Waters" is the most ambitious project in the Reclaimed section, and one of the best in the Triennial. A 45-acre park now under construction in Vintondale, Pa., it is reclaiming land polluted by the drainage from a former coal mine. To produce the design Ms. Bargmann, a landscape architect, recruited a historian, a hydrogeologist and a visual artist. They have produced what the curators call "a giant ecological washing machine" that invites visitors to witness basins, spillways and other stages in the water-cleansing process.
The themes slither through one another like a series of spinoffs and mergers. "Testing the Waters" would fit just as well or better in the section called Local, dedicated to our archaic attachment to place. The Local highlight is a remarkable house designed by Marwan Al-Sayed for a couple in Phoenix. Formerly employed by the New York architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien (who are handsomely represented in the Physical part of the show), Mr. Al-Sayed uses thick masonry walls, metal trusses, tent fabric and the desert surroundings in a design that recalls Frank Lloyd Wright's Taliesin West.
Architecture in general is sketchily handled. The selections are choice but misleadingly labeled. Given the earnestness with which Steven Holl pursues architecture's metaphysical dimension, it is painfully obtuse to classify his M.I.T. dormitory under Physical. Nor is Neil Denari's work all that Fluid. Scary is more like it. With a vocabulary derived from space age technology, his designs tend toward the hard-edged. Beautifully conceived, Mr. Denari's projects are beginning to look like cold war antiques.
Richard Gluckman and Robert Wilson's project for the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust is filed under Minimal but is also a good example of Reclaimed, or even Branded. The design drapes backlighted, translucent theatrical scrims over the side walls of old industrial buildings that are being recycled into Pittsburgh's new arts district. A form of subliminal advertising, devoid of words or images, the design is a refreshing antidote to the cloying, scenographic buildings of Michael Graves and Charles Moore.
If Walter Pater were alive today, he might well conclude that all art aspires to the condition of movie titles. Examples of the genre, created by the Hollywood company Imaginary Forces, are found in the Physical galleries, and it is true that these haunting, hilarious and brilliant montages provoke a visceral response. Created for "Seven," "Mimic" and "Dead Man on Campus," these short films should come with a warning attached: please don't reveal the beginning.
The show's final two segments are utterly misnamed. Most of the work displayed under the Narrative rubric is actually illustrational. Projects by David Rockwell, Julie Taymor, Gary Lloyd and David Gallo are fine examples of scenographic art, but there is nothing narrative about them. Narration, in architecture and design, refers to a spatial or visual sequence that duplicates the formal structure of storytelling. That structure, analyzed by Russian linguists in the early 20th century, proceeds from an initial state of equilibrium through a series of unbalancing episodes to a final, heightened state of equipoise. (Think of rising, by stages, to the top of the Eiffel Tower.)
Lebbeus Woods's project is the only one in the section that follows a true narrative structure. Titled "Civilization," it is part of an exhibition that is to open in Berlin in May. Intentionally or not, the design recreates in architectural form the world according to Richard Rorty, author of the influential 1989 book "Contingency, Irony and Solidarity." Mr. Rorty, our most enlightened contemporary philosopher, has reflected on ways of adapting to rapid cultural change. Mr. Woods, whose previous work includes visionary studies of war-torn Sarajevo, has created a dystopic environment of sharp, fragmented shapes that will serve as an installation for a show on fantasies of 21st-century life.
Unbelievable, the show's final section, would be more accurately titled Next. Given the objects already seen, it is all too easy to believe that the projects gathered here, or variants of them, will soon be on the market. David Small's "Talmud Project" is a work of genius. A prototype for an interactive book, produced at the M.I.T. Media Lab, the project may be the Triennial's most powerful piece of architecture. Combining passages from the Torah and the Talmud, in English and French translations, the software enables viewers to manipulate blocks of text into the walls, streets and windows in an imaginary city of words.
The only thing that is truly Unbelievable at Cooper-Hewitt (apart from Martha Stewart's poison-free bug killer) is the entire exhibition. In recent years New Yorkers have come to depend on Moss, the SoHo store, for close-up inspections of new design. This routine reversed the standard protocol in Good Design days, when a museum display of well-designed objects preceded by some years the establishment of retail outlets where consumers could buy them. It is refreshing to see commercial and curatorial intelligence brought into closer alignment.
The Triennial was conceived a few years ago by Dianne H. Pilgrim, who stepped down as the director of Cooper-Hewitt in January. What a great parting gift.

HEADLINE: Geoffrey H. Moore, 86, Dies; An Analyst of Business Cycles

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Geoffrey H. Moore, who wanted to run a chicken farm but instead became a world-renowned analyst of business cycles, died Thursday at his home in Bloomfield, Conn. He was 86 years old.
Dr. Moore rose to prominence during a 30-year career at the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private body in Cambridge, Mass., that, among other things, is the quasi-official arbiter of when recessions begin and end. He also became a prominent figure in academe and in Washington, where he served as commissioner of labor statistics during the Nixon administration. 
 One of his Statistics I students at New York University in 1946 was Alan Greenspan, now chairman of the Federal Reserve, who yesterday called his former teacher "a major force in economic statistics and business-cycle research for more than a half-century." Mr. Greenspan told Congress in 1994 that he closely followed all of Dr. Moore's work, which focused mainly on economic fluctuations and ways of measuring them.
Dr. Moore continued this work until his death, having founded at age 82 in New York the Economic Cycle Research Institute, whose innovative gauge for predicting inflation has climbed in recent months.
Dr. Moore, a protege of Wesley Clair Mitchell and Arthur F. Burns, the founders of formal business cycle analysis, added much pioneering work of his own. For example, after the profession had responded to a Depression-era request by the Roosevelt administration to generate statistics that could point to revival, Dr. Moore enlarged on this work in 1950 to include economic downturns as well as recoveries.
"In a sense, he was the father of the leading indicators as we know them today," said Anirvan Banerji, co-director of research with Dr. Moore at the Economic Cycle Research Institute.
Later he refined so-called diffusion indexes so that each of their disparate forecasting components could be seen in their own cyclical contexts, preventing distortions that would otherwise arise from comparing unlike factors.
Ultimately, the Commerce Department adopted as its own the series of leading, coincident and lagging economic indicators that Dr. Moore developed with Julius Shiskin, his predecessor as head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. These indicators tend to warn of turning points in the economy by moving ahead of it or to confirm turns by moving at the same time or even lagging behind economic developments.
Although this series, now privatized, became less reliable in the 1990's, Dr. Moore was one of the few to correctly predict the brief 1990-1991 recession, which he said was only set off, not caused, by the Persian Gulf war.
For the last 20 years or more, Dr. Moore insisted on distinguishing between inflation cycles and economic cycles, implying that weak growth did not rule out rapid inflation, as occurred in the 1970's, and that inflation could decline in the face of strong growth, as occurred, to the surprise of many, in the 1990's.
Dr. Moore, whose father was in the real estate business, grew up in rural Pequannock, N.J., went to high school in Montclair, N.J., and graduated from the College of Agriculture at Rutgers University intent on a career in poultry after having worked after school and summers for a chicken farmer.
A professor induced him to return to graduate school, however, and he wound up studying under Dr. Burns, who in 1939 engaged the young agricultural economist as a research associate at the National Bureau.
Dr. Moore taught at N.Y.U. as well as Rutgers, Columbia University and the Colorado School of Mines and was a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford. He held a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard.
In the early 1970's he left Washington after accusations that he was part of the Nixon administration's efforts to politicize the Bureau of Labor Statistics, accusations that a House committee found largely unfounded. In 1979, at Rutgers, Dr. Moore set up the Center for International Business Cycle Research, which was moved to Columbia in 1983 for greater computer capacity.
A financial dispute with Columbia after Dr. Moore agreed to turn over rights to his work led him and his associates to leave in 1996 to found the Economic Cycle Research Institute on Lexington Avenue. This week, by apparent coincidence, Columbia told him that he could expect to have the rights returned to him.
In his later years, Dr. Moore spent much of his time developing a forecasting index for inflation and extending his work on business cycles and forecasting indexes to dozens of other countries.
He is survived by his wife, the former Melita Riley; two sons, Stephen, of Tolland, Conn., and Peter, of Fort Thomas, Ky.; two daughters, Kathleen Holness, of Somerset, N.J., and Pamela Pelligrino, of Center Harbor, N.H.; and a stepson, Bryant Riley of Mount Sterling, Ohio. Dr. Moore's first wife and the mother of his children, Ella C. Goldschmid, died in 1975.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Is Barely Higher; Other Indexes Close Down

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index edged higher yesterday, its second consecutive record close above the 5,000 level, despite losses in blue-chip stocks, after another consumer products company, the Dial Corporation, warned of disappointing earnings.
The Nasdaq, which on Thursday finished above 5,000 for the first time, ended with a gain of 1.76 points, at 5,048.62. 
 The index had been as high as 5,132.52, but a bout of late selling short-circuited its gains, sending it briefly into negative territory before it inched higher at the close.
"It was a combination of a tough week and it was Friday," said Ned Collins, head of trading at Daiwa Securities America. "People were anxious to get flat for the weekend in the last few hours; some of the leaders were giving up a little; and the bidders just pulled out."
Other major gauges fell. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 81.91 points, or 0.82 percent, to 9,928.82. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 6.62 points, or 0.47 percent, to 1,395.07. Declining stocks on the Big Board exceeded those advancing, 1,701 to 1,266.
"The disappointment from Dial reinforces the feeling that tech is the only game in town," said Guy Truicko, portfolio manager at Unity Management in Garden City, N.Y.
Dial -- the maker of soap, Purex laundry detergent and other consumer products -- warned of a 10-to-12-percent drop in its first-half profit two days after Procter & Gamble dealt the Dow index a blow, saying its earnings would be disappointing.
Dial fell 3 1/4 yesterday, to 11, in New York Stock Exchange trading, and during the session, touched a low not seen since late 1994. Procter & Gamble declined a further 4 1/2, to 53, its lowest close since November 1996.
Financial services stocks were volatile amid speculation of merger deals in the wake of Thursday's announcement in Germany that Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank would merge, jettisoning retail branches to focus on the lucrative investment banking business.
"People are thinking they may be getting into the U.S. market and are looking for an acquisition," said Amy Butte, an analyst with Bear, Stearns.
Shares of the Goldman Sachs Group, which surged as high as 119, closed with a gain of 5 1/16 at 112 1/4, and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter rose 4 1/8, to 86 5/8. Both touched intraday highs during the session.
Chase Manhattan fell 2 7/16 , to 78 11/16 , with traders speculating that the bank was seeking acquisitions. Chase said it would not comment as a matter of policy on the unusual trading in its stock after an explanation was requested by the New York Stock Exchange. The discount broker Charles Schwab jumped 5 1/16 , to 52. Schwab also refused to comment about a Big Board request for information on trading activity.
Transportation stocks, laggards this year, rose yesterday. The Dow Jones transportation average gained more than 1 percent after crude oil prices slipped. An OPEC official said the United States was asking producers for an additional 2.5 million barrels a day of crude oil.
Some semiconductor stocks surged, led by Rambus, up 41 35/64 , to 421, after the company announced a four-for-one stock split, and Motorola, up 10, to 172 1/2, after it said its business prospects for 2000 are strong in all regions of the world. Some computer disk-drive stocks added to recent gains.
Biotechnology issues, which have been giving back some of their gains lately, were lower for a fourth day.
For the week, the Nasdaq rose 133.83 points, or 2.72 percent, but the Dow industrials fell 438.38 points, or 4.23 percent.
Next week, economists and Wall Street analysts will get reports on wholesale and retail prices, which could give hints of any inflation.
In the fixed-income market yesterday, the price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 1/32 , to 101 1/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.17 percent from 6.15 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Britain Agrees to Support Germany's I.M.F. Candidate

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 10

 BODY:
Breaking days of conspicuous silence, Britain today endorsed Germany's substitute candidate to run the International Monetary Fund, significantly broadening his support within the European Union.
But with finance ministers from the 15-nation union meeting on Monday to decide officially on a candidate, it remained uncertain whether they would all unify behind the German, Horst Kohler. 
 "We cannot say today that there is a consensus," said a spokesman for Portugal, which currently holds the European Union's rotating presidency.
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain added his voice to those supporting Mr. Kohler only after days of saying nothing, reportedly cloaking a rift between him and Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, who remained uncertain of Mr. Kohler's credentials.
Mr. Kohler, a German economist and former high official in the German Finance Ministry, is currently head of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which invests in countries of the former Soviet bloc. He is the second candidate put forward by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder. The first, Caio Koch-Weser, who secured only ambiguous support in Europe, was vetoed by President Clinton because of what the American administration called Mr. Koch-Weser's lack of stature.
Despite that rebuff, the German leader is pressing a campaign to have a compatriot take over as managing director of the I.M.F., which has traditionally been run by a European since its creation after World War II. For much of that time, it has been run by senior French officials, like Michel Camdessus, the previous managing director.
Reflecting a new assertiveness, Germany's government now believes it is Germany's turn to run one of the world's most influential financial institutions. After Britain announced its support, a German spokesman said, "We are well on the way to agreeing on a common European candidate."
A European consensus is vital before Mr. Kohler's candidacy is put before the I.M.F. directors in Washington. Mr. Kohler has said publicly he wants assurances of broad support for his candidacy from the I.M.F. shareholders. But, while Mr. Schroder has enlisted Dutch, French, Portuguese and British backing, Italy and Spain have remained silent and the United States has been noncommittal.
Washington reiterated its position today. A White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said, "We're looking for a European candidate who has consensus support in Europe, who has support in the developing world, a gentleman or a woman who's got maximum stature."
Earlier today in Brussels, the Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright, said that while Washington supported the idea of a European candidate, "the important thing is to find one that has the right qualifications and the consensus." She did not, however, mention Mr. Kohler specifically.
The United States has made clear it wants a political heavyweight to take the job, while Italy is believed by many Europeans to be harboring ambitions for a candidate of its own, Giuliano Amato, the treasury secretary.
German officials regarded Britain's support as an important part of the effort to build a unanimous European stance. Mr. Schroder, the chancellor, also says he has support from South Korea and from Eastern European leaders who have come to know Mr. Kohler through his work at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Established in 1991, the bank invests in mainly business-sector projects in Eastern and Central Europe and Russia as part of a mandate to foster economic and political change.
A British government spokesman declined to say whether Mr. Blair had consulted with President Clinton before making known his support for the German candidate. "We have made clear now who we think should do the job, but will leave the Americans to decide whom they want to support," the spokesman said.

HEADLINE: NATO Chief in Kosovo Fears a Cross-Border Insurgency

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: PRISTINA, Kosovo, March 10

 BODY:
The commander of peacekeeping troops in Kosovo, with the former political leader of the disbanded Kosovo Liberation Army beside him, vowed today to stop any insurgency mounted from Kosovo into Serbia.
The warning came at a joint news conference when the commander, Gen. Klaus Reinhardt, was joined by Hashim Thaci, the Albanian leader. The appearance, which Mr. Thaci was urged to make by Gen. Wesley K. Clark, NATO's supreme commander, was an effort to send a political message to the population of Kosovo and beyond into Serbia. 
 Albanian leaders here are warning that tension in the Presevo Valley between the ethnic Albanian population and Serbian police forces is only going to worsen. And while the civilian population is overwhelmingly against more conflict, refugees from the Presevo area are arriving almost daily in Kosovo, spreading a deep sense of foreboding that the crisis is already unstoppable.
General Reinhardt warned of the dangers today. "This situation along the Kosovo and Presevo Valley border region constitutes a threat to peace and security for Kosovo, and could develop into a regional security issue," he said at Camp Monteith, the American base in eastern Kosovo. "Any insurgent activity based in Kosovo and the conduct of cross border operations cannot and will not be condoned or tolerated."
Gen. Ricardo Sanchez, the leader of American forces in Kosovo, who was also present, issued a written statement that his force had "significantly increased its security posture" on the border and was prepared to "take all necessary actions to ensure that Kosovo is not used as a staging base for exporting violence into the Presevo Valley," and would oppose "any attempts to extend violence back into Kosovo."
The statements were intended as a political message, said Capt. Russell Berg, an American military public affairs officer. American troops have already built new watchtowers on the border and stepped up surveillance. "The message is, we are absolutely not going to be drawn into anything," he said.
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, who helped negotiate the disarmament of the Kosovo Liberation Army after the war, intends to press Mr. Thaci and other Albanian leaders to stem the violence when he visits Kosovo this weekend, officials said.
Mr. Thaci and leaders of the Kosovo Protection Corps, the civilian structure that has replaced the liberation army, are apparently already listening and are moving to take the appropriate public stands. In an interview this week, just after a meeting in Kosovo with General Clark, Mr. Thaci clearly stated that the Presevo Valley, long a majority Albanian area and once part of Kosovo, was not his concern.
"I respect the right of the Albanians in Presevo. They should have the rights of democratic citizens. But in Kosovo we have different circumstances and we now have a different approach to the region," he said. "Now as the president of a political party in Kosovo, my concerns only cover the territory of Kosovo."
He stressed that Albanians did not want violence. "More than anyone else in the region, Albanians know what violence means," he said.
But Ramush Haradinaj, a powerful commander of the former Kosovo Liberation Army and now the deputy commander of the civilian force, showed a more independent mind.
While Mr. Haradinaj, one of the most renowned fighters of the war, said the armed insurgency in Presevo will only worsen the situation, he refused to condemn the men who are now trying to fight the Serbian police in southern Serbia. "I am against Milosevic," he said, referring to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. "I think they should protect themselves. It initiates more problems but I respect their decision. If I were in charge of the region, I would do the same."
He denied that he and his supporters are part of a new fighting force, the Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac. The army is a nascent guerrilla force that recently made a public stand to defend the Albanian population in southern Serbia. It is reportedly organized by former members of the liberation army and is thought to have strong backing from some of that group's senior leaders.
But Mr. Haradinaj admitted that former fighters, who are unemployed and disillusioned with the new corps, and also men from the Presevo area who fought in Kosovo, are likely to join the new force.
Foreign officials in Kosovo say that the K.L.A. no longer exists as a viable organization and that many of the leading characters have gone their different ways. Mr. Thaci has founded his own political party but cannot count on the support of all the major commanders of the liberation army. Mr. Haradinaj, for example, is expected to announce the forming of his own party soon.
Yet much of the old network clearly remains. Men who are fighting over the border are moving freely in and out of Kosovo and are visibly maintaining links with old comrades now in Kosovo's civilian force.
Many Albanians are comparing the nascent Presevo insurgency to that of the K.L.A., which, despite little military capability, was strong enough to provoke a violent reaction from Mr. Milosevic's forces.
Emrush Xhemajli, leader of the National Movement of Kosovo, which supported the K.L.A. organizationally and financially, is one of the few political figures to voice unabashed support for the new liberation group.
"To date, we have announced that we support them politically and morally," he said of the guerrilla force, leaving open whether he would finance it. "It would be totally inhuman to forget them."

PUB-DATE: March 11, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1420 words

HEADLINE: JOURNAL;
J. Crew vs. Banana Republic

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
I knew the presidential race had lapsed into a coma when I found myself gravitating toward Katie Couric's televised colonoscopy on the "Today" show instead of the usual chattering political heads on cable. Ms. Couric's selfless efforts on behalf of cancer prevention were not only more inspiring than the focus-group-tested nostrums prescribed by the surviving candidates, Al (Fighting for Us) Gore and George W. (Uniter Not a Divider) Bush, but also more entertaining.
Whatever happened to Americans' supposed hunger for authenticity and straight talk as an antidote to Bill Clinton? Wasn't that supposed to carry us through the whole election year? Well, as Gilda Radner's Emily Litella used to say, Never mind. 
 Eight months to go -- but hey, who's counting? -- and we're stranded with two establishment, tightly scripted, often robotic candidates who are about as different from one another as J. Crew and Banana Republic. Both are wealthy, Ivy-League-educated boomers who took safe paths through the Vietnam War, whose career advancement was greased by their dads, who advertise their intimacy with Jesus, who reek of smarmy soft money and who will do anything to win, whether it be Mr. Gore's lying about his own Congressional voting record in a debate or Mr. Bush's heartless exploitation of women's fears of breast cancer in a scurrilous attack ad.
In the true Clinton manner, both are also chameleons, ready to don new guises in a flash -- from Mr. Gore's down-home wardrobe to Mr. Bush's last-minute emergence as a champion of campaign finance reform, patients' rights and clean air. The substantive disputes between the men are, in truth, minimal in a prosperous post-cold-war era when both parties aspire to Rockefeller Republicanism (literally so in that each standard-bearer is the prince of a brand-name American dynasty). If this is going to be a campaign about issues, it may all come down to the environment, gun control, Roe v. Wade and, most of all, who's least likely to screw up the economy, stupid. Bill Clinton's low personal-approval but high job-approval ratings (still in the Reaganesque 60's) don't suggest Clinton fatigue so much as a convincing mandate for Clintonism without Clinton.
But even as we now end up where we began in yet another of our stalled political culture's recent variations on "Groundhog Day," the primary race was far from a waste of time. The John McCain crusade revealed yet again -- as the Bradley campaign might have, had there been one -- that a fast-growing minority hungers for an independent-minded political movement that shucks musty ideological litmus tests and playbooks. These voters (or if they're young, would-be voters) don't have an obvious home in either party (let alone the Reform zoo), and it's possible that many of them will sit out the election come fall. You can't blame them. In a country changing at the speed of a digital clock far faster than the analog gait of political reform, they may actually have better things to do in their own communities and lives.
This primary season also dealt another blow to the myth of media political clout. For all the swooning over Mr. McCain, he even lost New York, where his wide journalistic support included The Post, which was so distracted by his cause that for a couple of weeks it forgot to bash Hillary Clinton. People do hate the press, and in retrospect, there might have been more votes in going after TV's reporters than its evangelists. If only he had done it earlier in the campaign, Mr. McCain's on-camera tongue-lashing of the celebrity news hound Maria Shriver -- "as recognizable a personality as NBC News has," in the lukewarm description of her colleague Brian Williams -- could have won over the considerable constituency that sides with the mad-as-hell Peter Finch railing against the TV news gods in "Network."
The campaign further reaffirmed that race is still the last subject in America likely to generate straight talk, even when politicians are vying against the backdrop of Diallo and Louima verdicts, the Selma anniversary, the imminent multiracial majority in California, bitter divisions over affirmative action in Florida and new inquiries into possible racial inequities in the administration of capital punishment. Bill Bradley's earnest approach to the subject foundered on platitudes, then descended to a patronizing commercial in which Michael Jordan might as well have been shilling for cut-rate long-distance on MCI.
No Republican could find the courage, some 135 years after Appomattox, to take a stand against the Confederate flag. Mr. Bush pandered to Bob Jones University while pretending to be unaware of its racist policies; Mr. Gore pandered to Al Sharpton while pretending to be visiting his daughter. Perhaps the campaign's most shameless race demagogue was Alan Keyes, who cried racism every time he could, even saying he was a victim of a "media blackout" while hogging air time on a CNN debate. Political correctness dictated that no candidate or debate moderator could tell this egomaniacal blowhard where to get off.
Then again, the volatile Mr. Keyes had the virtue of being unpredictable. Surveying the Bush-Gore field, CBS's straight-talking Bob Schieffer spoke for the desperation of many when he remarked in language as plaintive as Samuel Beckett's: "We have got four months now until the convention. What are both these people going to do? What are we going to do as journalists?"
Larry King seemed on the verge of nodding off during an exchange between Bob Woodward and George Mitchell on Super Tuesday; a night later he was revisiting "Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?" The Drudge Report is now reduced to trafficking in speculation about Matt Drudge's own sex life, and National Journal, a normally sober Capitol Hill wonk weekly, gossips online that ABC's capsizing "This Week" may bring in Maury Povich and Connie Chung as new hosts. NBC, apparently abandoning hope for ratings gold from the real Washington, has hired Sally Quinn to write a fictional series called "Georgetown." In a pinch, though, JonBenet Ramsey will once more ride to the news biz's rescue: in only days, her bereaved parents will begin hawking their new book via Barbara Walters, Larry King, Newsweek and a full week's worth of segments on "Today."
But I for one refuse to give up on what Fox calls "You Decide 2000" just yet. True, there won't be much drama from Al Gore. He has both a united party and an effective persona: he may be the first public figure in history who has gone overnight from having the personality of a tree to that of a chainsaw mowing down anything in its path. No, the great hope for surprises in the eight months ahead is Mr. Bush, who, unlike Mr. Gore, is nowhere near the desired political center and so still must improvise to prove that he is not, as Mr. McCain branded him, a Bob Jones or Pat Robertson Republican after all.
This will be hard because Mr. Robertson is an irrepressible TV showboat; in Tuesday's election coverage he advertised his hammerlock on Mr. Bush before any camera he could find. Nor will Mr. Bush easily shake that gripping shot of his stride across the vast totalitarian carpet at Bob Jones U., now as much a visual staple of the All News repertoire as Monica Lewinsky on the rope line. Under these circumstances, it certainly won't be enough for Mr. Bush to apply the usual antidote for Republicans handcuffed to the far right -- making an "appeal to women" by pretending to be captivated by the vice-presidential aspirations of Elizabeth Dole.
And so, in his scramble to get back to "compassionate conservatism," he donned a yarmulke at the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles this week (a date hastily firmed up after the Bob Jones visit, according to the center's Rabbi Marvin Hier). In San Francisco, of all cleverly chosen venues, Mr. Bush indicated that it might not be a "nightmare" to meet with uncloseted gay Republicans after all (though Richard Tafel, the American Baptist minister who heads Log Cabin, says there's still been no call). The helpful Bush cheerleaders at The Wall Street Journal are proposing further remedies, including the vain pursuit of Colin Powell as a running mate. Peggy Noonan even mused that Mr. Bush should show his affinity for Latinos by forsaking Hiltons and Four Seasons when in California to stay instead in "little hotels in the barrio."
Imagine: George W. Bush livin' la vida loca! Authenticity was never this much fun.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1582 words

HEADLINE: Europe Plays Internet Catch-Up;
A Bewildering Choice of Portals, Most of Them Pricey

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 10

 BODY:
After a day at work advising bank clients on their investments, Karsten Finger, a 30-year-old Berliner, likes to spend an hour or two on the Internet, looking for bargain-priced rental cars, vacations, books and CD's. But one thing that baffles him, he said, is the price of going online because Germany has such bewildering choices of rival providers. "It's impossible to see which is the best offer," said Mr. Finger, who pays about $125 a month.
Over in Paris, by contrast, Jean-Vincent Fournier, a 39-year-old Canadian script writer, logs on for maybe 40 hours a month. That used to cost him up to $200 until he switched to a cable provider that offered him unlimited access for around $65. 
 The competition to provide Internet access, he said, is "fierce."
What both of them have in common with Web users across Europe is that, not too long ago, their net-surfing was hostage to the former state monopolies like France Telecom, Deutsche Telekom and British Telecommunications, which still control most of the "local loop" -- the last stretch of phone line reaching into homes and small businesses -- despite the deregulation that opened Europe's telecommunications market to competition.
These days, as start-up service providers, cable companies and American interlopers jostle to ride the coming wave of Europe online, the behemoths of telecommunications find they must compete or lose business on the local phone charges that once provided their most profitable mainstay.
"This is the land grab that's going on for the European Internet," said Peter Bradshaw, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "And clearly everyone is seeking to get the most consumers on their own portal. This is a war that will be decided very quickly."
What the telephone companies and other Internet service providers want, Mr. Bradshaw said, is to "grab customers now, and once they have the customers there'll be ways of taking money off those customers" through advertising, e-commerce and other businesses.
At the same time, though, European consumers -- in Britain in particular -- sense a rare victory. On Wednesday, for instance, British Telecom joined a furious price war over Internet access charges in this country. Reversing its previous hostility to anything but minute-by-minute charges for Internet use, British Telecom said it would introduce a $50-a-month flat-rate charge for unlimited telephone access to the Internet.
That came just one day after NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, said that starting April 17 it would offer free unlimited access to its customers, with a small charge for British Telecom's subscribers to take advantage of the same offer. And, one day before that, AltaVista, a unit of CMGI, said it would provide Internet access for a one-time subscription of $48 to $80 and an annual charge of $16 to $32.
One side effect was a display of the fickleness -- or at least the pace -- of the entire business. A mere 19 months ago, Freeserve seized the British market by offering what it termed free Internet access -- meaning metered telephone charges but no online charges -- and garnered 1.7 million customers to become the biggest service provider. Freeserve's shares plummeted this week as new challengers entered the fray.
But a further consequence is the proliferation of offerings. NTL, for instance, said it would provide Internet access through a portal called ntlworld to join an array of existing Web access routes ranging from AOL to Freeserve. And some analysts say the battle among service providers will not simply be fought on cost, but also on what the portals offer the subscriber by way of e-mail, e-commerce and online services.
"This is basically lowering the cost of access," said Morton Andersen, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney here. "More consumers will go online and will spend more time online. That's not just a function of cost, but also of content."
Britain is not alone either in the battle for Internet subscribers or in Europe's reluctance to simply emulate United States low-cost local phone charges. In Germany, surfers confront a bewildering choice of at least 36 price packages, ranging from $10 to $100 a month. But some are so complex -- and so misleading because of the fine print in the sign-up contracts -- that people like Mr. Finger in Berlin suspect "the companies want it that way so that you can't see what you'll be paying." Yet, Deutsche Telekom has said it will soon offer a flat-rate monthly charge for heavy Internet users for less than $50 a month.
In France, Nathan Perry, a 25-year-old American Web designer from Spokane, Wash., said the new competition had enabled him to lower the costs of his Internet use -- between two and five hours a day online for everything from checking his bank balance to videoconferencing with his family. By switching from a normal phone line to a faster line from France Telecom, he lowered his Internet connection bill to around one-third of the $250 he used to pay. Even so, he said, the system forces him to use a France Telecom portal to access AOL, which costs a further $19 a month.
Even with the new competition on price, most of Europe's telephone and online charges remain much higher than those in the United States -- a factor that Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain called a major hindrance to wider Internet use. "Our goal must be to see prices comparable with anywhere in the world, including the U.S.A.," he said Tuesday as he began a campaign to become the standard-bearer of e-commerce in Europe in advance of a European Union summit meeting in Lisbon later this month.
A study of European Internet use and access costs by the Booz Allen & Hamilton consultancy shows how expensive it is for users to go online. The average cost of 40 hours a month using the predominant Internet service in the user's country exceeds $85 in Spain, $76 in Germany, $62 in France and $49 in Britain, compared with about $37 in the United States.
Mr. Blair is not the only European politician promoting the Internet. Seeking to avert a "digital divide" between affluent people online and the offline poor, Mr. Blair said he wanted universal Internet access for Britons by 2005.
But in Germany, where the wealthiest 15 percent of the population accounts for a quarter of all Internet use, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder wants all of the nation's 40,000 schools online by next year, compared with 13,000 at present. Not surprisingly, Deutsche Telekom has offered to spend $60 million a year providing free high-speed Internet connections and the free use of its T-Online portal in those classrooms where the scholars of today will yield the customers of tomorrow.
At present, Europe's share of e-business remains minuscule. According to the Booz Allen study, all of Europe has only a 14 percent share of the world's e-commerce, compared with 70 percent in the United States. Of that, British e-commerce was valued at $1.89 billion, giving it the lead position among Europeans. German e-commerce was valued at $1.65 billion while France lagged with $1.2 billion.
European Internet use in general lags use in the United States, according to the study. While 60 percent of Americans regularly go online, and 40 percent of Scandinavians -- Europe's most-wired people -- do, most European countries belong to a "second tier" with 15 percent to 25 percent of the population regularly using the Internet.
But, as with just about any Internet business, it is the promise of the future that lures investors, start-ups, service providers and communications companies. Indeed, Mr. Bradshaw at Merrill Lynch said, the calculation among many of those offering what seem like relative bargains for Internet access is "you have to take some short-term pain" before profits kick in. "These are companies doing what they do for what they see as sound economic reasons," he said.
In Britain alone, four million new users join the Internet population every year, according to Booz Allen. But getting access to the Internet from personal computers is only part of what some of Europe's biggest businesses see as the future.
"We are behind the U.S. in terms of one-dimensional personal computer access" to the Internet, Mr. Bradshaw said. "But we are light years ahead through mobile phones." Indeed, he said, in use of wireless technology, where European countries share a common transmission standard and are developing wireless systems geared to the Internet, "Europe is obviously exploding at a much higher rate of growth than we are seeing in the U.S. at the moment."
With a potential market of 350 million in the European Union alone, that has already persuaded major players to clamber into a growing market. Vodafone AirTouch of Britain, the world's biggest wireless company, for instance, announced an alliance with Vivendi of France last January to create an Internet portal, or entrance, to the World Wide Web accessible via computers, mobile phones and cable or satellite television. Just this Thursday, British Telecom announced it would establish a separate mobile Internet business. British Sky Broadcasting, the biggest portion of which is owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, is offering interactive digital television by satellite, and cable operators are scrambling to compete.
"The idea of the Internet accessed purely through the personal computer is going to change dramatically over the next few years," Mr. Andersen at Salomon Smith Barney said.

HEADLINE: U.N. SEES VIOLATION OF A DIAMOND BAN BY ANGOLA REBELS

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

 BODY:
An embargo ordered by the United Nations two years ago to stop Angolan rebels from using diamonds to pay for their war has been undermined by several African nations and the "extremely lax controls" of the central diamond clearing house in Antwerp, according to a report prepared for the Security Council.
The report said widespread sanctions-busting -- by, among others, three African heads of state -- has allowed diamonds to continue playing "a uniquely important role" for the Angolan rebels, whose group is known as Unita, allowing them to purchase weapons from Bulgaria while buying favors from governments in Africa. 
 The 50-page report was prepared under the direction of Robert R. Fowler, the Canadian representative to the United Nations and chairman of the Security Council committee investigating violations of sanctions on Angola. Through a spokesman, Mr. Fowler declined to comment yesterday. The report was to be presented to the Security Council next week, but when copies began to circulate, it was released to members of the council last night.
Based on a six-month investigation by a panel of nine experts, the report is especially critical of the diamond bourse in Antwerp, Belgium, which does $23 billion of business a year and processes 90 percent of the world's rough diamonds.
"The unwillingness or inability of the diamond industry, particularly in Antwerp, to police its own ranks is a matter of special concern to the panel," said the report, excerpts of which were obtained by The New York Times.
The report said Antwerp's willingness to traffic in Unita diamonds "results from the often expressed fear that stricter regulation would simply cause traders to take their business elsewhere." It also said the Belgian authorities had failed to establish a credible system for identifying rough diamonds peddled by Unita, while making "no serious effort" to keep track of diamond traders known to deal with the rebels. A prominent Antwerp diamond trader trained the diamond experts who work for Unita, the report said.
The United Nations imposed sanctions on the sale of Unita diamonds in 1998 after the rebels seized control of major diamond mines in Angola in the mid-1990's and earned billions of dollars from them. Angola's mines produce some of the finest gem-quality alluvial diamonds in the world.
During the cold war, when it was fighting against the Soviet-backed Angolan government, Unita received up to $60 million a year from the Central Intelligence Agency.
But it fell out of favor with the United States, along with the United Nations, when its leader, Jonas Savimbi, lost an internationally supervised election in Angola in 1992 and refused to accept the vote. Instead, Mr. Savimbi returned to the bush and resumed a war against the Angolan government that began before the country's independence in 1975.
Diamond money transformed Unita into a far more ferocious military organization than it had been while receiving support from either the C.I.A. or the South African government, which supported it until the end of white-minority apartheid rule.
The diamond-financed escalation of war in Angola in the last decade has cost the lives of about 500,000 people while displacing about four million others, according to human rights groups and the United Nations.
Besides buying a war machine, Mr. Savimbi used diamond money to persuade African heads of state to do him favors, according to the report.
Mr. Savimbi gave a "passport-sized" packet of diamonds to the president of the small West African country of Togo, Gnassingbe Eyadema, after the president agreed to allow Mr. Savimbi's children to live there and go to school, the report said, citing testimony from Unita's former representative in Togo.
The report also said Togo was suspected of easing the way for six shipments of arms from Bulgaria to the rebels since 1997.
The report, which relies heavily on testimony from Unita defectors, said Mr. Savimbi's closest friend among African leaders was the president of Burkina Faso, Blaise Compaore. Last year, Mr. Compaore sent Mr. Savimbi three planeloads of diesel fuel, the report said.
In return, Mr. Savimbi made "substantial contributions" to Mr. Compaore's political campaigns, the report said, adding that on at least two occasions he gave money to help the government pay its debts.
In cataloging the help that African nations have given Unita, often in exchange for diamonds, the report said that large amounts of fuel were obtained from Gabon, an oil-producing state in West Africa where Mr. Savimbi "maintained a very cordial relationship" with President Omar Bongo.
The government of Rwanda often provided Unita diamond traders with a safe haven for meeting with diamond buyers from Antwerp, as well as a refueling stop for aircraft flying weapons from Eastern Europe to rebel headquarters in the Angolan city of Andulo. Those flights ended last October when Angolan government forces took Andulo.
Bulgaria is singled out in the report as the primary supplier of Unita's weapons and spare parts. But the report played down earlier reports that Unita had purchased large numbers of tanks and heavy artillery pieces.
It said that most of the rebels' inventory of large weapons had been captured from the Angolan government and that most of its purchases in Bulgaria were of spare parts to keep the captured weapons operating.
De Beers, the South African conglomerate that controls about two-thirds of the world diamond market, escaped serious criticism in the report.
The conglomerate announced last month that it would issue written guarantees that its diamonds do not originate with African rebels. It announced last year that it would stop buying all Angolan diamonds, except those it was contractually obligated to buy from the Angolan government.
De Beers was stung in 1998 by accusations from a London-based human rights group, Global Witness, that it was helping violate United Nations sanctions by trading for Unita diamonds through its huge network of buying offices in Africa. The company's cartel-like Central Selling Organization, which in effective sets world diamond prices, is based in London, but many of its diamond traders work in Antwerp.
The company, which is owned by the Anglo-American Corporation in London, has responded to the criticism by taking steps that human rights groups have said the entire diamond industry should follow.
About a third of diamonds traded in Antwerp are purchased from traders who are not employed by De Beers and are not bound by its new rules.
The report on sanctions-busting recommends that diamond traders who violated the embargo should be barred "from any involvement in the diamond industry worldwide." It also asks that countries, including Belgium, criminally prosecute traders for violating international law.
As for African nations that have been profiting from Unita's diamond trade, the report recommends that they be subject to a three-year embargo on all arms sales. And it suggests that Bulgaria's involvement in sanctions-busting should be an obstacle to its joining NATO.
The report also called for the Security Council to create a "substantial bounty" to be paid to any institution, government or individual that tracts down Unita's assets.
Members of the panel included a diamond expert from Namibia, a small-arms expert from South Africa and an oil expert from Britain.

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Tries to Link Giuliani's Policies to Bush's

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 10

 BODY:
Just three days after the Super Tuesday presidential primary, Hillary Rodham Clinton sought today to link Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, her opponent in the race for United States Senate, with the Republican Party's all-but-nominated presidential candidate, Gov. George W. Bush.
It is part of a strategy, Mrs. Clinton's aides say, to capitalize on both the strength that Vice President Al Gore, the presumed Democratic candidate, has shown in polls among New York voters and what the Clinton campaign sees as the unpopularity in New York of some of Governor Bush's positions. 
 Mrs. Clinton spent the day campaigning from central New York to the state capital, where she and the vice president shared a stage at a convention of the state's Hispanic legislators.
At two points during the day, Mrs. Clinton took pains to cast herself and Mr. Gore as offering profoundly different positions and leadership styles than Mr. Bush and Mr. Giuliani, saying the names of the two Republicans in virtually the same breath.
"If you compare the positions of the vice president and myself with Governor Bush and Mayor Giuliani, you could not have a starker comparison," Mrs. Clinton told reporters after speaking at a youth center in Cortland, N.Y., which is near Ithaca.
"Vice President Gore and I are for continuing fiscal responsibility," Mrs. Clinton continued. "Both Governor Bush and Mayor Giuliani would do a U-turn and take us back to the days of exploding deficits. Bush and Giuliani are for education vouchers, which would take money out of the public schools. Vice President Gore and I would like to support the public schools."
Mrs. Clinton was responding to questions about the results of Tuesday's New York primary, in which Mr. Bush won the Republican contest and Mr. Gore was the victor in the Democratic race.
"I'm pleased that I'm going to be in a campaign in the next eight months with a candidate who I think is going to be a great president and who has a very different view with what we need to do with America," Ms. Clinton said. "And I support that view and will be campaigning very hard for his election."
This evening, at the conference of the New York State Puerto Rican-Hispanic Task Force, Mrs. Clinton shared the stage briefly with the vice president. The two were greeted enthusiastically by the crowd of more than 500 people.
"The vice president and I stand for continuing the economic policies that have worked for America," Mrs. Clinton said.
"And George Bush and Rudy Giuliani want to do a U-turn back to the days when it didn't work for any of us, and instead go back to exploding deficits, the end of surpluses, a lack of investment in education and health care."
In Cortland, an area where Republicans often do well at the polls, Mrs. Clinton spoke at a center that sponsors programs intended to curb teenage pregnancy. After that, she traveled to Ithaca, where she greeted residents at a center for the elderly.
Later in the day, Mrs. Clinton spoke before one of the largest crowds she has faced since her campaign for the Senate began. Addressing a crowd of 5,000, Mrs. Clinton was the keynote speaker at Cornell University, for the college's Women and the New Millennium program.
But Mrs. Clinton's campaign staff was also peppered with questions about an article in The Los Angeles Times, which reported today that federal prosecutors, in internal memorandums on the campaign finance investigations stemming from the Clinton-Gore 1996 re-election campaign, criticized Mrs. Clinton for not notifying Democratic National Committee members of donations that had been illegally collected from foreign donors.
Mrs. Clinton and others had learned of the problems with funds collected by a well-known Clinton friend, Yah Lin Trie, and she and others decided to return the money that he had raised for the Clintons' legal defense fund. These accusations were made during the Senate campaign finance hearings led by Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee.
Howard Wolfson, Mrs. Clinton's spokesman, said that "this matter has been investigated with many others at great expense to taxpayers over the last several years." Mr. Wolfson added that "New Yorkers have made their judgment and know that there is nothing there."

HEADLINE: Go West, Young Man

BYLINE: By Walter Bernstein; Walter Bernstein is a screenwriter and the author of a memoir about the blacklist, "Inside Out."

 BODY:

A Walk Toward Oregon
 A Memoir.
 By Alvin M. Josephy Jr.
 Illustrated. 333 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50. 
 On a business trip to the Midwest as a young man, Alvin M. Josephy Jr. happened to arrive at a time of dangerous flooding. In his engaging memoir, "A Walk Toward Oregon," he states matter-of-factly that he volunteered to help pile sandbags against the rising waters. He takes this diversion for granted. Josephy is an activist. More to the point, he is a liberal activist. Helping others comes naturally to him. At a very early age, he discovered who he was and what he would remain: "a reformist liberal of the optimistic F.D.R. variety" who felt "that my father's generation had bequeathed to mine a fundamentally unjust and unsound society, with whose disastrous results President Roosevelt was trying to cope, and that my generation would have to help him reform it if the America of our founding fathers was to survive."
To this end, the 84-year-old Josephy has been many things in his extraordinarily rich life: writer, advocate, soldier, politician, conservationist and civil servant. In all these roles, he has acquitted himself with honor and courage. Josephy is part of that generation, as is this reviewer, whose lives have been formed by two world wars, the Great Depression, the New Deal, the fight against fascism and the continuing struggle against racism. Whether it was the "greatest generation" is moot. It was a hard-knocks generation, and a tough one.
We believed in politics and, strange as it now seems, in government. We felt it could operate as a bulwark against poverty or oppression. Looking back, the belief seems quaint and rather touching. We took it seriously. We needed to take it seriously. All around us was suffering and despair, the sense of a system gone murderously wrong, the desperate need to find an answer, any answer, that promised relief. The government supplied that answer. It performed the necessary role of an elected government: to help the people who elected it. It is instructive to remember that the heroes of Steinbeck's "Grapes of Wrath" are not only the plucky Joad family but also the government agencies that shelter and protect them.
Josephy is best known for his work with and for American Indians (he does not call them Native Americans). He had always been interested in the West, had longed to go there since he was a child growing up comfortably in New York as a member of the Knopf publishing family on his mother's side. His heart was set on Oregon, trail's end. After dropping out of Harvard, he found a writing job at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in Hollywood in 1934. That got him to the Pacific Ocean, but not the real West.
Only after the war, on a trip for Time magazine, did Josephy begin to find what he was looking for. He had stopped at a Nez Perce reservation in Idaho, where he was told of the tribe's current problems of neglect and unemployment, the broken government promises. He was also given a lesson about the tribe's history, the proud fact that it had "once fought a war against the United States and beat four American armies." The injustice and the bravery moved him to action; he had come upon his life's work.
Since then, Josephy has written widely about Indian history and resistance, and he has lobbied and demonstrated for their cause. He was one of the few non-Indian supporters of the National Congress of American Indians, a lobbying group. He seems to have been accepted by Indians of different tribes. Undoubtedly that has been because of his advocacy, but it may also have been because of his humanistic appreciation of their inner life. He had, he explains, "learned to appreciate the depth of the full-time spirituality that permeated every aspect of their lives, made them group-oriented and cooperative, believing firmly that the well-being of the group came ahead of that of any individual." He discovered "much of comfort in them for myself."
Josephy is secure in his liberalism and not sentimental about it. Maybe the Depression cured him of sentimentality, or maybe it was his war experience. He served, he tells us, in the Pacific as a Marine combat correspondent. The difference between a Marine correspondent and an Army correspondent (which this reviewer was for Yank, the Army weekly) was that in the Army you could see action with an outfit and then leave to write about it. In the Marines, you stayed and continued to fight. It made all the difference. Josephy describes fighting through the bloody battles of Guam, Saipan and Iwo Jima, going into action with rifle and tape recorder. He received the Bronze Star.
When he finally did get to Oregon, in the mid-1950's, he found the land as receptive as he had dreamed. He bought a ranch there and pursued his writing. Along with his Indian books, he has written books about being in combat and about the Civil War in the West. He served briefly as an assistant to Stewart Udall, secretary of the interior in the Kennedy administration. In between, Josephy became an editor of American Heritage magazine and developed an interest in conservation. He was a premature environmentalist, he says, attacking the "forces of greedy growth and development for their past or present sins of spoliation, pollution and destruction."
When Vietnam came, Josephy, ever the liberal dissenter, worried that he was not doing enough against the war. By then he had moved to Greenwich, Conn., returning to his beloved Oregon only for summer vacations. But one day in Greenwich, a delegation of Indians arrived unannounced at his door. They were Lakota Sioux who had driven from South Dakota to march with the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in a New York peace parade. The group included several medicine men, and that night they conducted a spiritual ceremony in the Josephy living room. The sound of their singing and the beating of their drums was not something ordinarily heard in Greenwich, and alarmed neighbors hurried over to make sure all was well. But the Indians had come to see their friend, and in the parade they marched in a place of honor and Josephy marched with them.
This book is about a member of a scarred generation living through a barbarous century. It is written modestly and without adornment. Occasionally, it could stand a little more adornment, a little more drama where there is now simple description. But there is drama enough in the events. Josephy has seen his time clearly; he has acted on his idealism; he has written a valuable book about a valuable life. 
http://www.nytimes.com
