HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
New Apartments Proposed in Downtown Hartford

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
AFTER the Capital City Economic Development Authority announced last year that $35 million in subsidies would be available to build apartments in downtown Hartford, months went by and no developers called to express any interest.
"Now, we've got so many proposals we can't fund them all," said R. Bartley Halloran, the panel's chairman. His agency is considering applications for partial subsidies for projects that would, at a total cost of more than $300 million, add more than 1,000 apartments to downtown Hartford. In addition, the state has proposed building 400 apartments at Adriaen's Landing downtown, a proposed $1 billion development on the banks of the Connecticut River. That would more than double the housing stock in the downtown, where fewer than 900 units exist now. 
 "There hasn't been a new apartment building built downtown since Bushnell Towers, and that was in the 1970's," Mr. Halloran said. "It took a long time to get the interest of a couple of national investors, but once that happened, everyone started to ask: 'Wait a minute. What am I missing here? Why are these other developers interested?' "
Among the national developers that have presented projects in Hartford are Casden Properties Inc., a Los Angeles company that owns more than 60,000 units in California. It would handle the 400 apartments proposed for Adriaen's Landing. A second national developer, the Northland Investment Corporation of Boston, has received approval for $30 million in subsidies for a 250-unit apartment tower that will be part of a $120 million redevelopment of the Civic Center.
All of the new apartments will have market-rate rents, and the subsidies will take the form of low-interest loans to developers.
Lawrence R. Gottesdiener, the chief executive officer at Northland, said he hopes to change how people view the city. "We have no illusions that this is going to be a short-term process," he said. "Right now Hartford is a ghost town after 5 p.m. and on weekends, unless there's a special event, and it's going to take a long time to turn that around. But we have the ability to ultimately shape this entire neighborhood, create a 24-hour environment where people can feel comfortable living and working and playing until 11 o'clock at night."
Anthony M. Caruso, the executive director of the Hartford Downtown Council, said that Urban Strategies Inc., a Toronto consulting company, reached a similar conclusion in a study his group commissioned.
"That report saw that housing is going to be a critical piece of any development strategy," Mr. Caruso said. "It clearly demonstrated that if the right opportunity presented itself at the right location and the right price, there would be interest on the part of certain demographic groups to come live in downtown. And I take a similar position. If there aren't people here 24 hours a day, interacting on a business and a social basis, we lose the opportunity to create a vital city."
There is considerable debate over just how many new apartments the city might be able to absorb in the short term, said Donald S. Gershman, the executive vice president of the Konover Investments Corporation in Hartford, which is proposing a $40-million, 22-story apartment building with 154 units overlooking Bushnell Park.
"No one knows for sure what the market is, because there has been nothing built for more than a decade," Mr. Gershman said. "There is a sense that there is pent-up demand in the empty-nester market and in the young professional market. The young lawyers and accountants are moving to Rocky Hill or Manchester now, but there's a sense that a large number of them might like to be within walking distance of their office and downtown activities."
The Bushnell Park property would cater to both empty-nesters and young professionals, he said, with a fitness club, pool, game room and meeting rooms, and a feature not found in many buildings, a suite for guests.
"A lot of what's going to happen in the future is going to depend on the success of the first one or two projects that come on the market," Mr. Gershman said. "If they're well conceived and offer a good living experience, it will have a very positive effect on the overall market."
Other developers think the market could be considerable right from the outset. Among them is Suzanne M. Hopgood, the president of the Hopgood Group, which is proposing a $21 million development of 100 apartments, a 175-room hotel, 600 parking spaces and 8,500 feet of retail space on a parcel bounded by Trumbull, Pearl, Lewis and Gold Streets.
D OWNTOWN right now is 100 percent occupied," Ms. Hopgood said. "Very clearly, the demand has been increasing downtown. I think we're following the trend of a lot of cities. One of the great advantages to Hartford that people are starting to understand is that it has a very strong network of neighborhoods, it's a very active neighborhood city, and for a lot of people that's a very appealing lifestyle."
She said she saw the turnaround starting four years ago, when there was an all-day block party to celebrate the presidential debate that was taking place in Hartford. "That started people thinking, 'Maybe it isn't what we thought it was,' " she said. "So you had a few people move back, and a couple of restaurants open up and maybe a nightclub. Every time you add a couple of hundred units, it adds to the appeal of the city. Certainly in the short term, it could support 200 to 400 new units. I think you also have room for, say, 100 really high-end units, but that's speaking just from owning a building and watching what's going on."
Northland is the first to have its application for the subsidies approved by the economic development authority: $15 million for housing and $15 million for commercial and retail space. Mr. Gottesdiener, Northland's chief executive, said he thinks there is a recognition that his company is committed to the downtown, since its first investment, the 648,000-square-foot Metro Center, which it bought in 1996, came just two weeks after the Hartford Whalers hockey team left the city. Some critics saw this as evidence of a new period of downtown decline.
"We had to go to 29 lenders, but we financed it, closed the deal, and within a short time had brought in 950 new jobs," Mr. Gottesdiener said. His estimate is that downtown could support 1,000 new apartments immediately.
Mr. Halloran of the development authority contends that all of the developers are overly cautious. He said there are 75,000 people working downtown, and 20,000 of them currently live in apartments. "But the apartments are all in Rocky Hill or Cromwell, 25 or 30 miles outside of the city," he said. If Hartford can entice just 10 percent of those workers to live in the city, he pointed out, that's an instant demand for 2,000 units.
Meanwhile, Martin LeGault, the president of the Corporation for Independent Living, a nonprofit housing organization in Wethersfield, said the city and state need to pay more attention to Hartford's existing housing outside of downtown.
He estimated there are 400 vacant houses in the city now. While that is down considerably from 700 three years ago, when the city began an effort to get rundown properties fixed up or torn down, it is still too many, Mr. LeGault contends.
He said his organization has renovated 21 houses and apartments so far at a cost of $2.15 million, and work is under way on another six. It has now started its most ambitious project, a $10 million investment to build or renovate 70 houses and apartments along Mortson and Putnam Heights Streets in the Frog Hollow section near downtown Hartford.
"We can't do just one or two of these properties and have an effect," he said. "We have to do all of them, and we're putting together the financing to do it all in two phases. You have to take a comprehensive approach because you're never going to get homeowners to come in and make an investment in a house if it's sitting by a blighted property."
But his group and others working on inner-city housing -- among them, Broad Park Development, the Urban League and Sheldon Oak Central -- all have to scramble for the few subsidies available, he said. "The only way you're going to have viable downtown housing is if you revitalize the neighborhoods," he said. "Nobody's going to want to live next to a blighted neighborhood. We're not saying downtown development shouldn't happen. It just shouldn't be done to the exclusion of neighborhood development. They should be done in tandem."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1164 words

HEADLINE: Displacing the Ghosts of Students and Sailors

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD 

DATELINE: PORT DEPOSIT, Md.

 BODY:
PERCHED on steep cliffs above this curious little riverside town, which is just a mile long and 500 feet deep, is a ghostly granite-and-limestone group of buildings that have preoccupied residents for decades.
The former Tome School for Boys, with its sweeping views of the Susquehanna River, was considered one of the most beautiful boarding-school campuses on the East Coast at its peak in the 1920's. Named for Jacob Tome (the last name rhymes with home), a Port Deposit lumberman and banker and Cecil County's first millionaire, the Beaux-Arts campus was designed by the New York firm of Boring & Tilton, which also designed the main building on Ellis Island and the Heights Casino in Brooklyn. 
 Now, the school has become a symbol of the town's past, particularly its heyday a century ago as a "port of deposit" for goods moving by boat and rail between the Susquehanna Valley and the Chesapeake Bay.
Later, the school became part of the Bainbridge Naval Training Center, etched in the memories of tens of thousands men and women who served there, from 1942 until its closing in 1976.
Flanked by the river to the west and cliffs to the east, Port Deposit, in the northeast corner of Maryland, about 35 miles from Baltimore, has a population of about 800.
The Main Street recalls the town's commercial prominence in the 19th century with Georgian, Greek Revival, Federal, Victorian and Italianate structures built well above street level to avoid damage from floods, which are usually controlled by Conowingo Dam six miles upstream. The entire town is on the National Register of Historic Places.
The Navy did little to alter the symmetry of the Tome School campus. The dozen buildings that lined the quadrangle in a century-old drawing -- the gymnasium, dormitories, classroom buildings, dining hall and headmaster's house -- are completely recognizable today. The row of two-story clapboard houses built for teachers, the heating plant, sidewalks, roads, drinking fountains and even street signs give the impression of a town deserted very suddenly.
Only deterioration of the buildings and the untrimmed grounds, including an overgrown terraced garden and a nine-hole golf course, provide clues that the last class graduated from the Tome School in 1941 and that the Navy closed the base in 1976.
Now, the weedy 1,200-acre tract is facing a new life as development plans, sponsored by the State of Maryland, get under way.
"A shadow of our history is up there," said Erika Quesenbery, a curator at the Paw Paw Museum, named for bushes that once graced the museum entrance. "People feel an amazing sense of pride about it -- and an amazing sense of loss."
The school was built in 1900 with about $1 million of the $3 million bequeathed by Mr. Tome. The trustees in charge of the bequest set about creating an exclusive preparatory school, but its prestige was short-lived, and during the Depression, the school fell on hard times financially.
Robert T. Jones Jr., 77, a retired funeral director who lives in Newark, Del., went to the school in the late 1930's, and he remembers how he liked to stand on the bluff and watch storms whipping up on the Susquehanna.
On Sundays, he recalled, the boys would troop into town to church, descending the steep cliffside steps they called "Jacob Tome's ladder."
At the outbreak of World War II, the Navy came looking for recruit training sites, and the school was sold to the government for $900,000. The entire campus was incorporated into the new naval base, and since 1942, the property has been off limits to most civilians, although drivers crossing the Susquehanna on Interstate 95 can glimpse the elegant headmaster's house and the clock tower of the main classroom building.
Once the Navy closed the base, residents of Cecil County worked for years to reclaim the property. In 1991, the 125-acre Tome School section was annexed by Port Deposit. Then last year, the Navy agreed to transfer the entire site to the State of Maryland.
In a military ceremony last month, attended by Tome graduates, former sailors and local officials, the Navy formally transferred the parcel to the Bainbridge Development Corporation, an agency set up by the state.
I DON'T think people can understand what the significance of that day was to us," said Mayor Wayne L. Tome Sr., a great-great-great-nephew of Jacob Tome. "We've been sitting there looking at that site. It's been a thorn in our sides."
The development corporation, whose board is made of area residents, is charged with developing and marketing the property. Possible uses for the Tome campus include a conference center, retirement community or university extension campus, and the rest of the site could be devoted to recreation, home sites, office buildings or light industry. Development is expected to take place over the next 15 to 20 years.
The first order of business is to create a master plan for the entire parcel, said Harland Graef, a retired DuPont executive who is the development corporation's chairman. A study is also under way to determine the best way to establish a modern water and waste treatment system, and the corporation is now applying for grants to pay for necessary repairs to keep the historic Tome buildings from deteriorating further.
When it comes to restoring the buildings, the development corporation will have its work cut out for it. Vandals made off with much of the ornamentation on the Tome buildings, inside and out. Even the weather vane on the clock tower of Memorial Hall was stolen.
"It was demolition by neglect," Mayor Tome said. "Vandals stripped out plumbing for the copper and chipped out the marble steps."
In 1991, the Navy began tearing down all but 60 of 600 military buildings at Bainbridge, demolishing barracks, mess halls, a hospital, drill hall, indoor rifle range, bowling alley, theater and apartment complex. Among the buildings still standing are a mess hall, a recreation building, barracks, officers' houses, some quite large, and the water treatment plant.
Porter E. May of Malvern, Pa., the president of the Bainbridge veterans' organization, said most of the buildings that were demolished were built as temporary structures during World War II and contained asbestos. In fact, one reason it took so long for the property to be turned over to the state was the need for a massive environmental cleanup that took place in the last 10 years. That included removal of 138,000 tons of soil contaminated with asbestos.
Men and women who served at Bainbridge hope that at least one of the remaining Navy buildings will be used as a museum to honor the 500,000 sailors trained at Bainbridge.
"Anybody who goes up there and just stands in the quiet can literally feel the presence of things past," said Albert F. Bagley Jr., 74, of nearby Havre de Grace, Md., who was one of the first recruits at Bainbridge during World War II. "You can almost believe you hear the men."

HEADLINE: For High-Tech Merger, No New Jobs Soon

BYLINE: By ROBBIE WOLIVER 

DATELINE: ISLANDIA

 BODY:
THE proposed merger between Computer Associates International Inc. and Sterling Software Inc. of Dallas will not open the thousands of technology jobs that some Long Islanders had hoped for, contrary to several recent reports.
What might have been good news for prospective technical personnel is neutralized by the shallow pool of candidates in information technology, or I.T., representatives of both companies say. 
 With a 2.8 percent unemployment rate on the Island and a limited number of technology personnel, Computer Associates, a leading provider of business software, did not have much choice.
"The employment pool is already tight on Long Island," said Gary Quinn, executive vice president of global information and administrative services of Computer Associates, which is based in Islandia. "It's not really large enough to support us if we had a large growth spurt. But right now, we're not lacking for potential employees."
And for the longer term, technology companies are aggressively supporting training and education programs to broaden the range of talent. Computer Associates, which employs 3,000 on Long Island, follows many avenues of recruitment, from luring personnel from smaller companies with attractive benefit packages to offering long-term internships.
Taking advantage of regional colleges and universities, the company has first choice of their graduates. It also courts students from community colleges. "We'll reimburse further education," Mr. Quinn said.
No longer counting on outside headhunters, Computer Associates employs eight of its own full time.
The 24-year-old Computer Associates, a $6.3 billion global corporation with offices in more than 40 countries, has already demonstrated its reluctance to relocate talent from other areas.
"We haven't really needed to do that," said Mr. Quinn, who also oversees human resources for the company. "When we've merged, the companies with which we've merged remained in their own cities, employees remained at their old jobs. That's what happened with Platinum; they all stayed in Chicago. We believe in leaving things intact."
Computer Associates took over Platinum Technology International in July for $3.5 billion. The takeover of Sterling, which specializes in data storage, is valued at $4 billion in stock and should be completed by May.
Cindy Foor, a spokeswoman for Sterling, agreed with Mr. Quinn. "We have no known plans on moving to Long Island," she said. "A lot of the operations will remain as they are."
But there will be opportunities for jobs to move to Long Island in the future, said Elissa LiVecchi, spokeswoman for Computer Associates. "Any acquisition certainly creates more opportunities for additional growth." By 2006, Computer Associates is planning to add more than 5,000 jobs, bringing the total to 8,000.
Mr. Quinn said that while Computer Associates respected the general trend against relocation, the company welcomed the return of those who had moved to Silicon Alley in Manhattan. "We're seeing many tech types who live on the Island and commute to the city change their minds and come back here to work with us," he said.
Computer Associates has set up or participated in several programs to help their employees adapt to life on the Island. One is the Suffolk Home Works Partnership, Suffolk County's affordable-housing alliance, which was set up to offer partial public financing of down-payment costs to first-time home buyers whose employers match the assistance. Computer Associates was the first Long Island company to support the program.
Other perks include one of the largest Montessori-based child development day-care centers in the Northeast, as well as summer and holiday programs for employees' children.
"Why wouldn't they attract the I.T. candidate?" asked Mark Papalexis, president of J2 Resources, a technical-employment firm in Farmingdale. "The pool for I.T. employees is small enough that they can really write their own ticket. So companies like Computer Associates need to win them over with great perks."
Both Mr. Quinn and Mr. Papalexis agreed that since the Island's engineering population dwindled after Fairchild-Republic and Grumman closed, there has not been much of a focus on technical and engineering jobs.
Mr. Papalexis, a 13-year veteran in placing technical personnel, said that although potential workers are available, the pool has not replenished itself during the sharp decline of such jobs over the past two decades.
If there were a large influx of openings from a merger like Computer Associates and Sterling, he said, there would not be enough local talent to fill those jobs.
"With all the businesses consolidating on the Island, it's tightening an already tight market even further," he continued. "After any merger, instead of two entities needing the personnel, only one is hiring. People then move on to other fields."
Computer Associates has worked actively with local schools, hoping to funnel even teenagers into the lucrative field. But it will be another four or five years before a deeper talent pool is developed, Mr. Quinn said.
Already seeing positive results from colleges, Mr. Papalexis said: "Potential employees for lower-level entry positions are being constantly cranked out of the local technical schools. The I.T. field is extremely well paying and Long Island is a very desirable place to live. There are predicted shortages of I.T. people in general, so it's not just Long Island; it's just a little tighter here."
For the longer term, Mr. Quinn is optimistic.
"The community is highly educated and it's near New York City," he said. "It's certainly more appealing than Silicon Valley, where homes are three times what they are here. You have to get creative. You just can't run an ad anymore. You have to work through the Internet, and most importantly you have to offer a great package. Right now Long Island is providing us with a high standard of tech employee. And it will only get better."

HEADLINE: Q&A/Lester M. Crystal;
Newsman With Community College Link

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
AS a journalist for more than 40 years, Lester M. Crystal, executive producer of "The Newshour With Jim Lehrer" on PBS, has met his share of impressive, and yes, he said, occasionally not-so-impressive news makers.
Dr. Henry A. Kissinger is one who fits into Mr. Crystal's impressive category. A longtime resident of the Edgemont section of Greenburgh, Mr. Crystal used his influence to induce Dr. Kissinger to speak at Westchester Community College in Valhalla. 
 Others Mr. Crystal has called on to speak there include Tom Brokaw, Art Buchwald, the humorist Al Franken, the playwright Wendy Wasserstein and the regular essayist on "The Newshour," Roger Rosenblatt.
As one of the news gatherers who went to China with President Richard M. Nixon, Mr. Crystal met Dr. Kissinger in 1972. Later, when Mr. Crystal was president of NBC News, he and Dr. Kissinger worked together on some documentaries.
Mr. Crystal began his news career in 1958 as a writer for radio and television and spent 20 years from 1963 to 1983 in various positions with NBC News before joining "The Newshour." The show, which draws an average of three million viewers each night, is produced in Arlington, Va. Mr. Crystal and his wife, Toby, commute each week from Westchester to Washington. Here are excerpts from a conversation with him:
Q. How did you get involved with Westchester Community College?
A. I'm social friends with Joe Hankin, who is the president of the college, and also with Betsy Stern, who is on the board of the college. She and her husband, Walter Stern, have been very involved in the college. Hearing about the school through them, I became very interested in what I think is the extraordinary work that this school does and that community colleges do across the country.
I think they provide what is almost an unknown service in terms of offering educational opportunities to people who otherwise wouldn't have them. So I joined the board of the college's Foundation and have been on it for several years.
Q. You said the college has done extraordinary things. What do you mean?
A. Certainly in terms of those people who can't afford the high cost of education today, even can't afford the state schools, for those people who don't have the time to devote to college education, for these people Westchester Community College affords great opportunities to get a basic education and to move on either to a better job or a four-year school. There are examples of people who have been able to raise their employment level from one point to another because they were able to take some courses.
Q. Not every community college gets Dr. Kissinger as a speaker. How did that happen?
A. Dr. Kissinger has an association with a number of people at the school, and he very graciously agreed to do this lecture. I think it will be interesting, given his background and his knowledge and the fact that he has stayed very much in touch in the foreign affairs area with everything going on. He travels overseas constantly.
There are two or three functions that the college has that creates a better awareness of the college and its connection with the community. They do a literary symposium every year. They have a celebrity salon in the spring. In addition they have some special award dinners.
Q. The reporters for "The Newshour" never express their personal opinions. How does the program maintain that?
A. That's something we adhere to. I would say in terms of what are the most important fundamentals of our program, one is thoroughness and accuracy and seriousness. The other is fairness and balance. We really do go out of our way not to demonstrate what our opinion is -- to extract information from the people we are talking to, not demonstrate what we know or what we think.
Q. Has any thought been given to changing the serious format of "The Newshour"?
A. We have tried to keep from in any way diluting the seriousness of what we do and not to dumb it down in an effort to make it more popular. But at the same time we are trying very hard to broaden what we do -- to not just concentrate on politics and government and economics and those issues. So we've done sports. We're doing music, arts, books, science, medicine, technology. We're trying to make the program interesting to a greater variety of viewers.
Q. Please describe what is planned for "The Newshour" in this presidential election year?
A. We're always trying to stay on top of how the campaign is developing. We don't have any particular things planned that are new. One of the things that we have done over this primary season, as nighttime debates have become an important factor, we've run extended excerpts in the 8-to-12-minute range. And we will continue following candidates on the stump and giving viewers an extended view of what the candidates are saying. And especially when we get into the general campaign, we will look at the issues very closely. The election is a huge story, and we're going to concentrate on it and try to get as many different perspectives as we can.
I don't know exactly what Dr. Kissinger is going to talk about at the college, but the foreign affairs issues have not really surfaced that much in the primary campaign. But I think they will in the national campaign.
Character is a big issue on people's minds -- character and leadership. What kind of person is this? How will that person react when that inevitable foreign crisis comes down? How will that person react with the question of troop commitments?
Q. Besides Dr. Kissinger, who else among recent politicians has a similar stature?
A. There are many people. I currently have great admiration for Jimmy Carter, not so much in how his presidency went but in how he has conducted himself since in terms of leadership. There are some senators who have since retired that I admire or admired. I think Senators Danforth, Nunn and Boren brought a lot to the public discourse. Also: Hubert Humphrey, Walter Mondale, Mike Mansfield.
Q. Does it come as a surprise how inarticulate some decision makers are?
A. We try not to have them on the air. We try to filter them out. However, when it comes to people in government who are responsible for a particular issue, you do have them on the air because they are responsible, whether they are as articulate as they might be or not. Yes, sometimes it reveals that they don't have a very good grasp of the subject matter and you wonder how they got there. At other times it just may be that the person is just not that good on television and may still be quite good at doing his job.
I'm also amazed how people sometimes get selected to be the government spokesman or the spokesman for an organization. Their grasp of issues is very superficial sometimes, and because they are selected as spokespeople they don't feel free to express their own views, because they're worried about what the boss might say. So, often a particular organization should put the boss on the air who would feel free to engage the subject, instead of the spokesman.
 
Kissinger to Speak
Dr. Henry A. Kisssinger, secretary of state in the Nixon administration, will speak at a benefit tonight at 6:30 at Westchester Community College in Valhalla. Tickets at $500 a couple for dinner and the lecture or $50 a person for just the lecture, which starts at 7:30, can be obtained by calling the college at 785-6558.

HEADLINE: CABARET;
Where the Talent Is

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Theatergoers looking for the authentic "performer as activist" and social commentator will never find these artists at glitzy places like Feinstein's or in swank hotels and supper clubs. But they are in neighborhoods across our city, particularly those in which residents daily experience social, political and economic oppression and repression -- not the typical life experience of those who can afford $50 cover charges.
Artistic counterculture is encouraged, and flourishes, in theaters, clubs, bars, galleries, storefronts and lofts in the the East Village and on the Lower East Side. Often the shows may lack the polish of standard, American-style upscale cabaret, but they do have the bite, edge and irony of authentic European-style kabarett. 
 Most of the artists performing their new material in these spaces are desperate for audiences and critics to appreciate and help them develop their craft. Their work may be a bit rough, but the experience is real.
And it is there that future Kurt Weills will be found.
 
MARK HANNAY
Manhattan

HEADLINE: Iron Furnace Rises Again -- Minus the Soot

BYLINE: By FRANCES CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S Northwest corner is characterized by pastoral scenes, winding roads and scenic farmland. It's hard to picture that at the turn of the last century there was a sprawling network of blasting hot iron furnaces, billowing soot, trains loaded with pig iron, and an industry that made part of Litchfield County look anything but pastoral.
Today, you have to imagine much of this -- wooden buildings have collapsed or burned, gigantic stone furnaces have collapsed, forget the trains and few signs remain of what was once a thriving business. 
 Along Lower Road in East Canaan, one of three former furnaces in that area has been restored and gives the public an opportunity to see how such a furnace used to operate. In fact, enough interest has arisen around the remains of the iron industry to create "The Heritage Trail," seven sites that tell the story of Connecticut's booming turn-of-the-century iron industry. In the Housatonic watershed, there were 44 furnaces over three states, about 19 in Connecticut.
Fred Hall, Canaan's town historian, said he remembers, as a young child, going out on business with his father, a stonecutter and blacksmith. His father had been called make a repair across the road from the Beckley Furnace, which closed in 1918.
"Someone invited me to come over to the furnace," Mr. Hall recalled. "And I stood by the hearth as the hot iron began running out. I could feel the heat of it, like a volcano."
The temperature in the casting shed probably reached 140 to 150 degrees as the iron poured into troughs. From there it would be cooled and transported to the foundry in Lime Rock for final transformation into something useful like cannons and railroad wheels.
While the industry started in other areas, it was in the region from Stockbridge, Mass., down to Dover Plains, N.Y., that it really became successful, because here there was water power, hardwood forests to make charcoal and hills containing carbonate rock that could be quarried for lime, which removed the impurities from the iron. Wrought iron was first produced in forges shortly after the Pilgrims landed, but in 1644 the first blast furnace began producing tools, nails, cooking utensils, and plows.
Connecticut produced bog ore, which develops from bacterial action in bogs, until 1731, but the discovery of limonite iron in Salisbury triggered the growth of a huge industry. In 1734, the first forge was built in Lime Rock, and for the next 190 years, the iron industry determined how life would be lived in this state.
The Beckley Furnace in Canaan would have eventually fallen into irreparable decay if it weren't for the efforts of a group of volunteers. The Committee for the Preservation of the Beckley Furnace consists of 10 people, including Mr. Hall, Dr. William Adam of Canaan, whose family used to operate the business in the 18th and 19th centuries, and Edward M. Kirby of Sharon, a retired school administrator and historian.
Mr. Kirby combined a serious interest in science with history. "My field was really geology," he said. That led to an interest in the important rock formations that allowed Northwest Connecticut's iron industry to prosper. "They needed this local rock formation to get lime," he explained. "Most came from Salisbury. There was a belt of iron ore and wood from north of Pittsfield to Dover, New York, called the Salisbury Iron District. It has a certain kind of manganese that was shock resistant and therefore perfect for cannons and railroad car wheels."
Today, there are fields waiting for an archaeological dig, all in the hopes that unearthing things will help piece together how the furnace worked. Memories like those of Mr. Hall and old pictures have helped reconstruct part of the history, but iron furnaces were such a common part of life that people didn't always notice the day-to-day routine or make a record of it.
On the other side of Lower Road, across from the Beckley Furnace, trains unloaded lime ore and charcoal, which was ferried across the road by a small suspended bridge to be fed into the top of the furnace.
The furnace started out at 32 feet high, then was later raised to 40 feet. To make a ton of iron, 138 bushels of charcoal had to be fed into the 40-foot-high opening. The furnace was fired up with the assistance of huge bellows, pumping tubs and water power from the Blackberry River, just a few yards away.
Even the language of the furnace sounds quaint today. "The tuyere was a nozzle that shot blasts of hot air into the furnace," Mr. Kirby explained. "The tuyere reduced the amount of charcoal and time to get the furnace up to a productive heat."
The bustle pipe, which came around the furnace from the back, shot air into two tuyeres. In addition to the tuyere arch, and tuyere, there was a "downcomer" to the tuyere, and the bottom of the bosh, where the blast furnace shaft tapered inward to meet the hearth and crucible. Eleven salamanders, dense iron that couldn't be melted down again, were found on the site, each weighing about 10 tons.
Research has indicated that a team of oxen, yoked to a log platform, would drag a salamander to the river where it would be dumped out of the way. Tuyere arches on each side of the furnace give the structure a graceful look and these, plus the casting arch, the hearth, and the bottom of the bosh, give the furnace a Medieval rather than Colonial appearance.
"These types of furnaces date to 1450 in Britain and France," Mr. Kirby said. "The Chinese had even smaller ones dating back to about 700 A.D."
Different furnaces were built in different ways, depending on the time, the available materials and the geographical location, but all made use of this three-fold resource of water power, wood and lime.
A few years ago, Ronald D. Jones, a committee member who lives a short distance away from the Beckley Furnace, helped Mr. Hall create an explanatory sign about the furnace. "I felt it didn't make sense to put up a sign if the furnace is going to fall down," he said. "We formed the best committee; there's no chairman because everyone has an equal interest in the project."
The Committee for the Preservation of the Beckley Furnace had two primary goals. One was to preserve this particular historical monument and the other was to develop the iron heritage trail, an industrial historical route through Norfolk, Canaan, Salisbury, Falls Village, Cornwall and Kent, and into New York and Massachusetts. Mr. Kirby said the Beckley Furnace was intended as a centerpiece, but the trail could also serve as an attraction to tourists, a boost to local economic development, and a source for historical study.
The Beckley structure has been owned by the State Department of Environmental Protection since 1946, but it had no plans to invest in restoration, Mr. Kirby said. The committee started with a Valentine's Day pancake breakfast. They gained legislative support and received $250,000 from the state bonding commission in early 1998. All work was done by the State Department of Public Works.
"Work is now being done on the dam on the Blackberry River, for safety reasons, and there is a move to purchase the remains of the original office buildings so we can do a dig, plus study a partially intact turbine," Mr. Jones said.
"Our idea is to make this all visitor friendly," Mr. Jones said.
Mr. Kirby's passion for the Beckley Furnace restoration was preceded by the management of restoration of the Lime Rock furnace. Retired from school administration and teaching, he has plunged into historical archaeology, publishing, most recently, "Echoes of Iron: The Iron Industry in Connecticut's Northwest Corner" with the help of the Sharon Historical Society and the Connecticut Humanities Council.
"In the 1870's to the 1880's, this area was America's biggest producer of railroad car wheels," Mr. Kirby said. "It seems to have all vanished, but it's out there if you look for it."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The Park Row Building, 15 Park Row;
An 1899 'Monster' That Reigned High Over the City

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
IT'S still a gawky-looking thing, but the landmark 29-story Park Row Building, at 15 Park Row near City Hall, has nowhere near the impact it did in 1899, when it signaled New Yorkers that tall-building construction was running unchecked.
Now it is almost empty, as the owner prepares for a complete renovation and a partial conversion to residences that is to include two of New York's most unusual apartments -- dual triplexes in the building's two rooftop cupolas. 
 In the 1890's advances in steel-frame construction opened up new opportunities for developers. The height of buildings had been restricted by the limits of bearing-wall construction -- those more than eight stories or so had impossibly thick walls on the lower floors. But steel frames meant that the only limits were elevator service. (There were no height restrictions for commercial buildings until 1916, when a zoning resolution was passed.)
The mid-1890's saw buildings getting taller and taller. Civic organizations protested that they were unsafe, that they blocked light and that they defaced the city. Early in 1896 the Chamber of Commerce announced its opposition to skyscrapers.
But later that year construction began at 15 Park Row, which was to be the tallest building yet and would reach back to Ann Street and Theater Alley. According to research by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, the Park Row Building was put up by a syndicate headed by August Belmont, the financier who in 1900 became the head of the group that built New York's first subway. Belmont was also a horse-racing enthusiast, and established the Belmont Park race track on Long Island in 1905.
He had been active in transit matters since the 1880's, but there is no evidence that his Park Row plan anticipated the first subway project, which was built from 1900 to 1904, ended at City Hall Park across from the Park Row Building and increased the value of downtown properties.
The 391-foot-high Park Row Building -- 26 floors, plus the two three-story cupolas -- was completed in 1899 and succeeded the 350-foot-high Manhattan Life Insurance Building at 66 Broadway, just south of Wall Street, as the tallest building in New York. The foundation of the Park Row Building was made of 3,900 Georgia spruce piles driven into wet sand and topped by granite blocks. About 4,000 people a day worked there, using a semicircular bay of 10 elevators.
In an 1899 article, the building's architect, Robert H. Robertson, wrote that he had tried to make the building "look less than its real height." He had designed the facade, he wrote, so that the floors appeared to be in groups of four or five, and he had added heavy horizontal forms. The building also has four heroic-scale female figures on the front.
Architectural critics were not impressed. In 1898 The Real Estate Record and Guide lamented that "New York is the only city in which such a monster would be allowed to rear itself." The Record and Guide called the cupolas "ineffectual and insignificant" and said that the huge blank side walls were "absolutely inexpressive and vacuous."
Indeed such raw expanses were a frequent sore point with writers. In a 1908 article in The New York Times, the French architect Augustin-Adolphe Rey scornfully wrote of the building that "one side of it is an entirely bare wall -- what difference does it make how the other sides are treated?"
ANOTHER French critic, Jean Schopfer, in his 1900 article "American Architecture from a Foreign Point of View" in the magazine Architectural Review, simply called the Park Row Building "detestable."
The 1900 census taker found two families in occupancy: James Jackson, the building engineer, his wife, Mary, and two children, and Alice Harrison, the "janitoress," a 38-year-old widow, living with her 9-year-old son, Alfred, and Charles Michial, 19, the elevator operator.
The Park Row's reign as the tallest building in New York lasted for nine years. In 1901 another syndicate announced that the Aetna, at 33rd Street and Broadway, would be 455 feet high -- but it was never built. In 1908, however, the 612-foot-high Singer Tower was completed at Broadway and Liberty Street and took over first place.
By the time of the stock market crash in 1929, the Park Row was just another old office building, and it went into receivership. To attract new tenants, the lower floors were redesigned by the architects Clinton & Russell, and much of the heavy stonework was replaced with gleaming bronze. The building has changed little since.
Last year the Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the Park Row Building a landmark, without objection from the owner. Charles Herzka, chief operating officer for Broadway Management, which manages the building, said that "from an economic standpoint it didn't materially adversely affect what we want to do."
Those plans include a gut renovation of the entire structure, including converting the 11th floor and above to 210 rental apartments, at a cost of more than $30 million. The rents are to range from $1,900 a month for a studio to $4,400 for a two-bedroom. The lower floors will remain commercial. Mr. Herzka said that the project would be completed next year and that the most unusual apartments would be the pair made out of the two three-story turrets.
And the cost of living at what was once the highest point in New York? "We'll see what the market can bear," Mr. Herzka said.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Financing A Home for Zero Down

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AS many aspiring home buyers know, to their regret, the biggest obstacle to ownership can often be the down payment. And while the percentage needed for a mortgage has dropped in the last 20 years from the traditional 20 percent to 10, 5 and in some cases even 3 percent, the prices of homes have doubled, tripled and even quadrupled.
Now some large lenders have started to offer zero down payment mortgages that also allow financing of the closing costs. Some lenders even make it possible for new owners to leave the closing with more cash than they had when they walked in -- at the price of course, of more debt. 
 Paul Reddam, chief executive officer of DiTech.com, a mortgage lender in Costa Mesa, Calif., said that what his company calls a Dream Loan allows home buyers to obtain a mortgage for up to 125 percent of the purchase price.
"This loan is for people who have good credit and strong income but who have never been able to save enough for a down payment," he said. "It's also for people who feel they have a better use for their money than tying it up in their home."
Mr. Reddam said that good credit generally refers to a credit score of 660 or above. The credit score is calculated using factors such as the payment history on other loans, the number of open credit lines and the type and amount of an individual's indebtedness.
"A borrower with sterling credit would have a score above 700, and a 'B' borrower would have a score below 620," Mr. Reddam said. "So a person with a score of 660 is in the middle of the range."
In addition to having a good credit score, he said, a borrower seeking a Dream Loan needs a somewhat better income-to-debt ratio than normally required. In most cases, Mr. Reddam said, for a borrower to qualify for a mortgage, total monthly expenses -- including all recurring debt payments and the payment on the mortgage being applied for -- cannot exceed about 38 percent of gross monthly income. For Dream Loans, however, notwithstanding the income-to-debt ratio, the borrower must have at least $2,000 a month left after all bills are paid.
"There's no application fee, and the actual cost of the loan depends on the person's credit score and how much over 100 percent they want to borrow," he said, adding that the interest rate also depends on the amount of the loan, with the current rate for a 125 percent mortgage around 11 percent. The rate for a conventional mortgage from DiTech, he said, averages around 8 percent.
Another company aggressively marketing zero-equity loans is Countrywide Home Loans in Calabasas, Calif. "We give you a choice," said Stephen Brandt, the company's senior vice president. "You can get either a Zero Down Plus with P.M.I. or an 80/ 20 No Down, No P.M.I."
Mr. Brandt said that the Zero Down Plus mortgage is a 103 percent first mortgage that requires private mortgage insurance. The 80/20 mortgage, he said, is actually two loans -- an 80 percent first mortgage plus a 20 percent home equity loan.
With the Zero Down Plus mortgage, he said, the extra 3 percent usually covers the borrower's closing costs. Private mortgage insurance, typically referred to as P.M.I., is required on first mortgages for more than 80 percent of a home's value. The insurance -- paid for by the borrower as part of the monthly mortgage costs -- provides the additional security needed for lenders to be able to sell such loans to institutional investors on the secondary market.
Mr. Brandt said that the principal and interest payments on a $250,000 Zero Down Plus mortgage for 30 years at 8.875 percent -- the current rate -- would be $1,989 a month. Private mortgage insurance on the part of the mortgage that exceeds 80 percent of the home's value, he said, would add $203 a month, making the total payment $2,192.
The company's other zero-down offering works differently. Since the 80 percent first mortgage is considered a conforming loan, meaning that it conforms to the standards set by Fannie Mae and others who buy the loans from the issuers, then repackage them in pools of securities for purchase by investors, there is no requirement for P.M.I. But while the interest rate charged on the first mortgage is still 8.875 percent, the interest rate charged on the second mortgage -- in essence, a home equity loan -- is 12.875 percent.
The first mortgage, for $200,000 at 8.875 percent, would require monthly payments of $1,591; the home equity loan, for $50,000 at 12.875 percent, would cost $559 a month. The total, $2,150 a month, is $42 a month less than the mortgage that requires P.M.I.
Mr. Brandt said that while the Zero Down Plus loan allows financing of the closing costs, the P.M.I. portion of the monthly payment is not tax deductible. On the other hand, he said, with the 80/20 loan, in most cases the interest on both the first and second mortgages would be deductible.
So what's the catch?
"I think these loans can be extremely risky," said Gerri Detweiler, education adviser for Credit Counselors of America and a co-author with Marc Eisenson of "Slash Your Debt" (The Financial Literacy Center, Kalamazoo, Mich., 1999). "If the value of your house drops, or even if it just doesn't increase, you could be in big trouble."
Ms. Detweiler said that since only a small portion of the monthly payment is applied to the principal in the early years of a mortgage, a homeowner could end up having to sell a house for less than the outstanding balance on the loan. That could easily happen with a home that has a 125 percent mortgage, she said, and is even possible for a home with a 100 percent mortgage when the costs of the sale are considered.
"If anything happens to your income stream, or you have to move unexpectedly, you're stuck," Ms. Detweiler said. "You have no breathing room. You may never get out from under."

HEADLINE: Tenant Harassment And Rent Regulation

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The letter to the editor on Feb. 13 "On Harassment of Tenants" , responding to the Times article "Is It Harassment? Or Is It the Law?" Jan 16 , states that tenant activists predicted that when rent laws were "weakened" by removing all apartments with rents over $2,000 from rent regulation, harassment would increase. The writer concludes that the Times article on harassment should be required reading to prevent further weakening of the rent laws. 
 I read the same article and I conclude that all apartments should be freed from any form of rent regulation, ending an unrealistic and unfair economic system that, in addition to inducing harassment, causes wholesale decay of existing housing and discourages new housing from being built. Once rent regulation was ended, there would be no reason for owners to harass. When tenants pay market value, why would owners try to force tenants to move?
 
KENNETH MATTHEWS
Manhattan
 
The writer is lawyer specializing in real estate.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A Wave of Construction on Jersey City's Waterfront

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
WALK outside the PATH stations at Exchange Place or Newport Center here, and the Hudson River waterfront is much different than it was just two years ago.
Tracks for the first half of the 20-mile riverfront light-rail system have been laid from Bayonne to the area, and trains are expected to start rolling next month. At the water's edge there also are two hotels, hundreds of new apartments and six office towers with 2.6 million square feet of space recently completed or under way. 
 Most of the office space has been built at the huge Newport Center complex at the northern end of the Jersey City waterfront and at Colgate Center, the site of Colgate-Palmolive's former toothpaste factory about a mile south of Newport Center. And most of it has been leased by Manhattan-based companies, including Merrill Lynch, which is expanding by 300,000 square feet. All of this activity reflects the fact that Jersey City's riverfront has become a viable corporate address.
The activity shows no signs of abating, with construction expected to start this year on two more buildings, with nearly two million more square feet. A third building, with 1.3 million square feet, is to be started by Goldman, Sachs, the investment bank, which owns the site.
Those buildings would bring the total of office space -- built, under way or about to be built -- to 4.6 million square feet, said Robert P. Antonicello, the president of the ACI Real Estate Group in Jersey City. When added to the existing 7.5 million square feet, the Jersey City office market mushrooms to 12.1 million square feet, surpassing Newark as a Class A market, he said.
"Before, companies had to take a leap of faith to move here," Mr. Antonicello said. "Now, with the infrastructure and critical mass here, it's a no-brainer."
What is also spurring construction is the tight office market in New York, said Charles R. Borrok, a vice chairman in the Manhattan office of Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage company that is the leasing agent for Newport Center. "In the last three months as Manhattan's rents have increased and space there has been absorbed, Jersey City has flourished," Mr. Borrok said. Today's riverfront, he added, is not just attractive for financial-services companies or back-office operations but to a mix of businesses, including media and Internet companies, some of which are moving their headquarters here.
As proof he pointed to Lord, Abbett & Company, an investment firm that relocated its operations from the General Motors Building in Manhattan, and the Insurance Services Office, an information clearinghouse, which is moving its headquarters from 7 World Trade Center.
The activity may spill into nearby Hoboken. Construction of a 550,000-square-foot building on Hoboken's southern waterfront may start this year if a lease being negotiated with John Wiley & Sons, the publisher, is completed. Wiley is looking for 300,000 square feet for its headquarters, now in Manhattan. The Wiley building would be one of a pair of similar-size buildings that SJP Properties of Parsippany could build next to the landmark Hoboken Terminal.
"The Hoboken building is a forerunner, but we have not yet come to agreement with government agencies over the tax incentives," said Susan Spilka, a Wiley spokeswoman.
At the end of 1999, the Hudson County waterfront had a vacancy rate for prime space, most of it in Jersey City, of 2.5 percent, down from 3.9 percent the year before, making it among the tightest markets in North Jersey's 11 counties, Cushman & Wakefield reported. It is also one of the most expensive in New Jersey. The average annual asking rents rose to $34.41 a square foot for prime space last year, from $32.97 in 1998. The average for the 11 North Jersey counties was $28.50 in 1999. Still, the waterfront figure of $34.41 is nearly half the cost of new space in Manhattan, Mr. Borrok said. When other benefits are factored in -- lower rates for electricity, real estate taxes and operating costs -- the price is reduced another $10 to $15 a square foot, he said.
THOSE factors are giving developers confidence to continue to build. "The waterfront is in a period of hyperactivity," said Richard S. LeFrak, the president of the Lefrak Organization in Rego Park, Queens, the developer of Newport Center, where it is completing its second new office building in two years. "We have the right product at the right price," Mr. LeFrak said, adding, in a reference to his father, Samuel J. Lefrak, "and an 82-year-old chairman who is screaming he wants to see the project get done and is willing to invest his resources to see that happen."
Last week, the company announced it would start construction next month on a third speculative office tower. The strategy? "Build it, and they will come," Richard LeFrak said.
With 800,000 square feet, this third new building will be similar in size to the one now under way. Nearly 500,000 square feet of that building is leased to three tenants: the Insurance Services Office leased 390,419 square feet, and U.S. Trust and Automated Securities Clearance, 40,000 square feet each. Leases are are being negotiated for the rest of the space, Mr. LeFrak said. The first building, with 567,318 square feet, is fully leased. Rents for the new building will range from $32 to $33 a square foot.
The Lefrak Organization is also planning a full-service hotel with about 450 rooms to complement the 189-room Courtyard by Marriott Hotel that will open in July. "The center is beginning to feed on itself," Mr. LeFrak said.
The arrival of Goldman, Sachs, many real estate brokers and developers said, is a big boost for Jersey City. Last month, the company bought four parcels at the 20-acre Colgate Center site, where it intends to build three buildings, including a training center, on three of the sites. The total square footage will be about three million. Construction on the first building, with 1.3 million square feet, is to begin this year; this building will house several Goldman, Sachs operations, including its asset management group.
Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus is under contract to buy the fourth Goldman, Sachs parcel, at 77 Hudson Street, in Colgate Center. Zoning would permit a building as large as 1.1 million square feet. The site is near two other Hartz buildings, one complete and one under construction.
"We believe there is still time left in this real estate cycle to develop," said Emanuel Stern, the president of Hartz.
His company's first building, at 90 Hudson, with 422,000 square feet, is fully leased, and its tenants include Lord, Abbett & Company. The second building, at 70 Hudson, with 412,000 square feet, is under way. Annual rents are expected to be about $35 a square foot.
The Datek Online Holdings Corporation, with offices in Edison and Manhattan, is looking at the possibility of leasing all of 70 Hudson for its growing stock-brokerage business. "We're definitely looking at that and other buildings," said Michael Dunn, a spokesman, "and hope to make a decision fairly soon."
Mr. Stern said only that "there was a lot activity on the building" and that he was now focusing on 77 Hudson. He said he hopes construction there will start by year's end.
"There's no overbuilding, rents are going up, and Wall Street is still growing," he said.
Merrill Lynch also is expanding at Colgate Center. The company, which occupies 600,000 square feet at 101 Hudson Street, has leased an entire 300,000-square-foot building at 95 Greene Street. It will be used for the "expansion of similar technical and operational groups," said Michael R. Cowan, the head of corporate real estate at Merrill Lynch, and 1,400 workers will occupy the space later this year. The former factory is being renovated by SJP Properties.
Late last year, Merrill Lynch also bought a Colgate Center parcel, zoned for a building as large as 1.2 million square feet. "We're growing our support functions in Jersey City so our front office can expand in Manhattan," Mr. Cowan said. The space that could be built at Colgate "gives us the flexibility we want to continue to grow," he said, noting that eventually, there could be 7,000 employees in Jersey City.
The last parcel at Colgate Center was acquired by Essex Waterfront, a Manhattan partnership formed by Leonard Boxer, a Manhattan real estate lawyer; Lester Fisher, a developer in Purchase, N.Y.; and the Ramius Capital Group, an investment banking group in Manhattan. which plans to build 650 apartments, completing the plan drawn up by Colgate-Palmolive a decade ago. Now, the company is hoping to move the landmark 55-foot octagonal Colgate Clock to a new waterfront location, Robert Murray, a spokesman said.
At the 1.9-million-square-foot Harborside complex, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, already a tenant, has sublet an additional 45,000 square feet and is said by industry professionals to be interested in expanding its space there gradually by up to 1 million square feet. While the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation of Cranford, which owns Harborside, confirmed the sublet, it declined to comment about any further expansion plans. Dean Witter declined to comment on the sublet or an expansion.
Mack-Cali said it would finish the 185,000-square-foot building it is constructing at the site for T. D. WaterHouse, in two months. By this summer the company also will start construction on a 350-room Hyatt Hotel on a pier jutting into the river.

HEADLINE: LAW AND ORDER;
The Aid Is All Spent, But the Police Stay

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Six years ago, the federal government held out a tantalizing offer: Money for cities and towns to hire police officers, paying up to 75 percent of the salaries and benefits for up to three years. The catch: The officers had to be additions and not replacements, and the municipalities had to agree to keep the officers after the aid had lapsed.
The money to pay for the new officers is about to end -- or has, in some circumstances -- and municipalities that over time had wrung almost $150 million to hire the 1,950 officers must now begin to weigh the cost of keeping them on the payroll. 
 Whether it is Spring Lake, where only a single additional officer was hired, or Newark, where 220 were added to the force, it is a time of hard choices and fiscal legerdemain. For still others, it means using surpluses from growing ratables with little or no effect on individual tax bills.
Interviews with officials in several muncipalities found them generally pleased with what the new officers have enabled them to do -- though somewhat perplexed as they seek ways to keep the officers.
The program introduced by President Clinton in 1994 has proven so popular that there are efforts in Congress to extend it for another five years, said David Buchanan, a spokesman for the Justice Department's Office of Community Oriented Policing Services, which oversees the program.
Mr. Buchanan said in a telephone interview that most municipalities saw the program as a long-term solution rather than a quick fix. Consequently, most had found ways to assume the full cost of the new officers as the financing ended in December -- or in next year's budgets in cases where the assistance is to end in October.
For Newark, keeping the new officers has accounted for the bulk of a 3 percent tax increase in the latest budget proposed by Mayor Sharpe James. But Mayor James said in an interview that he had no regrets. The new officers -- financed with $16.5 million in federal funds spread over a six-year period -- have largely contributed to the decline in the number of auto thefts in a city that once had the dubious honor of leading all municipalities in that category.
In addition, the mayor said the new officers have played a role in the 45 percent decline in overall crime over the last five years. "It was not even a choice considering not continuing them," said Mayor James, noting the increased nightlife in the city since the opening of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and plans for a new arena. "More police means a reduction in crime as well as an attack on the myth that Newark can't be a safe."
In Northvale, in Bergen County, where the program has paid for three new officers, Mayor John Rooney can even name them. The township of 4,600 people now has a force of 13 officers as a result of the $225,000 in federal assistance.
The addition of the new officers came at a time when older officers were retiring and the department's average salaries were beginning to decline, said Chief Edward Gianotti. In addition, the new officers contributed to a drop in overtime that was bloating the budget. The combination of those two factors, Mayor Rooney said, allowed the township to absorb the new officers.
"It was a great program and it came at the right time for us because we needed new blood but were holding off on hiring anyone," he said. "With the higher-salaried guys aging out, we can afford to keep the new officers at lower salaries without raising taxes."
In Atlantic City, which received $3 million over six years to hire 40 officers, Andrew Mair, the city's business administrator, said that the government had been aggressive in seeking an array of grants to keep the officers at a time when local funds were not readily available.
Mr. Mair said it was like "managing a stock portfolio," moving officers from one grant program to another. With the money coming in and older officers in higher pay grades retiring, he said the department had been able to maintain the level of the police force at 450 officers.
Nor is he concerned about the day the grants run out. "We don't have a static ratable base, but massive planned development will mean billions in ratables by the time the grants all expire," he said.
Growth is at once the rationale for keeping new police hires and the means for paying for them in South Brunswick, said Mayor Deborah Johnson.
"Because of industrial growth, we have a surplus and we were going to need additional police any way to cope with the growth," Mayor Johnson said, explaining the town's initial decision to seek $375,000 in federal funds for five new officers. "So from the beginning we had the mind-set that we were going to pay for this."
But that has still meant some scrimping for the 70-member force, she said. For example, the department brass would like to have had five new police cars next year -- but they decided to get by with two of them a little longer and just buy three.
For some municipalities, the painful reminder of student violence in such instances the shootings in Littleton, Colo., last year has kept up the pressure for an increased police presence in the schools.
In the fiscally distressed city of Camden, where state officials now supervise the budget, October is the cutoff date for continued federal contributions, which totaled $4.2 million for the hiring of 23 officers. It is also working with funds from another grant, which will not run out until 2002.
Richard Wright, the finance administrator in Camden, noted that even though Camden had been operating with a "structural deficit" as a result of a declining tax base and levels of state aid that had not kept up with inflation, local and state officials sought grants without giving much thought about how to continue the financing.
This year -- for the first time in five years, Mr. Wright said -- the state aid received by the city would be indexed for inflation, a move that was expected to provide an additional $700,000. Still, he said, the cost of paying for the additional officers after the federal funds this year is $750,000.
"The police department has submitted a retention plan for these officers, and so we will no choice but to increase our budget, and we don't know what they will mean for other services," he said.
Moreover, Mr. Wright said that officials were wary of seeking future federal assistance that would eventually require them to pick up the tab. For now, the city is holding off on seeking federal funds to hire officers to patrol the schools until the board of education agrees to help with the cost.
In Spring Lake, an upscale shore community in Monmouth County, the federal program allowed the town to hire one officer and bring the force serving its 4,000 people to 14, said Mayor Thomas J. Byrne III.
Mayor Byrne said that since the town hired only one officer there would be no problem absorbing that salary.
"There may be a tax increase, we don't know yet," he said. "But if there is one, it won't be because of the additional police salary but because of the generally higher costs of everything."
In Paterson, Mayor Martin Barnes, a Republican, was less sanguine, noting that federal help in paying the salaries for about 20 of the 60 officers hired under the program had ended and that the city faced a "major burden" in assimilating them.
Mayor Barnes said the Clinton administration sold the program with much fanfare and made it irresistible in communities where residents were clamoring for more police without understanding that the short-lived benefit came with a price tag.
"We knew it was a false sense of security, but at the same time we were constrained by local pressures to take the grants," said Mayor Barnes, noting that a tax increase to meet the city's $140 million budget might be necessary. "We're just going to have to come up with the bucks for this first group, but we are in trouble in 2002 when the federal assistance on that second, larger group ends."

HEADLINE: OPERA;
Presenting the Grandeur That Colors Verdi's Aida

BYLINE: By JILLIAN HORNBECK AMBROZ 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
INTERNATIONAL divas and their blue-jeaned male counterparts march around the small wooden dance floor of the Crystal Room of the Robert Treat Hotel here. Bewitching, powerfully performed melodies swirl around upturned red velvet banquet chairs, substituting for grand-scale props. An imposing tub of cough drops and a water cooler provide the singers' oasis between scenes.
It is the second day of rehearsals for the New Jersey State Opera's production of "Aida," Giuseppe Verdi's 1871 classic. The artistic director, Alfredo Silipigni, has assembled a diverse cast of far-reaching talent in his effort to bring "world-class opera to the citizens of New Jersey." His production will be presented this week on the stage of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center for three performances, including a one-act performance for students. All performances will include English supertitles. 
 "Aida" is the tragic love story of an enslaved Ethiopian princess in love with an Egyptian warrior, Radames, who conquers her homeland, and captures her father, the King of Ethiopia. Radames is also the object of affection and intended spouse of Amneris, an Egyptian princess. Radames chooses Aida, betrays his country in the process, and is condemned to be buried alive. In a heart-wrenching finale, Aida elects to die by his side in classic tragedy fashion.
Arguably the world's most performed opera, "Aida" caters to a wide audience. Verdi's score is enchanting and grand, full of rich arias and well-known marches. Book ended by two glorious arias, "Celeste Aida," sung by Radames in the first scene of the opera, and "O terra, addio," the final duet by Aida and Radames as they are entombed in the last scene, the captivating melodies have ageless appeal.
In the title role, Daniela Longhi, an Italian lyric soprano whose acting style may be a bit subtle for an emotional role, possesses an impressive vocal high range shadowed with warm, dark hues. The Bolshoi Opera's prima donna, Makvala Kasrashvili, gives a powerful performance as Amneris, perhaps at times even overshadowing the lead. Interestingly, Verdi considered calling his opera "Amneris," as the rival mezzo-soprano plays such a strong role. Given Ms. Kasrashvili's considerable talent, one may wish Verdi had followed through with that idea.
Constantin Nica, a Romanian tenor, performs Radames, projecting an engaging stage presence and displaying a comfortable relationship with the high notes in his demanding role. George Fortune, a baritone who has performed with Placido Domingo and Luciano Pavarotti, is Amonasro, the King of Ethiopia. Luiz-Ottavia Faria, winner of the New Jersey State Opera competition, sings the role of the King of Egypt, with a rich and soulful bass. Stefan Szkafarowsky, a bass renowned for his technical ability, performs the role of the high priest Ramfis. And the tenor Gabriel Barrueco, a native of Cuba, performs the role of the messenger.
The State Opera's production also offers 28 West Orange High School students the opportunity to sing in the 70-member chorus. Their teacher, Cynthia Rowberg Pearson, a longtime student of opera, was selected to perform the role of the High Priestess. Backing this immense vocal ensemble is an 80-piece orchestra, including six Egyptian trumpets, conducted by Mr. Silipigni. Adding to the grandeur, eight ballerinas from the New Jersey Ballet, perform with choreography by George Tomal.
"Other than the Wagner Ring, few operas are as costly to produce as 'Aida,' " said Scott Holderer, production manager for the New Jersey State Opera. "This is by far the most expensive production this year for us." he added, "Aida," costing hundreds of thousands of dollars, accounts for nearly 40 percent of the State Opera's annual budget, he added.
Over the years, opera buffs have come to expect all sorts of pageantry and gimmicks from "Aida," from explosions to onstage livestock. Mr. Silipigni intends to deliver a production that is pure and traditional, closely following Verdi's original score and stage directions. That means no elephants or horses. However, compared with Verdi's gaslit performances, Mr. Silipigni and the renowned former Metropolitan Opera stage director Nathaniel Merrill are bending the rules a bit to incorporate some modern effects.
"A large portion of our audience will experience their first standard repertoire with us and we want it to be world class," said Mr. Silipigni, who has been with the State Opera since its inception. "The emphasis will be on the music, the cast, the chorus and the ballet."
Though limiting for a full-scale production, the small stage of NJPAC will be transformed into an Egyptian setting, complete with temples, thrones and a flying statue of Isis. The colors of the stage, earth tones with copper and gold highlights, match the elaborate, bejeweled costumes, designed by the Emmy Award winner Peter Hall.
On the eve of another opera mutation, this time perpetrated by Disney and Elton John for Broadway, the New Jersey State Opera offers a traditional, more economical alternative with its newest production.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA -- UPDATE;
Builder Fights to Finish High-Rise the City Says Never Began

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
The city has rejected the appeal of a developer who wants to build a 20-story high-rise on West 18th Street, where zoning rules were changed last year before the building's foundation was completed. A six-story building would be allowed. But the developer, Martin Brody, vows to fight on.
Mr. Brody obtained a building permit last summer for an apartment tower at 224 West 18th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. On Sept. 9, new zoning rules took effect restricting development in the area to smaller buildings. 
 Soon after, the city rescinded Mr. Brody's permit. He contended that he should be permitted to finish the building because its foundation had been largely completed before the zoning changes took effect.
But in a Feb. 29 ruling, the Board of Standards and Appeals said it found "no evidence that any foundation work had commenced."
Mr. Brody, the board said, "entered into this development project aware of impending zoning amendments," and "took a calculated gamble" by trying to "race the clock."
"Neither the mere issuance of permits, nor the developer's substantial expenditures and physical improvements are enough, standing alone, to confer a vested right to the project," the board said.
Mr. Brody's lawyer, Adam Roth- krug, said he would appeal the decision in court and would seek a zoning variance from the board.
"My client has spent over $1 million based on the zoning that was in effect when he began," Mr. Rothkrug said. "The building that would be permitted now is not economically feasible. He won't build that."
 DAVID KIRBY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER MANHATTAN;
Filling a Wire-Hanger Void, Dry Cleaner Expands Kingdom

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
In most parts of Manhattan, dry cleaners are as common as brush on a prairie. But in the northern reaches of the borough, from Harlem to Inwood, residents often voice the same lament: "Where, oh where, can I get my shirts pressed?"
It may seem like a superficial complaint in neighborhoods with many other social ills. But people spearheading the economic development of Upper Manhattan say the dearth of dry cleaners can affect whether wealthier New Yorkers are willing to live and invest in the area. 
 Luckily, Jose O. Aguiar Jr. was trained all his life to become uptown's Kleener King. When his parents, Jose and Carmen, who came from Puerto Rico, married, they used a small inheritance of hers to open a dry-cleaning shop on Intervale Avenue in the Bronx. By the time their son was an adult, they had five stores, all with different names. Jose Aguiar took over the business when his father died 17 years ago, then developed the Kleener King brand and logo, using Blockbuster Video as his model. Eventually, he opened 19 stores under that name.
Last year, Mr. Aguiar received a $6.1 million loan from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, the Bronx Overall Development Corporation, the Empire State Development Corporation and other investors to continue his expansion. He plans to open 10 stores in Upper Manhattan and the Bronx in the next two years, creating 200 new jobs.
Mr. Aguiar opened the first of the 10 at 215 Dyckman Street, at Broadway in Inwood. On the bustling stretch of Dyckman between Broadway and Post Avenue there are discount stores, check-cashing places and many other businesses, but the Kleener King, painted in the chain's distinctive royal blue and gold, is the first dry cleaner.
"You see dry cleaners on every block of Manhattan, because it's all white collar," Mr. Aguiar said. "I'm in blue-collar areas. That means we have to take a different approach to dry cleaning."
To accommodate lower-income customers, Mr. Aguiar said, he has to charge less: $3.50 on average for a pair of pants. Since his stores are in neighborhoods where rents are cheaper, he saves some money on overhead, but the big savings come from centralizing operations. Two months ago, Kleener King opened a dry-cleaning plant in Bathgate Industrial Park in the Bronx, which he hopes will ultimately serve about 50 stores.
"When I started getting a real feel for the business in 1986, I looked at Blockbuster and McDonald's and I couldn't even see myself in that space mentally," he said, seated in a royal blue chair in his new store. "As I sit here today, I can see it." NINA SIEGAL
