HEADLINE: My Dress Is Older Than Yours Is

BYLINE: By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
On a sale rack at Jeffrey on West 14th Street one day shortly after Christmas, there hung a cap-sleeve minidress cut in the same "Jetsons go to Coconut Grove" manner that led Courreges, the Parisian house that made it, to prominence three decades ago. Originally $1,500, it was marked down to $800.
That same afternoon at Resurrection, a Mott Street shop selling vintage apparel -- the clothing formerly known as used -- a similar version of that orange Courreges dress, actually made and worn in the 1960's, was also for sale. The vintage model was $1,200. 
 A visit to Resurrection suggests that clothing is not in fact the world's most bubble-headed investment. Next to the Courreges was a navy A-line Pierre Cardin minidress from the same period with white vinyl trim and a circle in the center -- the kind of dress that would make the wearer look like a 7-year-old who has been reading Buckminster Fuller. Anyone hoping to leave the store with it would have to part with $1,500.
In the past 20 years, the vintage-clothing market has undergone marked changes, catering of late to a fashion elite that is hungry to signal that it has acquired something that other people haven't and can't. Through the 1980's, the market was fueled by sales of 50's bowling shirts, 40's floral housewife dresses and jackets once worn by gas-station attendants -- working-class clothes from which college students could forge ironic wardrobes for very little money. But with the growth of stores like the Gap and Old Navy in the 90's, and the widespread availability of inexpensive khakis, pedal pushers and shift dresses that are inspired by old ones (the Gap's current line is called "1968"), many purveyors of vintage clothes had to rethink their strategy. They began offering rarefied and more costly merchandise.
Alice Lindholm has sold old clothes for 15 years; when she started her business, Right to the Moon Alice, she conducted most of it directly on college campuses, traveling from Cornell to Vassar to Oberlin with her stock. With the boom in tasteful, lower-priced clothing, "we had to reinvent ourselves," Ms. Lindholm said. Today, she and her husband, Ron Lindholm, have Chanel sweaters and Schiaparelli hats moving in and out of an inventory they keep in Cooks Falls, N.Y. The Lindholms sell at vintage shows like the one to be held at Pier 88 over the next two weekends.
What the term "vintage" means in reference to clothes is, as one might expect, the subject of some debate. To Liz Goldwyn, 23, a filmmaker and avid collector-wearer, with 150 Yves Saint Laurent pieces, most of them older than she is, vintage is defined as anything more than 10 years old. To Mark Walsh, a private dealer who traffics in clothes worth thousands of dollars from the early 1900's through the 30's, vintage clothes are those meant for museums. ("I'm not crazy about the wearing clientele," he said.) Anything from the 70's and 80's he dismisses as "thrift shop."
At the moment, though, among the broad range of people who consider themselves fashionable, vintage implies clothes made by well-known designers from the mid-20th century onward, mostly the 60's and 70's -- the period that continues to maintain a bottomless fascination for popular culture.
Ina Davidson, who runs Buy Gone Days, based in Montgomery, N.Y., has been a vintage-clothing dealer for 20 years, selling garments to designers who use them for inspiration and to people who wear them to dinner. Recently, she said, she has become "compulsive" about acquiring high-profile clothes from the Lyndon Johnson years through the Gerald Ford years. "Either you have designer clothes from the 60's and 70's or you're not going to make money," Ms. Davidson said. Six months ago, she came upon 10 Rudi Gernreich dresses from this period and has sold 9 of them, one for $1,200.
Resurrection focuses exclusively on clothes from the 60's and 70's. Katy Rodriguez, 30, the store's owner, a former student of fine-art photography, opened her first store on East Seventh Street in 1996. Two years ago she added the Mott Street shop, and in May she will open a third Resurrection in Los Angeles. During her four years in business, Ms. Rodriguez said, customers have become increasingly eager to delve into high-end vintage. The same has been true at What Comes Around Goes Around, a vintage shop on West Broadway, where the Puccis and Halstons are chained up.
In the beginning, Ms. Rodriguez said, "we'd sell a Pucci dress for $250 and we'd have to explain to the customer why it was $250." Today, the customer knows something about a Pucci dress and is willing to pay the $500 or more it now easily costs.
In fact, expensive old clothes have been so sufficiently scrubbed of whatever negative stigma they once had that Barneys New York is opening a vintage boutique on April 1 in its Madison Avenue store. Across the street at DKNY, vintage pieces have been selling as part of the mix since the store's opening in August, just as they have at the Polo Sport store on West Broadway since it opened in July.
The Barneys shop, on the third floor, will be run in conjunction with Cameron Silver, the owner of Decades, a Los Angeles vintage store that, like Resurrection, specializes in clothes from the era of Gucci's original heyday.
Among the items at Barneys are some chain-mesh halter tops from Whiting & Davis and two 60's python jackets -- one from Lanvin, the other Bill Blass -- that Mr. Silver and Julie Gilhart, vice president for fashion merchandising at Barneys, found in January at the Metropolitan Vintage Fashion and Antique Textile Show, which is held three times a year and attracted a record 65 dealers this winter. The python jackets cost more than $2,000 each, and they are likely to cost more than twice that when they reach the store.
In the era of the unstoppable economy, however, with growing numbers of people actually able to part with the thousands of dollars a few Jil Sander sweaters could cost, the appeal of buying vintage clothes at an elevated level is the comfort of knowing you won't be an exact replica of someone else.
In 1998, Kim Kassel, a 30-ish Upper East Side resident who attends many charity benefits with her husband and who now works in public relations at Jeffrey, wore a Dolce & Gabbana to the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute gala, only to find that someone else was wearing it, too. So in December 1999, Ms. Kassel attended the gala in a beaded blush-colored Norman Norell gown she bought from Rita Watnick, owner of Lily in Los Angeles, perhaps the country's most exclusive vintage boutique.
"There was a fur-trimmed Oscar dress," Ms. Kassel said of a new Oscar de la Renta style she spotted at the Met party. "Three people had it. It's a $9,000 dress."
Ms. Kassel could not abide vintage clothes a few years ago, she said, because "old had a negative connotation for me." But she said her introduction to Ms. Watnick's pristine collection, as well as the heightened exposure vintage clothes received during the tenure of the socialite Tiffany Dubin as head of the fashion department at Sotheby's, helped her change her mind.
Another woman wearing vintage at the Met party in December was Laura Steinberg Tisch, who had on her mother's Warhol-inspired Emeric Partos fur jacket from the 60's.
Another important reason for the flowering of interest in old clothes among people accustomed to buying costly new ones is that contemporary fashion has gone beyond simply invoking the past, the period of the 60's and 70's especially, to photocopying it. Prada's spring 2000 collection is a replay of Yves Saint Laurent's wardrobe for the 1967 film "Belle de Jour," as so many fashion editors have pointed out. This, in turn, has sparked the market for vintage Saint Laurent pieces from the era. "I could go out and spend $500 on a Prada shirt," Ms. Goldwyn said, "or I could buy what it was copied from and have something that no one else has."
As the crowds funneled out of Marc Jacobs's very-Julie-Christie-in-"Darling" fall show in New York last month, the expression one kept hearing people use to describe it was "vintage-y." In London the following week, a young designer named Russell Sage, who recycles vintage fabrics, formulated the most aggressively postmodern comment on the already postmodern notion of mining the past by sending an old John Galliano jacket down the runway with the Sotheby's price tag still hanging on it.
Ronnie Cooke Newhouse, a former creative director at Barneys and Calvin Klein and a vintage shopper, said she felt that vintage dealers had become what stylists were in the 80's; that is, crucial influences on the designer's creative process.
That fashion has drawn so heavily from the 60's and 70's and that the diligently stylish now hanker for the actual sources of inspiration, rather than their more commonplace but not very different-looking byproducts, suggests that consumers of fashion will go only so far in the name of self-expression. Well-heeled shoppers, the sort who turn up at Barneys, might crave things they feel are unique, but ultimately they don't want to look radically different from their tribe.
That is something Mr. Silver, the Decades owner, seemed to understand well as he tried to stock the Barneys boutique with a spree at the Metropolitan Vintage Show in January. Python coats called to mind any number of recent designer collections, so he bought them. Bell-sleeve fur jackets with oversize buttons did not, and he avoided them. A Pierre Cardin shoulder bag with an enormous "C" on the front spoke to the current logo-obsessed moment. But it will never make it to Barneys. Donna Karan, one of the designers scouting for inspiration at the Metropolitan Show, bought it from Mr. Silver just after he returned to Los Angeles.
"I love Adrian suits," Mr. Silver said later, referring to an American designer of the 40's. "But if you wear one you're going to look like Joan Crawford."
Often, what dealers fail to sell tells as interesting a story as what they do sell. A few months ago, Ms. Lindholm, the dealer based in Cooks Falls, was offering a Chinese embroidered coat from the turn of the century in fine condition. Given that clothes that are 100 years old are not as easy to find as 25-year-old clothes, logic suggests that it might have been a hot property. No one was interested. When Ms. Lindholm posted a 17-year-old Betsey Johnson dress on eBay recently, she was shocked to see it sell instantly for $306. Of course, as anyone who followed the fall collections last month knows, the 80's are back.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
And the Band Played On

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL; Alan Cowell is the London-based financial correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:
REMEMBER L.T.C.M.?
In September 1998, Long-Term Capital Management, the most notorious hedge fund of the late 20th century, was saved from the brink of collapse by a consortium of American, Swiss, German and British banks under the watchful eye of the Federal Reserve. Its capital is now reported to have fallen to less than $800 million. Its outstanding positions in the highly leveraged and often arcane derivatives markets stood at some $1.25 trillion. Its losses totaled $4.6 billion. The bailout cost $3.6 billion. 
 At the time -- hard on the heels of Russia's default -- it was widely thought that the teetering fortunes of this hedge fund, with its miraculous blend of the best minds of an academic generation and the smartest of Wall Street traders, threatened to pull down the global financial system with it.
In "Inventing Money" (John Wiley & Sons, $29.95), Nicholas Dunbar, a British financial journalist, tries to reconstruct what happened. But in recalling the panic and hype of the debacle, it seems to illuminate another lesson altogether.
The dogs have barked, as it were, but the caravan has moved on. The public outcry in Congress and elsewhere over the idea of a handful of multimillionaires being rescued from their own folly has faded. Thanks largely to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, rapid-fire cuts in interest rates immediately after the bailout restored market confidence, and investors have since turned their attention to the hoped-for riches of the stock market and the New Economy.
If the conclusion to be drawn from the affair is that no money-making system, however brilliantly conceived, is immune to the unpredictability of the world beyond the trading floor, then the markets' subsequent behavior suggests that few people have taken it to heart. Greed, in other words, has no memory.
Of course, the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital was all the more riveting to outsiders for the size of the stakes, magnified by the huge amount of leverage -- borrowed money -- that the fund was using. And the reputations of the principal players -- the economists Robert C. Merton and Myron S. Scholes, whose work on options pricing won the Nobel in economics in 1997, along with the founder, John W. Meriwether, a former Salomon Brothers bond-trading wizard -- imparted a celebrity glamor to the fall. These were no faceless backroom characters, but the very icons of the market-driven 1990's, the magicians who had fused rocket science and the trading floor.
As the supposed masters of the universe stumble, brought low not so much by their own theories as by global events that no theory could foresee, the book reveals a certain Schadenfreude. Indeed, for the nonspecialist, Mr. Dunbar's study is at its best when it highlights ways that even the mightiest of financial institutions were blinded by a desire to clamber aboard a money-making machine returning more than 40 percent a year.
Consider Mathis Cabiallavetta, then the chairman of UBS, Switzerland's biggest bank. "For him, the pinnacle of Wall Street mystique was John Meriwether," Mr. Dunbar writes. That fascination was to cost UBS some $685 million, and Mr. Cabiallavetta his job.
Mr. Cabiallavetta's fate became a public event. But problematically for Mr. Dunbar, the principal figures at Long-Term Capital have largely avoided any public discussion of their role, and there is no sense in the book that the author was able to draw directly on in-depth interviews with them relating to events that brought the fund to its knees.
Consequently, much of the first two-thirds of "Inventing Money" is taken up with relating the history of markets, options and arbitrage, dating (a bit improbably) to the Code of Hammurabi and sweeping in, among other things, the study of physics in 19th century France and the growing alliance between Wall Street and American universities. It adds up to a substantial primer on the history of financial theory, not least because of Mr. Dunbar's knack for colorful parallels that illuminate his arguments.
AT the beginning, he quotes from Swift's "Gulliver's Travels," describing Laputa, "an island in the air, inhabited by men, who were able (as it should seem) to raise or sink, or put it into a progressive motion, as they pleased."
In a way, there is no further need for explanation, for that is exactly how Long-Term Capital was depicted by many outsiders at the time of its fall. Insiders, too: the partners who ran it and the supposedly hard-nosed bankers who backed it looked at the complex mathematical formulas for derivatives trading and thought they saw the alchemist's stone. And no wonder, since through the mid-1990's the fund almost effortlessly made its exclusive, already rich clientele even richer.
Why, then, did it unravel? Unlike his subject, which turned out to be concentrating risk instead of diffusing it, Mr. Dunbar hedges. One view, he says, is the "perfect storm" theory put out by the firm's partners, namely that a freak event wrecked "the world's most advanced trading vehicle."
The other is the "human folly" theory: "While L.T.C.M.'s own partners were reckless or misguided, the real reason L.T.C.M. became so big and dangerous was because the people running the investment banks were greedy and ignored the risks."
The truth is a mixture of the two theories, Mr. Dunbar writes. What is clear, he says, is that as the liquidity of the markets dried up in the late summer of 1998 after the Russian default, "everyone was trying to shut down or at least reduce the speed of the complicated money machines which had been exploiting discrepancies between bond, swap and options markets around the world."
But those same machines, Mr. Dunbar says, had become so big and were running so fast "that the sheer act of trying to shut them down made them blow up."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Porsche StockIs a Play On Dot-Com Dreams

BYLINE: By JOANNE LEGOMSKY 

 BODY:
AN investor looking for an option on the bull market could have done worse than to buy the shares of Porsche A.G., the German automaker whose high-performance sports cars have become chariots of choice for dot-com millionaires.
Porsche's preference shares -- nonvoting ordinary shares -- have had a nice ride on the Frankfurt stock exchange, climbing 44.4 percent, annualized, for the three years through March 3, versus 14.1 percent for Germany's CDAX auto index. The voting shares are controlled by the Porsche and Piech families, including Ferdinand Piech, chairman of Volkswagen and a nephew of the founder, Ferdinand Porsche. 
 "I call this my dot-com play," said Glen Hilton, an auto analyst with Montgomery Asset Management.
Much of the power behind that rubber-burning run-up belongs to the Boxster roadster, introduced in late 1996. At $40,000, it was, for Porsche, an affordable sports car. The Boxster opened the Porsche market to younger, less affluent buyers -- without cannibalizing sales of the $65,000-plus Porsche 911.
In the fiscal year ended July 31, 1997, encompassing most of the first model year that the Boxster was available, overall Porsche unit sales climbed 68 percent, to 32,383. Fully 15,786 of those were Boxsters. Unit sales rose to 43,982 in fiscal 1999.
Because of the increase in sales, pretax margins doubled last year, to 11.3 percent of sales, among the highest of any automaker.
And some experts say the American rollout last November of the premium-priced Boxster S, combined with the planned introduction in May of a premium 911 Turbo, will keep margins growing. The extra money that buyers pay for these racier models -- $8,000 to $15,000 for the Boxster S, and up to $50,000 for the 911 Turbo -- "flows straight to the bottom line," Mr. Hilton said, because incremental production costs are modest. He says Porsche shares, now at 2750 euros, could hit 4,000 euros within a year.
Dominic Baker, a manager of the Munder Framlington International Growth fund, which holds the stock, said he expects earnings to grow at least 25 percent a year, on average, over the next few years. Porsche is a model of German efficiency, Mr. Baker said. He calculates, for example, that some 30 to 35 percent of the components in the Boxster and the 911 overlap.
Porsche enjoys other advantages, analysts say. Its contract engineering business, accounting for about 14 percent of sales, helps Porsche maintain the highly paid engineering team it otherwise could not afford. "The combination of the high-performance car business and engineering services is one of Porsche's strategic strengths," said Christian Breit sprecher, an analyst at Deutsche Bank.
And the strong dollar and buoyant American economy bode well, analysts say, because North America is Porsche's biggest market.
Moreover, although Porsche purists wince at the prospect, a sport utility vehicle planned for 2002 could add a third strong model to the lineup.
In the interim, some analysts say the 1.1 billion marks budgeted for development of the S.U.V. may slow earnings momentum. And some money managers and analysts say they are inclined to balk at that steep share price. Sabine Blumel, an analyst at Banca IMI in London, rates the stock a hold, saying that at 15 times her earnings estimate of 184.4 euros for next year, Porsche trades at a 65 percent premium to peer companies.
But Mr. Breitsprecher thinks the valuation is justified, saying Porsche's move to outsource some production in 1996 cut its capital requirements.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1145 words

HEADLINE: Credit Cards at 50: The Problems of Ubiquity

BYLINE: By the Associated Press 

 BODY:
IN the 1950's, dapper men with mustaches and fedoras used them to settle their bills at Delmonico's, the "21" Club or the Copacabana. They were a novelty for the affluent and the urbane.
Today, consumers use them to buy nearly everything, from groceries to gasoline to psychic hotline calls, and not having one can be a significant handicap. But they have also been blamed for seducing millions of profligate spenders into crushing debt, and for opening a door to fraud and identity theft. 
 The credit card, an idea born 50 years ago when an absent-minded businessman dining out discovered that he had left his wallet elsewhere, now provides financial convenience for 157 million Americans, more than three-quarters of the adult population.
For Chantal de Jonge Oudraat of Washington, the cards' convenience means that when she flies on her frequent trips to Europe, she often takes less than $20 in cash. "There are two things I check before I go on a trip: my passport and plastic," she said.
Ms. de Jonge Oudraat, 43, generally carries five or six cards, about average for Americans, and uses her bank A.T.M. card to obtain local currency when she is overseas.
The first charge card is said to have appeared in February 1950. After dining at Major's Cabin Grill in Manhattan, Frank McNamara was embarrassed to discover that he had left his wallet in another suit. His wife paid the bill, but the experience left him thinking about a better solution.
At a later meal at Major's, Mr. McNamara presented a small cardboard card bearing his signature, which he called a diner's club card, and said he wanted to sign for the meal the way members at a private club do and be billed later. He was well known at Major's, and the restaurant decided to accept his idea. Encouraged, Mr. McNamara and his lawyer founded Diners Club, now owned by Citigroup.
The first card was offered to 200 people, mostly Mr. McNamara's friends and acquaintances. Fourteen Manhattan restaurants agreed to accept it. A year later, the company estimated that 42,000 Americans were carrying the card and that more than 330 businesses were accepting it. Membership cost $3 a year.
At first, all cards were charge cards, meaning that balances had to be paid in full each month. Revolving credit cards, which charge interest and allow customers to make partial payments each month, were introduced in 1951 in New York by Franklin National Bank, which eventually became European American Bank.
A half-century later, the simple charge card has a hundred variations. There are cards issued by individual retailers. There are affinity credit cards that earn frequent-flier miles or make donations to your favorite charity. There are various kinds of debit cards, like A.T.M. and check cards. There are cards with tiny ID photos or microchips imbedded for security. There are no-frills credit cards and, at the other end of the spectrum, a new super premium card from American Express with a $1,000 annual fee and all sorts of services.
Credit cards are hugely profitable for banks, in part because most interest rates on them average 18 percent, much higher than for most other consumer loans. As a result, card issuers stuff mailboxes with hundreds of millions of solicitations every year.
Today, almost as many people carry cards as have driver's licenses, and three times as many have cards as have valid passports. "Children, dogs, cats and moose are getting credit cards," the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, recently told the Senate Banking Committee.
CONSUMER GROUPS and other critics say heated competition has driven credit card companies to abusively aim marketing campaigns toward young people, especially college students.
About 70 percent of students at four-year colleges have at least one credit card, and revolving debt on those cards averages more than $2,000, according to a Georgetown University sociologist, Robert Manning, who has studied credit card debt among college students.
In the worst cases, he said, students are forced to drop out and work full time to pay off their debts. Some recent suicides by college students have been attributed to their despondency over mounting credit card debts.
There are other concerns:
* Federal regulators worry about a rise in risky lending by banks to people with poor credit histories. Subprime lending played a role in several bank failures last year, including BestBank of Boulder, Colo., which sold high-interest credit cards as part of a travel-club membership to consumers nationwide with inferior credit records. BestBank's failure drained some $232 million from the Federal Deposit Insurance fund.
* In recent months, there have been reports of large-scale breaches of credit card security on the Internet. After someone stole thousands of credit card numbers from the computers of CD Universe, an Internet music seller, in January, the industry saw what analysts called the largest mass cancellation of credit cards ever recorded.
* Visa and MasterCard, the two card networks that between them account for 75 percent of all transactions, are under legal attack on two fronts. The Justice Department has sued them, arguing that they do not really compete because both are effectively controlled by the same group of big banks; the case is due to be tried in June.
Separately, major retailers like Wal-Mart Stores are suing the two over their dominance of the debit card business, which retailers say has led to high transaction fees. Visa and MasterCard are contesting both suits, saying consumers can choose among cards from thousands of member banks competing not only against rival brands but also among themselves by offering different rates, credit limits and other features.
The credit card industry has also spent millions lobbying for new legislation to make it harder for consumers to escape payment of credit card debts through personal bankruptcy. The number of bankruptcies filed annually has been rising steadily despite the boom economy -- in part, consumer advocates say, because so much easy credit is offered to so many people by the credit card industry and others.
The stakes are high. Unpaid balances for the 80 million households with credit card accounts now average $6,000 to $7,000, according to the Consumer Federation of America. Still, about 43 percent of consumers pay off their credit card balances every month, according to industry figures.
From Frank McNamara's first office on the 24th floor of the Empire State Building, credit cards fanned out and eventually arrived in the farthest reaches of the third world and on the Internet.
Alfred Bloomingdale, who succeeded Mr. McNamara as president of Diners Club, mused in a 1959 magazine interview: "Where will it end? I don't see any limits. I think someday you're going to be able to charge anything."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3232 words

HEADLINE: On Smith Street, a Dream Made Real

BYLINE: By CHRIS ERIKSON 

 BODY:
SHORTLY after sundown on Dec. 9, a diner walked into Banania Cafe on Smith Street in Brooklyn, sat at a corner table and ordered oysters. Ten minutes later, the oysters, fried in cornmeal, arranged on a bed of celery root puree and dappled with a tomato-seed vinaigrette, arrived from the kitchen. They were placed in front of the man, Joseph Gannascoli, who ate them and pronounced them "sublime."
If it was the most mundane of transactions between eater and eatery, one played out millions of times each day. It was also a milestone for Danforth Houle, the bistro's chef and owner. 
 Mr. Gannascoli was the first customer on Banania's opening day, and in serving him, Mr. Houle inched closer to the realization of a dream he has had since his teens, to run his own restaurant.
This dream prompts hundreds of people to try their luck each year in New York City's high-stakes restaurant marketplace, braving staunch competition, Herculean labor demands and daunting odds. With the city's economy humming, more hopefuls than ever are throwing their hats into the ring. The 2000 Zagat Survey, which tracks only a small fraction of the city's restaurants, noted 274 openings in 1999, more than 5 a week. If industry averages hold true, at least two-thirds of those will close or change hands within two years.
If each new restaurant represents a considerable risk of time and capital, it is also an act of creation involving a thousand small decisions about food, decor and atmosphere.
"A restaurant is a compendium of choices that the owner has made," says Danny Meyer, owner of the top-rated Union Square Cafe and Gramercy Tavern. "If you look around a restaurant, everything represents a choice: the kind of salt shaker that's on the table, the art on the walls, the uniforms on the waiters."
This was certainly true for Mr. Houle, who by the time he served his first customer had invested countless hours doing everything from scouting a location and planning a menu to varnishing tables and choosing napkins.
The undertaking required not only slavish attention to detail, but also an inexhaustible supply of time, patience and energy. Not to mention a sense of humor and a deft hand with a screw gun.
 
Another Opening, Another Postponement
It's a brisk day in October, an odd time to be thinking of air-conditioning, but Dan Houle is taking no chances. You never know when you might hit a warm spell, he says, so he's on his cell phone, dickering over costs and schedules.
His opening, once set for Nov. 2, has been pushed back another week, and judging by the restaurant's condition, that's not a bad thing. Sawdust and wood scraps litter the floor, the windowless front of his 800-square-foot space at 241 Smith Street in Carroll Gardens is boarded up, and the kitchen is an obstacle course of unconnected appliances.
Mr. Houle has been here since January, held up for much of that time by cash flow troubles. He had spent well over a year combing Manhattan for a site suitable for the restaurant he had in mind, one combining a bistro's casual atmosphere and moderate prices with innovative cuisine.
"I'd literally crisscross the city block by block, from Columbus Avenue down to TriBeCa," recalls Mr. Houle, a squat, muscular 34-year-old, typically dressed in jeans and sneakers, with earrings and a near-shaved head. "I'd write down numbers and call them from a pay phone. If I saw a closed door, I'd knock on it. I had no shame."
He was at his wits' end when a friend suggested Smith Street, which young chefs have transformed into a thriving restaurant row in the last two years. He found a corner spot for under $3,000 a month, far less than he'd pay in Manhattan.
There was a catch. The space was a wreck. Unable to afford a general contractor, Mr. Houle, who grew up around the building trades -- his father is a mason, his stepfather a contractor -- lined up help and went to work. He hired a motley crew of various nationalities and offbeat temperaments. But they're a good bunch, he said, and "they're willing to work with me if the money is short."
Which, at the moment, it is. As he inches toward his opening, Mr. Houle's finances are stretched to the breaking point. Separated from his wife of six months, he's sleeping at a friend's apartment, running up his credit card debt and eating on a few dollars a day. Expenses pile up: a walk-in refrigerator, a handpainted sign, a $3,000 espresso machine. "This is crunch time," he says. "When the details start coming in and the money starts flying out, it adds up. It's like holding your breath and going under water."
 
Born to Work in a Kitchen
Mr. Houle grew up on Cape Cod and got his first restaurant job at 15, spending his high school years cleaning toilets and peeling garlic six afternoons a week. At 16, he had a set of keys and was going in on Saturdays to make the sweet rolls himself.
After college and the Army, he worked at various jobs, among them bouncer and shellfisherman. But nothing clicked, and he felt directionless, until he realized that he really wanted to be behind a stove.
"The kitchen was the only place I ever felt really comfortable," he says. "To me it felt like one of the few places where you can be whoever you are."
He enrolled at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., graduated with honors and plunged into the competitive restaurant world, enduring back-stabbing co-workers, hotheaded superiors, long hours and slave wages while working at top restaurants: the River Cafe, Bouley, and the SoHo bistros Jean-Claude and Caffe Lure. The owner of these last two, Jean-Claude Iacovelli, became a mentor, teaching Mr. Houle how to manage a restaurant and serve three-star food at bistro prices.
He put the lesson to use in his next venture, when he and a partner opened an Upper West Side bistro, Savann. He created a menu akin to what he would serve at Banania: contemporary French food with a smattering of global influences and a reliance on vegetable reductions and infused oils rather than butter and cream sauces. Savann was a success, attracting critical praise and enthusiastic crowds, but the partnership foundered. Mr. Houle left, determined to make it on his own.
That is how he has come to be wedged into a basement staircase, screw gun in hand, tacking up drywall on the afternoon of Nov. 6. Banania has an investor, Mr. Iacovelli's brother, Stephane, but Mr. Houle maintains control over the operation.
This was to be opening week, but he's nowhere close. The walk-in refrigerator has just been finished and the pay phone installed, but the air-conditioner is not. It costs $10,000 that Mr. Houle doesn't have. (He declined to say how much he invested in Banania, but he said an owner could expect to pay more than $100,000 to open this sort of restaurant.) A more serious problem is that he still doesn't have gas and hot water, and a feud between the plumber and the landlord has progress at a standstill. His carpenter has been arrested for assault, and his handyman, who is said to have hit the numbers, is nowhere to be found.
At week's end, the deadlock with the plumber is unresolved, and as workers from the soda supplier run lines to the bar, Mr. Houle and his landlord, Howard Solins, commiserate in the basement. Mr. Solins says the buzz on Smith Street is so strong that two dozen restaurateurs have expressed interest in renting the space. He said he chose Mr. Houle not only because of his resume, but also because he was impressed by the chef's drive to succeed.
"I know how difficult the restaurant business is," Mr. Solins says. "I thought that Dan had the ability to bring something in that he was going to nourish and watch over like a dog. There are so many details you have to look after."
By the next week, there is still no gas or hot water. But the dining room is shaping up. Mr. Houle envisioned a warm bistro atmosphere, and to that end, he has outfitted the dining room with a cream-colored tin ceiling, polished copper wainscoting, racks for magazines and newspapers, beige stucco walls lined with wine bottles, and a huge mirror covering the rear wall. Near the front was a cartoonish painting of a grinning man, the logo of Banania (pronounced ba-NAH-nya), the French hot chocolate drink from which restaurant takes its name. A few touches are to come: Tin-Tin figurines, a blackboard for specials.
 
Going for Warm and a Bit Hip
"I didn't want it clutter-filled, with too many tchotchkes and posters on the wall," Mr. Houle says. "At the same time, I didn't want it harsh and masculine. I wanted it warm. Not trendy, but a little bit hip."
He walked a similar line writing the menu. Wary of anything that smacked of pretense, he wanted to avoid sounding precious. He wanted the menu studded with what he called "ding words," items with built-in appeal that jump out at the reader. "Spring roll" is a ding word, as is "sweet and sour."
Mr. Houle's prices are deliberately low. Many new places on Smith Street like Saul and the Grocery have entrees up to $18 or $19, but his most expensive item is steak frites at $15. The industry standard is that food costs are 32 percent of a dish's price, but with gentle pressure from Mr. Iacovelli, he's aiming for less of a margin, hoping to make up for it in volume.
"I tell him, 'It's a neighborhood place, it's very important to work with the neighborhood,' " Mr. Iacovelli says. "You have to respect the customer's money. You sell him an entree for $12, $13, the customer knows you respect him, and he'll come back."
A standard formula is that a restaurateur can break even if he fills each seat once every night, says Mr. Houle, whose place seats close to 60. But even restaurants packing in customers can run into financial problems given the expenses: utilities, insurance, garbage collection, exterminators, licensing fees, taxes. Linen bills can be a killer; at Savann they ran $1,200 a month. Employee theft is a chronic problem.
"There are so many ways money can leak out of a restaurant," Mr. Houle says. "There are many, many expenses beyond what people see, and those are the things that can kill a place. A restaurant can be packed all the time and barely breaking even."
The prudent owner must keep a constant eye on wastefulness. "For a restaurant owner, the garbage is an excellent place to look," Mr. Houle says by way of example. "Silverware goes into the garbage, or plates wrapped up in the tablecloths. People might be throwing out the ends of herbs that they don't feel like chopping. This stuff adds up."
It's Nov. 20, and while the gas stalemate has been resolved, permits are needed, and progress is mired in paperwork and bureaucratic inertia. Mr. Houle has been working endless days, making business calls in the morning, looking after construction all day, and working on the computer at night: creating work schedules, calculating his linen needs, and deciding which of his handful of employees is responsible for each task, from frying oysters to filling salt shakers. The staff -- a mix of people referred by Mr. Iacovelli and colleagues Mr. Houle has come to know over the years -- is in place, taking care of one potential headache.
 
Cuisine Is in the Details
While the grind is wearing him down, he's determined to push ahead to his opening, now set for Dec. 1. By the end of Thanksgiving week, things are in decent enough shape that it's time to outfit the restaurant. On Sunday he heads for a restaurant supply store on the Bowery for the hundreds of items he needs: a five-quart mixer, trash cans, knives and cutting boards, whisks and tongs, pliers for deboning fish, a giant colander, saute pans, an 80-quart stockpot that is two feet across. On the way to the cash register, two last-minute items are selected, a $50 mop bucket and a "No Spitting" sign for the kitchen.
A last hurdle remains: the liquor license. It's one of a laundry list of permits that every restaurateur needs, along with approvals from the Health, Building, and Fire Departments. Months earlier, Mr. Houle had filled out a 30-page application detailing his sources of financing, and his fingerprints were taken. He has been conditionally approved, but he doesn't have the license.
 Tuesday morning he goes to the State Liquor Authority office near City Hall. Permit in hand, he says, he'll open in two days. Given the state of the restaurant, where sawdust and tools cover the floor and pots are stacked in boxes, that seems ambitious. But, he says, chaos is the norm in the restaurant business.
"Mistakes are going to happen," he says. "But there's a prevailing attitude in the restaurant business. It gets done, somehow or another."
Finally his name is called and he gets his license. "I want to scream I'm so happy," he says. The only question now is one that has haunted every restaurateur before the opening: Will anyone show up?
"You can have all the right ingredients, and have everything going in the right direction, and still fail," he says. "It happens often in this city. You just have to have the right stuff, a combination of ambience, food and service, and throw in a pinch of luck. You just don't know."
It is Wednesday night, the eve of the opening. Standing under the glowing light fixtures, Mr. Solins is exultant. "It's the most alive-looking place on the street," he says, as passers-by peer through the window. Music pulses in the dining room, and the kitchen is humming with activity as pomegranates are juiced, fennel is sliced, and a giant pot of lamb stock bubbles on the stove. Decked out in chef's whites, Mr. Houle looks charged and happy. His 5 o'clock shadow is gone, and with it the patina of fatigue that surrounded him in recent weeks. He cooks until after midnight, then spends two hours ordering food.
By noon on Thursday, small gaps in the planning are starting to become evident. Mr. Houle realizes he forgot to order bread, and after striking out at the bakery next door, he gets on the phone and secures an emergency delivery. A beer order was likewise neglected, so he loaded his Volvo with a few cases of Heineken and Sam Adams. There's no corkscrew, so Mr. Houle sprints out in his chef's whites to fetch one.
At 2 p.m., it comes to his attention that there's no toilet paper or soap in the bathroom, and a waiter is dispatched. Meanwhile Mr. Houle, who had learned the night before that the fish purveyor wouldn't deliver to Brooklyn until after 5 p.m., heads to Manhattan to pick up the fish delivery at Jean-Claude. When he gets there at 2:30, three hours before his opening, the fish still hasn't arrived. "I hate this," Mr. Houle says, pacing nervously. "This stress kills."
Ten minutes later, the fish arrives, wrapped in brown paper: cod, snapper, salmon, calamari, oysters. Mr. Houle pulls out a huge salmon and buries his nose in it. "Beautiful," he says. "This is sexy stuff."
 Back at the restaurant, candles are lighted at 5:15, and Mr. Houle and the Iacovelli brothers huddle. How many escargots in an order, Mr. Iacovelli asks. Seven, Mr. Houle answers. "That's fair," Mr. Iacovelli says. "Do you have forks or toothpicks?"
The first customer, Mr. Gannascoli, arrives at 5:30, and Mr. Houle works carefully but quickly, ringing a bell as each dish is finished and examining the plates as they return to the kitchen, a habit he learned from David Bouley. They're spanking clean, a good sign.
At 6:30, a pair of young women come in; half an hour later, two more. By 7:30, people are arriving steadily, and at 9 two dozen diners fill the space with a conversational buzz. The menu in the window seems to exert a magnetic pull. Few pass by without stopping to examine it. As the night goes on, the reviews come in, and the word is good. Mr. Gannascoli says he is "moved." Renee Ryerson, who shared the red snapper with her friend Karen Lichtenstein, calls it "amazing," and praises the presentation and the moderate prices. Juventino Avila, a chef who lives a block away, calls it the best meal he has had in weeks.
There were complaints; one couple found the service lacking, another thought the menu confusing. But Holly Merry and Maureen Brennan, who came in for a glass of wine and left planning to return soon, were more typical.
Despite the praise and the lack of catastrophes, at the end of the night, after 40 people have been fed, the atmosphere feels less like a celebration than a rolling up of the sleeves. As the kitchen is cleaned and food wrapped and stored, Mr. Houle, who has a large burn on his forearm, gripes a bit. An illegible order led to a mistake, and some of the music had loud, pounding bass lines.
Still, he's generally satisfied, he says, as he rummages through the garbage. Sure enough, he finds a ladle, pan lids and a handful of napkins. Then he phones to order food for the next day; lemon grass, a case of blood oranges, goat cheese, lamb shanks.
 
Problems but No Disasters
The last table leaves at midnight. Candles are blown out and money is counted. "I think he did pretty well," Jean-Claude Iacovelli says. Nobody wait too long for the appetizer, nobody wait too long for the main course. Everybody was happy."
"When you do 40 covers, it's easy," he says. "Tomorrow and Saturday it'll get busier. When you get a rush, that's when the trouble starts."
The weekend passes without a disaster, though not without problems. Friday the dishwasher fails to show, but Mr. Houle has a replacement in an hour. Saturday afternoon the boiler goes out, and is restarted only half an hour before opening. A misunderstanding with the garbage haulers lets trash pile up beside the building. But 75 to 80 people come each night, and everyone is fed.
In the next month, the number of diners begins to climb. Soon Banania is pulling well over 100 people for dinner on weekend nights, and when brunch service starts just before Christmas, the response is huge. Expecting to serve 50 people, Mr. Houle is taken aback by an onslaught of customers.
As January progresses, the restaurant gets busier, and soon lines are forming on weekends. Brunch in particular is a madhouse, with a steady crowd of people waiting for tables. At the end of the month, Eric Asimov gives Banania a generally favorable review in The New York Times, and the lines get longer still.
As January moves into February and March, things are looking good for Cafe Banania. But if there's one thing that restaurateurs agree on, it's that success only brings the need to work harder.
"You've got to constantly look at every aspect of the operation and ask how you can do it better," Danny Meyer says. "It's like Bill Parcells used to say when he was coach of the Giants: there's no such thing as maintaining excellence. You're either getting better or you're getting worse."
Mr. Houle, working 14 hours a day, seven days a week to nurture his offspring, believes he's up to the job. While satisfied, he sees a lot of room to grow. A sidewalk cafe in the warm months, maybe a raw bar.
"Some people make it and move on," he said. "I don't want to do that. I want to stay here and polish the diamond. I want it to be one of those places you see where it's always busy, always packed; a place that people like to walk into, and they're happy when they leave. I've worked all my life to do this.
"To stop short, why would I do that?"

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Sure, Banks Are Down, But Maybe Not Out

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
IN a stock market that, except for technology stocks, has developed a decidedly bitter edge, regional banks are among the groups that taste the worst.
Since last May 13, the Standard & Poor's index of major regional banks has declined by nearly 40 percent. For the most part, the decline does not reflect poor performance at the banks themselves. While the banks do not have the growth rates, say, of dot-coms, they are out there making money in a strong economy, and their balance sheets are in good shape. 
 According to the stock market, which tends to have a forward look, all of that is going to change sharply for the worse. But Thomas K. Brown, chief executive of Second Curve Capital, a financial services research and money management firm in Manhattan, has a rosier view. Last week, he took some time to discuss what may happen later this year. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. The slide in regional bank stocks really started to accelerate after the Federal Reserve started pushing up interest rates. Have investors become too pessimistic?
 
A. We look at three measures: price-earnings ratios relative to the S. & P. 500 index, bank dividend yields relative to the S. & P. 500, and relative price-to-book ratios.
Today, with or without the technology component of the S. & P. 500, those valuation measures are at extremes. In terms of relative prices, bank stocks have never been more attractive. And relative yields are higher than they were in 1990, when banks were cutting dividends.
The stock prices are telling you we will go through an environment that is comparable to 1980, when we had an unprecedented increase in short-term interest rates on top of a recession, or in 1990, when we were going through a general recession and a real estate depression.
There is a risk that might happen, but the probability that it will happen is low.
 
Q. In your view, what is a more likely prospect for the economy?
 
A. I have a high degree of confidence the Fed will be successful in slowing the economy without tipping it into recession. It is just a question of how many interest rate increases it will take to accomplish that.
When the market sees they are achieving that goal, there will be an incredible cyclical rally in bank stocks. I think that will happen sometime in the next six months.
 
Q. What if you are wrong, and the market is right, that the Fed will tighten too much and push the economy into recession. Do the bank stocks have a further downside?
 
A. We would see lower prices from today's levels. But I don't think the downside risk is more than 20 percent.
 
Q. With the whole group at such a low market valuation, some banks have started looking at making acquisitions. Just last week, North Fork Bancorp made a hostile $1.8 billion bid for Dime Bancorp. Would a wave of new mergers and acquisitions set off a rally in the stocks?
 
A. That's not possible. There have been too many failed deals for both shareholders and the buyers over the last three years to make the market excited about mergers. Investors have been burned too many times.
A more likely scenario, in my view, is that the rally in financial stocks will come first, and that will trigger a wave of consolidation. There is a perception among buyers and sellers that there is a need to do something this year, because pooling-of-interest accounting methods will no longer be available in 2001.
But if there is no rally in financial stocks, there will not be a consolidation wave.
 
Q. Are there any potential mergers out there that you think make a great deal of sense?
 
A. You could do a great deal with Banc One. At its current market price of around $21 a share, you could do a great deal by offering $40. I could make an argument that if Citigroup did that deal, it would be terrific, because it is a terrific fit for both franchises.
 
Q. Which stocks do you like at this juncture?
 
A. We like a number of thrifts, which are trading at much lower prices now than they were a year ago.
One company we like is Golden State Bancorp. The stock is trading at less than five times this year's earnings. The company has a great management team, which has done a great job historically of running and selling savings and loans.
We also like Washington Mutual and Greenpoint Financial. These are not riskless investments, and they are not having a great first quarter. And we like TCF Financial.
 
Q. What about banks?
 
A. National City Corporation, US Bancorp, First Star and Wells Fargo are all cheap stocks and are all good banks. And we like Capital One and Providian among the consumer finance companies.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 551 words

HEADLINE: Gore's Achilles' Heel

BYLINE: By Floyd H. Flake; Floyd H. Flake, a former Democratic Congressman, is the pastor of the Allen A.M.E. Church in Queens.

 BODY:
Now that Al Gore has locked up his party's nomination for president, it's time for him to start thinking beyond his loyal Democratic base. How can he appeal to independent voters?
He should take a page from President Clinton. In the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton made welfare reform a paramount issue, which helped him reach out beyond his party and win the votes of moderates. His political astuteness enabled him to craft legislation that both Republicans and Democrats agreed on in 1996. This will be a lasting legacy of his administration. 
 Al Gore could do for education what his boss did for welfare. In polls during the primaries, voters consistently said that education was their foremost concern. Promising to reform the education establishment would give Mr. Gore a means of building a broad base of support.
But Mr. Gore has not picked up this mantle. He has not embraced school choice, which offers vouchers and charter schools to lower middle class parents, giving them the chance to get their children out of failing schools. Choice brings the discipline of the market to our stagnant school systems.
Instead, Mr. Gore has chosen to win the support of the teachers' unions, which have stubbornly opposed almost all innovation. But this strategy comes at a price. Mr. Gore sacrifices the support of a powerful combination of advocates. Market economists like Milton Friedman find themselves on the same side as common-sense community activists, black Baptist preachers and those tired of empty promises from entrenched special interests.
Al Gore may have to contend with this potent bloc in the general election. A preview came at the Democratic candidates' debate in Harlem last month, when Tamala Edwards, a writer for Time, challenged Mr. Gore on education reform. With "what's good for the goose is good for the gander" clarity, Ms. Edwards asked about Mr. Gore's opposition to school choice, in light of his own decision to exercise school choice for his family. (All his children have gone to private schools.)
Ms. Edwards asked why Mr. Gore had not sent his children to the same public schools he defended, the schools where millions of poor and lower middle class people have no choice but to send theirs.
Mr. Gore didn't answer her question in any real way. That won't do. He and other Democrats must seriously address the disparities that exist in public education. If they don't, they face losing the interest of their most faithful constituency: African-Americans.
Al Gore might think he has the African-American vote in his back pocket. But George W. Bush's call for education reform could pose a challenge. After all, African-Americans want good schools for their children, yet they have the hardest time gaining entry to them.
In March, the Applied Research Center in Oakland, Calif., reported that minority students in urban communities suffer big disadvantages because of lack of access to good schools. This shocking report comes 46 years after the Brown v. Board of Education decision that ended racial segregation.
If Mr. Gore is going to pluck the heartstrings of the African-American community -- and of middle America at large -- he is going to have to answer why what is good for the Gores is not good for families with less power and wealth.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Productivity Finally Shows The Impact Of Computers

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
SINCE the early 1970's, the standard of living of most Americans has risen at a snail's pace. Are the gains finally coming faster?
That is really another way of asking whether the productivity of the nation's workers, which has risen at a snail's pace, has now finally shifted into a higher gear. And the tentative answer is yes -- the remarkable economic boom since 1995 has at last brought an enduring improvement in the output of goods and services for each hour spent on the job. 
 Don't rush out and borrow against the national good fortune. We have not entered into a New Economy in which computers, the Internet and fancy information technology shower efficiencies and prosperity reminiscent of the 1960's. Their effect is less dazzling, according to the most sober new studies. But the improvement is there. And the famous quip tossed off in 1987 by Robert M. Solow, the Nobel laureate in economics -- "You can see the computer age everywhere but in the productivity statistics" -- finally stands amended.
"You can now see computers in the productivity statistics," Mr. Solow said in an interview last week.
The most significant evidence comes in a soon-to-be-published research paper by Stephen D. Oliner and Daniel E. Sichel, two Federal Reserve economists.
In a landmark study five years ago, they looked into how computers contributed to labor efficiency and found little impact. That study threw cold water on the New Economy enthusiasts, who had argued that statistics showing productivity in the doldrums in those days were faulty.
Since then, the statistics have recorded a surge in the productivity growth rate. The enthusiasts no longer see so many flaws in the numbers. And Mr. Oliner and Mr. Sichel now find that computers -- both the manufacture of them and their use, particularly the large-scale networking of computers since 1995 -- are making a measurable contribution.
THEIR findings fall short of the New Economy, and do not match the enthusiasm of their boss, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, whose recent public pronouncements put him close to the New Economy camp. The authors note that the annual rate of productivity growth has risen by more than one percentage point from the roughly 1.5 percent average from 1973 to 1995. But they decline to estimate how much of the improvement is temporary -- a result of companies straining to produce more while the boom lasts -- and how much will persist through the next recession.
Still, they are optimistic. "Information technology has been the key factor behind the improved productivity performance," Mr. Sichel and Mr. Oliner write, adding that "a sizable portion" will persist.
Productivity is a straightforward concept. It rises when a long-distance telephone operator, for example, handles three more calls an hour this year than last. A result is more toll revenue for the same labor cost, increasing profits or wages or both. If enough finds its way into wages across the economy, living standards rise, as they have since 1995, although profits have absorbed much of the gains.
The productivity improvement is strongest in manufacturing, especially of computers and semiconductors. And the statistics reflect a bonus beyond the combination of labor and new equipment: the efficiencies that result from the way people work. All these factors account for two-thirds of the increase in the growth rate, Mr. Sichel and Mr. Oliner write. There have been surges in productivity growth before, but none in which information technology played so big a role.
The added wages and profits that flow from all this will last if the productivity improvement is permanent -- a result of more efficient equipment, for instance, rather than an operator straining to keep up with a rising workload in a booming economy.
Efficiency, however, is not enough to sustain productivity. There is a demand side to the equation. The productivity growth rate gets whittled away if customers fail to buy all the additional goods and services generated with every hour of work.
And then there is the capital spending aspect. Responding to the tremendous demand of the last four years, companies have raised capital spending to record levels. This spending, in turn, is a major contributor to the surge in productivity.
Mr. Oliner and Mr. Sichel reflect these caveats in their new study, which is why their research is likely to be a benchmark in the continuing debate over American prosperity. Or as Mr. Solow put it, "I will feel better about the endurance of the productivity improvement after it survives its first recession."

HEADLINE: The Metamorphosis Of Germany Inc.

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: MUNICH

 BODY:
AS chairman of Allianz A.G., the German insurance conglomerate with $370 billion in assets under management, Henning Schulte-Noelle is about as close as anybody to the heart of Germany Inc.
Far more than just an insurance company, Allianz is at the center of a web of cross-holdings and interlocking directorates that have made German industry a seemingly impenetrable fortress for decades. 
 From his bland five-story headquarters building here, Mr. Schulte-Noelle controls sizable stakes in this country's most powerful corporations: Deutsche Bank, Dresdner Bank, Siemens, Bayer and BASF, to name just a few.
Yet as he relaxed briefly in his office on Thursday, Mr. Schulte-Noelle not only acknowledged that the old system was crumbling, but also said he planned to swing the hammer himself.
"The dismantling is obvious," he said, without a trace of regret. "After the Second World War, Germany needed to be rebuilt, and we obviously needed a cohesive system. Everybody had to be part of it. Now, indeed, we are in the process of changing."
That is not idle talk. In the last few months, the structure and ethos underlying Fortress Germany have begun to crack like a house on a California fault line.
The most stunning evidence came last week, when Allianz brokered a $30 billion merger deal between Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank. What at first blush looks like simple retreat to corporate giantism is in reality a major step toward dismantlement.
Not only will the new Deutsche Bank spin off its entire retail banking business as an independent company, but Allianz and Deutsche Bank plan to steadily reduce their stakes in each other -- and, ultimately, unwind all of their mutual cross-holdings.
Even that is just a start. Thanks to a radical tax plan that will allow corporations to sell off investments without paying capital gains taxes, German banks and insurers are now salivating at the prospect of divesting industrial holdings accumulated decades ago and now worth more than $100 billion.
Those sales will essentially unravel Germany's corporate safety net. And they will come precisely as conglomerates across Europe are engaged in a frenzy of mergers, acquisitions and spinoffs aimed at bolstering shareholder value.
A result is that old loyalties are dissolving. Not long ago, hostile takeovers were taboo. One month ago, Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. of Britain won its battle to acquire Mannesmann A.G. of Germany for $183 billion -- the biggest hostile takeover anywhere, ever.
At the same time, Germans' willingness to take on risk has undergone a revolution.
As recently as 1997, young companies in technology industries had no chance of raising money through public stock offerings in Germany. Now more than 200 companies are listed on the Frankfurt exchange's New Market, and their combined value has soared to $220 billion.
The breakup of Germany Inc. has reached deep into the national fabric. American and British companies are scouring for acquisitions among Germany's vast mittelstand, or middle class, of smaller family-owned industrial companies.
Time-honored notions of career success are falling by the wayside, too. University graduates who once sought lifelong careers at prestigious companies are defecting to entrepreneurial start-ups. Stock options and golden parachutes, both nonexistent three years ago, are the rage.
It all sounds like the United States 10 or 15 years ago, and most experts are convinced that the changes are healthy. German companies are becoming more competitive, more flexible and more innovative. Young entrepreneurs have become national heroes.
But to many Germans, it is a shock. Tens of thousands of union workers protested fiercely against Vodafone's bid for Mannesmann. But they were equally shocked to learn afterward that Mannesmann's chief executive had a severance package worth $30 million.
Corporate executives have been jolted, as well. Two years ago, Deutsche Bank executives were dumbfounded when the American investment bankers they had recruited with huge pay packages defected abruptly to a rival -- for even bigger packages.
And the fear of takeovers and job cuts is relentless. Bayerische Motor Werke, the Bavarian car manufacturer, has been the topic of unending takeover speculation, despite the insistence of its controlling shareholders, the Quandt family, that the company should remain independent.
Few remarks capture the new spirit as well as a recent one by Gerhard Cromme, chief executive of Thyssen Krupp, Germany's biggest steel company.
As head of what was then the Krupp Group, Mr. Cromme shocked Germans in 1997 by starting a hostile bid for Thyssen. Pelted with eggs by union workers, Mr. Cromme soon found himself under attack by the then chancellor, Helmut Kohl. But Mr. Cromme ultimately prevailed, hammering out a friendly merger deal that has proved quite successful.
Yet when he appeared at a conference on mergers last month, Mr. Cromme sounded almost alarmed as he considered the implications of America Online's recent deal to acquire Time Warner.
"This can happen to everybody -- even those of us with big market capitalizations," he said. "Internet companies can buy up whatever they want in the world, and it's really something we have to think about."
 
New Path at Deutsche Bank
Sheathed in reflective glass, the twin towers that house the Frankfurt headquarters of Deutsche Bank project both gravitas and power.
Today, Deutsche Bank is the biggest shareholder in DaimlerChrysler, with 12 percent of the shares. Its portfolio of industrial holdings is worth about $20 billion. Its executives serve on the supervisory boards of more than a dozen big corporations.
Yet ever since he took over as the bank's chief executive in 1997, Rolf-Ernst Breuer has been preoccupied with breaking up these old ties.
"We lived with the old model of Germany Inc. very successfully over the last 50 years," he said in a recent interview. "But in a globalized environment, you have no chance to pursue an island model -- and it was an island model. It was very German."
Even before the Dresdner deal, Deutsche Bank towered over any German competitor. But investors assign it a value far below that of America Online -- or, perhaps more relevantly, the discount broker Charles Schwab. Despite the immense size of Deutsche Bank, its return on equity of about 9.9 percent compares poorly with the 15 percent earned by many American rivals. So in the new world, Mr. Breuer knows his bank is vulnerable.
"We have to ask ourselves: What is the reason?" he said. "What can we do about getting a better market capitalization?"
Mr. Breuer has begun answering the question by leading Deutsche Bank's systematic retreat from Germany Inc. He has prohibited bank executives from heading the supervisory boards of companies in which it holds significant stakes. Last year, he split off the bank's industrial holdings into a separate company that could be managed more actively. In a big move last fall, Deutsche Bank sold off more than $1 billion of Allianz shares -- the first step toward untangling the two companies.
But all that was a mere prelude. Just before Christmas, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder proposed eliminating capital gains tax for companies selling shares in other corporations. Now Deutsche Bank plans to reshuffle its holdings from top to bottom -- and cash in a big chunk of the gains it has accrued over the course of Germany's post-war boom.
Almost every other company with such a portfolio is doing the same. At Allianz, Mr. Schulte-Noelle hired the head of the Frankfurt office of Goldman Sachs, Paul Achleitner, as his new chief financial officer. Allianz has already swung into action, selling $1.5 billion of bonds, convertible into Allianz's shares in Siemens A.G. Much deal-making is expected as other stakes are disposed of.
At Deutsche, Mr. Breuer plans to turn the profits from his stock sales into Internet projects, which could consume more than $1 billion a year. In a separate move, Deutsche Bank is planning to reduce its stake in the German stock exchange, which plans to go public later this year.
"Saying goodbye to Germany Inc. is a process which is not very easy," Mr. Breuer said. "It served us well, but more and more it gave rise to criticisms -- especially from the side of Anglo-Saxon observers who said there was an ongoing conflict of interest."
Once upon a time, those criticisms could have been brushed aside, and a case made for the strong growth, full employment and social stability that Germany's cozy economic cocoon afforded. Not anymore, given the way German industry, with its high costs and consensual decision-making, fell behind the re-engineered economies of the United States and Britain.
"It developed into a competitive disadvantage," Mr. Breuer said.
 
Invasion in the Heartland
Beru A.G., a small company with headquarters near Stuttgart that makes glow plugs for diesel engines, seems a world away from takeover brawls and American-style high finance. But a fax delivered to Beru's chief executive, Ulrich Ruetz, offered a tough lesson in how mobile money can be.
The message was from a representative of the Carlyle Group, a corporate buyout group based in Washington. It informed Mr. Ruetz that Carlyle's subsidiary in Munich would like to buy his company for about $30 a share, or about $300 million.
That was startling enough. The real shocker was this: Carlyle had already cut a deal with two of Beru's four founding families to buy 26.25 percent of the stock.
"It bothered me that they didn't even let us know before they came to us," Mr. Ruetz said. "It is hardly how I would have made a friendly approach."
At the moment, the outcome is undecided. The other founding families, which control 29 percent of the shares, say Carlyle will have to raise its offer before they sell out. Public shareholders, who own the rest, have not yet been approached. For Carlyle's part, Michael Hildisch, director of the firm's Munich office, said its partners were interested only in friendly deals. "We want management to be on board," he said.
Whatever happens, the case is evidence of how, with little attention, a flood of foreign money is aiming at Germany's mittelstand, the family-controlled industrial companies that make ball bearings, engine casings, automobile seats and water pumps.
A few of these companies, like Beru, are listed on the stock exchange, even though family members retain majority control. Most are entirely private, largely inscrutable to outsiders.
But private or public, the mittelstand companies have become hot properties. Carlyle, which set up a $1 billion buyout fund for Europe in 1997, has a permanent subsidiary in Munich. Other American and British buyout companies are looking for deals in Germany, too.
So are foreign industrial companies, particularly American automobile parts suppliers. Under heat from big car manufacturers to become faster, cheaper and more global, parts suppliers on both sides of the Atlantic are trying to consolidate.
Much like leveraged buyout funds operating in the United States, Carlyle has a goal of acquiring solid but sluggish manufacturers, sprucing them up and -- if all goes well -- selling the companies or taking them public for a big profit four or five years later.
"In most cases, the family members are very reluctant to sell," Mr. Hildisch acknowledged. But often, he said, companies realize that they cannot raise the capital for expansion on their own.
It took him nearly a year to negotiate the purchase of Honsel A.G., a company based near Dortmund that builds gearboxes and engine blocks and had sales of about 900 million marks, or about $450 million, last year. Carlyle finally acquired Honsel last fall for 300 million marks, or about $150 million. Now, Carlyle executives are acquiring a small American producer in the same field and have plans to merge it with Honsel.
Maximilian Dietzsch-Doertenbach, a consultant who advises family-owned German companies, says the vast horde of smaller companies badly need to raise capital but are shunned in the stock market as ugly ducklings.
"There are 5,600 auto suppliers in Germany, but only about 70 of them have sales of more than 500 million marks," Mr. Dietzsch-Doertenbach said. "These companies have to grow. They have to be more international. But what should they do? Sell out, which they don't like? Go public, when they know they won't be well received?"
Though entirely independent of the Carlyle Group, Mr. Dietzsch-Doertenbach argues that it and similar firms fill a crucial void. "The Carlyles of the world are very much needed," he said.
At Beru, in the little town of Ludwigsburg, Mr. Ruetz says his company does not need any outside help. Beru's sales last year climbed 12 percent to 426 million marks, about $218 million. Its net income climbed 29 percent to 37.3 million marks, or about $19.1 million.
But Mr. Ruetz is too realistic to dismiss Carlyle. In the stock market, diesel engine glow plugs are not as exciting as Internet companies. If Carlyle offers more money, he said, Beru might easily be sold: "It's all a question of price."
 
A High-Test Market Takes Off
 If the breakup of Germany Inc. has left Mr. Ruetz in a quandary, it is has made Thomas Haffa a billionaire.
Mr. Haffa and his brother Florian are co-founders of EM.TV A.G., an 11-year-old television and film company outside Munich that has acquired broadcasting rights to a huge collection of children's programs. Last month, Mr. Haffa made international news with a deal to acquire the Jim Henson Company and its Muppets for about $680 million.
But the most extraordinary aspect of Mr. Haffa's story is his rise in the German stock market. Until 1997, the restrictive rules of the Frankfurt exchange virtually prohibited new companies like EM.TV from going public. That reflected the mindset of Fortress Germany -- that a good company is a big company, and the best company is a very big, very old company.
"I had a lot of American friends who told me, 'Haffa, you have to go public,' " he recalled in an interview. "I said sure -- but where?"
The answer, it turned out, was Frankfurt. In 1997, the stodgy Deutsche Borse started a new exchange with far easier entrance rules called the Neue Markt, or New Market. EM.TV was one of the first companies to go public there.
In the three years since, the New Market has achieved dazzling success, listing more than 200 companies, most of them new enterprises based on innovative technology or new business concepts.
Mobilcom A.G., which started out as a scrappy marketing concern for cellular telephone services, was the first company to list on the New Market. Today, having expanded to compete directly against Germany's main telephone company in long-distance service, Mobilcom has a market value of more than $6 billion. So does Qiagen, a company that makes products used in biotechnology research.
But EM.TV has been the most spectacular success. The stock has soared more than 31,000 percent and has a total market value of $13 billion. Mr. Haffa, who spurns traditional German modesty about money and flaunts his yacht, owns nearly half the shares, along with other family members.
To be sure, the New Market may well reflect naive dreams and bubble valuations. But it has contributed in its own way to the dismantling of Germany Inc.
Thanks to its listed companies, stock options have changed the way thousands of German workers think about risk and reward. Options were nonexistent here three years ago, and they still are at many established companies. But at many New Market companies, including EM.TV, stock options are part of almost everyone's pay package.
Recruiters say older Germans are still more nervous than American or British executives about jumping to little-known technology companies. But young managers who would have stayed at an established company for life are now leaping at the age-old dream of getting in the ground floor.
"I have one opening for a chief financial officer at a messaging company, because it plans to go public," said Jurgen Rohrmayer, an executive recruiter at Kienbaum Consultants in Munich. "I have had an amazing number of senior financial officers applying -- and they are doing it over the Internet."
Now 44, Reto Francioni has nearly reached the pinnacle of the Deutsche Borse itself. As deputy chief executive, Mr. Francioni oversees most of the exchange's trading operations, including the New Market.
Yet Mr. Francioni, a Swiss citizen, has decided to bail out himself and join one of Germany's fastest growing Internet brokerage firms, Consors A.G.
"The question is, do you want to act as an entrepreneur, or do you want to join a big corporation?" Mr. Francioni said last week. "For me, the size of the company is not the issue. The issue for me is the opportunity for growth."
Despite his top position at the Deutsche Borse, Mr. Francioni receives no stock options at his current job. He will at his new one.

HEADLINE: Aiding the Neediest Cases

 BODY:
Perhaps the most striking thing about the Neediest Cases Fund drive is its diversity. The money gathered -- more than $6 million this year, second only to last year's record -- goes to help an extraordinary array of people, and it helps them in ways that specifically match their individual needs. Moreover, the drive reminds us that generosity takes as many forms as need itself. This is money raised in large amounts and small. It comes from people who can easily afford to give and from people whose giving makes a real difference in their own weekly budgets. The gifts are seldom thoughtless or offhanded. The money is given not so that we can dismiss from our minds the poor or the sick or the helpless but so that we can remember them.
We are all inured to charitable appeals and inundated by images of suffering. It can be hard, at times, to remember that they reflect an imbalance in human equity, an imbalance that is, unfortunately, one result of our prosperity. The impersonal forces of our growing economy have helped to lift many people out of poverty and suffering. But the neediest cases are precisely that. Their needs lie beyond the ordinary. The only relief prosperity will bring them comes from our prosperity, from the abundance we feel. 
 Your contributions, which are deductible on federal, state and city income taxes to the extent permitted by law, are still welcome. They go directly to seven charitable organizations: the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service; the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York; the Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens; the Children's Aid Society; the Community Service Society of New York; the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies; and the UJA-Federation of New York. Send your checks to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087. You may also donate with a credit card at www.nytimes.com/neediest. 
http://www.nytimes.com
