HEADLINE: THE NATION: Succeeding;
From the Ruling Class, Meet the Next President

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
ONE of them was born just a dozen blocks from the White House and reared, at least when Congress was in session, in a hotel set amid the embassies of Washington. The other knew 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue as the place where his father worked for a dozen years in successive jobs: vice president of the United States for two-thirds of that time, president for the rest.
Their parallel paths of privilege took them past landmarks that were different in name but identical in spirit: St. Albans School and Harvard University for one, Phillips Academy and Yale for the other. 
 And politics pumped so strongly in their blood that one of them first ran for a seat in the House of Representatives -- the same seat his father had once occupied -- in 1976, at the age of just 28. (He won.) The other lagged only two years behind, making his own bid for Congress in 1978 at the age of 32. (He lost.)
Now, despite all the primary-season chatter about giving Americans a new kind of politics, despite the tussles in both parties over which presidential contender could bring a fresh and unjaded perspective to governing, the contest has narrowed to these two: Albert A. Gore Jr. and George W. Bush, a former senator's only son and a former president's firstborn -- namesakes and political princes with dissimilar styles but astonishingly similar inheritances.
Presidential historians and political analysts said they could not recall a previous election in American history when the nominees (presumptive, for now) of both major parties were not only such prominent political heirs but also from such similar stations and members of the same generation.
That equivalence could simply be accidental, the analysts said, but several said it speaks in part to the state of politics and the mood of the electorate. It also imbues this year's presidential race with an unusual and unusually fascinating dynamic: among the challenges facing both Vice President Gore and Mr. Bush, the Texas governor, is how they relate to their political ancestries, particularly the degree to which they reap the benefits of their backgrounds while avoiding the drawbacks. That balancing act has been a theme in both men's careers.
"I don't think either of them is going to have a slogan of 'Vote for me, keep the tradition alive,' " said Bill Carrick, a Democratic strategist, adding that such bald elevations of pedigree over merit would surely invite rejection.
But to some extent, he and other political analysts noted, the Democratic voters who backed Mr. Gore and the Republican voters who supported Mr. Bush were indeed choosing to keep certain traditions alive.
In Mr. Gore's case, the more relevant tradition may have been the last seven years of the Clinton administration. But in the cases of both candidates, voters were choosing someone with an almost congenital grasp of politics, all the social and material advantages that went along with that life style and milieu and a relative unfamiliarity with hardship or tests of character on the scale of Senator John McCain's five and a half years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam.
Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush both dealt with that war in a way that reflected their memberships in a younger, more coddled generation. Mr. Gore went to Vietnam, but only briefly, and as an Army journalist. Mr. Bush got a coveted spot as a pilot in the Texas Air National Guard and was able to stay close to home.
"If we were in a recessionary period, where class distinctions are more on the surface, there might have been more of a dialogue about that," said Don Sipple, a Republican strategist. Similarly, he said, if the nation were in the grip of a crisis, voters might reject any semblance of the status quo and seek someone who seemed just a bit more idiosyncratic and adventurous, a bit less destined.
ABRIEF period of economic fright yielded the man from Hope, Bill Clinton. A nationally devastating corruption of the public trust yielded the man from Plains, Jimmy Carter. With the world relatively peaceful and the nation phenomenally prosperous, there is no such invitation this time around for a slightly unusual upstart or self-styled maverick.
"I don't think Bradley or McCain understood that," said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster. "There's sometimes an assumption that Americans are risk-takers in good times. But Americans are really only risk-takers in bad times. There's a real interest out there in finding someone who is going to preserve what we have, someone who knows the ropes."
Ms. Lake said that in some focus groups she has conducted, voters expressed both an assumption that Mr. Bush might call his father at crucial times and a sense of comfort -- not alarm -- in that likelihood.
Mr. Gore, Mr. Bush and their supporters say it is the men's accomplishments that have made them credible presidential contenders. But their ancestries undeniably helped start and guide them on their way in politics, providing them with networks, access to money, instantly high profiles and other tactical advantages.
Additionally, their fathers' careers -- especially their failures -- taught them valuable lessons, some reflected in their current campaigns. When Albert Gore Sr.'s many distinguished years as a senator from Tennessee ended with his defeat at the polls in 1970, one reason was his Republican rival's nasty and negative approach, which Mr. Gore did not match. His son exhibited no such reticence in taking on former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey over the last nine months.
"His father's political demise was as instructive to him as anything that his father did while in office," said Bill Turque, author of a recent biography of the vice president, "Inventing Al Gore" (Houghton Mifflin). "It taught him the power of attack politics."
Mr. Bush has a similar reference point: his father's failed bid for a second term as president in 1992. President Bush ran a campaign more responsive than assertive and hampered by dissension and disloyalty in the ranks. His son sought to avoid those mistakes, quickly putting Mr. McCain on the defensive and entrusting his effort to a tightly knit circle of longtime political allies.
And yet both candidates' relationships to their patrimony are more complicated. They recognize that if they seem to be trading too heavily on their backgrounds, it could turn off voters. They also realize that their backgrounds inform and play into some of their most potent liabilities: in Mr. Gore's case, that his life and world view are utterly circumscribed by politics; in Mr. Bush's case, that his late-blooming political prominence is the result of his father's connections, not his own talents and toilings.
In the years between 1992, when Mr. Gore won the vice presidency and his father said publicly that "we raised him for it," and 1998, when his father died, Mr. Gore's advisers sometimes sought to steer reporters away from his dad.
These days, Mr. Gore almost constantly invokes Albert Gore Sr. on the campaign trail, but largely to emphasize what a self-made man his father was. He mentions that his father was poor and had to attend law school at night. The vice president need not worry that voters will think he is trying to trade on Americans' affection for his father, because only older voters in Tennessee would have the requisite memory of the man.
Former President George Bush, by contrast, is keenly remembered -- he left office only seven years ago -- and that creates both an added impetus for his son to mention him and a greater danger that some voters will raise an eyebrow when he does so. So the Texas governor is artful and sparing about it.
For much of last year, Mr. Bush's stump speech included a passage in which he acknowledged that the leap from governor to president would be a big one. "But," he added, "I've had some pretty good training."
He then went on to talk about running Texas, but the pauses he took before and after that line, and the applause it reliably elicited, left no doubt about its intent. Mr. Bush was saying, without quite saying, that being his father's son should give Americans some reassurance.
ON the eve of the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Bush and his advisers abandoned such subtlety, putting the governor's parents on a stage with him. The event was deemed by many to be a disaster, signaling to voters that a torch was being passed, rather than earned.
It was odd, because Mr. Bush usually goes out of his way to avoid that impression. His almost strenuously folksy side -- the cowboy boots he sometimes wears, the hyper-informal manner that recently prompted him to address several of the physicians at a recent campaign event as "Doc" -- seems like a self-conscious purging of the blue in his blood.
Mr. Gore takes his own stabs at a common touch. Did you know that he once lived in a trailer park? That he likes and watches "The Simpsons"? Voters at his town hall-style meetings do, because Mr. Gore has made a point of telling them.
It promises a somewhat surreal spectacle between now and November: two candidates whose life stories could not be more entwined in establishment politics, and whose current situations owe a great deal to those circumstances, competing to convince Americans that they have just the right distance from it all.

HEADLINE: Where the Money Is;
Six Central Counties Draw Jobs, People and Enormous Wealth

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: BERNARDS TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
THERE are not enough hours in the day or square feet on the ground to build all the houses that people want to buy in the Hills, a development that blankets 1,600 acres in the Watchung Hills.
Toll Brothers, one of the builders working on the last open patch of mountainside, releases lots for sale in small batches to keep demand at bay. A few weekends ago, seven lots went in three hours. With options, some houses cost $800,000 or $900,000, but the buyers want the granite and marble, sun rooms and guest suites with lavish baths. 
 "We literally cannot build fast enough," said Peter Alles, the assistant vice president overseeing the company's Hills developments. "It's where the hot spot is -- Somerset County has the gold badge for that. And the supply is drying up."
Even the 5,200 homes of the Hills cannot make a dent in the demand for housing in Somerset County, the richest and fastest-growing in New Jersey. Indeed, people here were not surprised when a national real estate survey last month declared Somerset, Middlesex and Hunterdon the hottest market in the United States.
And these three counties form the heart of what two Rutgers researchers have identified as the "wealth belt" of New Jersey. As the state booms, James W. Hughes and Joseph J. Seneca said in a report made public last fall, the money, the jobs and the population growth are drawn to the state's six central counties -- Monmouth, Middlesex, Somerset, Mercer, Hunterdon and Morris.
"We've had this tidal wave of metropolitan expansion coming out of New York and Philadelphia as a long-term dynamic," said Mr. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy. "Then, in the 1980's, we had the emergence of edge cities and suburban growth corridors."
The result, he said, was the shift of economic power from the northern suburbs to the more scattered office-and-freeway nodes to the south.
In this picture, the state's midsection exemplifies roaring exurban good times: a convergence of ever-richer pharmaceutical and telecommunications industries, stock market money that buys half-million-dollar houses and sport utility vehicles, a surge in consumer appetite for things large, and new Interstates to tie them all together.
In per-capita income, four of the top five counties -- Somerset, Morris, Hunterdon and Mercer -- are in the wealth belt. (The exception is Bergen, at No. 2.) Together, they are the richest slice of a state that is second in wealth only to Connecticut.
"This place is awash in money," said Barbara Lawrence, director of New Jersey Future, a statewide planning organization based in Trenton.
Ms. Lawrence says the surge in central Jersey's housing costs is largely due to the rapid growth of the pharmaceutical industry. "To me, that's what is driving prices," she said. "Government regulations are important, but the power of the capitalist system is more important."
Indeed, the system has given New Jersey an average of 73,000 new jobs a year in the last four years, and Mr. Hughes estimates that the wealth belt got nearly three-quarters of them. And everyone agrees that these are not average jobs.
"Most wealth belt residents work in a new information-age economy," Mr. Hughes said. "A good portion of the wealth belt's wealth is due to the pharmaceutical industry, all the communications employment and all those activities in the Route 1 corridor. These are extraordinarily high-quality jobs."
A second factor, he said, is the increase in dual-income households: While one spouse is usually working close to home, the other has access to the 3.8 million jobs all over the state, plus 3.4 million in New York City and 1 million in Philadelphia.
The job-fest is apparent in the environs of the Hills, built at the convergence of Interstates 287 and 278 and Route 206. Just south of Pluckemin, an old one-steeple village bisected by Route 206 and now engulfed by new housing,the corporate campuses appear: AT&T, then Pharmacia and Upjohn, then Aventis.
It seems that the highly educated, highly paid Baby Boomers that Mr. Hughes describes are just the people showing up at Toll Brothers new Patriot subdivisions, where townhouses start at $340,000 and single-family houses at about $500,000.
Mr. Alles said the average buyer is 46 years old and trading up; about 40 percent are two-income households. "A lot are professionals, upper management," he said. "The stock market is a major source of income right now."
He said about 25 percent are local residents and about 10 percent come from other parts of the country. Another 15 percent, he said, come from New York City: "You have your New York buyer, used to a two-bedroom apartment that's $800,000, coming here to get grass under his toes."
So Mr. Alles was not surprised when the National Association of Realtors, in its report for the fourth quarter of 1999, found that resale prices had risen 23.3 percent in a year. That increase was the highest in the nation; the national median price increase was 3.6 percent, and in the region comprising Essex, Union, Morris, Sussex and Warren counties, it was 9.2 percent.
If the wealth belt is drawing people who are willing to pay handsomely to go where they want to go, it is nowhere more clear than in the epicenter of desirability, Princeton.
"It's frightful," said Katherine McCool, the broker-manager of the local Gloria Nilson real estate office. Ms. McCool said that to price a house today in Princeton Township or Borough, using as a baseline a comparable property that sold in September, she would add 22 percent for the last quarter of 1999 and 10 percent for the first weeks of 2000.
Ms. McCool said increases in outlying areas were lower but still pushed up by a "phenomenal" relocation market.
"This is much different from the 80's," she said. "In the 80's we had a lot of new construction going on, so you could see the supply was coming. All buyers should be concerned about this because the inflation is not in the teens like it was then, and if you look around, there's no room to build."
Planners say the building will occur not in Princeton's ZIP codes, but in the wealth belt's rural reaches.
The Regional Planning Partnership, a nonprofit land-use planning organization, forecasts a 40 percent population increase by 2020 in its region, Mercer County and the southern portions of Middlesex and Somerset counties. According to 1999 census data released last week, the population in Somerset rose 19.4 percent.
The even more striking change, and the one that planners want to avert, is the rate at which the population is spreading out. The Regional Planning Partnership reports that while the region's population grew 21 percent from 1976 to 1996, the land area developed increased by 61 percent.
New Jersey Future, in a county-by-county calculation of how fast undeveloped land was consumed from 1986 to 1995, placed Somerset at the top. In that decade, which included a serious recession and preceded the latest boom, Somerset ate up 10 percent of its open space. Close behind were Monmouth, at 9.1 percent; Mercer, at 8.8 percent, Middlesex, at 8.6 percent, and Morris, at 7.7 percent.
Some planners say efforts to channel development to already-established centers -- the "smart growth" envisioned by the state's master development plan -- can restrain the centrifugal force. But even those working furiously to make that happen do not see how even the best planning can stop big new incursions into undeveloped areas.
One of those incursions is a 3.5 million-square-foot office complex that Merrill Lynch plans in Hopewell, near Interstate 95 north of Trenton. While the proposal caused a local furor -- and much criticism of the needed extension of sewer lines from Trenton -- the Regional Planning Council gave the proposal its qualified support.
"For 30 years we've looked at where the infrastructure is and where it should go," said Dianne R. Brake, the president of the council. "Even if you revitalized the cities and the towns in our area, there would still be a lot of growth, and where would you put it?"
Neil Upmeyer, a political consultant who serves on the board of New Jersey Future, said the Merrill Lynch proposal should have been no surprise. "From the development community's perspective, the opposition seems rather ludicrous," Mr. Upmeyer said. "You have an exit on an interstate across the road from an airport, and of course that's where you'd put an office park."
Mr. Upmeyer, like the Rutgers researchers, points to the interstates as the avenues of big development: "If you want to get to the root of the problem, it's roads."
It is fairly recent, he said, that Interstate 287 and 78 were completed and then became invitations to office parks that would draw people from the Hudson River to Pennsylvania. As an example, he cited Merck & Co., which in 1992 moved its world headquarters from Rahway to the shoulder of Interstate 78 in Readington Township.
A resident of Hunterdon County, Mr. Upmeyer is especially aware of the effects of Merck's move; with Merrill Lynch building in Hopewell, he said, "you have one place to the south and one to the north, and these put ever-increasing pressure on the middle, meaning Hunterdon County."
There, as in the other desirable and already-wealthy parts of the wealth belt, the terrain is eaten up especially fast because of large-lot zoning -- meaning big houses with lawns of two to six acres.
For that reason, among others, Mr. Upmeyer is not optimistic about Governor Whitman's well-advertised plan to preserve a million acres of open space in 10 years.
"I don't think in 10 years that this is going to happen," he said. "What are her neighbors going to think? If Tewksbury is developed, where is her legacy then?"
Ms. Brake agreed that the current zoning in most of the developing wealth belt only invites sprawl. "Single use, low density, free parking -- that's the model everywhere," she said. "Cutting up your land into two-acre lots is not going to retain your rural character."
While the loss of open space is alarming to planners and environmentalists, builders are not happy about the future either.
"Land costs generally in New Jersey, and it's true in those counties as well, have gone through the roof in the last year or two years," said Patrick O'Keefe, the director of the New Jersey Builders Association.
One reason, Mr. O'Keefe said, was the exhaustion of the supply of land that builders had bought during the big housing downturn in the last 1980's and early 90's. He also attributed some of the price increases to the new public-sector interest in acquiring land and development rights.
But while environmentalists fault state and local governments for doing too little to stop growth, Mr. O'Keefe says it has done too much.
"The state as a matter of conscious policy has strangled the approval process," he said, referring to the many applications that builders must make to public agencies before they can break ground. "There's plenty of raw land out there," he continued. "It's not an issue of acreage; it's an issue of approvals."
Mr. OKeefe said housing costs in the wealth belt were "going to get much, much worse, " noting that in Hunterdon the average price of a new price was approaching $400,000.
The consensus is that the building boom has to slow down soon. The governor's Council of Economic Advisers, which is headed by Mr. Seneca of Rutgers, forecasts a decline of 20 percent in housing starts this year. And in their report, Mr. Seneca and Mr. Hughes venture that when the Baby Boom empties its nests and retires, it will revive the market for smaller, more urban living spaces.
But for now, the researchers acknowledge, the big, new, expensive houses are selling better than ever -- especially in the big, new economy of central Jersey.
"What's been happening recently reflects the 45-to-50-year-old," Mr. Hughes said. "With their two-point-something kids, when they become teen-agers, or when people feel they can afford it, they do finally want to settle into a West Windsor, a Princeton or a Montgomery. Each kid needs a bedroom, and you need his-and-hers offices, and maybe a great room."
This, he said, is part of a national penchant for living large -- large homes, large lots and large SUV's (Mr. Hughes calls them SAVs, for suburban assault vehicles). And since the appetites can be indulged in the relatively open territory of the wealth belt, they are.
Ms. Lawrence at New Jersey Future questions whether the inflation in the size and price of housing is driven by the buyers or the builders. "We're building larger and larger houses, which of course are going to be more costly," she said. "If you ask the builders, their response would be: That's the market. But if you're selling doughnuts and 99 percent of your customers buy doughnuts, then that's your market."
To be sure, executives at Toll Brothers say: That's the market. "Our biggest homes are by far our most popular sellers," said Wayne S. Patterson, a senior vice president.
Mr. Patterson noted that Toll Brothers was building assisted-living complexes in Jackson and Monroe, and offering townhouses in many developments. But he said the majority of buyers wanted single-family homes in the 4,000-square-foot range -- and could pay for them.
Kira McCarron, the company's vice president for marketing, said central Jersey was one of the best markets in the 19 states where Toll Brothers builds.
"We've seen it go through several cycles," Ms. McCarron said, including the chancy years when AT&T started layoffs and common wisdom predicted a crash. "But given the investment made by so many already in the state, it seemed unlikely that anyone would let it tank. Where it is in the transportation corridor, how could it fail?"
At the Hills, Mr. Alles said prices had risen by an average of $75,000 since the fall of 1998. In that time, among other things, Aventis Pharmaceutical announced that it would bring 2,400 employees to its new North American headquarters in nearby Bridgewater and construction started at the Mountain View Corporate Center, which could expand to six large office buildings in Basking Ridge.
Pharmacia and Upjohn, with headquarters down the street from the Hills, plans to complete its merger with Monsanto Company in a few months, at which point employees from Monsanto's pharmaceutical operations will move in from St. Louis.
Mr. Alles said he was seeing some of the transferees. They have generous relocation packages, and they are looking for big new houses.

 CORRECTION:
The main front-page headline in the New Jersey section today refers imprecisely to the state's wealth and differs from the statistic in the article. New Jersey is not the richest state in the nation. It is second to Connecticut in personal per capita income, though higher in median household income.
An article on March 12 about population growth in central New Jersey misidentified two developments being built by Toll Brothers in Jackson and Monroe Townships. While open only to buyers 55 and older, they are not assisted living complexes.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1477 words

HEADLINE: With Applications Jumping, Going Private Gets Tougher;
Strong Demand Means Independent Schools Are Becoming More Picky

BYLINE: By MARY ANNE CHUTE LYNCH 

 BODY:
LIISA WALSH, 14, of West Hartford began applying to private high schools in October, attending open houses, taking the four-hour Secondary School Admission Test, being interviewed by admissions counselors, and obtaining teacher recommendations.
The eighth grader spent January completing applications for Miss Porter's School, a boarding school for girls in Farmington, and Kingswood-Oxford School, a coeducational day school. 
 Liisa's is one of the estimated 350 applications Miss Porter's has received for the 64 freshman seats next fall.
Kingswood-Oxford received 200 applications for its 30 openings. At Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, 22 applicants from around the world, including South Africa, Thailand and France, showed up for interviews on Jan. 13 after a snowstorm that was bad enough to close schools throughout the state.
The students are among the increasing number of eighth graders seeking limited seats in the state's private high schools. Admissions directors said they have been sorting through 8 to 25 percent more applications and handling up to 70 percent more inquiries than last year. Hopkins School in New Haven received 440 applications, up 10 percent from last year's 400, and Taft School in Watertown had 1,230 applicants compared to 1,142 last school year. The increasing interest has enabled college preparatory schools to be more selective in whom they admit.
And many applicants are about to find out if they have made the cut. Most schools sent out their acceptance letters on Friday.
"This year is a definite jump up" in applications, said Dana Blanchard, admissions director at Hopkins School, a coeducational day school. "It is pretty ubiquitous with just about everybody all over the country." The costs of the schools are going up, too. Margaret Goldsborough, spokeswoman for the National Association of Independent Schools, said private high schools in New England, New York and New Jersey continue to cost more than schools in the rest of the country. The median tuition for day students in private high schools in New England is $16,200, with the range being $5,850 to $21,100. Five years ago the median cost in New England was $12,208 for day students and $20,535 for boarding. The current median boarding rate is $25,900, with the range from $15,500 to $29,690.
Admissions offices said the strong economy is certainly responsibile for the increase in applications, with more and more people being able to afford the schools. The National Center for Educational Statistics in the federal Department of Education said the increased number is mostly due to the baby boomlet, or baby boom echo, because they are the children of baby boomers. These children are now moving through late elementary, junior high and early high school grades.
The federal Education Department estimates enrollment in public high schools will increase 8 percent by 2008. The number of students in Connecticut's private secondary schools rose to 9,127 from 8,500 between 1992 and 1998, and Catholic high schools have reported higher enrollments over the last eight years, said Barbara Keebler at the National Catholic Educational Association in Washington, D.C. In fact, the Association of Boarding Schools said that 1 in 6 boys and 1 in 10 girls at boarding high schools in the United States go to school in Connecticut.
"The demand for seats far exceeds supply," said Margaret Goldsborough, spokeswoman for the National Association of Independent Schools.
For eighth graders the application process can be a lot of work. Theresa and Jennifer Lamontagne, 13, twin sisters from Bloomfield, applied to four schools: Suffield Academy, Westminster School in Simsbury, Loomis Chaffee and Kingswood-Oxford. They did rough drafts of the four-page applications.
"Some of them were a little bit more involved," said Theresa Lamontagne. "It took a while.
The girls' mother, Marilyn Lamontagne, said her daughters wanted to go to boarding school, but she restricted them to Connecticut. "I have enough problem with them going an hour away," she said.
Demand may be up, but unlike public schools, which must often build additions to accommodate a growing student body, most private schools don't have any plans to make room for more students. The schools pride themselves on small classes and the individual attention students receive.
"The huge majority of schools are absolutely at max enrollment and most schools are constrained not to exceed a certain size," said Peter Tacy, director of the Connecticut Association of Independent Schools.
Greenwich Academy, for example, has been at full enrollment for the last seven years and has "no plans to expand," said Patsy Howard, the headmistress. Choate Rosemary Hall and Kingswood-Oxford have actually shrunk, cutting their admissions by 200 students in the last 10 years.
Brunswick School in Greenwich is an exception, opening a new middle school in September, a move that will make room for 20 to 40 more high school students.
The increased demand has led some schools to tighten their academic requirements and made them less tolerant of behavior lapses of enrolled students.
The current crop of freshmen at the Taft School scored in the 80-90th percentile range nationally on the Secondary School Admission Test, said Frederick Wandelt, admissions director for the coeducational boarding school. At Choate, the freshmen had a 3.8 grade-point average and similar exam scores, a leap from the 3.2 grade-point average of the late 80's, said Charlotte Murphy, a school spokeswoman.
"Ninety-eight percent of applicants can do the work and admissions committee meetings get heated," said Tom Southworth, admissions director at Loomis Chaffee School, a coeducational boarding high school in Windsor. The admissions staff must examine not only academic qualifications but also exceptional athletic, artistic or leadership skills of the applicants.
"You end up turning away a lot of qualified applicants," said Mr. Blanchard at Hopkins.
Despite the huge demand, schools continue to recruit. "For a long time, private schools were pretty quiet about our existence and didn't do much outreach," said Mr. Southworth. About 15 years ago, many schools changed how they recruited. "We've tried to make the student population as reflective as could be of the national population," he said, and to let people know "we were not just available for the sons and daughters of alumni."
Applicants to the state's private schools come from across the United States, particularly Florida, California and Texas, where wealth, large cities and a base of students had been built up in the past, said Ms. Murphy. Kingswood-Oxford has students commuting from 55 towns in Connecticut; Choate has boarders from 40 countries and 40 states; Taft even has students from Vietnam.
Financial aid is given to 28 percent of the students at Loomis Chaffee and to 41 percent of the pupils at Miss Porter's, which lists Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and Laura Rockerfeller among its alumnae. "We have this huge commitment to having a balanced student body," said Rebecca Ballard, admissions director at Miss Porter's, where 18 percent of the students are minorities and 11 percent are from outside the United States.
Stephen Quish of West Hartford has three children in private schools. "I think it is a good investment in my kids," he said.
His oldest daughter, Sarah, is a sophomore at Kingswood-Oxford and her sister, Amanda, is applying for the freshman class. His son Steve is in sixth grade at Kingswood-Oxford.
"So far, for Sarah, the school has been excellent," Mr. Quish said. "She is hard-working, self-motivated and gets a lot out of the school."
Paul Rudd of Greenwich said he thought that private school would be best for his daughter, Kathryn, 13, who is an eighth grader at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, an all-girls day school in Greenwich. She said she wants to remain there for high school. "They know you better in a private school," she said.
After six years of coeducation, Kathryn said she found that "an all-girls school makes learning so much easier." "If you make a mistake, you wouldn't feel as awkward in a class with all females."
Steve Richard, 14, of Harwinton, a freshman at Taft, sought a boarding school because his public school didn't have a football team and Taft offered him financial aid, his three favorite sports and an academic challenge. One of the hardest adjustments in boarding school is "making my bed every morning," he said.
Now that most acceptance letters have been sent out, the students who have been selected will be invited to attend classes before the April deposit is due. There they will find out about such things as mandatory Saturday classes, busing cafeteria tables, dress codes and, of course, making their own beds.

PUB-DATE: March 13, 2000

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1931 words

HEADLINE: An Iconoclast Goes It Alone;
On the Net PSINet's Schrader Is A Force to Reckon With

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Consider it a classic Bill Schrader moment.
At a big telecommunications convention in Geneva last October, William L. Schrader, chairman of PSINet Inc., the biggest independent Internet service provider, announced that PSINet had just struck a deal to offer high-speed Internet access in Europe. The partner, he said, was Winstar Communications Inc., an American wireless carrier, allowing PSINet to bypass the Continent's traditional phone systems. 
 Trouble was, Winstar's top executives in New York knew nothing about a deal with PSINet.
"Maybe Bill was predicting the future," William L. Rouhana Jr., Winstar's chairman, said lightheartedly in an interview last week, noting that his company had never announced such an agreement.
All Mr. Schrader would say, by way of explanation, was that PSINet had indeed negotiated a European deal with Winstar. "The fact that Rouhana didn't know isn't my problem," he said.
Odd? Bizarre even? From another chairman at another company, perhaps. But for Mr. Schrader, it was simply business as usual.
In building PSINet from its modest roots in upstate New York to an international Internet powerhouse with a market value of $7.3 billion, he has never been afraid to be a bit ahead of himself -- or to risk alienating a potential partner. In fact, PSINet and Winstar are in preliminary discussions about working together, according to executives close to those talks.
Mr. Schrader, whose hobbies include target shooting, is an executive who often fires from the hip, so to speak, aiming verbal shots at allies and enemies alike and establishing a reputation as perhaps the most iconoclastic executive of his stature in the communications industry.
PSINet, with fiber optic lines around the globe, some of the world's most advanced Internet systems and a fast-growing customer base, looms as a highly attractive acquisition candidate -- one whose shares are up nearly 300 percent since October, as investors have noted its potential takeover value. It is the biggest of the Internet access providers not already snatched up by telephone companies looking to expand into cyberspace.
But PSINet has been valuable for years. And Mr. Schrader, who owns 7.45 percent of the company, has always refused to sell, sometimes leaving prospective buyers to walk away wondering if he is shrewd or headstrong -- or both.
"I think the real reason PSINet is still independent is Bill Schrader," said Richard G. Ellenberger, chief executive of Broadwing Inc., the former Cincinnati Bell. Broadwing recently filed to reduce its stake in PSINet to about 11 percent but would still be its largest shareholder. "He has built it from the ground up, and he's not through. He believes he's one of the new age of executive leaders, and he's not ready to quit."
Mr. Schrader, 48, may not be ready to quit because he has already come so far. A biologist by training, he was a co-founder in 1985 of one of the first Internet operations, called Nysernet, which initially linked academic computing centers in the cold reaches of upstate New York. In 1989, when for-profit activity was still ostensibly banned from the government-financed Internet, he founded what was then called Performance Systems International, moving it to northern Virginia to be closer to the federal agencies then overseeing the Internet.
PSINet was not only one of the first providers of Internet access service but one of the most innovative. In 1995, for instance, PSINet was a pioneer in offering unlimited Internet service at a fixed monthly fee to consumers across the nation. The pricing was set in typical Schrader fashion.
"I remember when I asked him how they chose what to charge for the flat fee," Mr. Ellenberger said. "And he said, 'Well, it was 1995 so we chose $19.95, and $19.95 sounded good to us.' And I asked him, 'You didn't do any economic modeling?' And he said, 'Nope.' "
Since then, PSINet's tactical focus has changed; the company got out of the consumer Internet business in 1996, selling its consumer unit to Mindspring Enterprises so it could focus on serving business customers and acting as a carrier's carrier for smaller Internet service providers. More recently, instead of merely providing raw Internet links, PSINet has begun to add more advanced and lucrative services by managing Web servers and computer systems that deliver corporate software applications across networks.
But the company's ultimate goal has remained constant. "I would like to build a system," Mr. Schrader said, "that can deliver all the media to all the customers on earth."
Harold S. Wills, PSINet's president and chief operating officer and a former executive at I.B.M. and Xerox, first met Mr. Schrader in the spring of 1996. "I thought he was crazy," Mr. Wills said, recalling his job interview.
"Bill said, 'We're going to kill the phone companies, and we're going to be bigger than AT&T, and it will be a lot of fun.' And I said, 'How much revenue have you got?' and he said, 'Well, last year we had $35 million.' And I said, 'Well, how are you going to do what you want to do?' And he began to explain in ways that I hadn't understood before the power of the Internet."
Many other people did not understand either. PSINet's stock traded below $10 throughout 1996, 1997 and 1998. It was not until last year, when PSINet generated more than $550 million in revenue, that investors began climbing onto the PSINet bandwagon as a way to play the growth of the Internet.
And to ride the PSINet bandwagon is to hear none of the bland modulations of boardroom-speak.
One recent day, as he drove his silver-gray Lincoln Town Car (he also owns a Porsche Boxster) from PSINet's headquarters in Herndon, Va., to one of the company's nearby network centers, Mr. Schrader was asked about one of his competitors, John W. Sidgmore. Mr. Sidgmore runs UUNet, the No. 1 Internet carrier, which is now part of MCI WorldCom and is also based in northern Virginia.
"In terms of where the market's going, we see eye to eye," Mr. Schrader said. "But John is a typical executive who will say what he thinks people want to hear and I'm not."
(In an interview later, Mr. Sidgmore said, "I'm willing to bet that on Bill's report card in sixth grade it said something like, 'Doesn't play well with others.' ")
And do not even get Mr. Schrader started on Stephen M. Case, chairman of America Online and another Virginia neighbor.
"Mr. Case is a perfect example of someone who misrepresents the truth for his own interest," Mr. Schrader said as he drove.
He cited what he saw as America Online's about-face, after it agreed to acquire Time Warner, on the need for the government to regulate the delivery of Internet data over cable television systems. Before the deal, America Online had called for a government role; after hooking up with Time Warner, the nation's second-largest operator of cable systems, many people in the industry perceived America Online as changing its stance.
"I don't like hypocrites, and Mr. Case is a hypocrite," Mr. Schrader said. He peered over the wheel, then added: "He is a self-serving businessman who's into hypocrisy and I'm not. That's why he decided to stop competing against us as an Internet service provider and get into the content business."
In a statement responding to those comments, America Online said, "Mr. Case's position on open access has been consistent from day one."
Mr. Schrader reserves his deepest ire, however, for local telephone incumbents, which he says are monopolists holding back the digital future. Bashing the Bell companies is hardly unusual among smaller communications carriers, but Mr. Schrader's company must also deal with the Bells on a daily basis, renting their local communications lines in order to reach customers.
He is particularly outspoken about Bell Atlantic, the East Coast giant with which PSINet does a significant amount of business. "I call them 'Bell Atlantis,' " Mr. Schrader said, still dishing as he drove. "Bell Atlantis is dead. They cannot exist in tomorrow. We know the customer better than they do and they can't keep up."
Why lash out at a such an important supplier?
"Because I'm honest," Mr. Schrader said. Referring to Bell Atlantic's chairman, he said, "It's not in my best interest to tell you that Ivan Seidenberg is a poor manager of a multibillion-dollar company, because they're our major supplier."
Asked for a corporate response, Susan Kraus, a Bell Atlantic spokeswoman, replied: "This is not even worth commenting on but I'll say this. Consider the source. It's hard to take anything he says seriously. This guy has a long history of making irrational statements and taking gratuitous potshots at his competitors."
Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of Mr. Schrader's blunt style is that it has not prevented him from garnering the deep respect of his peers, even those he does not treat gently. As someone who spoke up for and invested in the Internet early and often, Mr. Schrader is considered by many to be one of the handful of true Internet visionaries.
"He has enormous courage and he's as smart as a fox," said George H. Conrades, chairman of Akamai Technologies and former chairman of BBN, one of the big three early independent Internet companies, along with UUNet and PSINet. "I admire him," Mr. Conrades said.
Mr. Sidgmore of UUNet also offered a compliment of sorts. "I'm a big supporter of Bill's, as wacky as he is," Mr. Sidgmore said. "Whatever else you say, good or bad, he is steadfastly committed to his vision for the company."
In fact, Mr. Sidgmore said, "I would not be surprised if you read soon that we will do some investments together."
Perhaps because of all he has built, Mr. Schrader has been reluctant to sell, despite the hundreds of millions or billions of dollars a deal could bring him, considering his personal stake in PSINet.
The last few years, Internet providers of all size and description have been snatched up by more traditional communications companies. UUNet agreed to be acquired by MFS Communications in 1996 just before MFS was acquired by WorldCom. In 1997, BBN was acquired by GTE.
That has essentially left PSINet holding out against assimilation with the communications giants. Deutsche Telekom, for instance, has explored acquiring PSInet, but those discussions were strictly preliminary. Far more likely to be suitors are the new breed of communications carrier in the United States, companies like Level 3, Qwest, Broadwing and Nextlink.
"I've tried to buy PSINet at least 10 times over the last few years," Mr. Sidgmore said. "Right after MFS bought us we tried to buy him. I tried after WorldCom. I tried a bunch of times and he would never sell."
Invariably, it comes down to Mr. Schrader being Mr. Schrader. "He always had the opinion that PSInet is worth 10 times whatever his stock price is," Mr. Sidgmore said.
One reason that other Internet companies have sold out -- beyond the financial incentives -- has been their executives' notion that integrating into a bigger company can give them access to a broader set of customers.
Mr. Wills, PSINet's No. 2 executive, takes a bit more pragmatic view. "Some day, they will buy us and we will be sold, and my job is to make it more expensive for them every day that they wait," he said. "What they could have bought for $200 million, they will now probably have to pay $20 billion for."
Ask Mr. Schrader about selling his company -- well, maybe it's better not to ask. "Why should I sell the company?" he said, bristling. "Tell me."

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Down 13% in Month

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
United States orders for tools that make manufacturing parts fell in January, with decreases in the Northeast, the South and the Midwest, according to an industry survey.
Machine tool orders declined 13 percent to an estimated $432 million from $494 million in December, a joint report of the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association said. 
 Still, January orders were 5 percent higher than a year earlier. And that gave some hope to an industry that has slumped the last two years. "On the heels of a disappointing 1999, the industry is optimistic for growth in 2000 as January orders reflect positive activity" said Ralph Nappi, president of the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association.
Orders fell 28 percent in 1999 to $5.6 billion, after falling 38.7 percent in 1998. The Standard & Poor's machine tool stock index has fallen 46 percent since January 1998.
Analysts watch the monthly order report since it gauges investment in manufacturing capacity and production. Other evidence, though, suggests that manufacturing will pick up in the months ahead.
Manufacturing increased in February at its fastest pace in four months, paced by export and production gains, a survey showed. The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index increased to 56.9 for the month from a January reading of 56.3.

HEADLINE: A Bit Nervously, Theater Row Packs Up

BYLINE: By JULIAN E. BARNES 

 BODY:
In the late 1970's when Times Square belonged to the prostitutes and peep shows, a collection of theater companies moved into a handful of stages carved out of shuttered massage parlors on West 42nd Street.
In the years that followed the theaters suffered through stickups, recessions and aborted development projects and survived to see a renewed Midtown rise around them. 
 But now the redevelopment of 42nd Street is altering the theaters' future. The local development corporation that helped create the strip now known as Theater Row is closing four of the playhouses as it prepares to break ground on an apartment tower and collection of new stages between Dyer and Ninth Avenues. There are no definite plans for the western half of Theater Row, between Dyer and 10th Avenues, but the property owners and the theater companies that make their homes there say development is inevitable.
Although actors and stagehands are eagerly anticipating working in the new spaces that will rise on Theater Row, many said they would miss the idiosyncrasies of their current homes. Others fear that the most experimental theaters, which are also generally the poorest, will be pushed out of the neighborhood.
"I would moan about the lousy dressing rooms, but there is something that is very actor-friendly and theater-friendly about these spaces," said Anita Keal, who performs in "The Countess," a play about a 19th-century love affair. The show plans to move to Lamb's Theater on West 44th Street after its current home, the Samuel Beckett Theater, closes on Sunday.
As Ms. Keal spoke, crew members preparing the stage for the next performance offered their assessments of the theater, with its slightly-too-small stage, oddly sloping ceiling and unpredictable heat.
"It's got its quirks," said Juliet King, the assistant stage manager.
Ralph Carhart, the master electrician, added, "But the quirks are what give it its charm."
Playwrights Horizons, a nonprofit theater company, opened the first stage on the strip in 1975. Three years later the 42nd Street Development Corporation opened several more theaters in an attempt to use the performing arts to renew a desolate block. The development corporation offered inexpensive, often below-market rents to theater groups, which in return stabilized the neighborhood and brought in new, paying visitors. Theater Row became one of the early successes in the continuing effort to reinvigorate 42nd Street.
Of the eight playhouses on Theater Row, Playwrights Horizons has been the most significant, giving a start to Broadway productions like "Driving Miss Daisy," "Sunday in the Park With George" and most recently, "James Joyce's 'The Dead.' " Other theaters have also had success. "Nunsense" ran for nine years at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater.
"There was a sense of purpose; we were united on this bizarre block of Manhattan," said Andre Bishop, who worked at Playwrights Horizons from 1975 to 1991 and is now the artistic director at the Lincoln Center Theater. "Real estate gentrification was the last thing on our minds. We were just putting on plays."
But the theaters did renew the neighborhood, and now the more recent Midtown boom has opened the way for more lucrative development. The first theaters to be affected will be the four owned by the development corporation: the Theater Row, Judith Anderson, Harold Clurman and Beckett Theaters.
All four will close this month to make way for the redevelopment project. Although the contracts are not complete, the developement corporation is planning to rebuild much of the block between Ninth and Dyer Avenues and create four 99-seat stages, a 199-seat theater, a 499-seat playhouse co-owned by the Shubert Organization and an apartment tower. Some theater hands wonder aloud if the nonprofit theaters that built the row will return.
"The theaters held that area together when no one wanted to go there," said Tom Herman, who has directed shows at the Beckett and at the Pulse Ensemble Theater. "But it will be difficult for the small producers to get back into Theater Row."
Fred Papert, president of the development corporation, disputed that prediction. The proposed theaters will continue to offer discounted, affordable space to nonprofit theater productions and will not change what has made Theater Row a vibrant artistic community, he said.
"There is something that is nice and cozy about Theater Row, and that is not going to disappear," he said. "It will be just as it has always been."
But the current weekly rent for nonprofit groups, $1,800, will probably rise when the the old, worn stages are replaced with new, well-equipped performance areas, Mr. Papert acknowledged. It is also unclear how much office space will be available in the new complex for nonprofit groups to rent.
The Jewish Theater of New York has until next Monday to move its offices from Theater Row, and Tuvia Tenenbom, the artistic director, is desperately hunting for a new home. The real strength of Theater Row, Mr. Tenenbom said, was that it gave small companies access to a mainstream, suburban audience that the small downtown stages have a harder time attracting.
"On 42nd Street you get a different audience, people from New Jersey and Long Island," he said. "Here we were trying to convince the general public that pure theater isn't dead." Mr. Tenenbom said he feared that the Jewish Theater would have trouble finding the money to rent the new stages.
"It will be all commercial; it will be Merrill Lynch in the theater," he said. "It is sad. It is a little bit of the death of the theater."
Not everyone agrees. Max Ferra brought the Intar Hispanic-American Arts Center to Theater Row in 1978, leaving last year to make way for the renovation. But he said that he had been promised space in the new complex and that he believed it would attract a bigger audience and help his organization grow. "We will be part of the new 42nd Street," he said. "It will be a complete uplift of the whole street from east to west."
Ben Sprecher, the Off Broadway theater manager who will run the new 499-seat theater, said the larger theater would bring a new, bigger audience to the smaller theaters.
"We are building an ideally suited playhouse for plays and small musicals," he said. "Off Broadway is entering into what people think of as mainstream."
Although there are no specific plans for the block between Dyer and 10th Avenues, tenants there are on short-term or month-to-month leases. William J. Condren, the general partner of Theater Row Phase 2, which controls the property, said he anticipated conducting a beauty pageant among developers interested in building on the land. "Mr. Right hasn't shown up yet," he said.
But some of the theater companies on the block worry that Mr. Right will come along shortly. Alexa Kelly, the artistic director of the Pulse Ensemble Theater at 432 West 42nd Street, said she feared her company would lose its space.
"We have worked very hard to help the community, and now we are feeling very upset that we are just being ousted," Ms. Kelly said.
Eric Krebs, the owner of the John Houseman and Fairbanks Theaters, said his stages would remain open at least two more years. He said he hoped that whoever was chosen to rebuild the block between Dyer and 10th Avenues would create new spaces for Off Broadway theater.
"It is inevitable that the whole block will be changed," Mr. Krebs said. "The only hope is that the Off Broadway need will be met and the vision will be realized with a string of theaters along 42nd Street."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Berkshire Hathaway considers buying back some of its own shares.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
WARREN E. BUFFETT is not particularly enamored of the stocks that Berkshire Hathaway now owns, even though they have declined substantially in price. But he has found a stock he thinks is cheap -- one that Berkshire may begin buying soon: Berkshire Hathaway's own shares.
Last year was a dreadful one for Berkshire. Its major 1998 acquisition, General Re, had poor results and many of the stocks in the portfolio that brought fame and wealth to Mr. Buffett, the Berkshire chairman and chief executive, lost value even while the overall market was rising. Over all, Berkshire reported profits of $1.56 billion, or $1,025 a share, in 1999, down from $2.83 billion, or $2,262 a share a year earlier. 
 As a result, Berkshire's Class A stock fell during the year for the first time since 1990, and it has continued to fall this year, closing Friday at $41,300, less than half the $84,000 peak it reached in June 1998.
In a letter to shareholders in Berkshire's annual report, released over the weekend, Mr. Buffett again warned that stock prices are generally very high, reflecting investors' "wildly optimistic" expectations. As for the companies in which Berkshire has large positions, "the prices of the fine businesses we already own are just not that attractive," he wrote. "That's why we haven't added to our present holdings."
Berkshire has never bought back any of its own shares, and Mr. Buffett said that he thinks that share repurchases are often done by companies interested in pumping up the price of their shares even though they are already overvalued and buying back shares will, in the long run, hurt those shareholders who stay.
But Mr. Buffett said that when the share price fell below $45,000 in February, he considered making purchases, but decided against doing so until shareholders could be told of the possibility. The February plunge came on rumors regarding Mr. Buffett's health. The price soon recovered when those rumors were denied, but in recent days it has begun falling again.
By setting a price below which he deems the shares attractive, Mr. Buffett may have provided some support for the stock even if the company does not make purchases. "I view it as an I.Q. test for investors," said Alice Shroeder, an analyst for PaineWebber. "If Warren Buffett is a buyer, would you be a buyer or a seller?"
That comment reflects Mr. Buffett's legendary status as an investor. It is a reputation that has made Berkshire's annual meeting something of a pilgrimage for thousands of investors -- so much so that this year's annual meeting is being held on a Saturday, rather than on a Monday as in past years, because Mr. Buffett feared the crowds would tie up traffic in downtown Omaha if it were held on a weekday.
But Mr. Buffett's recent performance as a money manager leaves something to be desired, as he wrote in his letter to shareholders. Mr. Buffett has long measured his performance against the Standard & Poor's 500 index. It gained 19.5 percent last year, not including dividends, while Berkshire's book value, largely reflecting the value of the investments, rose just 0.5 percent.
"We had the worst absolute performance of my tenure and, compared to the S. & P., the worst relative performance as well," Mr. Buffett wrote in the company's annual report, released Saturday. "Even Inspector Clouseau could find the guilty party: your chairman."
Among the company's seven largest investments at the beginning of 1999, only one -- American Express -- rose as much as the S. & P. did during the year. Two others, The Washington Post Company and Wells Fargo, showed more modest gains, and four declined: Coca-Cola, Walt Disney, Freddie Mac and Gillette. During 1999, Mr. Buffett did not add to any of the positions. He appears to have sold all -- or at least most -- of the Disney stake and to have made smaller sales of Wells Fargo and Freddie Mac shares. So far this year, all of the six still held have gone down in price, while Disney has recovered.
Historically, Mr. Buffett has avoided technology investments. "We share the general view that society will be transformed by their products and services," he wrote in the annual report. "Our problem -- which we can't solve by studying up -- is that we have no insights into which participants in the tech field posess a truly durable competitive advantage."
Early last year, Berkshire did invest in Microsoft preferred stock that was later converted to common stock. If the company still owns that stock -- and Mr. Buffett did not discuss it in his letter -- it would be worth $19 million now. But that is a small amount relative to Berkshire's six major equity investments, whose market value at the end of last year ranged from $960 million for The Washington Post to $11.7 billion for Coca-Cola.
Over all, Berkshire Hathaway remains very much an "old economy" company. Its major business is insurance, as the owner of a number of companies including Geico, an auto insurer that has been gaining market share and in the process making life harder for other insurers with higher cost structures. In 1998, Berkshire Hathaway bought General Re, which suffered an underwriting loss of $1.2 billion last year. Mr. Buffett blamed industry conditions, but said there were signs that pricing of reinsurance policies was starting to rise.
Mr. Buffett said the company's other operations generally performed well, with the exception of its shoe business. As the owner of Dexter and H. H. Brown, Berkshire is now the largest shoe manufacturer in the country -- a dubious distinction given the decline of that industry. He said the company was trying to maintain American operations, but had shifted some production to other countries.

HEADLINE: Fiat Weighs Sale to G.M. Of a Stake In Auto Line

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER with ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 12

 BODY:
Fiat is close to selling a minority stake in its car operations to General Motors after apparently failing to sell the entire division to DaimlerChrysler, auto industry officials and executives close to the talks said today.
Fiat's board is scheduled to meet on Monday to review the proposed transaction with G.M. and is fairly likely to approve a deal, industry and other executives said today after insisting on anonymity. 
 But the meeting could last into Tuesday, and the board might ask its negotiators to continue working beyond then, especially if DaimlerChrysler comes back with a more attractive proposal at the last moment, they said.
Newspapers in Italy, where the troubles of Fiat's car division have been a long-running national story, reported today that Fiat would hand over a 20 percent stake in its car operations in exchange for a 5 percent stake in G.M. and possibly a seat on G.M.'s board. The transaction would also involve some sharing of engines and auto parts and Fiat's use of the Internet buying service for parts that G.M., DaimlerChrysler and Ford Motor are setting up, the papers reported. But auto industry officials said today that these and other provisions of the deal were still being worked out.
Foreign Trade Minister Piero Fassino of Italy said that some alliance between Fiat and a foreign carmaker was "an inevitable move." He told La Repubblica, a daily in Rome, that "whoever wishes to hold on to Fiat in its present form risks marginalizing it further and further."
G.M., DaimlerChrysler and Fiat representatives declined to comment.
If Fiat sells part or all of its car business, it is likely to focus on its profitable divisions, which make heavy trucks and tractors. Fiat is considering whether to make a bid for Volvo A. B., the world's second-largest maker of heavy trucks, executives close to the company said today. Fiat had tried unsuccessfully last year to buy all of the Swedish company, which decided instead to sell its car-building division to Ford and focus only on heavy trucks.
The European Commission is widely expected to use antitrust concerns to block Volvo's $7.4 billion acquisition of Scania, Sweden's other big truck maker. If the commission does so, Volvo would be a ripe target for a takeover, and Fiat might make an unsolicited offer, the executives said.
For its part, Volvo has made preliminary contact with several rivals including Renault's truck unit about a possible combination, the executives said, though talks are not expected to begin in earnest until the European Commission makes its final ruling.
Fiat, Italy's largest company with investments across many industries, has been struggling for nearly a year with the question of what to do with its car operations, which have been gradually losing market share in Italy and in Europe for years. Having publicly adopted the General Electric Company's management philosophy of abandoning markets in which it does not hold a commanding market share, Fiat has courted every big automaker in the world in recent months in search of an alliance or buyer for its car operations. Fiat still sells Ferraris in the United States but stopped selling new Fiat brand cars here in 1983.
Fiat's attractions are its strong market share in South America, its shrunken but still large market share in Italy and its lineup of freshly redesigned small cars, auto executives have said in interviews in recent months. While Fiat held 11 percent of the European market last year, it had nearly 38 percent of the Italian market last year and 30 percent of the promising Brazilian market.
And while the small-car market around the world is extremely unprofitable because manufacturers in South Korea and other recently industrialized countries are producing too many of them, rising oil prices are beginning to reawaken auto manufacturers' interest in the market segment.
But potential buyers have been leery of Fiat's reputation for overstaffed, inefficient factories in Italy, with powerful unions and mediocre quality.
The Italian government's recent enthusiasm for a Fiat deal with a foreign automaker has sparked hope that government money might be used to help unionized workers retire, allowing Fiat to slim down its factory work forces, said an American executive who insisted on anonymity.
G.M. has embarked on a global strategy of tying itself to midsize automakers with large stakes in their home markets or with valuable technology. In Japan, it has long had minority stakes in Isuzu and Suzuki and a technology alliance with Toyota Motor. This winter it took a stake in Fuji Heavy Industries, which makes Subaru cars and is a leader in all-wheel-drive technology, and agreed to start buying six-cylinder engines from Honda.
G.M. announced in early January that it was exercising an option to buy the half of Sweden's Saab that it did not already own. And in a single week in mid-January, the company entered into marketing partnerships with Sony, America Online and NetZero.
John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman, articulated the new strategy in a speech on Jan. 17, repudiating the company's nearly century-old strategy of self-reliance.
"Our approach is to develop long-term relationships with other companies that offer a unique advantage to the General Motors group of brands and businesses," Mr. Smith said then. "This alliance strategy is our major thrust, and it is clearly a different approach to growth than most people have associated with General Motors -- or with the rest of the industry, for that matter."
G.M. has been losing market share rapidly in the small-car segment in the United States to Korean producers and recently canceled plans to redesign the small Chevrolet Cavalier because it could not figure out how to make a profit on it. Even G.M.'s Saturn unit has been cutting back output because of slow sales.
DaimlerChrysler has also been looking for alliances and acquisitions lately, both to penetrate difficult markets and to respond to regulatory pressures.
Because its Mercedes and Chrysler divisions both make fairly large cars and sport utility vehicles, DaimlerChrysler faces difficulties in meeting the tighter fuel-economy requirements planned by the European Community, and has been looking for ways to increase its share of the small car market as a result.
Like G.M., DaimlerChrysler also needs to sell more small cars so as to lure younger, less affluent buyers to its brands.

HEADLINE: Cheap Oil's Tough Bargains

BYLINE: By Robert A. Mosbacher; Robert A. Mosbacher, chairman of the Mosbacher Energy Company and former chairman of the National Petroleum Council, was commerce secretary under President George Bush.

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
The press has trumpeted the news that crude oil prices are three times higher than they were a year ago. But it was the $10 or $11 price of February 1999, not the one today, that really deserved the headlines.
When inflation is taken into account, that 1999 price was the lowest in modern history, while oil has gone above today's seemingly high price several times. And for the past 14 years, at $17.50, oil has been one of the real bargains of the modern age. 
 The low price has been a mixed blessing. In the United States, we have lost over 500,000 jobs in the oil industry while we have grossly increased our dependency on foreign oil; we now import 55 percent of what we use. With little incentive for drillers to find and tap new oil, supplies eventually dropped, and in the past year the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries deliberately dropped its production as well. In response to the law of supply and demand, prices have now risen.
A high oil price is not the inflationary threat it once was because with the shift toward the information and services economy, and away from manufacturing, the United States is less dependent on oil. But try to tell a consumer paying to heat his home, a trucker moving goods across the country or a commuter who goes by car that oil and gasoline are not major factors in the economy, and the answer is likely to be, "It feels like I'm being ripped off."
American consumers have been lulled into thinking cheap oil is their entitlement. Syndicated columnist Carl T. Rowan wrote recently: "We are truly a spoiled society! We insist on driving gas guzzlers and using a grossly disproportionate amount of the world's energy, and we believe we should forever be able to do so at bargain rates."
Sooner or later, oil prices are likely to drop. But prices at today's level have their advantages. With the incentive for more production back in place, there will be more drilling in new places, like the deep water off the coasts of many countries of the world, including the United States. Off our Gulf Coast, deep-water drilling, developing and producing are already going on.
Remarkable new technology now allows pipelines to bring oil from miles out to sea, where the water is as much as 8,000 feet deep. The ubiquitous deep waters of the world have great potential for additional oil and gas reserves, but drilling in 5,000 to 10,000 feet of water and then through many thousands of feet of sand, shale and other formations makes for huge costs. In many cases, this kind of oil production can only be justified by prices of at least $25 to $30 a barrel.
A higher price also encourages development of other new technologies already on the horizon, including three-dimensional seismology for mapping and horizontal drilling. And $30 oil also brings attention back to development of synthetic fuel, solar energy, wind power, gasification of coal and other methods of producing energy.
Some members of Congress have been lobbying for taking oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to help bring prices down, and President Clinton recently announced he is not ruling this out. But these reserves are set aside for use in an emergency, and tapping them is only justified if there is a genuine threat of a supply interruption, as there might be in a war or political crisis.
The reserve holds about 570 million barrels, not much when we use about 19.4 million barrels of oil products daily. Even releasing all of it could be only a temporary solution to a price problem. Tapping it would also signal the main oil-producing countries that we were trying to control world energy prices, which is inconsistent with our normal free and fair trade policies.
Even if the control of oil prices were in American hands, which it is not (since we have no means of influencing it other than using our reserves or jawboning OPEC), we would still face a daunting decision. Would we be better off getting prices back under $20 a barrel to prevent any oil-influenced inflation today, or should we take the longer view and let today's price work to bring about more drilling and new interest in other sources of energy?
Simple realities argue for the latter course: In the long term, even if bent by cartels, the law of supply and demand will rule. And in the long term, we will need the new sources of energy that higher prices can bring. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
The Magic Blue Blazer vs. an Oily Patch of Bad Luck

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE lucky blue blazer is at home in the closet. Energy Secretary Bill Richardson last wore the raggedy 15-year-old Brooks Brothers jacket when he was jetting across the Middle East last month, trying to convince Saudi Arabia and Kuwait that the dramatic jump in oil prices was threatening the world economy.
The blazer became his sartorial trademark early in the Clinton administration -- when he was a diplomatic troubleshooter while a member of Congress, freeing American hostages from Iraq to North Korea to Sudan -- and later as American ambassador to the United Nations. 
 Last month, he said, the jacket proved its value once more; the Saudis and the Kuwaitis said they would examine their production levels, interpreted as a commitment to reopen the spigot for oil, if only slightly.
"Does it work? Sure, it works," Mr. Richardson said as his limousine sped across town on Friday afternoon, carrying him to a television studio for yet another interview to explain the administration's plans to drive down crude oil prices that have tripled over the last year. "I wear it for all my need-to-be-lucky events."
Whatever the magical powers of his wardrobe, it is difficult to think of Mr. Richardson as lucky these days.
An hour earlier, he had been in the Oval Office with President Clinton, hashing out the next move in the mess over oil prices; a report released by the Energy Department this month said gasoline prices should hit an average of $1.75 a gallon this summer because of production cuts by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. In some states, gasoline is expected to top $2 a gallon.
"It's not my fault, but I should try to fix it," he said. "A year ago, oil inventories were high. Nobody expected this. The states didn't expect it. Consumers didn't expect it. Even traders didn't expect it. I think everybody should have been better prepared."
Mr. Richardson inherited lots of bad news when he left the United Nations to take over the Energy Department 19 months ago.
First came the reports of security lapses dating back years in the department's nuclear weapons laboratories and the accusation that Chinese spies had obtained designs for this nation's most sophisticated nuclear warheads.
Then there was the department's admission, after decades of denials, that government workers making nuclear weapons had been exposed to radiation and cancer-causing chemicals that probably led them to an early grave.
And now, the explosion in oil prices has American drivers fuming at the pump.
The run-up in gasoline prices comes at a politically awkward time for Mr. Richardson, who knows he risks becoming the government's fall guy for expensive oil just as he was reported to be under consideration as a running mate for Vice President Al Gore.
MR. RICHARDSON, 52, a collegial, slap-on-the-back politician, has long been seen as an obvious candidate for the No. 2 slot.
He is the only Hispanic in the the Cabinet, a former Democratic House leader from New Mexico with appeal to the Latino voters who are being heavily recruited by both parties in the presidential race. Born in Pasadena, Calif., he grew up in Mexico City, where his mother was born. His father, a Bostonian, worked as an executive at Citibank in Mexico for several years.
When he was a boy he was an excellent pitcher, good enough to be drafted by the Kansas City A's after high school. Instead, he went to Tufts University outside Boston, where he earned a master's degree from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy.
Few of Mr. Richardson's rivals could have failed to notice him beaming behind Mr. Gore's confetti-caked shoulder last week as the vice president gave his victory speech after sweeping the Super Tuesday primaries.
Mr. Richardson said he had nothing to do with his conspicuous placement on the podium in Nashville. "I was behind him because that's where the Gore advance people put me. There was a piece of tape that said Richardson. I didn't elbow some little old lady to get there. Somebody put me there. I was flattered."
While Mr. Richardson campaigned for the vice president in Iowa, New Hampshire and California, often before Hispanic audiences, he insisted he has no designs on the Democratic ticket.
"We haven't talked about the vice presidency, and I'm not campaigning for it," he said. "I want to discourage speculation by answering questions like this, because it appears that I'm overeager. I just think the vice president should have a full, open search."
Certainly Mr. Richardson has begun to look more like a national candidate. After five months on the protein-heavy Atkins diet ("It works, but I'm starting to get sick of it") and a daily workout with a personal trainer, he has dropped 30 pounds, bringing his weight down to 210 pounds.
Apart from the lucky blazer, his rumpled wardrobe has been discarded; he now favors tailored suits and Hermes ties. His unruly mass of black hair has been styled back. "I've cleaned up my act," he said.
He rejected the charge of overambition, which dates to his daring -- and usually successful -- hostage-rescue missions when he was an otherwise little-known member of the House.
He made headlines around the world in 1995, when he traveled to Iraq and persuaded Saddam Hussein to free two American engineers jailed there. George Stephanopoulos, the former White House aide, used to call Mr. Richardson "a diplomatic Red Adair," alluding to the famed oil-well firefighter.
Said Mr. Richardson: "I'm as ambitious as anybody else in this town, but am I excessively ambitious? No. If I don't continue in public life, I'll be very happy."
And he admitted that he might soon find himself out of a government job. He acknowledged that his chances of winning the nod as Mr. Gore's vice presidential nominee could evaporate if gas prices continued to soar.
"I realize that gasoline prices at $2 a gallon in August or September is not good," he said. "But my main responsibility is to try to fix the problem and be a good energy secretary. If it becomes a burden, so be it."

HEADLINE: A Beneficial Trade Bill

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I support Thomas L. Friedman's call for swift Congressional action on pending legislation to increase trade with the countries of sub-Saharan Africa (column, March 7). The Africa bill is linked to another trade bill worthy of support. This bill would expand access for garments assembled in the 24 countries of the Caribbean Basin Initiative. 
 The partnership between the United States and the Caribbean Basin countries currently supports more than 400,000 jobs in the United States and more throughout the Caribbean. Our textile and apparel industry will benefit from expanding this relationship because garments assembled in Caribbean Basin countries use a high concentration of American inputs. The Caribbean countries will benefit as expanded market access promotes economic development and stability in the region. Consumers will benefit because reduced import duties will keep down apparel prices.
 
JAMES C. JACOBSEN
Chairman, American Apparel
Manufacturers Association
St. Louis, March 8, 2000

HEADLINE: Don't Raise Rates

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Lawrence Kudlow's March 10 Op-Ed article, "Greenspan, Through the Looking Glass," is eminently correct. Another rise in interest rates is unneccesary. The bluest of the blue-chip companies borrow money. The price of borrowing money is a cost that must be reflected in the sale of a product. It logically follows that raising interest rates is in itself inflationary. 
 The most important factor in raising our standard of living and containing inflation is productivity. Alan Greenspan has done a superb job. He is one of the best Federal Reserve chairmen this country has had. The economy is thriving. Let's leave well enough alone.
 
HERBERT BARCHOFF
New York, March 10, 2000
 
The writer served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers in the Truman administration.
