HEADLINE: They Hope to Move Up By Learning to Log On

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 12

 BODY:
Small hands shot up when Daniel S. Varner asked his after-school class of mostly poor, mostly African-American children here, "Who can tell me what the Internet is?"
"It's like a big dictionary," said Jordan Nichols, 9. "A new way of communication," offered Stacey Blair, 12. And across the room, Terrell Brazier, 13, said, "It's a superhighway to anything you want." 
 To these children, and others like them who grow up poor, the Internet is all that and much more. It can be a path to the future, all right, but its effect may be more profound on those who don't know how to use it. With more and more jobs requiring computer and Internet literacy, experts fear that children not exposed to those skills will be left further behind in the new economy.
A couple of Detroit lawyers who wanted to keep that from happening have chucked their law careers to start an unusual program here that helps poor children join the information age. They draw hundreds of children into after-school sports leagues, then offer free computer training. The children learn not only how to use the computers, but also how to take them apart, fix them and put them together again. The trophy they take home is a hand-me-down computer -- there are enough for everyone on the sports teams.
"We knew kids needed the character that comes with team sports, and we knew they needed the tools of the future that come with access to technology," said Michael F. Tenbusch, who founded the nonprofit group Think Detroit with Mr. Varner in 1997. Early on, the group organized sports leagues for children.
At the same time, the group began setting up 17 computer laboratories in churches, schools and nonprofit agencies -- enough to serve 2,000 people last year -- filling them with used computers donated by area companies. But it became clear that closing the gap in computer access would require reaching homes.
So in November, Think Detroit switched strategies and began the Balls and Bytes program -- combining baseball, soccer and basketball leagues with computer classes for children over 10. The group has donated about 30 computers and plans to give away 200 more this summer.
Stacey Blair, a seventh grader at Westside Christian Academy, said that when she joined the group's baseball team she did not know she would also get a computer. She spends about an hour a day on it and went back to Mr. Varner's class to learn how to use the Internet.
Her first computer classes were intimidating. "I can't do this," Stacey remembered thinking. After the instructor took the machines apart and "showed us which spaces were for the motherboard and the cards," she said, "then I was like, this is pretty easy."
Statistics show children like Stacey are at risk of being bystanders in the digital age. Although virtually the same percentage of all children have some access to computers at school, poor and African-American children are far less likely to use a home computer, according to a poll conducted last month by National Public Radio, the Kaiser Family Foundation and Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government.
"Using the computer and the Internet can be such an important set of skills to be marketable for the economy," said Mollyann Brodie, a vice president of the Kaiser foundation. "Any digital divide will further exacerbate the gaps we've always had in our country between the haves and have-nots."
Detroit is a good example, because it is the nation's poorest big city. Many poor children here will not go to college. In the past, they might have had a Ford factory in their futures, at best. Now few workers with only a high school diploma can pass the tests automakers require.
Social workers say the gap may be even more acute for poor people who are already out of school and have had little contact with computers.
Carris M. Carey, a social worker at Focus: Hope, a nonprofit organization in Detroit that trains poor people to work in the auto industry, said, "The kids who are in the younger generation, the 18-to-25 range, have had some type of exposure to computers," even if it is not as much as the children of wealthy families have. But, Mr. Carey said, older poor people are seldom familiar with computers and the Internet.
That observation was echoed in the new national poll, Ms. Brodie said. "The gaps by income are just profound," she said. The poll found that 56 percent of those in the 18-40 age group earning less than $30,000 a year had a home computer, while 87 percent of those earning more than $50,000 a year had one.
Public schools here are struggling to keep up with their counterparts in school districts that are better off. All 263 schools in the district have now been wired for computer access, but not all schools have computers, particularly up-to-date ones, to attach to the wires, said Stan Childress, a spokesman for the Detroit Public Schools. "None of our schools have computers in every classroom, and that is a goal," he said.
For now, the secondhand computers from Think Detroit will help close the gap between technology haves and have-nots in two ways. First, more children each month are being given computers to take home. Second, they are teaching older family members how to use them.
Troy Brazier, a sixth grader at George Crockett Academy, a charter school here, took home one of the Think Detroit computers after playing baseball and basketball on one of the teams set up by the organization.
His mother works at a Target store and an older brother is a security guard, so when he got the computer home, "I had to teach them, my mom and my brother, how to use it," Troy said during a break from Mr. Varner's Internet class. "I'm still trying to learn a little more."

HEADLINE: Plans for Industrial Revival Divide Hudson River Towns

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Decades after smokestack industries largely disappeared from the Hudson River valley, leaving behind an environmental and economic mess that took years to reverse, plans are afoot to build more than a dozen industrial plants in the region.
The proposals -- including a $500 million power plant in the town of Athens, a $680 million paper recycling and power plant in Ulster, and a $300 million cement factory in Greenport -- have sharply divided towns up and down the river that have struggled, and slowly recovered, since the decline of heavy industry. 
 Those who oppose the plants say they threaten to undermine the effort to reclaim the Hudson from industrial pollution and to rebuild the region's economy through tourism.
But others welcome the return of manufacturing -- particularly the Pataki administration, which has vigorously wooed the companies with promises of state-sponsored tax-exempt bonds and local tax breaks. They say it will lure better-paying blue-collar jobs to a region where employment has improved markedly in recent years, but where wages still lag behind those of more prosperous areas.
And they are adamant that the factories will not harm the river.
"If I thought a plant would destroy the natural beauty of the Hudson River, I would act," Gov. George E. Pataki said in an interview. "But it's not got to the point where anyone has told me this is destroying the scenic beauty."
A spokesman for Mr. Pataki said that since he took office in 1995, the state had spent $256 million on cleaning and protecting the Hudson.
"We are pro-business, pro-industry," said Mr. Pataki, whose family home overlooks the river in Garrison. "We are also pro-environment. There isn't any dichotomy."
Environmentalists and many residents are unconvinced, saying that the administration has oversold the promise of factory jobs and tax revenue and underestimated the environmental cost.
"Instead of everyone saying the river's never been cleaner, we should be saying the river's never been under such threat," said Alan Neumann, president of Hudson River Heritage, a preservation group established 25 years ago. "It's been decades since we've been faced with such a concentrated series of proposals."
The proposed plants -- most of which would use the river for some part of their operation -- are early in the approval process. A spokesman for the Public Service Commission said a decision on whether to build the 1,080-megawatt Athens plant had been postponed for the third time, until April 30.
But the final approval on air quality standards has already been granted, as has the draft permit for water discharge.
Officials with the St. Lawrence Cement Company, which plans to ferry cement along two miles of conveyor belts to the riverfront, say they hope to conduct public hearings this summer. They filed their final environmental impact study on March 1.
But even if the final decisions are months, even years away, emotions are running high. Twelve New York environmental and preservation groups, led by Scenic Hudson, wrote to Governor Pataki recently urging a moratorium on industrial development until the state issues an overall plan for the development of the Hudson River.
In towns along the river, opposing sides have mounted expensive public relations campaigns. In Athens, a group collected 4,000 signatures and produced a video lambasting the proposed power plant there. In Saugerties, a citizens' group gathered 1,500 signatures against the recycling plant and claims credit for the company's decision to move to Ulster.
And preservationists aligned with Olana, Frederic Church's Moorish villa in Greenport, have joined in a lawsuit against the gas-fired electrical plant -- which they say will despoil their view.
The prospective plants even played a role in a handful of elections last fall, in which voters in Hudson and Newburgh ousted mayors who had supported factory proposals.
Things have also become a little bizarre. In Hudson, a group opposing the cement plant only a few miles away anonymously placed eight cinder blocks in prominent locations around town with one-word labels that together formed the questions: "Who will really pay? Who will really profit?"
For more than a century, the people of the Hudson Valley have tried to balance industry with maintaining the scenic landscape.
Poets, painters and philosophers trumpeted the virtues of the wilderness and the beauty of the river, and along the way the industrialists built their railroads and factories.
First came brick factories, iron mines and riverside quarries, then cement, then General Electric, all in search of cheap, unlimited river water.
By the 1960's, the Hudson River was in trouble. Industries had been dumping chemicals, and municipalities had been dumping sewage. Scientists found fish full of polychlorinated biphenyls from the General Electric plant in the Upper Hudson, cadmium from a battery factory in Cold Spring, and diesel fuel from the Metro-North yards in Croton-Harmon. The authorities banned commercial fishing and advised people not to eat striped bass caught in the river.
Meanwhile, groups committed to saving the Hudson had sprung up, and by the early 1990's, the river was being reclaimed. Billions of state and federal dollars had built state-of-the-art municipal treatment plants. Chemical dumping was curtailed.
Anticipating the deregulation of the electric industry, and eager to compete for business, New York State in 1992 created a board to expedite permits to build environmentally sound power plants. More recently, with the economy in the city booming and the demand for cement and computer chips growing, the Pataki administration began courting more industry.
The administration, aided by local towns, has extended the companies a range of tax breaks and support dollars. For instance, the Besicorp Company, which has proposed the paper recycling plant in Ulster, says it has been promised a $300 million tax-exempt bond, a $400,000 technical assistance grant and other benefits, including employment tax credits and utility discounts.
The Pataki administration has tried in particular to lure microchip-manufacturing plants, by creating four "shovel-ready" sites near the river, with licenses and environmental permits completed, so that a plant can move in quickly when a deal is struck. No companies have yet committed to the sites.
The companies have used different methods of persuasion. In Athens, for example, the town board initially opposed Athens Generating, and its promise to pay only modest taxes. But the town fathers changed their minds after the power company promised the town a $3 million "community benefits grant."
In the neighboring towns of Hudson and Greenport, the dispute over the St. Lawrence cement plant is a microcosm of the broader debate.
It has involved young and old, rich and not-so-rich. Dave Eger, one of 15 children raised to farm the rocky fields here, likes the idea of the $300 million factory set to be built about a mile from his spinach and strawberry fields. The new plant in Greenport would replace a shuttered plant across the river and would produce three times as much cement as the old one.
"The other industry has all been run out," Mr. Eger, 43, said. "People around here need jobs, and frankly, I could use the lime from the cement dust to sweeten my soil."
Next door in Hudson, the town that once thrived on the jobs provided by the defunct Atlas Cement Company, Albert Cook is far less enthusiastic. Mr. Cook, who operated a crane for Atlas for 24 years, says things have changed since his old company packed up and left in 1977. The glue factory closed down, too. So did the match factory. Even the junkyards left.
Hudson has been saved over the last decade, he said, by the people who came up from New York City and turned the down-at-the-heels town into a hive of antiques shops in restored brick buildings. He said a new factory would drive the tourists away.
"It'd be a ghost town without them," Mr. Cook said. But he knows that not everyone in Hudson agrees. "My wife feels the cement plant is a blessing," he said.
One issue the two sides have argued over is the matter of jobs, and both sides admit that unemployment has gone down in Ulster, Greene and Columbia Counties since the early 1990's.
In fact, the Hudson Valley region enjoyed the state's greatest job growth -- 5.5 percent -- in 1999.
But in Hudson, for example, wages still lag behind the state's average by almost 14 percent. And St. Lawrence's starting wage of $15.50 an hour looks good: Deena Pewtherer, the executive director of the Columbia County Chamber of Commerce, said that most area industry paid minimum wage or slightly above.
Before opening its operations in Greenport and Hudson, St. Lawrence will close the plant it still operates in Catskill. Thus, while people on the east side of the river may snag jobs, the net effect for the state will be a loss of 25 jobs, St. Lawrence officials concede.
But Mr. Eger and others like William First, 54, remain unmoved. Mr. First, who has just sold the family construction business he ran for 27 years, said the new industry would be a boon to a region suffering ever since I.B.M. laid off thousands of workers starting in the early 1990's.
"It's not just the taxes," Mr. First said, "it's the business spinoff to the restaurants, the motels, the hotels. The benefits just go on and on."
The debate is fierce, and not apt to end soon.
"It's polarizing the community in a really bad way," said Carole Clark, the chef at the Charleston Restaurant in Hudson and a member of the opposition. "It's been too easy to portray the issues in terms of the gentrifiers versus the real people."

HEADLINE: Diallo's Bronx Neighborhood Defies Stereotypes;
Multiethnic and Poor, Soundview Is Neither All Shadows Nor All Contentment

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
When four police officers turned down Wheeler Avenue in the Bronx one night in February 1999, they saw a dark block in a high-crime neighborhood in a borough with an international reputation for danger. In part because of where they were, they read ominous shadows in innocent movements.
To the prosecutors trying those police officers one year later for the shooting of Amadou Diallo, who lived on Wheeler Avenue, it was a place of stubborn normalcy, of mothers, strivers and neighbors. It was a tapestry of ordinariness worth celebrating. 
 One block, two visions. More than in most cases, the shooting of Amadou Diallo put a place -- Wheeler Avenue, the Soundview section and the Bronx itself -- on trial. At issue was perception: how a place appears to those who live there and to those who are just passing through; how old stereotypes of the Bronx have obscured a new and more complex reality.
Is the Bronx today a bastion of the working class, a lure to immigrants, a home to young families, as many of its residents and boosters claim and as Wheeler Avenue seems to affirm? Or is it, as the defense suggested, a place still under the sway of the old demons of drugs and crime?
Another police shooting, on March 1, shortly after the not-guilty verdict, and on Boynton Avenue just a few blocks from where Mr. Diallo lived, seemed to bolster the defense version: the block of Boynton Avenue where the shooting occurred had been the site of 144 drug-related arrests since 1997.
The truth, not surprisingly, is somewhere in between.
The Bronx today is certainly far better, brighter, safer and more stable than it was 10 or 20 years ago, but pockets of the old persist. That is why the borough president, Fernando Ferrer, can say that the Bronx today is "the same kind of place it was when I was a kid growing up -- working-class people looking for a better life," but also say, "There's been a serious drug and gun problem here for 25 years."
It is why the lead prosecutor in the Diallo trial summed up his case by painting a picture of the lives of Wheeler Avenue and saying, "None of those lives were easy, but they were solid and the neighborhood was good." And also why, District Attorney Robert T. Johnson said afterward, he did not bring the Albany jurors to the block: because he was unsure how they would react.
"For me, that is a quiet tree-lined block in the Bronx," Mr. Johnson said. "For them, it might have been seen differently."
With Mr. Diallo's bullet-pocked vestibule adorned with candles, flowers and angry signs, it is easy to forget just how normal life on Wheeler Avenue was before his death. Almost any day on the block, which is lined with red-brick row houses, men work on cars, children play basketball, an ice cream truck beseeches attention.
The citywide drop in crime was felt strongly and received thankfully on this block, where residents who once retreated inside with darkness now feel comfortable sending small children alone to the corner store at night. In 1994, there were 400 homicides in the Bronx, and 51 in the 43rd Precinct, which includes the Soundview section. In 1999, there were 137 homicides reported in the borough, and 22 in the 43rd Precinct. Almost every other major crime category except rape dropped significantly as well.
There are residents going back more than two decades on the block, but there are also many who have arrived within the last five or so years. They, like most of the block's residents, are members of the working class, with an emphasis on work: often at night, or at some distance, or for more than one employer. These are the faces, in many cases, of the service economy.
That was evident just from the scraps of information the trial witnesses provided about their own lives: Momodou Kujabi, Mr. Diallo's roommate, for example, working two jobs as a nurse's aide, from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m., or Ida Vincent, a 25-year-old mother of four, opening the window a crack against her asthma and waiting for her husband to return home from his night job at a warehouse.
The median household income for Community District 9, which includes Soundview and the surrounding neighborhood, was $23,572 in 1996. The jobs, mostly, are in Manhattan, and so the elevated No. 6 train, which curves around and stops on Westchester Avenue at Elder Avenue, one block past Wheeler, is a vital economic artery. Thus did Thomas Bell, one of the trial witnesses, spy Amadou Diallo about midnight, less than an hour before the shooting, as Mr. Bell walked home down Wheeler from a long day of work as a "loss prevention officer" at Saks Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.
A Guyanese man, who gave his name only as Singh, said he makes a similar trip, working late into the night doing maintenance in Manhattan, and then catching the train home about 2 a.m. He is 62.
He arrived on the block some 15 years ago, a pioneer of immigrant life there.
Starting in the 1980's, he said, West Indians began buying homes on the block -- he bought his from an Italian woman living on Long Island -- and, if necessary, renting out rooms to cover the mortgage. More and more immigrants have arrived since, many drawn by the drop in crime.
"Fewer and fewer Spanish people," Mr. Singh said, gesturing to a few lonely Puerto Rican flags hanging out windows. In fact, there are not fewer Spanish-speaking people, according to household surveys, but their origins are diversifying. At Teleparranda, a one-stop store for long-distance calling and wiring money on Westchester Avenue, for example, the countries most frequently contacted are the Dominican Republic and Ecuador.
Wheeler Avenue and its surroundings are a microcosm of a larger trend: immigrants settling in areas that for a long period were the almost exclusive province of Puerto Ricans and African-Americans. The newcomers are West Indian, Ghanaian, Nigerian, Pakistani, Dominican, Ecuadorean, Bangladeshi, Albanian and others.
From 1990 to 1996, more than 100,000 new immigrants settled in the Bronx.
That figure does not include immigrants who did not arrive through formal channels, and it does not include those who resettled from other places. Many of the Mexicans in the Mott Haven section, for example, came from the West Coast; many of the Caribbeans in Wakefield and Williamsbridge moved from places like Brooklyn. Some Dominicans have gone straight from their homeland, but many are also moving east from Washington Heights.
Unlike, say, Brooklyn, the Bronx has relatively few ethnic enclaves; most neighborhoods now comprise a host of nationalities. And yet, across cultural divides, some blocks, this stretch of Wheeler among them, have reproduced the close-knit communities that Bronxites of old -- the Jews, Irish and others who departed for safer climes -- reminisce about.
"Everybody knows everybody" by face, if not by name, was the refrain on Wheeler in the days after the shooting, and it still is. "This block, everybody knows that is your kid, that is your grandkid," Mr. Singh said. "If a kid is missing from home, someone will grab him and take him to the right house."
But just as a block in the Bronx can hold multitudes, a neighborhood can also hold multiple personalities: one block can be solid and decent, the next, full of problems. There is no easy explanation why, although large apartment buildings full of renters seem to attract more trouble than blocks with smaller homes and homeowners.
Just one block over from Wheeler, for example, is Elder Avenue, which was mentioned frequently by the defense during the trial. For about a year, the police kept a constant watch on both ends of the block in an effort to curb drug dealing.
But today, the street is no longer cordoned off -- the police opened it up about four months ago -- and it is home to a growing Mexican colony. One of those Mexicans, Hector Soliz, a 34-year-old from Cancun via Denver, said he had moved to Elder because it seemed safer than the place he was living: Boynton Avenue, just one street over.
Boynton Avenue is where, 12 days ago, a police officer shot Malcolm Ferguson, a 23-year-old, after pursuing him in a building where there had been 86 drug arrests in the last three years.
For all the proletarian promise of Wheeler, there is Boynton Avenue, where the ladder up seems out of reach. The block where Mr. Ferguson was killed abuts the Bruckner Expressway, and is farther from the subway than Wheeler; it feels far more isolated. Its buildings are either public housing or large apartment buildings indifferently maintained.
Most of its residents are Puerto Rican, with a good number of African-Americans as well.
It is a block brightened by murals -- brightened, that is, until one takes a closer look and sees that they all commemorate death at an early age. One celebrates a young woman, Suly, killed in 1993 at age 16. Nicholas Quinones, a young man who grew up on the block, said she was accidentally shot when someone was cleaning a gun and it went off. She was pregnant, he said, so "it was two bodies."
On the opposite building is another, smaller mural, for T J. He killed himself, Mr. Quinones said. Up the block a bit is a massive mural, featuring Christ bearing a crucifix, for Victor, dead at age 17, from what cause Mr. Quinones was unsure.
Mr. Quinones's friend, Victor Alvelo, said other murals on the street had been painted over, including one at the corner that commemorated two men who died young: "One shot up," he said, "one stabbed up."
Their talk is a reminder that a drop in crime does not necessarily mean a low crime rate: even with the reduction, in 1999 the 43rd Precinct was in the top 10 citywide in murders, rapes, robberies and felony assaults.
"It is New Jack City," said Tamiko Tucker, 29, who moved to the block with her 9-year-old daughter from a shelter a year ago. With the help of a federal housing voucher, she pays $657 for a one-bedroom apartment that she said was not worth the money.
"There's drugs all over," said her friend Charlene Gidron, who has lived with her son, 7, on the block for about four years. "Dope fiend zombies, I call them."
From rodents to truants, their list of complaints was long. "I get depressed coming back here every day," said Ms. Gidron, who is 25 and pays $535 for a one-bedroom apartment. Both women gave friendly greetings to a half-dozen neighbors and their children who walked by.
But, they said, there is animosity between blacks and Hispanics, between people trying to get out and those trying to drag them down, between gangs, and between everyone and the cops.
"What are you looking at?" Ms. Gidron snapped at the officers in a passing patrol car.
Not many people on the block are working, she said. "A few."
"A few," Ms. Tucker reiterated. Both women, being squeezed off welfare, are looking for work.
Ms. Tucker disdainfully watched a woman cross the street in her slippers. "It's real low-budget over here," she said. "As soon as you move in this area, you go down."
Ms. Gidron agreed. "This is ghetto," she said of the block. "This is bad."
With their anti-cop language, gold jewelry and baggy jeans, Mr. Quinones and Mr. Alvelo seemed very much "ghetto." But they were surprisingly eager to put some distance between themselves and the street, which suggests that even on the worst block, things are not always what they seem.
Mr. Quinones said he was studying at Bronx Community College. "It beats being out here," he said.
Mr. Alvelo works as a janitor in lower Manhattan, the 4 p.m.-to-midnight shift. He is almost 21, and goes home tired. "I'm too young to be coming home and feeling old," he said of the work. "It's not something I see myself doing for the rest of my life."
With a 2-year-old daughter to support, he says he would like to sit behind a desk and make money.
"I don't see myself in the streets," he said. "That's for sure."

HEADLINE: The Tribulations of Mozambique

 BODY:
The floodwaters in Mozambique have subsided, but the need to provide for the victims is by no means diminished. The United States and other wealthy nations should be generous in providing aid. Nearly a million of Mozambique's 17 million people have lost their homes, farms or food supplies. The official death toll of 400 is expected to rise into the thousands. Tens of thousands of villagers have fled their homes for the safety of high ground. The United Nations says 250,000 Mozambicans are now living in makeshift camps, and another 250,000 remain in ruined villages around the country.
The most urgent needs are food, tents, medicine and plastic sheeting and blankets. The U.N. estimates that a third of the country's corn, the staple crop, has been destroyed. More than 40,000 head of cattle have drowned, and 141 schools have been obliterated. 
 The long-term economic consequences could be devastating for a country that is still struggling to rebuild from a 16-year civil war that ended in 1992. Mozambique remains one of the poorest countries in the world, with a per capita annual income of barely $150. But it had made impressive gains in recent years. The government of Joaquim Chissano had embraced economic reform, encouraging foreign investment, increasing exports and boosting economic growth to close to 10 percent a year, one of the highest rates in the world.
But flood damage could reduce the country's domestic product by as much as a third. After the first floods in early February, the government and the U.N. issued an urgent appeal for $65 million in foreign aid. They are expected to double or even triple that request in the coming weeks. So far, foreign donors have pledged more than $100 million. Debt relief would also help. Washington has said that it will forgive Mozambique's remaining debt. Britain, Italy, Spain and Portugal will do the same. The World Bank has accelerated its debt relief program and diverted money from long-term infrastructure to emergency road-building. These are welcome expressions of support for a country that could take years to recover from this disaster.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Assails Bush on Taxes And Calls Rival Inexperienced

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 12

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore ventured into Gov. George W. Bush's backyard today and hurled spears at him, portraying his rival as so inexperienced that he would imperil Social Security for the sake of an unnecessary tax cut if elected president.
"Does Governor Bush have the experience to be president?" Mr. Gore asked a small group of retirees here at an assisted-living community. "No. A proposal like that makes you wonder, because right now we are heading in the right direction with a strong economy and continued prosperity." Mr. Gore said Governor Bush would take the nation in "the wrong direction" by trying to satisfy the wealthy special interests who were financing his campaign and wanted a tax cut. 
 Mr. Gore said that if Mr. Bush cut taxes as much as he had proposed, he would be forced to cut Medicare, dip into the Social Security trust fund or cut money for environmental and education programs. In any case, Mr. Gore warned, Mr. Bush would "take us back to the Bush-Quayle recession."
Mr. Gore is courting voters in Texas and across the South this week in advance of several primaries on Tuesday that he will undoubtedly sweep. Although these primaries are anticlimactic in the aftermath of former Senator Bill Bradley's withdrawal from the Democratic presidential race last week, Mr. Gore was trying to drive up interest in his candidacy and lay the groundwork for the fall campaign.
Even though the election is eight months away, the two putative nominees are already locked in battle, and are trying to define each other. Mr. Bush cast Mr. Gore today as galling in his presumption to adopt the mantle of campaign finance crusader, saying that Mr. Gore had in fact committed ethical lapses and "would say anything to get elected."
Meanwhile, with Gore aides saying that one of the chief concerns that voters harbor about Mr. Bush is his lack of experience, Mr. Gore is trying to stoke those doubts by portraying Mr. Bush as so unseasoned that he would ruin Social Security just to give a tax break to his wealthy contributors.
Mr. Gore said he would take all of the Social Security surplus and devote it exclusively to the Social Security program.
He said Mr. Bush had opened the door to raising the retirement age for full benefits for Social Security. Mr. Gore did not mention that the age is set to rise over the next few years to 67 anyway. Citing an account by The Associated Press, the Gore campaign noted that Mr. Bush had said in November that raising the retirement age and creating personal savings accounts might be "part of a trade-off" for securing Social Security for the baby-boom generation.
Mr. Gore said that those who were well-to-do might choose to set up private accounts, but others would be left behind. "Then you'd have a two-tier Social Security system," he said. "I say, if it ain't broke, don't fix it. Shore it up the way we always have. Social Security is the most popular program and the most successful program that has ever been enacted in the United States of America. It doesn't need to be privatized."
Having congratulated a woman in the audience who was 102 years old, Mr. Gore noted that the average lifespan of Americans was increasing, so that there were now 75,000 people over the age of 100.
"But just because lifespans are increasing," Mr. Gore said, "that doesn't mean that someone who works at hard physical labor, whether it's lifting steel or a waitress carrying a tray, has any less wear and tear on her skeleton and muscles, on the tendons and on the body, and that person is ready to retire at the age of 65 and shouldn't have to wait until the age of 70 to retire. I'm against raising the retirement age."
Mr. Gore reiterated his proposal to Mr. Bush that they both refuse to take so-called soft money, the unregulated donations to the parties, that they eliminate all campaign advertising and that they debate each other twice a week, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 8 p.m. He said this approach would prompt "a renaissance in our democracy."
He is making his arguments every chance he gets these days, both overtly and subliminally. For example, he used to deride the Reagan-Bush years that he said led the country to economic disaster. Now, he talks about the Bush-Quayle administration, which, he said in Houston on Saturday night, led to "the worst depression since the Dust Bowl days of the 1930's."
By invoking the name of Dan Quayle, who as vice president was not known for his experience or substance, and linking it with the presidency of Governor Bush's father, Mr. Gore is trying to conjure up the image of a candidate who is neither ready for the presidency nor capable of sound economic decisions.
At the same time, Mr. Gore is trying to pump up his standing with key Democratic constituencies. He arrived here this afternoon from Houston, where he rose early this morning to go jogging with Carl Lewis, the Olympic medalist. He spoke at a black church in Houston, where he delivered an extended soliloquy on the nature of racism, and visited a Mexican restaurant before flying to Dallas.
Mr. Gore is courting minority voters, here and elsewhere, because a high turnout, especially among blacks, is essential if he hopes to capture any states in the South.
Though Mr. Gore appears to have no hope of winning Governor Bush's home state of Texas, he is making a serious foray into that other Bush territory, Florida, where George Bush's brother Jeb is governor, in an effort to woo voters in that Republican-leaning state. Mr. Gore is planning to watch the primary returns on Tuesday night in Tallahassee, a sign that he intends to compete in the state in the fall.

HEADLINE: F.C.C. TO PROMOTE A TRADING SYSTEM TO SELL AIRWAVES

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
As the airwaves grow ever more congested with modern wireless communications, the federal government is developing plans to open up the spectrum by in effect treating its frequencies as commodities to be bought and sold as routinely as pork bellies or soybeans in the open market.
Officials at the Federal Communications Commission say they are preparing rules that would create a trading system in which telecommunications companies of all kinds, from old-fashioned radio stations and telephone companies to purveyors of wireless Internet services, could bid for underused slivers of the spectrum that are already under the control of other companies. 
 It would be a radical overhaul of the rules governing one of the most valuable, if intangible, forms of property in the new economy: the rights to transmit electronic signals at specific radio frequencies that constitute the spectrum. It would also have profound implications, not only for the telecommunications industries, but for consumers as well.
Under the current system, the federal government licenses each user and regulates what frequencies and signal power can be used. Most times these rights have been sold to the industry, although the oldest license holders got them free. But they have never been bought and sold in a secondary market like so many bushels of grain.
With the proliferation of cell phones, pagers, satellite services and other wireless devices, the communications agency's top officials have warned that demand is so outstripping supply that it may lead to what they call a spectrum drought, making the scarce spectrum even more valuable to haves and have-nots alike.
Now, for instance, the agency reports that the volume of traffic on the Internet is doubling every 100 days, a stunning increase considering that telephone traffic has traditionally risen about 5 percent a year. As consumers increasingly reach the Internet through wireless connections, like cell phones and handheld computers, experts fear the heavy use of the airwaves will begin to create bottlenecks and interference that could greatly frustrate the further development of the technology.
"What a tragedy it would be if, right as we're on the verge of the Internet migrating to inexpensive handheld devices and offering real hopes of truly democratizing the technology, the movement would be stymied by overloading the spectrum," William E. Kennard, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said in an interview on Friday.
Mr. Kennard, who has been pushing the agency to consider what rules need to be changed to help deregulate the spectrum to foster a new market, said the F.C.C. was just beginning to enable the licensees who own the rights to a given slice of the spectrum to make money from any surplus they have, like parts of the airwaves they may not be using 24 hours each day.
The plan began to take effect last week and will take many months to complete. In a little-noticed announcement last Thursday, the F.C.C. released rules for an auction this spring of a slice of the spectrum used by public safety organizations, including police departments and hospitals, as well as railroads.
Described by Mr. Kennard as "putting our toe in the water," the rules will reserve some of the frequencies to be auctioned to "guard band managers." They would be able to lease and trade the frequencies they win at the auction to commercial companies or private wireless users, setting up a system that opens the door to brokers who could help match buyers with sellers.
Another auction this year for even more valuable frequencies, those being vacated by broadcasters as they convert to digital television, is also being prepared in a way intended to encourage new spot markets. These frequencies, considered beachfront property by the industry, can be used for a variety of technologies beyond television, including cell phone and Internet communications.
If the idea works, the trading of spectrum futures could benefit the telecommunications companies that own licenses and other companies that cannot function without obtaining access to the airwaves. And consumers, in theory, would benefit from more capable communications devices and cheaper bills.
Just as the trade in physical commodities allows farmers to hedge against abrupt swings in price and enables consumers to count on steady supplies, economists and communications experts say a new approach that treated scarce frequencies as a commodity would allow new and older technologies to continue to flourish.
In theory, officials and economists say, the secondary market would be beneficial to consumers in several ways. Economically, it would create a more efficient and predictable way of matching supply and demand, and therefore would result in lower costs for using any equipment that makes use of the spectrum, like cell phones and pagers.
Technologically, it offers the hope of better reception for consumers who have begun to encounter greater interference as the spectrum has become overloaded.
"There is a severe spectrum shortage," said Peter Cramton, an economics professor at the University of Maryland who as chairman of the Spectrum Exchange Group, a Washington company, is involved in a private effort to auction parts of the U.H.F. television spectrum in conjunction with the broadcast auction.
"Consumers want better services," Mr. Cramton said. "They want high-speed data. They want a connection every time they place a call on their cell phones, not three-quarters of the time. The needs for users right now are great."
Officials at the Federal Communications Commission described a variety of ways a commodity market in the spectrum would work.
*News organizations covering political conventions or the Olympics would be able to buy contracts to use a piece of the spectrum during the event to give them extra capacity to beam pictures, sound and data back to their headquarters.
*A large metropolitan airport congesting the local airwaves around it with everything from air traffic transmissions to car rentals and cell phone users would be able to reserve space from other spectrum users who are not fully using their space during peak hours.
*Nationwide cell telephone companies would be able to buy and sell pieces of the spectrum in different regions of the country depending on the available supply and the demands of their customers.
Mr. Kennard and executives of some companies that are involved in creating markets for fiber-optic cable use said they envisioned a secondary market that could be set up by brokers on the Internet, much the way a secondary market exists for reserving the excess capacity of fiber-optic cable. They said the market would exist on a Web site listing what is available from licensees to trade to other companies who would want to buy or lease space, an eBay for telecommunications companies.
Companies like Arbinet Communications, Enron and the Williams Companies now act as brokers to essentially buy and then sell unused telephone time on fiber-optic cables.
At a telecommunications conference sponsored by Credit Suisse First Boston in New York last week, executives from some of the companies now involved in trading unused telephone time said that the F.C.C.'s proposal held great promise, but that it would take time to develop.
"The beauty of wireless is that the current system for trading it is so inefficient," said Eric L. Rabb, managing director of AIG Telecom, a unit of the American International Group that acts as a broker for access to time on fiber-optic cable. "What we apply now to the wired world we can apply to the wireless."
Officials at the F.C.C. say they are planning a forum this spring on ideas and rules changes for encouraging spot markets for the spectrum.
"Just through our licensing records we already have the most comprehensive list of potential sellers," Mr. Kennard said. But even as it seeks comment on changing the rules, he said, the agency is beginning to take steps beyond just the way it structures spectrum auctions to encourage the new marketplace.
This week, for instance, the agency plans to begin writing rules for a new technology that could have a profound effect on a secondary market. The technology is known as digitally defined radio, and it would allow new kinds of radios and cell phones with special software to seek out different and broader frequencies than current radios and phones.
The military has expressed interest in digitally defined radio because it would enable radios to avoid being jammed by an enemy by searching for a clean signal. But other companies are also developing products that rely on the technology.
By making broader use of the spectrum, digitally defined radio would also encourage telecommunications companies that are not using all of their licensed frequencies to their full capacity to lease their underused portions in a secondary market.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TEXAS GOVERNOR;
Gore Talking About Reform? Hah! Says Bush

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALCOA, Tenn., March 12

 BODY:
Declaring that Vice President Al Gore would "say anything to get elected," Gov. George W. Bush of Texas ridiculed Mr. Gore today for stating that reform of the nation's campaign finance system would be a centerpiece of his presidential campaign.
Mr. Bush, who has repeatedly sought to turn the Clinton administration's ethical lapses into an albatross around the vice president's neck, pounced on Mr. Gore's decision to champion more restrictions on the role of money in politics, which Mr. Gore described in an interview today in The New York Times. 
 Mr. Bush said that when he saw the article, "I wasn't sure if it was an April Fool's edition or not of the newspaper."
"I couldn't believe that he is going to make campaign funding reform a cornerstone of his campaign," Mr. Bush said at a news conference in Plant City, Fla., where he was campaigning at the state's annual strawberry festival before flying to a rally in Tennessee, Mr. Gore's home state. Florida, Tennessee, Texas and several other Southern states hold primaries on Tuesday.
"After all, it was not all that long ago that he went to a Buddhist temple to raise money," Mr. Bush said. "One of his close friends was indicted and convicted of fund-raising excesses. I think the vice president is somebody who will say anything to get elected. At least that's my interpretation of how he handles things. I look forward -- the more he talks about campaign funding reform, the better off it will be for my campaign."
Karl Rove, chief strategist for the Bush campaign, referred to the fund-raising event at the Buddhist temple in California in an appearance today on the "Fox News Sunday" television program. "This is more than just a little teensy-weensy mistake," Mr. Rove said. "Sometimes Vice President Gore has a big problem telling the truth."
"The Buddhist temple involved violations of law," Mr. Rove said. "Fifty-five thousand dollars in illegal contributions were funneled through that fund-raiser, and the vice president has consistently not told the truth about his involvement in that fund-raiser."
In the interview in The Times today, Mr. Gore said he had learned from his involvement in past campaign finance problems and would vigorously try to change the system. He also said Mr. Bush, who has twice been elected governor of Texas, lacked the experience to be president.
The sparring over campaign finance reflected the extent to which the candidacy of Senator John McCain of Arizona in the Republican primary was affecting the general election. Both sides are eager to court Mr. McCain's supporters, many of whom indicated that they were attracted to Mr. McCain because of his campaign against what he deemed to be the increasingly corrupting influence of money in Washington.
Mr. Gore appeared to hope that by acknowledging his involvement in fund-raising situations that raised questions, and proclaiming that he was redoubling his efforts to change the system, he could head off Mr. Bush's effort to portray him as unprincipled.
At the news conference today, Mr. Bush emphasized his response: nothing that Mr. Gore proposes -- and no amount of mea culpas -- can erase the taint of the Clinton administration's ethics record.
While Mr. Gore referred often to Mr. McCain in his comments, seeking to cast himself as a McCain-style reformer, Mr. Bush did not mention his former rival once today. Instead, Mr. Bush promoted his own campaign finance proposal, which has been greeted coolly by advocates for tougher rules, but only when asked about it by a reporter. Bush aides said later that Mr. Bush wanted to keep the focus on the vice president's ethics.
Like Mr. McCain, Mr. Gore favors prohibiting the largely unregulated donations to political parties known as soft money. Mr. Bush supports a ban on soft-money donations from corporations and unions, but not from individuals. A soft-money ban sponsored in part by Mr. McCain has failed in Congress because of opposition from Republicans.
After discussing his campaign finance proposal, which also includes more disclosure of donations, Mr. Bush quickly returned to the theme of Mr. Gore's performance.
"Campaign funding reform starts with having people who are going to obey the laws that exist," Mr. Bush said. "That is the best campaign funding reform immediately -- is to obey laws that are on the books and have an attorney general who will fully prosecute the laws on the books."
Mr. Bush also brushed aside Mr. Gore's criticism in the Times interview that Mr. Bush was not prepared to be president. Mr. Gore cited as evidence Mr. Bush's economic plan, which Mr. Gore said was based on a "risky tax scheme" that would "threaten our prosperity." The vice president also questioned whether Mr. Bush was proposing tax breaks for wealthy contributors.
Mr. Bush characterized those comments as typical of someone with a Washington mentality.
"The vice president, I think, is probably going to make the case that since he spent so much time in Washington, D.C., that only he can be the president," Mr. Bush said. "I'm going to make the case that there is life outside of Washington. That being in the business world is part of an experience necessary to become a chief executive officer. Being the governor of the second biggest state in the union."
"The vice president obviously believes that all wisdom and knowledge emanates out of Washington," Mr. Bush said. "I don't think that. I think all wisdom and all knowledge emanates from the people."
Douglas J. Hattaway, a spokesman for the Gore campaign, contended that Mr. Bush would be foolish to campaign on his record as governor.
"I don't think that George Bush is much of an expert on wisdom and knowledge," Mr. Hattaway said. "Under his so-called leadership, Texas is one of the most polluted states in the country and one of the worst places to raise a child. That is not the kind of experience that America is looking for on the national level."
Mr. Hattaway also promoted Mr. Gore's proposal to Mr. Bush to forswear soft-money donations, withdraw all television and radio advertising and hold debates twice a week. Mr. Bush has rejected the offer.
On another issue, Mr. Bush said he was considering supporting a move by some Republicans in Congress to repeal a 4.3-cent increase in the gasoline tax enacted in President Clinton's first term. The Republicans have sought to put the administration on the defensive over the recent increase in gasoline prices, which could turn into an important political issue in the high-gasoline-consumption summer vacation season.
Mr. Bush said he agreed with Energy Secretary Bill Richardson that the government should not dip into the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in an effort to depress prices. Still, Mr. Bush excoriated the administration for failing to persuade oil-producing countries to export more oil.
"These are countries with which we should have enormous amounts of capital," Mr. Bush said.
In Tennessee, at an airport rally outside Knoxville, Mr. Bush received an endorsement from Senator Fred Thompson, a Tennessee Republican who had been among the few Congressional Republicans to back Mr. McCain.
Mr. Bush also took a few geographic gibes at Mr. Gore, who moved his campaign headquarters to Tennessee from Washington last year when it seemed that he was stumbling.
"I understand that Al is in Texas today," Mr. Bush said. "I wanted to go to his home to campaign today as well, but I couldn't get reservations to Washington, D.C."

HEADLINE: Tribune Co. Is Seen in Talks On Union With Times Mirror

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
The boards of the Times Mirror Company, a media giant whose flagship newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, shaped and dominated Southern California for 119 years, and the company that publishes The Chicago Tribune were in advanced talks last night on a possible combination, according to a Times Mirror executive.
Although details were scarce, if the two companies were to combine, either in a merger or acquisition, the result would form a media conglomerate with 11 dailies, 22 television stations and a combined market value of $11.7 billion. 
 A joined company would hardly be the largest in a landscape that includes the merged America Online-Time Warner. Still, it would have enough heft, with $6.3 billion in combined annual revenues in 1999, to keep unwanted suitors at bay and to continue the Tribune Company's acquisition strategy and its push into Internet properties.
An announcement, which could come as early as today after a weekend of intensifying rumors, would end five years in which Times Mirror was reshaped by the cost-cutting zeal and combative optimism of its chief executive, Mark H. Willes. After arriving in the spring of 1995, Mr. Willes presided over the closing of both The Baltimore Evening Sun and New York Newsday and began asset sales that left the company pared largely to its basic newspaper operations.
His determination to see his papers buck the economic tide, win new readers and lead Times Mirror to new profit won Wall Street's favor for his first two years, but this strategy appeared to falter over the last 18 months, as circulation growth came in smaller increments and profits at the flagship newspaper fell below expectations.
Any combination would raise questions about the new company's ownership of both a newspaper and a television station in the markets of New York, Los Angeles and Hartford, an arrangement ordinarily prohibited by federal regulations.
The company's options would include seeking a Federal Communications Commission waiver of this requirement or divesting itself of some of the properties involved -- The Los Angeles Times and KTLA, a Warner Brothers affiliate; Newsday and WPIX, also a Warner Brothers affiliate; and The Hartford Courant and WTIC, a Fox affiliate.

Correction Appended

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 773 words

HEADLINE: Danger, Real and Affected, Lingers at Bikers' Jamboree

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 11

 BODY:
Bike Week 2000 headed for the finish wire on Sunday, leaving a trail of broken bodies and smashed motorcycles.
And that was just on local roads and city streets. The damage on the track at Daytona International Speedway, where professional cyclists zip around a long cantilevered track at speeds well over 100 miles an hour, was nothing compared with the deaths and injuries that resulted when an estimated 600,000 motorcyclists crowded into this Atlantic resort for 10 days of racing thrills and full-throttle partying. 
 By tonight, 13 bikers had died in traffic accidents, local police agencies reported, and scores more had been injured, the highest toll in the 59-year history of the popular event.
"We think it's very alarming," Officer Rick Gregory of the Florida Highway Patrol said about the traffic deaths.
But cyclists said much of the blame for the accidents rested with motorists who ignored or did not notice bikers as they turned or passed other vehicles.
It is a touchy subject for motorcyclists everywhere: accidents caused by car drivers oblivious to bikers. It is also a rationale for the supercharged exhaust blasts that announce the arrival of the bikes.
"Loud Pipes Save Lives" is a ubiquitous decal plastered on helmets and leather jackets.
It seemed impossible, however, for unnerved motorists not to notice bikers on Daytona Beach's sun-washed streets this weekend. The bikers hurtled across the city and the Halifax River bridge connecting the beaches with the mainland, thousands on the move at any time of day.
Some darted in and out of lines of slower traffic, sped along highway shoulders and threaded crowded intersections.
Riders can leave behind a cone of noise that rips the air with ear-splitting thunder, even when accelerating at legal speeds. Eighty-eight-cubic-inch engines, twin Mukini carburetors and Wimmer velocity stacks have a deep-throated gargle at idle, the pride of every biker, and the va-va-ROOM is a sweet melody to their ears.
Aside from accidents, the Daytona Beach police said, this year's crowd was well-behaved and cooperative. "It's an older crowd who come here for the weather, and they're not looking for trouble," said Sgt. Craig Buth.
"There's always some hotheads and some bar fights when people drink too much," Sergeant Buth said, "but this has been the mildest group in my memory."
The outlaw image persists more in legend than in the reality of a conclave like Bike Week, where grandmothers and grandfathers could be seen checking out exhibits of candy-apple red Harley-Davidson Soft riders and chrome-laden Fat Boys beside tattooed younger men and women wearing cutoff leather vests and fringed riding chaps.
"I was one of the bad guys 40 years ago when bikers, for good reason, intimidated people," said Bennie Bauer, a burly man in his mid-50's with a full sandy beard going gray.
"Things have mellowed with the times," he noted, with only a whisper of regret, adding that some of Bike Week's participants showed up riding $40,000 customized bikes.
"Everything down to the last stud on their saddlebags is done for them, and they don't know what they're paying for with their gold credit cards," he said in a good-natured growl as he motioned toward a knot of middle-aged men.
"Take the do-rag off one of their heads and you'll find a doctor or a businessman," he said.
The men stood on a sidewalk on Main Street along with thousands of other spectators, admiring an endless stream of motorcycles and their riders cruising by in raucous procession. In addition, thousands of bikes were parked handlebar to handlebar on both sides of the street, buffed and brushed to a high polish.
What really seemed to be on parade was a national economy that fuels weekend extravaganzas like Bike Week, enabling more than a half-million hobbyists to spend an estimated $300 million on the event.
"You can't have a Harley unless you can afford one," said Debbie Torpey, a self-described computer networker from Rhode Island.
Bike Week, she added, "is just a chance for a lot of middle-class and educated people to dress up and let loose."
Many of the women here, from outward appearances, seemed to buy into the dirty fingernails and rowdy image that bikers acknowledge as a cultural inheritance. There was topless exhibitionism, beer-swilling and macho swagger on parade, as well as skull-and-crossbones insignia and Confederate battle flag regalia.
"But where can you put 600,000 people together for 10 days and have as well-behaved and peaceful crowd as this group?" said Tom Guest, owner of Chopper World, a biker's boutique on Main Street.

HEADLINE: In a Side Effect of Economic Prosperity, White-Collar Crime Flourishes

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
Gary Ahlert, an agent for toy inventors, was in a financial hole. He had lost $400,000 on a plan to market a material to cover artificial limbs. So in 1998, when a potentially lucrative mining deal came up, the pitch, from an apparently credible businessman, seemed worth listening to: invest in an Arizona mine filled with ore that could be used to make cellular telephone batteries.
To get a stake, Mr. Ahlert called a Georgia company whose newspaper advertisements offered "Hard Money. Financing available. $250K and Up." Mr. Ahlert sent the company a $5,000 processing fee for a $3 million capital investment loan, and he and a partner invested about $200,000 of their own money in the mining project. 
 In the end, though, the offer of a loan was fraudulent, the mining project was a scam and Mr. Ahlert and his partner were out about $300,000, all the poorer for having proved a law enforcement adage that a booming economy breeds white-collar crime.
In recent years, while violent crime has plummeted nationwide, white-collar crime, against individuals and small businesses, has skyrocketed, fueled by the economy and made easier by the Internet, law enforcement officials say.
"When there is a lot of money around, they are going to go after the money," said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. "So, when you look back and you have high activity in the market, and we have never seen anything like this, you are going to have a lot of fraud.
"The generalization is that the honey attracts the bears," he said.
That has created a difficult situation for a criminal justice system designed to deal, primarily, with street criminals, experts say.
For Mr. Ahlert and others like him, the situation adds insult to injury.
And because it is so hard to track down this kind of scam artist, prove the case and recover the money, prosecutors and the police are sometimes reluctant to try, law enforcement officials said.
According to securities regulators, law enforcement agencies and the National White Collar Crime Center, which studies the phenomenon, white-collar crime has risen 10 percent to 20 percent in the last five years.
And the federal Securities and Exchange Commission, which deals with investment fraud, reported a 20 percent jump in the number of complaints from 1995 to 1999.
Law enforcement officials said the Internet had complicated the situation for them by making it easier for swindlers to quickly steal money and disappear into cyberspace.
Lynne A. Hunt, the chief of the financial crimes section for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said in an interview that the bureau was investigating more than 26,000 white-collar cases, using more than 2,400 agents. In a decade, bureau officials said, the F.B.I. has more than doubled the number of agents and resources dedicated to white-collar cases.
But, law enforcement officials acknowledged, that is still not enough.
"The advent of new technology has really affected us tremendously," Ms. Hunt said. "Traditional white-collar criminals are now utilizing the Internet to do the same types of crime."
Paul Leighton, a sociologist and professor of criminology at Eastern Michigan University, said it was a difficult transition for law enforcement to make.
"We try to keep this image of the street criminal and the idea of the threat coming from the poor, but we have long had all this white-collar crime, which is much more likely to affect the average American," Professor Leighton said.
Mr. Ahlert is one of those affected. He and his partner spent about $220,000 on the mining and the loan schemes. And, having devoted about another $80,000 to lawyers and investigators in an effort to recover his losses, he has lost his business, is considering filing for bankruptcy and is about to close his office on Main Street here. He and his partner do not even know if they can afford to hire a bankruptcy lawyer, he said.
Perhaps most striking about the case is law enforcement's lack of action.
Mr. Ahlert said he had appealed for help from New York to El Paso, Tex., and had compiled thick files of evidence. In one letter, the men running the mining project claimed to own more than 700,000 tons of ore in Arizona, ore that really belonged to the Department of Defense. One Texas police agency considered pressing charges against one of the men in the mining project, but the El Paso County district attorney's office dropped the charges because prosecutors believed they could not make the case, the police said.
Law enforcement officials said that a case like Mr. Ahlert's was difficult to investigate because white-collar criminals tended to be good at hiding their assets, and generally it was not cost-effective for prosecutors unless they could amass a long list of victims who had been defrauded of much more than what Mr. Ahlert and his partner could reclaim.
Law enforcement officials in Texas, Georgia and New York who have looked at Mr. Ahlert's case said that it appeared he had amassed evidence of fraud, but that it was very unlikely the case would ever go to court.
The officials said that investigating even the simplest white-collar crime case could take years and often involved sorting through thousands of pages of documents. Furthermore, jurors often have a hard time understanding white-collar crime or feeling sympathy for the victims, the officials said.
Given those realities, the officials said, prosecutors are reluctant to proceed with small cases or those that involve few victims. Arrest trends for white-collar crime, which peaked in 1995, suggest that after making a strong push to address the growing number of people being victimized by white-collar crime, the authorities pulled back and began focusing on bigger cases, experts said.
"We have been told by prosecutors that our case was not sexy enough," Mr. Ahlert said. He later added, "We are just two little guys who can't do anything for them."
The increase in white-collar crime is felt most acutely in financial centers, like the New York region, officials said.
"What everyone is worried about is that if the market corrects downward we are going to be swamped with complaints," said Eric Dinallo, a former Manhattan prosecutor who is now chief of the New York State attorney general's investor fraud and securities bureau. "Because people will not even know that they are being scammed until they take their money out."
Ralph Lambiase, the director of the securities division at the Connecticut Banking Department, said more street criminals were moving into the world of white-collar crime because they could get away with it.
"If you mug someone in Connecticut I could get you arrested today," he said. "But if you do white-collar stuff, there are so many ways to hide and shield yourself, and it is much tougher to convict you in front of a jury."
Mr. Lambiase said that experienced people like Mr. Ahlert were increasingly being defrauded.
Mr. Ahlert was hardly new to the workings of the business world. One of the authors of a book called "Selling Your Idea or Invention" (Carol Publishing, 1994), which included a chapter on how to avoid scams, he also worked with Hasbro, Mattel and other major toy companies.
Mr. Ahlert saw the advertisement for the loan in The New York Times classified section in February 1998.
Mr. Leighton, the sociologist, said that people like Mr. Ahlert were easy targets in good economic times because "people feel more comfortable about spending on things that sound risky."
But Mr. Ahlert said his experience had left him far from comfortable.
"It's turned my life upside down," he said as he smoked cigarette after cigarette in the conference room of his office in February.
He said he was living on money borrowed from friends and his daughter, Noel, 33, a schoolteacher.
"I am embarrassed," he said.

HEADLINE: Just What's Going On Inside That Head of Yours?

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE 

 BODY:
Two hundred years ago, the German anatomist Franz Joseph Gall dazzled the public with his science of phrenology, the practice of divining personality and intellect from the shape of the bumps on a person's head. Each localized bump, he said, represented a different characteristic, like secretiveness, acquisitiveness or cautiousness. Later practitioners of phrenology even found locations for pampering children, gluttony and Republican politics.
Now the public is being dazzled once again by a technique called functional magnetic resonance imaging, or F.M.R.I., which is finding precise brain locations related to all sorts of human traits and activities. Among them are hyperactivity centers in children, cells that specialize in the naming of fruits and even a spot in the brain that lights up when a man is sexually aroused. 
 Instead of having their bumps "read" during a Victorian parlor game, people lie down and put their heads inside a powerful magnet device that detects certain molecules in blood flowing through the brain.
When a particular location of the brain is engaged in a cognitive task like naming fruits, it requires extra energy to do its job. The energy arrives in the form of glucose, a simple sugar, that is carried to the fruit-naming location via increased blood flow. This increase in blood flow is then detected by the magnet and depicted on a screen as splotches of light inside the brain.
F.M.R.I. is wildly popular with researchers, thrilled to have a tool that can peer inside the thinking, feeling human brain, said Dr. William Newsome, a professor of neuroscience at Stanford. Unlike standard M.R.I. scans that take static pictures of brain anatomy -- used when doctors search for abnormalities -- functional imaging captures the brain in action as it plans, schemes, imagines and hallucinates.
Thus, each week journals report new studies of ways the brain works based on analyses of F.M.R.I.-based splotches of light inside human heads. But many leading neuroscientists, including Dr. Newsome, now chide colleagues, saying they are misusing a potentially priceless research tool on studies that are often poorly designed and sometimes bordering on the simple-minded.
Most researchers using the new imaging are not asking difficult questions about brain function, these critics say. Instead of asking how the brain works, the technology is being used to answer simple questions that repeat what is already known about the brain or shed little light.
For example, Dr. Newsome said, a researcher might put someone in a scanner, ask the person to count from 1 to 10 and later to count backwards from 10 to 1. The end result: an area for counting backward that lights up as a blob in the brain.
The technology is seductively easy to use, said Dr. Christopher Moore, a postdoctoral fellow at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston who is carrying out a number of imaging studies. "You can think of an idea, throw five friends into the scanner overnight and write up your results the next day. People don't have to think very hard about what they're doing."
Just because an area lights up does not mean something important was found, Dr. Newsome said. Nor will researchers understand the brain when the entire map is filled with blobs.
"Localization data provide little insight into the exact nature of the signals encoded in a given structure, the computations being performed and the interactions between different structures," Dr. Newsome said. In other words, knowing where something happens does not reveal how it happens.
Neurologists now know that the brain is a dynamic system of cellular circuits that constantly shift as people go through the day. So the hard part of deciphering brain function is to figure out how cells and widespread circuits are interconnected. How do they fire together to produce behaviors?
Moreover, "there's a dirty little secret that people who publish these studies don't reveal," said Dr. Terry Sejnowski, a neuroscientist at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, Calif. "The signals they get are highly massaged. It means they clean up their data to make it look good, like applying makeup, for a general audience." The actual data they collect are far more complex, he said, but difficult to decipher.
Another problem is that some parts of the brain seem to light up all the time. The anterior cingulate -- found in front of the brain near the fissure separating the two hemispheres -- is active when people carry out scores of tasks, including, as French researchers found, thinking about sex.
And just because a brain area is correlated with a behavior in F.M.R.I. studies does not mean that it causes the behavior, said Dr. John Moore, a psychology professor at the University of Massachusetts. Imaging studies often make this mistake, he said.
The most serious criticism of the imaging has to do with what the researchers are measuring. Increased blood flow, as shown in splotches of light, may not be an accurate surrogate for brain cell function, some say. Sometimes a signal is picked up by the magnet because the blood is draining into a larger vein and not from cells that are using more energy. Thus, some imaging experiments may measure what veins, not brains, are doing at any given moment.
But all these criticisms do not mean that researchers abandon their projects, Dr. Sejnowski said. "Keep in mind that every time a new technique comes along, a majority of the early studies will be misguided," he said. "F.M.R.I. has shown us things we could not have seen any other way. It is especially useful in studying uniquely human traits like spoken language, reading and sophisticated moral reasoning."
For example, at Princeton Dr. Jonathan Cohen, a neuroscientist, and his colleagues have used the imaging to discover a function for the anterior cingulate that may explain its widespread activation in imaging experiments. Many believe that this part of the brain is responsible for controlled attention or that it responds to errors, Dr. Cohen said. But experiments that could have been done only with F.M.R.I. suggest that its real role is to register conflict. This, in turn, leads a person to pay more attention to what is happening. The distinction is subtle but important, Dr. Cohen said.
Dr. Newsome, an expert in monkey brains, said an imaging experiment in humans got results that conflicted with what was known in monkeys. "We went back and found that the monkey data were incorrect," he said. Thus, human experiments can pay off in unexpected ways.
The imaging technology is improving rapidly, Dr. Sejnowski said. Soon, it may be possible to measure blood flow in tiny areas called cortical columns, clusters of neurons that carry out a single function like detecting edges or direction of motion. It is believed that these columns carry out the basic work of the cerebral cortex, and if researchers can see how they wire and fire together, they will have a better idea of how the brain is organized.
Other improvements include new methods of computer analysis that allow researchers to distinguish meaningful signals out of confusing experiments with the new imaging.
Brain imaging researchers are extremely excited about efforts under way to combine F.M.R.I. with other brain imaging techniques, like magnetoencephalography (MEG) and electroencephalography (EEG). The new imaging is good at finding functional locations but is very slow at picking up signals. While brain cells work in thousandths of a second, functional imaging needs a couple of seconds to detect blood flow. Other technologies like MEG and EEG are fast but not good at identifying where brain activity occurs.
By combining images from all three techniques with the help of powerful computers, researchers hope to produce "movies" of thoughts inside a human head.
Right now, "our knowledge is akin to looking out of the window of an airplane at night," Dr. Newsome said. "We can see patches of light from cities and towns scattered across the landscape. We know that roads, railways and telephone wires connect those cities, but we gain little sense of the social, political and economic interactions within and between cities that define a functioning society." The same is true of efforts to look into the human brain, he said.

HEADLINE: Talks in Japan on Forming Banking Giant

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 13

 BODY:
Sanwa Bank Ltd. is negotiating to join the merger of Asahi Bank Ltd. and Tokai Bank Ltd., a combination that would create the third-largest bank in the world in terms of assets, executives close to the deal said today.
The merged bank would have about 104 trillion yen ($979 billion) in assets, second in Japan to the Mizuho Financial Group, which will come to life this fall when Fuji Bank, the Industrial Bank of Japan and Dai-Ichi Kangyo merge into a bank with $1.3 trillion in assets. The proposed merger of Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank in Germany would create the world's second-largest bank, with $1.2 trillion in assets. 
 It would mean that in less than one year, the ranks of large Japanese "city" banks have started shrinking to five from nine as the industry is forced to reorganize after the financial crisis that gripped the country in late 1997 and early 1998.
Only the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, which is itself a result of an earlier merger, and Daiwa Bank remain unaligned, and many analysts think Daiwa has to find a partner.
A Sanwa-Asahi-Tokai merger, which is expected to be completed in the fall of 2001, would create Japan's first megabank aimed squarely at Japanese consumers, a group of customers traditionally ignored by Japan's biggest banks. Asahi, which is strong in the Kanto region around Tokyo, and Tokai, which caters to customers in the Tokai region between Tokyo and Osaka, had already announced a merger that is scheduled to take place this fall. Adding Sanwa, which is strong in the Kansai area around Osaka, would give the consolidated bank a solid grip on the most populous part of the country.
"This gives Asahi and Tokai the Osaka piece they've been missing," said James P. Fiorillo, a senior banking analyst at ING Barings. "Geographically, it makes sense."
But Mr. Fiorillo cautioned that while the merger was likely to have long-term benefits, it would be disruptive and difficult over the next three to five years. Like their European and American counterparts, Japanese banks have found consolidation is a bigger challenge than they had anticipated. The struggles that have troubled Citibank and UBS of Switzerland, to name two of the more prominent examples, have become front-page news as they struggle to mesh distinct and often conflicting cultures and management styles.
Japanese banks are no different. Dai-Ichi Bank and Kangyo Bank maintained separate personnel departments for decades after their merger into Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in the 1970's. And Mizuho, as Dai-Ichi, Fuji and the Industrial Bank will become after their merger, will have three presidents, all of whom are well past what Americans would consider retirement age.
The challenges here may be even greater because Japanese banks face a bigger challenge in getting up to speed with information technology. When the Bank of Tokyo joined with Mitsubishi Bank in 1996, the costs of merging their computer systems was twice what they had anticipated, Mr. Fiorillo said.
"They all have a tendency to overestimate cost-savings and underestimate the costs of merging systems, and that's not limited to Japanese banks," he said.
