HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
$50,000 Gift Puts Amputee Closer to Dream House

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Last April, in a widely publicized assault, Edgar Rivera was pushed in front of an approaching subway train by a stranger with a history of mental illness.
Mr. Rivera, 37, a father of three from the Soundview section of the Bronx, yelled, "Oh, my God!" as he teetered on the edge of the platform for a split second before falling off. Moments later, his legs were run over by the first two 75,000-pound cars of a screeching uptown No. 6 train as he crouched beneath the platform. 
 "He looked like a person who had just come back from Vietnam," said his longtime friend Noel Moreno, who was with him at the hospital on the night of the attack.
Eleven months later, Mr. Rivera, a printer by trade, wants to again provide for his wife, Elizabeth, and their three children, Elijah, 14, Chanel, 9, and Essence, 4. "I'm trying to transition myself back to the work force," he said recently, sitting in his motorized wheelchair. "I'm not going to sit in this chair forever." He practices using his prosthetic legs for a few hours a day.
It's not that Mr. Rivera minds getting back on the subway, which forever changed his life. He often cannot even get out of his building.
His apartment near Bruckner Boulevard is on the top floor of a seven-story public housing building with an unreliable elevator and other obstacles to the disabled. Four times in the months since he was released from the hospital, Mr. Rivera has had to pull himself backward up the dark, graffiti-scarred flights of stairs while his son carried his wheelchair behind him.
Through a $50,000 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, one of the largest to this season's campaign, which ended on Sunday, Mr. Rivera is a good deal closer to his goal of having a handicapped-accessible home built for his family and then returning to work.
The donation, which came in December from DesignWrite, a small company in Princeton, N.J., that arranges seminars for pharmaceutical companies, was directed to provide medical equipment for a disabled person, without a specific individual in mind.
"I wanted to give the money for someone who had a health-related disability and for whom this would allow a return to a high level of functioning," said the president of the company, Mitchell A. Leon.
Though the primary goal of the fund is to serve seven of the oldest and most respected charities in the city with broad assistance, occasionally, donations come with specific terms attached, and where appropriate, the donor's wishes are honored.
When officials of the Community Service Society of New York, one of the seven charities, learned of DesignWrite's gift, they saw a potential match in Mr. Rivera. Solving his housing needs would make a disabled person productive again, just as the donor had envisioned.
Last week, The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the Neediest Cases Fund, gave its consent.
Mr. Rivera said the city's Housing Authority had done all it could to help him, including retrofitting his apartment with wider doors and giving his building special attention.
"Now that he lives here they always fix the elevator on the same day," said a girl in the building's elevator who would give only her first name, India.
In the months since the assault, Mr. Rivera has forgiven his attacker and has worked to raise money for his dream house.
The Edgar Rivera House Fund has raised about $51,000, largely from people who gave donations of $15 to $100, said Pedro Espada Jr., a former state senator who is coordinating the fund-raising effort.
Mr. Rivera is still searching for a suitable plot of land in his neighborhood. Aiding him are Mr. Moreno and Mr. Espada, who have distributed fliers in the neighborhood and taken to the airwaves to broadcast a phone number to call to make tax-deductible donations, (718) 589-2232.
Mr. Rivera said the house he wanted, with special features like lower cabinets, wider hallways and ramps to the outside doors, would probably cost $200,000. He said his heart was warmed by every donation.
"It's special to me," he said. "These are not people who have benefited from any boom in the economy, and their pockets are not that deep. For them to help me, it shows there are people out there who care, whether it's $5 or $50,000."
After Mr. Rivera builds his house, he would like to build a treatment center for the mentally ill, so that people like the man who pushed him in front of the train can get help.
"You never think about mental illness until it affects your sister or your brother or yourself," Mr. Rivera said. "Unless people with mental illness are treated, the abilities and talents that they have will never be put to use."

HEADLINE: Rothschild Partner Plans to Set Up OwnFirm

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Wilbur L. Ross Jr., one of the best-known investors in troubled corporations, said yesterday that he was leaving the investment bank Rothschild Inc. at the end of the month to form his own investment firm, W. L. Ross & Company.
Mr. Ross, who is 62, said he would sell his partnership interest in Rothschild and buy bigger stakes in investment funds that he has run for the firm and will continue to manage at his new firm. About 20 Rothschild employees who work on the funds in New York, Tokyo and Seoul, South Korea, will join his firm, he said. 
 Rothschild, which is trying to build up its presence on Wall Street, will maintain investments in the funds but will no longer control them. The split will head off possible conflicts between Rothschild's investment banking clients and its own interests as an active investor in stocks and bonds of troubled companies, said Raymond W. Smith, chairman of Rothschild North America.
Mr. Smith said Rothschild managers saw a need for a change as Mr. Ross finished investing one fund and started planning to raise others to invest in distressed securities in the United States and Asia.
"When we went from one fund with a few investments to the potential of one or two more, we saw the possibility out there of a train wreck," Mr. Smith said, referring to potential conflicts of interest.
Mr. Ross declined to say how much he was paying to acquire a majority interest in the general partner of the Rothschild Recovery Fund and the Asia Recovery Fund. The funds, which specialize in investing in companies trying to stave off bankruptcy, or "workouts," have about $450 million in assets.
Despite the long economic boom, "distressed investing" is a thriving practice, Mr. Ross said. The failures are less spectacular these days than they were in the 1980's and early 1990's, but more small and midsize companies failed in this country in 1999 than in any previous year, he said.
The departure of Mr. Ross represents a big change for Rothschild. Having been married to Betsy McCaughey when she ran for governor of New York in 1998 -- they have since filed for divorce -- Mr. Ross has a high profile. But the type of investing he does is, as one person who knows him well said, "distinctly downmarket" for a boutique investment bank with a proud European heritage.
Led by Gerald Rosenfeld, a former partner at Lazard Freres in New York, Rothschild aspires to compete with Lazard as an adviser to chief executives of large corporations. "The new Rothschild will not be a workout shop," Mr. Smith said. "We will provide adult-to-adult advisory services."

HEADLINE: Alfred Neal, 87, an Economist Who Influenced Trade Policy

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Alfred C. Neal, an economist whose interest in developing the global economy influenced United States trade policy in the 1950's and 1960's, died Wednesday. He was 87 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.
Dr. Neal, who was one of 11 children, got early exposure to free-enterprise realities when he was 10 years old and began delivering milk, using a pony and a cart, to other families in his hometown of Kentfield, Calif. 
 As a college student, he arrived at the University of California's Berkeley campus in 1929, just weeks before the stock market crash that led to the Great Depression. As a result, Dr. Neal's career became focused around the prevention of similar catastrophes.
While much of the economic theory at the time contended that peacetime economies were doomed to failure, Dr. Neal worked to find alternatives to war that would permit businesses to flourish. Among those was the concept of a controlled recession that would affect some people, but not all, for a brief period of time, and prevent deeper economic problems.
After Berkeley, he studied at the London School of Economics, where Harold Laski, the political theorist and socialist, was one of his professors. Dr. Neal earned his doctorate from Brown University.
During World War II he worked at the Office of Price Administration, moving on to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston.
Shortly after the war he became the first president of the Committee for Economic Development, a nonprofit organization of economists and company executives that tried to foster progress around the world. He worked with many prominent economists, including Alan Greenspan.
Dr. Neal's sister, Carolyn N. Hedley, said: "The Depression left deep impressions on Al. When he graduated from Berkeley, all of the graduation speakers just spoke in despair and said we couldn't live without wars, that if you didn't have a war raging the economy would go to hell."
With Arthur Burns and Donald Watson, Dr. Neal wrote "Modern Economics," which became widely used in the 1940's as a basic textbook. He retired in 1976 from the Committee on Economic Development, and is credited with influencing the creation of the European Economic Community; helping to rebuild the German and Japanese economies after World War II; and getting the United States off the gold standard. He advised President Dwight D. Eisenhower, President John F. Kennedy and President Lyndon B. Johnson on trade as a member of several commissions.
As head of the Committee on Economic Development, "he was unique in his ability to bridge the gap between the ivory tower and the marketplace," said Sol Hurwitz, who worked with Dr. Neal on the committee. "He brought business leaders together with economists, and the two sides actually developed a healthy respect for one another -- and they learned from one another," Mr. Hurwitz said.
He took pride in the committee's counterparts in Japan, Germany, and Sweden, among other countries, and worked to strengthen them. He also had a knack for persuading the committee's trustees to come to an agreement on something. "He didn't simply wait for a consensus to unfold," Mr. Hurwitz said. "With a twinkle in his eye, he would tell them what the consensus ought to be and would bring them around to his way of thinking."
Outside the office, Dr. Neal, who had no children, loved to entertain with clambakes held in his backyard in Harrison, N.Y., where he lived for many years before moving to Sarasota in 1997. He was also knowledgeable about wine, and shared his insights with his siblings. "After a while, we knew a good Margaux," Dr. Hedley said.
In addition to Dr. Hedley, of Sarasota, he is survived by three sisters, Stella Hadley, of Petaluma, Calif.; Rose Nelson of Azalea, Ore.; and Jeanne Doellstedt of Richmond, Calif.; and two brothers, William, of Novato, Calif., and James, of Santa Rosa, Calif.

HEADLINE: Both Parties In Albany Seek a Halt To Gas Tax

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 13

 BODY:
Responding to the recent jump in the price of gasoline, legislative leaders from both major parties called today for the suspension or even repeal of the state's gasoline tax.
The move by the leaders of the Democratic-led Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate is intended to defuse what many believe will be a major pocketbook issue in this year's elections. 
 The price of gasoline has risen sharply over the last few months, and many lawmakers here and across the nation fear voter reprisal in November if they do not move to address the situation.
The average price of a gallon of regular unleaded gasoline in the state is now around $1.50 -- up from about $1.25 in December. The main reason for the hike was a move last year by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to force up the price of crude oil by limiting production.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today joined the chorus of lawmakers calling for elimination of the federal and state tax on gasoline. He also sought to put Democrats on the defensive, blaming President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore for the increase.
Mr. Giuliani, who will face Hillary Rodham Clinton in a bid for the United States Senate this year, said that people were being "absolutely economically ruined by the policies of the Clinton-Gore administration with regard to gasoline."
Here in Albany, the situation has led to dueling proposals, with Democrats and Republicans attempting to outflank each other on the politically charged issue in a year when all 211 members of the Legislature are up for re-election. But no matter which party gains the upper hand, consumers are almost certain to benefit in the end, because action by the Legislature seems imminent.
The Democratic speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, made the opening bid when he proposed eliminating the state's 4 percent sales tax on gasoline during July and August, the height of the summer travel season.
Mr. Silver today urged adoption of the measure, saying it would save drivers $63 million over the two months and encourage them to travel to New York's vacation destinations. Mr. Silver's plan would also give all localities the option to eliminate their local share of the gas tax, which ranges from 3 to 4 percent.
"New York is a tourist state from eastern Long Island to Niagara Falls," Mr. Silver said. "This proposal will make it more attractive for people to get in their cars and vacation in New York."
The Republican majority leader of the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, immediately countered with his own plan, calling for the complete elimination of the state's sales tax on gasoline. His plan would save motorists about $300 million a year, and it would also allow localities to repeal their portion of the tax.
Mr. Bruno said the state could afford to provide the tax cut because his aides estimate that the state will amass a budget surplus of more than $1 billion when it ends its fiscal year on March 31. "We think that that money really belongs to the taxpayers," Mr. Bruno said of the surplus. "We have to come up with appropriate ways to return it to the taxpayers."
The plan is the latest in a rapidly growing list of tax-cut proposals and spending items that the lawmakers have placed on their agenda even before budget negotiations have begun in earnest. All in all, the measures will likely lead to weeks, if not months, of maneuvering and negotiation between the two houses and Gov. George E. Pataki.
This afternoon, Mr. Pataki, a Republican, said that he, too, favored the elimination of the state's gasoline tax. But he warned that there had to be trade-offs for it in the negotiations over a new state budget.
"Given the strength of the state's economy," he said, "we could afford a tax cut that would get rid of the state's sales tax on gasoline for years to come, but not if we're going to go on spending binges in other areas, not if we're going to pass other massive tax cuts."
The Democrats in the Assembly also called today for a $1.3 billion rise in state spending in aid to schools, nearly triple the increase that Mr. Pataki has proposed, setting the stage for a protracted budget fight.
The Republicans in the Senate, for their part, proposed a $900 million increase in state spending for primary and secondary education, placing even greater pressure on Mr. Pataki to move well beyond the $355 million, or 2.8 percent, increase he has proposed for schools.
In addition, the Democrats are also proposing that the state provide $500 million to help school districts across the state repair or replace crumbling buildings. "It makes sense to invest in our children," Mr. Silver said this afternoon as he unveiled his education plan.

HEADLINE: White House to Publish Accord on China's Entry Into W.T.O.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN with CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Bowing to pressure from Congress, the Clinton administration plans to release the text of the agreement it negotiated on China's entry to the World Trade Organization, as early as Tuesday.
That reverses a decision to keep the accord classified until China completed talks with other countries. 
 Both Republican and Democratic lawmakers demanded that the administration release the agreement, which has been under wraps since it was signed in November, because they say Congress cannot vote on whether to grant China permanent normal trade relations while the W.T.O. agreement remains secret. As part of that accord, the administration asked Congress to give up its annual review of China's trade rights in this country.
The vote on permanent normal trade relations is one of Mr. Clinton's top foreign policy priorities, administration officials have said. Mr. Clinton argues that it is a strategic imperative to get China into the World Trade Organization, where it would be subject to the trading rules that most other nations follow. He has also said that freer trade supports the drive for economic openness in the Communist country.
But the agreement has sparked a legislative battle in Congress. Opponents argue that China does not deserve permanent normal trade relations because it violates human rights standards and continues to threaten the use of force against Taiwan, which China regards as a rebellious province. The Senate looks set to grant normal trading rights, but the vote in the House is still up for grabs, Congressional leaders and administration officials said.
"We are taking away an unreal issue and responding to the concerns of some members who wanted to see this agreement and share it," said Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, who is leading the campaign to persuade Congress to grant permanent normal trade relations. "We are just going to get it out there and everyone will see that it confirms what we have been saying -- this is a great deal for the United States."
The pressure on Congress to vote on the matter also increased today when China vowed to join the trade organization, regardless of what the United States does. If Congress were to deny permanent normal trade relations, and China were to join the world group anyway, Beijing could potentially offer other countries more access to its market than American companies would get.
Until now, China had indicated that it would not join the W.T.O. if it was not freed from the annual review. But, apparently sensing that such a declaration gave Congress the leeway to deny China the rights, without incurring any damage to American companies, Beijing signaled that it would pursue entry anyway.
Permanent trade relations affect bilateral ties, said Shi Guangsheng, China's minister of foreign trade. "It will be up to W.T.O. members to decide" whether China enters the global trade body, he said.
Some members of Congress and executives who have security clearances have been allowed to view the full text. But the administration agreed to China's request to delay releasing it to the general public. That fueled suspicions among some opponents that the accord was not as favorable to United States interests as the administration claimed.
Adding to the sensitivity of releasing the text, the White House enraged China in April when it released onto the Internet the negotiating text of the trade agreement even after Mr. Clinton decided not to close the deal at that time. The administration hoped to try to keep China from backtracking in negotiations. But the release was seen as a blow to Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, who came in for heated criticism domestically for concessions he made.
Clinton administration officials said they agreed to keep the agreement secret because China did not want Europe, Mexico and some 20 other countries that had yet to complete their own bilateral negotiations on China's entry to the trade body to try to one-up the United States. Administration officials said they also did not want extended haggling by other countries to delay China's admission to the trade body.
The administration argues that it has disclosed all the relevant contents of the agreement. But it has only released the headline concessions China made, not the full text.
The full text contains 250 pages of detailed legal language on tariffs, quotas and market access for some 5,000 types of goods and services, administration officials said.
Among the highlights, the pact allows foreign companies to own 49 percent of Chinese telecommunications companies once China joins the W.T.O., a level rising to 50 percent after two years. Foreign banks will be allowed to conduct local-currency business with Chinese enterprises two years after China enters. China will cut the tariffs it imposes on cars to 25 percent from 80 percent or higher by 2006.
China also agreed to raise quotas and lower tariffs on wheat, corn, rice and cotton, products in which the United States is thought to have a substantial comparative advantage.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
Shells Wound 2 in Tehran In Attack Tied to Leftists
Several mortar shells were fired into a residential complex abutting a military base in Tehran's northern suburbs, a day after one of Iran's leading democratic reformers was critically wounded in a shooting on a street in the capital. A leftist group took responsibility for the attack, in which two people were hurt. A4
 
Barak Holds His Post
The Israeli Parliament debated two motions of no confidence in Prime Minister Ehud Barak but failed to garner the necessary votes to bring down the government. A3 

Pope Adds West Bank Stop
Pope John Paul II scheduled a visit next week to a traditional site of Jesus' baptism in a West Bank area under Israeli military control. A3
 
China Deal to Be Made Public
The Clinton administration plans to release the text of an agreement it negotiated on the terms of China's entry to the World Trade Organization, reversing a decision to keep it classified until China completed its talks with other countries. A10
 
China and Taiwan Waste Talks
China and Taiwan secretly agreed to pursue a multibillion dollar deal to make the mainland a final resting place for waste from Taiwan's nuclear power plants, officials said. Such a deal would represent a major reversal in Taiwan's policy of restraining economic ties with China. A10
 
Politics Drives Taipei Sell-Off
Taipei's stock market had its largest single-day point loss on fear that the Nationalist Party might lose the presidential election Saturday. A10

HEADLINE: Forlorn and Forgotten in the Stacks;
Low Pay Is Driving Many Librarians Out of New York City

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Jane Pierce, manager of the Hamilton Fish Public Library on the Lower East Side, loves almost everything about her job.
She loves holding storytelling time for the dozen elementary school classes that visit each week. She loves leading adult book discussions. And she loves reading aloud at nearby homes for the elderly and at hospices for AIDS patients. She sees being a librarian as being a missionary for books and for reading. 
 But Ms. Pierce has been increasingly bothered by the one aspect of her job she does not love: her salary, which is just $40,000 after 14 years, so low, she says, that she faces eviction from her $1,650-a-month apartment.
"What we earn isn't enough to live on in New York City, with its high rents and living costs," Ms. Pierce said. "I blame the city for the low salaries. Librarians play a vital role in the lives of New Yorkers, whether it's kids, teenagers or adults, and we're not valued enough for that."
It is a complaint that is echoed by her colleagues across the city. If the 1,000 librarians at New York City's public libraries -- the 99-pound weaklings of the municipal labor force -- had a mantra, it would have to be: we get no respect.
They point out that they are paid less than the city's garbage collectors, even though librarians are required to have master's degrees. And they say it is difficult to get anyone to pay attention: many politicians, they say, are too busy listening to the salary complaints of the city's more numerous teachers and police officers, who have far more visibility and public support.
As a result, many librarians are leaving the city's public libraries for bigger salaries in the suburbs and private industry, creating an exodus that library officials say has left New York City facing a critical shortage. Even library administrators acknowledge that librarians are leaving because many make less than $35,000 after five years on the job and often 25 percent or more below levels in the suburbs and industry as a whole. Library officials say the exodus, which parallels that of teachers and police officers, is also depriving the public library system of experienced personnel.
Half of newly hired librarians leave within three years, library system officials say, while the city is unable to attract enough qualified librarians to fill the many openings. One result is that nearly one-third of the branch libraries in the Bronx do not have children's librarians, at a time when experts say the city's schoolchildren need to read more to improve their test scores.
The presidents of the public library systems for the five boroughs have asked Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to give librarians a 15 percent catch-up raise as the city begins contract talks with unions representing nearly 300,000 municipal workers.
"The overwhelming majority of people who run branch libraries earn $37,265, even though they have huge responsibilities," said Ray Markey, president of the union representing 1,800 librarians and library aides in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island. "They oversee book collections. They manage custodians, security guards and library assistants. They fix computer printers, fix toilets and sometimes even shovel snow. The amount they are paid to do all this is ridiculous, and that's why so many people are walking out the door."
But City Hall officials have already indicated that a 15 percent raise is out of the question, saying it would help erase the city's budget surplus and encourage other city employees to seek similar salary increases.
Many librarians say City Hall's hard line will only accelerate their exodus, especially because the Internet economy is making their salaries all the more uncompetitive. High-paying dot-com companies are snapping up librarians because of the valuable database and research skills they are taught while obtaining their master's degrees.
Upset about the pay, Nancy Trott left her $30,000-a-year job at the Brooklyn Public Library's business branch to take a position paying nearly double that at McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm.
Carol Freitag was paid $32,000 a year to run a branch library in the Rockaways, but last year she jumped to Elmont, N.Y., lured by a $39,000 post as a children's librarian.
And Sean Flynn quit a $32,500 job at the Queens Central library to take a post paying $42,000, nearly 30 percent more, at a library in Setauket on Long Island.
"I loved my job in Queens, and I would still be there except for the salary thing," Mr. Flynn said. "My wife also works at a library in the city, so it was very difficult for us to make ends meet. The pay certainly prevented us from buying a house, and it gave us pause about having kids."
For many librarians, the most dismaying aspect of the city's pay scale is that maximum pay is generally $42,000, even for librarians with 20 or 30 years' experience. In a field that is overwhelmingly female, librarians often assert that sexual discrimination is a factor behind their pay levels.
"By any measurement, New York City public librarians are underpaid," said Paul LeClerc, president of the New York Public Library, which runs the public libraries in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island. "Librarian salaries start lower and increase slower than they do for librarians in major cities, such as San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Cleveland or Philadelphia."
James F. Hanley, the city's labor commissioner, recently told union leaders that the city would grant librarians a sizable raise only if they first agreed to increase productivity, specifically by working longer hours.
John Socha, president of the local representing librarians in Queens, rejected that idea.
"My members would kill me if I agreed to more hours," Mr. Socha said. "Why would we give up the 35-hour week for more money, when the city's union members won the 35-hour week from Mayor Robert Wagner in lieu of raises they gave up?"
Library and union officials say the city's librarians have already raised their productivity in recent years. Use of the 85 branch libraries in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island grew by 33 percent from 1995 to 1998, while reference inquiries rose by 26 percent, all without an increase in staff.
And many librarians note that in addition to their traditional responsibilities, they now must supervise computer use, help with database research and teach many people how to use the Internet.
Seeing that many well-trained city librarians are ripe for the plucking, libraries in the suburbs and in private industry are recruiting them heavily.
Ms. Pierce said she was starting to pay serious attention to the many fliers that suburban libraries mail to her branch. A recent one came from New Rochelle and advertised an opening for a children's librarian that would pay more than she receives now, even though she heads a thriving branch and manages 10 people.
One recent afternoon, Ms. Pierce read dinosaur stories to a kindergarten class, followed by Langston Hughes poems to a fifth-grade class. Afterward, she helped the fifth graders select biographies for Black History Month and provided Harry Potter books to children whose families would have a hard time buying them.
Ms. Pierce said a big concern among librarians is that low pay has created a shortage of librarians, and as a result, many city libraries have to rely on inexperienced, uncertified assistants.
"One day, a person came in here and said, 'Do you have a book that I can use to explain to my child that I'm going to die of AIDS?' " Ms. Pierce said. "A good children's librarian will know about that. Someone who's not experienced, someone who is not certified, might not be able to help."
The city's librarians face an array of tempting offers. Matthew Willis left the library system to take a $60,000 job at agency.com, an Internet services company. Zahra M. Baird left her $31,000-a-year job running a library branch in the South Bronx to take a $37,000 job as a children's librarian in Scarsdale.
"I didn't choose this career to become rich," Ms. Baird said, "but I didn't take a vow of poverty, either."
Miriam Mandelbaum, a 15-year veteran with two master's degrees, decided to remain at her job in the rare book section at the main New York Public Library, even though Christie's, the auction house, offered her a post paying nearly 50 percent more. She described her work as charity work, made possible only by her husband's salary.
Some are even being lured to the city's own public school system, where the pay for school librarians can rise to $70,000 after 20 years, not to mention summers off.
Carrie Schadle, a Vassar graduate who worked for five years as a children's librarian in East Harlem, recently left to work as a librarian at a school in Williamsburg, attracted by a $5,000 raise that lifted her salary to $37,000.
"I know people who have worked as branch librarians for 25 years and aren't even making $40,000," she said. "It's really hard when all my friends from college are investment bankers and lawyers and are making a quarter million, and I can't even afford to go out to dinner with them."

HEADLINE: Former Gov. Malcolm Wilson, 86, Is Dead

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Malcolm Wilson, who spent 15 years as Nelson A. Rockefeller's lieutenant governor and one year as governor of New York, died yesterday at his daughter's home in New Rochelle. He was 86.
Long the understudy (and after 36 years of state service in all), Mr. Wilson finally became governor in November 1973, when Mr. Rockefeller resigned, and inherited a growing fiscal crisis. A year later, Mr. Wilson was swept from office in the post-Watergate Democratic landslide, losing to Hugh L. Carey by more than 800,000 votes. 
 Known as a consummate parliamentarian, Mr. Wilson spent 20 years in the State Assembly and then, as lieutenant governor, presided over the State Senate. His command of the rules was such that, even as they complained, Democrats could not help but express admiration for Mr. Wilson's political skills.
Mr. Wilson, who often lapsed into Latin and kept an unfailingly cheerful mien in public, often gave the impression of being too erudite, too much the gentleman and too lacking in concern for appearances to play the roughhouse game of politics. In the mid-1970's, he refused his aides' pleas to give up the narrow ties he wore, then badly out of fashion, insisting that they were still perfectly good.
Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday described Mr. Wilson as "a wonderful human being" who, to his detriment, disdained talk of politics and the careful positioning politicians engage in. He recalled that in the 1974 campaign, reporters peppered the governor with questions about President Ford's pardon of Richard M. Nixon. Mr. Wilson disagreed with the pardon, said Mr. Pataki -- who was then a young lawyer working on Republican campaigns -- but Mr. Wilson would not say so because he thought it irrelevant to his post.
"There were a lot of political issues that could have been attractive and could have helped him in the campaign," Mr. Pataki said. "But what he wanted to focus on was policy."
In 1938, at age 24, Mr. Wilson was first elected to the Assembly from a district that included his hometown, Yonkers. Using skills acquired as a member of the Fordham University debating team and an eye for detail, he became known for his ability to get his bills passed. One of the best known created the Higher Education Assistance Corporation, which made college loans widely available for the first time in the state.
In 1958, he threw in his lot with Mr. Rockefeller, scion of the nation's wealthiest family, who had never before run for office. Mr. Wilson became a political tour guide of sorts, driving Mr. Rockefeller about the state to introduce him to local chieftains eager for a fresh candidate.
Quietly and just the two of them, they made the rounds in Mr. Wilson's own car in order not to flaunt the novice's immense wealth. Mr. Wilson sold his man, who then insisted that Mr. Wilson be chosen as his running mate.
Some looked upon Mr. Rockefeller as a sacrificial lamb to run against Gov. W. Averell Harriman, the Democratic incumbent. But Mr. Rockefeller beat the odds and Mr. Wilson stood in his shadow for the next nearly 15 years. Although the law severely limits the lieutenant governor's executive functions, Mr. Rockefeller put Mr. Wilson's vast expertise and connections to use by making him a member of his inner circle.
Through those years, the two men publicly differed on only one issue of principle. Unlike Governor Rockefeller, Mr. Wilson -- a Roman Catholic -- opposed the legalization of abortion. He was generally considered a conservative but, rejecting such political labeling, he defined himself as "an economic conservative and a human-rights liberal."
Forever loyal, he never spoke ill of the ever-upward spiral of spending and debt under Mr. Rockefeller that led to the fiscal crisis, though friends and aides said it doubtless contradicted his own instincts.
As the enduring No. 2, Mr. Wilson always presented a proper, for the most part amiable, face to the world. At the same time, it was no secret in Albany that he would not mind dropping the "lieutenant" from his title once Mr. Rockefeller moved on to indulge his well-known higher ambitions. As he waited, Mr. Wilson presided over the Senate with a ready gavel and an intimidating command of Robert's Rules of Order.
Aside from his mastery of the state budget, Mr. Wilson had a hand in shaping the Governor's priorities. It was he who persuaded Mr. Rockefeller to press for federal revenue sharing to help states that were in financial straits, an idea Mr. Rockefeller successfully pushed after Mr. Nixon won the White House in 1968.
At age 59, Mr. Wilson, by then a grandfather, got his big chance when Mr. Rockefeller, his presidential ambitions thwarted, grew bored with state government and resigned. (The following year, President Ford named Mr. Rockfeller as his vice president).
One of Mr. Wilson's worries as governor was the growing practice by local governments, particularly New York City, of financing local government expenses with a dubious array of fiscal gimmickry. At one point, he admonished, there must come the day of reckoning, as New York City soon learned when it came near financial collapse.
But the first piece of the fiscal crisis to break into view occurred in Mr. Wilson's own bailiwick, at the state's Urban Development Corporation, which flirted with bankruptcy -- an issue Mr. Carey used against him in the 1974 campaign. After taking office, Mr. Carey accused his predecessor of having tried to hide the severity of the crisis, and asserted that Mr. Wilson's outgoing administration had granted him "limited access and little rapport" during the transition.
After losing office, Mr. Wilson was at first an active political fund-raiser and a sought-after speaker at party functions. But increasingly, liberal Rockefeller Republicanism fell from favor, and Mr. Wilson faded from the political scene. He returned to his law practice and served as chairman and chief executive officer of the Manhattan Bank for Savings from 1977 to 1986.
His wife, the former Katharine McCloskey, died in 1980. In 1991, Mr. Wilson underwent surgery for an aortic aneurism, then experienced serious complications. Since then, he had lived with his daughter Katharine Wilson Conroy, a lawyer and former member of the New Rochelle City Council. In addition to Ms. Conroy, he is survived by another daughter, Anne Matthews of Freehold, N.J., and six grandsons.
Charles Malcolm Wilson was born Feb. 26, 1914, in New York City, one of four children in a family of Irish and Scottish ancestry. His first name eventually disappeared, to distinguish him from his father, Charles H. Wilson, a patent attorney who had made an unsuccessful run for the Assembly in 1912. His mother, Agnes, served as a member of national Republican women's groups and as a district party leader in Yonkers, where the family moved in 1920.
Malcolm Wilson graduated from Fordham Preparatory School at 15, Fordham College at 19 and Fordham Law School at 22, in 1936. He spent his entire legal career with the White Plains firm that would become Kent, Hazzard, Jaeger, Greer, Wilson & Fay, becoming a partner in 1946.
He enlisted in the Navy in 1943 and oversaw a gun crew on an ammunition ship that shuttled across the Atlantic and supported the landings at Normandy and Anzio. He kept his Assembly seat, winning re-election in absentia, and returned to New York in 1945 with the rank of lieutenant j.g.
As a government official, aides said, Mr. Wilson was addicted to detail and studied tomes of reports that caused lesser mortals to doze off. His discourses on the affairs of state tended to be soporific, although no Albany insider would have disputed his ability to grapple with complex issues.
In fact, Mr. Wilson had a distaste for the oversimplification so common to politics. Beware of simple answers, he warned, quoting the Swiss historian Jacob Burkhardt: "The essence of tyranny is the denial of complexity."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. WILL ENDORSE EUROPEAN NOMINEE TO LEAD THE I.M.F.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
President Clinton told Germany's chancellor today that he would accept Horst Kohler as the new head of the International Monetary Fund, ending a heated diplomatic contest over who would lead the institution that battles global financial crises.
Mr. Clinton's apparently reluctant support virtually ensures that Mr. Kohler, a former German finance official who is now president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, will win the post of managing director of the I.M.F. 
 But the rift that opened during the selection process -- during which Mr. Clinton refused to support Germany's first nominee and developing nations tried to install their own candidate -- leaves open many questions about how the much-criticized institution will change, and about the tradition-bound method by which its leaders are chosen.
In interviews today, senior administration officials who had been far from enthusiastic about Mr. Kohler last week began to speak of his strengths, describing him as "an important player" in the economic unification of Germany and the creation of the European Monetary Union.
Just a few weeks ago, his name was not even on the short list of finance ministers, central bankers and European politicians judged by the United States Treasury and European officials to have the political standing and judgment for the job.
Privately, Clinton administration officials had sent signals that they were partial to the candidate Italy was pushing for the job, Treasury Secretary Giuliano Amato. Italy had been the most vocal opponent of Mr. Kohler, but agreed to support him at a meeting today of European Union finance ministers.
Washington's approval seemed driven more by a sense that Mr. Clinton could not turn down a second German candidate, and one endorsed directly by the German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, according to administration officials close to the internal deliberations.
Just two weeks ago, Mr. Clinton rejected the selection of Caio Koch-Weser, Germany's deputy finance minister. That led one of Mr. Schroder's top advisers, Michael Steiner, to complain that the United States "sees its global role not only in the military area but also in setting the rules of globalization through the I.M.F."
But in the end, Germany, an essential NATO ally, won its struggle. Mr. Clinton and Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, according to the administration officials, concluded that they could not violate the 50-year unwritten rule that allows Europe to fill the I.M.F. post while the United States appoints the head of the World Bank.
The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said Mr. Clinton had spoken to Mr. Schroder this afternoon from Cleveland, where he was promoting his plan for expanded prescription drug coverage.
"The president told Chancellor Schroder that the United States was prepared to support Mr. Kohler as the new head of the I.M.F.," Mr. Lockhart said. "The president and Schroder agreed that Mr. Kohler should come to Washington to meet with the I.M.F. board, particularly with the developing countries," Mr. Lockhart said. They also agreed that Mr. Kohler "should retain the talented management team at the I.M.F."
That was thinly veiled code to suggest that Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official of the bank and the man promoted by African and Middle East nations for the top job, should remain in place. Mr. Fischer, formerly head of the economics department at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was the I.M.F. architect of the bailout of Asia during the economic crisis that began in 1997.
Mr. Clinton's decision came only hours after all 15 nations within the European Union today endorsed Germany's new candidate.
As the administration has learned in the last five years or so -- first when the Mexican peso collapsed, then when the Asian tigers, Russia and Brazil saw their economies implode -- the United States has an enormous stake in who heads the I.M.F. In return for providing emergency loans and arranging bailouts, the fund can command great changes in a country's economic policies. Sometimes it is heeded, as it was by Thailand and South Korea, two of its biggest success stories. Sometimes its prescriptions touch off political instability; it was widely criticized for hurting Indonesia's poor while saving the banks that lent the country money. Without question, the I.M.F.'s prescriptions in Indonesia sped the departure of its longtime dictator, President Suharto.
In Russia, however, the fund has met considerable political resistance and little success. It has repeatedly delayed disbursing funds until Moscow fulfilled its economic commitments. And Mr. Kohler will find himself maneuvering with Russia's acting president, Vladimir V. Putin. That will be an important test because Mr. Kohler's current institution, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, watched loan after loan to Russia go bad, and often found itself at the losing end of negotiations with Russian authorities.
Mr. Kohler presided over a large-scale write-off of Russian loans in 1998 that led to the bank's first-ever yearly loss. But it has since returned to profitability, and Mr. Kohler has sought to refocus the bank on small-business loans and smaller-scale development projects since then.
Nonetheless, Mr. Clinton clearly endorsed him before hearing his views on the I.M.F.'s future. In the conversation with Mr. Schroder, one official said: "The president said we need to engage about what his vision will be. And Schroder said 'We'll do it.' "
Mr. Kohler, 57, never topped the list of European candidates to head the I.M.F. When Michel Camdessus announced his retirement last fall, Mr. Kohler's name was among those briefly floated among European officials. But Germany decided to push Mr. Koch-Weser. One reason was almost certainly domestic politics: Mr. Koch-Weser was chosen personally by Mr. Schroder to serve as the No. 2 official in the finance ministry, while Mr. Kohler held the same job under Helmut Kohl, the longtime German chancellor whom Mr. Schroder defeated.
Mr. Kohler comes closer to meeting the litmus test the Treasury Department set for any new I.M.F. director. He has a higher political stature than Mr. Koch-Weser, Clinton administration officials said. He was the financial point man during the unification of East and West Germany, overseeing West Germany's program to quickly integrate the East by unifying the currency on terms favorable to the East and channeling tens of billion dollars in development aid to help development in the Eastern half of the country.
Mr. Kohler was also the top international official in the German finance ministry when European countries agreed on the terms of monetary union in 1992. That showed he had much more experience than Mr. Koch-Weser dealing with currency matters -- a crucial part of the I.M.F.'s duties. Mr. Koch-Weser focused almost exclusively on internal management and poverty relief programs during his 25 years at the World Bank.
Left out of the running was Mr. Fischer, the I.M.F.'s deputy director. In an interview today, he said, "I intend to remain" in that post. He would probably be running the I.M.F. if he did not hold a U.S. passport, and Mr. Clinton was unwilling to have a showdown with Europe over ending the longtime practice that the I.M.F. head would come from the Continent.
Mr. Kohler's likely appointment comes at a time when the I.M.F. is under attack from Republicans in Congress, some of whom are pushing for a drastic streamlining of the fund's operations.
A Congressional commission headed by Allan H. Meltzer, a monetary policy expert at Carnegie Mellon University, issued a report last week that calls for the fund to eliminate many of its lending programs and sharply limit its role as a de facto world central bank.
Clinton administration officials were highly critical of the report, and it is unlikely that all the changes in the report will be put into practice. But the next leader of the I.M.F. will have to grapple with members of Congress who control how much money the United States, the largest I.M.F. donor, contributes.
"Congress has lost confidence in the I.M.F.," said Representative Doug Bereuter, a Nebraska Republican, who serves on the House Banking Committee. "The I.M.F. has been unwilling to admit its errors but sooner or later it will have to."

HEADLINE: City Contracts For Workfare Are Criticized

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi objected yesterday to $469 million in welfare-to-work contracts awarded by the Giuliani administration, saying they raised the appearance of "corruption, favoritism and cronyism." But he acknowledged that he had no power to block them on those grounds, and the administration said it would move forward with the contracts.
"We are not alleging criminality, we are not alleging bribery, we have no evidence of that," Mr. Hevesi said. "We are talking about a corruption of this process, of favoritism, for whatever motive we don't know." 
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dismissed the comptroller's charges in a statement issued after Mr. Hevesi's news conference, suggesting that they were merely the latest move in Mr. Hevesi's bid to build his profile for a possible run for mayor.
"The comptroller's motivations here are purely political and his allegations are phony," Mr. Giuliani said. "These are excellent contracts that will move thousands of people from welfare to work."
The city comptroller's office oversees the granting of city contracts, but the City Charter allows the mayor to override the comptroller when the comptroller's objections involve corruption, and aides said Mr. Giuliani would exercise that right.
The 17 contractors are being hired to reshape, consolidate and run the city's welfare, job training and employment programs, and are to find jobs for about 80,000 over the next three years. There are about 600,000 city residents on welfare, about two-thirds of them children. In 1995, the year Mr. Giuliani began his campaign to reduce the welfare rolls, more than 1.1 million residents were on public assistance.
In objecting to the contracts, Mr. Hevesi said the Giuliani administration had illegally circumvented rules that required competitive bidding.
The comptroller also contended that the company that won the biggest share of the contracts -- Maximus, of McLean, Va. -- had been improperly granted special access by the Giuliani administration. All the while, Mr. Hevesi said, Maximus improperly planned to grant a large piece of its award to a company run by Richard J. Schwartz, a former senior adviser to the mayor on issues including welfare.
As a result, for only the second time in his six years in office, Mr. Hevesi formally raised the allegation of corruption and refused to sign off on the contracts.
The comptroller, already anticipating that the mayor intended to override his objections, said yesterday he was prepared to forward his findings to other authorities for investigation. An associate said these could include the United States attorney, the city's Department of Investigations and the Manhattan district attorney's office.
"We are not talking about $20 or $200,000," Mr. Hevesi said. "We are talking about, with extensions, close to a billion dollars in contracts being presented to this office. The three-year deals in question can be renewed for an additional three years.
"This will lead to independent investigations outside this office," he said. "Others will have to pursue what happened and when and where and who benefited and who didn't benefit in this process."
A month ago, Mr. Hevesi formally rejected the first 3 of the 17 welfare-to-work contracts and threatened to hold up payments, if necessary, to stop them. Yesterday, 31 days after the mayor's office resubmitted the original three contracts and 14 others, Mr. Hevesi said he was required by law either to approve them or object to them. But the Giuliani administration last week submitted documents answering most of the comptroller's outstanding questions, and so the only grounds Mr. Hevesi had to object to the contracts were his allegations of corruption.
Deputy Mayor Anthony P. Coles said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani would override Mr. Hevesi's objection within 24 hours.
Yesterday, the mayor also vetoed two bills related to welfare that were recently passed by the City Council: one would create a government-subsidized employment program giving temporary jobs to 2,500 welfare recipients each year; the other would allow welfare recipients to file grievances if they encountered dangerous working conditions or other problems in their assigned jobs. A City Council spokesman said the council would override the vetoes.
The welfare-to-work program has been a centerpiece of Mr. Giuliani's efforts to reduce the welfare rolls. The city, in fact, has already started to give work to the 17 contractors. As of Wednesday, the city had referred about 5,000 unemployed city residents to the contractors, and 1,010 had already been placed in jobs, at a possible cost to the city of $1.62 million, city officials said.
To date, the companies have been doing the work on speculation, given that the Giuliani administration has not had the ability to pay them. Several companies have been threatening to curtail their services unless the payments are processed quickly.
The contracts in question are broken into two groups: $145 million over three years is slated for firms that are supposed to quickly place welfare recipients into clerical, data entry, custodial or other types of jobs; an additional $320 million over three years is for companies that handle harder-to-place clients. In these more difficult cases, the welfare recipients would first be offered job training or counseling.
The contractors are to be paid three months of start-up costs, but after that they only receive payments if their clients are placed in jobs, with the compensation increasing if the clients hold the jobs for more than three months, a provision that both Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Hevesi support.
Mr. Hevesi's objections to the contracts were divided into three main categories. He said the city had improperly skipped its normal competitive bidding procedure, citing what Mr. Hevesi called false deadlines for the start of the program. The city also offered to pay two contractors, including Maximus, $400 more for each client placed in a job than the companies had asked.
Finally, Mr. Hevesi said, as far back as January 1999, three months before documents show that the city began to formally consider inviting bids for the project, Maximus and top officials at the Human Resources Administration were already involved in detailed discussions of the project. The early meetings with the city allowed Maximus to prepare a much more extensive proposal, Mr. Hevesi said, giving it an advantage over the other bidders.
Mr. Hevesi also said that, while Maximus had indicated it intended to hire a firm run by Mr. Schwartz, it did not disclose a partnership agreement to automatically assign to Mr. Schwartz's Opportunity America consulting firm 30 percent of the $104 million Maximus now expects to be paid over the next three years.
Mr. Schwartz, who left the Giuliani administration in 1997 to found Opportunity America, said his company's involvement in the Maximus bid had been disclosed from the start.
"Opportunity America has behaved in a totally appropriate manner throughout this process," Mr. Schwartz said.
He added that his firm is a subcontractor for Maximus, and not a partner, and that the documentation Opportunity America filed with the city reflected that.
"I have all the documentation to prove that we're a subconcractor," Mr. Schwartz said.
Officials at Maximus disputed the allegations of impropriety yesterday, saying they welcomed any additional investigation of the process.
"The procurement process was above reproach," said Bill Macfadden, Maximus' New York City project director. "It was open, fair and competitive."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Tourism Expo Canceled

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Even some of upstate New York's major tourist destinations have better places to be this spring.
Lack of interest by tourist attractions led the Mohawk Valley Chamber of Commerce to cancel its Spring Tourism Expo, according to the chamber's president, Robert Fowler. 
 "No one wanted to participate," Mr. Fowler said Friday. "We boast that we have 100 tourist attractions and we got 34 that said yes."
That is despite the fact that the area, which includes tourist destinations from Little Falls to Verona, is struggling with economic decline.
The exposition attracted 6,800 people last year. This year's show had been scheduled for March 18-19 at the Mohawk Valley Convention Center.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Aid for Napier Workers

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
About 300 workers who lost their jobs when the Napier Company in Meriden, Conn., abruptly closed last October have received more than $710,000 in federal aid.
The 124-year-old jewelry company was shut down by Victoria & Company of Rhode Island, which bought the Meriden site last year, in an effort to cut costs. 
 The grant from the Department of Labor, announced on Saturday by United States Representative James H. Maloney, a Waterbury Democrat, will extend the time some workers can collect unemployment benefits from 6 to 18 months. The grant will also pay for job training and counseling, college courses and relocation if necessary.

HEADLINE: MULTIMEDIA DEAL: A New Approach to Old Media;
Tribune Company Feeds Content to Diverse Outlets

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 13

 BODY:
The announcement today that the Tribune Company was acquiring the Times Mirror Company elicited this response from Esther H. Dyson, the high-technology pundit: "So one newspaper buys another: so what?"
For Ms. Dyson, a seer of the new economy, the merger amounted to a marriage of survivors of a fading world. The parent company of The Chicago Tribune, which resides in a stately but fortress-like Gothic tower, is tying the knot with the parent company of The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, which has been run by a former General Mills executive, Mark H. Willes. 
 Yet here in Chicago, the Tribune Company has been quietly transforming itself in recent years into what its executives say is a new media company that funnels old media content to television, cable, radio and the Internet. Some journalists fret that these ventures have tarnished the company's newspapers, an accusation that corporate executives stoutly deny.
Before the deal, the Tribune Company had 22 television stations, reaching more than a third of United States households. There were four radio stations, an entertainment unit, a venture capital arm and an educational publishing unit.
The company was an early investor in America Online and Excite and owns a 25 percent stake in the WB television network and a 29 percent stake in cable television's Food Network.
Acquiring Times Mirror would add three of the nation's best known newspapers to that portfolio: Newsday on Long Island, The Los Angeles Times and The Baltimore Sun. The Tribune Company's coast-to-coast empire would include a newspaper and television station in three of the nation's largest markets: New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.
"We think we're creating the premier multimedia company in America," said John W. Madigan, the Tribune Company's chairman, president and chief executive. "We'll have a major presence in the three largest markets in the United States, and that presence will be defined by taking what are essentially local-market media companies and putting them together into a national footprint."
Shares of the Tribune Company dropped $6.375, to $30.8125, on news of the deal. But the company has been a winner on Wall Street in recent years largely because it is trying to meet the convergence of old media and new media head on -- even if not everyone is noticing.
"They're very smart guys up there in Tribune Tower," said Robert A. Davis, a former assistant metropolitan editor at The Chicago Tribune. "They look like ramrod flannel wearing suits, and they are. But they're smart. There's a long reputation of conservatism, but these guys are out there rocking and rolling."
The deal, however, took many here by surprise, even those within the Tribune Company. The company had been betting heavily on television and Internet properties, and now, a decade after selling The Daily News in New York, it was buying up huge newspaper properties in some of the nation's biggest markets.
Executives of the Tribune Company say the merger fits their larger plan, which is to leverage old media newspapers, with their prized content, into new media television, cable and Internet outlets.
Top executives say the new company, will have the influence to sell advertising nationally for its regional newspapers, television stations and its Internet outlets. The company will also create cross-marketing agreements among its properties and find synergies in a world-class news gathering force.
"The more I think about it, the more this furthers the path they began around 1989 to control as much content as humanly possible," said Jeff Borden, a reporter at Crain's Chicago Business who has covered the Tribune Company for more than a decade.
The new media format is also raising some concerns among journalists who worry that the quality of newspapers will suffer in a world driven by profits and entertainment.
The Tribune Company has a reputation not only for being a fierce cost-cutter and union buster but for putting greater and greater emphasis on entertainment and business.
Some reporters and editors in Chicago have complained about the company's drive to merge its newspaper, television and Internet properties into one media conglomerate, in which television reporters share office space with newspaper reporters, story ideas are shared among once competing papers and bureaus are consolidated.
In Washington, the Tribune Media Center houses reporters and editors from The Chicago Tribune, The Orlando Sentinel and several television stations; in The Tribune newsroom, CLTV, a Chicago cable station owned by the company, has set up shop to interview reporters live.
William J. Drummond, a professor of journalism at the University of California at Berkeley who once worked at The Los Angeles Times, said he was troubled by the interest in profits.
"It would really be distressing if the culture of The Los Angeles Times, even with its recent lapses, were hit by more attempts to make it efficient; if they were going to make the Times reporters cooperate with other newspapers and television stations in the name of the corporate glory of the parent," Professor Drummond said.
Others say the Tribune Company is remaking itself into an entertainment company. The company's entertainment arm used to produce Geraldo Rivera's daytime talk show, and these days, reporters at The Chicago Tribune often joke about how "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," the popular WB TV show that runs on many Tribune Company stations, fattens their paychecks.
Indeed, in a conference call with reporters, executives of the Tribune Company talked about how their new enterprise would create a platform for new e-commerce businesses that would sell everything from travel destinations to information.
Scott C. Smith, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, however, said the company was not surrendering its integrity or chipping away at good journalism. It was, he said, simply finding new synergies and a new way to deliver valuable content to readers and consumers.
"Yes it's true the Tribune newspaper margins have improved significantly over the last decade," he said. "But we have more journalists today than we had a decade ago -- and more talented ones."
There are no plans to develop a national newspaper, but the company wants a world-class news gathering organization in which newspaper, television and Internet reporters share information and real estate and even cross into one another's space.
Mr. Smith said The Los Angeles Times was planning a renovation of its newsroom, and the Tribune Company had already suggested that its KTLA television affiliate look at the plans to see whether it wanted to incorporate itself into the Los Angeles newsroom.
Wall Street analysts, surprised by the deal because the Tribune Company had been concentrating on broadcast and Internet properties, said, however, that the Times Mirror newspapers meshed nicely with the Tribune Company's plans.
"To draw an analogy, you've got radio and television companies trying to grab broadcast spectrum, I see this as trying to grab spectrum," said John Morton, who covers the newspaper industry as an independent analyst.
The new company will have papers with a nationwide circulation of 3.6 million, and its television stations will reach more than 38.4 million households. On the Internet, it already ranks as one of the top 20 news and information Web sites with more than 3.4 million visitors each month.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the old- and new-media strategies of the Tribune Company referred incorrectly to Esther Dyson, a technology newsletter publisher who said she was unimpressed by the company's merger with Times Mirror. She has no middle initial.

HEADLINE: Florida's Vouchers a Spur To 2 Schools Left Behind

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: PENSACOLA, Fla.

 BODY:
When Gov. Jeb Bush initiated the nation's boldest voucher experiment last year, it was clear that its fate would depend on two things: the progress of the students using taxpayer money for private-school tuition and the impact on the struggling schools they left behind.
In their Roman Catholic school plaids and pleats, the voucher children stand as symbols of the program's promise: One fourth-grade boy has finally learned to read and a third grader is mastering cursive writing; their parents consider the vouchers a blessing. 
 But in the debate roiling American cities over whether vouchers are the greatest threat to public schools or the best hope to solve the problems that plague them, the more vexing issues arise at two elementary schools here in an impoverished corner of the Florida Panhandle.
Florida is the first state to grant vouchers to students whose schools fail standardized tests and it will probably soon have the nation's largest voucher program. It is the model for a national program proposed by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the likely Republican presidential nominee.
The two schools here, A. A. Dixon and Spencer Bibbs, were the first in the state to lose students to vouchers when the law took effect last summer because so many of their pupils performed so poorly on the tests two years running. While it may take years to gauge the program's success, its impact is already apparent at the two schools, nestled in two of the state's poorest neighborhoods.
With grants from the district and the state, the schools have hired more teachers, reduced class size, stretched the school year by 30 days and added afternoon tutoring.
They have also shriveled the curriculum, emphasizing subjects that will help improve test scores, while shunning science and social studies -- subjects not covered by the tests. They are drilling children on reading, writing, math and, inevitably, test-taking tips. Field trips have disappeared, replaced by events like a recent Saturday "test-taking fair."
"We're leaving out important parts of the education process," lamented Dixon's principal, Judith O. Ladner. "They're going to learn what's on a test. But are they going to learn to be able to cooperate with each other in the business world? Are they going to be creative thinkers?"
At its core, the question over vouchers is whether a market-based approach, embraced in so many sectors today, is appropriate for education. The notion of rating schools based on the standardized test scores of students is sweeping the nation as nearly every state strives to hold teachers and principals more accountable. But beyond providing an escape for children trapped in failing schools, vouchers may be shifting the student-teacher relationship in ways that some find troubling.
"When a low-performing child walks into a classroom," said Jim May, superintendent here in Escambia County, "instead of being seen as a challenge, or an opportunity for improvement, for the first time since I've been in education, teachers are seeing them as a liability."
First proposed by the economist Milton Friedman in 1955, vouchers have exploded from a pilot program of 300 students in Milwaukee in 1990 to 63,840 children in 31 states today, most from low-income families. That includes 11,538 students, mainly in Cleveland and Milwaukee, using public money to attend private schools, and about 70 small programs around the country that are less controversial because they are financed by philanthropists.
Florida has only 53 students using vouchers for private schools and another 85 who transferred to higher-performing public ones.
But school grades being released in June could expand the program to as many as 60,000 students in 78 schools. Those schools received "F's" last year because of poor performances on the Florida Comprehensive Assessment Tests and students would be eligible for vouchers if they are rated "F" a second time.
Though they touch only a fraction of the nation's 52 million schoolchildren, vouchers are among the most contentious issues today in cities including New York, and form a point of dissension between Mr. Bush of Texas and Vice President Al Gore, his expected Democratic opponent.
More than 25 state legislatures are considering voucher plans -- many, like Florida's, linked to standardized test performance -- while constitutional challenges to programs here and in Cleveland are expected to land before the United States Supreme Court.
The philosophical gap is wide: Opponents fear vouchers would drain resources from troubled schools, leaving them worse off for the students who stay. Advocates say that vouchers give poor children opportunities akin to the affluent and would force weak schools to improve.
Research so far has been murky, as partisans pick apart each others' studies.
Over all, experts believe that students using vouchers to attend private schools score slightly higher on math and reading tests than the students who remain in public schools.
But "the great question that nobody can really answer," said John F. Witte, a University of Wisconsin political scientist who has published a book on the Milwaukee voucher program, is, "Does it create competition and does it create change?"
Things are certainly different this year at Bibbs and Dixon, schools where nearly all the students are black and poor enough to qualify for free breakfast and lunch programs.
Hallways at Bibbs were lined with posters of sample answer sheets for the state assessment tests and with efforts to redefine the dreaded "F" label: "We are Fueled, Focused and Fighting." At Dixon, there is a trophy case of prizes -- Pokemon toys, a Sony PlayStation, a television -- for those who score best on the tests.
Inside every classroom, the mission is clear.
In Vickie Ward's fifth-grade class, there was an orange F.C.A.T. math workbook on every desk as Ms. Ward drilled the students on writing multidigit numbers in standard form -- numerals -- and word form. Fifth-grade math scores count toward the school grade.
Rosa Dean's fourth graders were practicing a reading comprehension exercise; their reading scores help determine the school's rating.
"You do the process of elimination," advised Mrs. Dean, sounding like the test-preparation gurus who coach teenagers for the College Boards. "You have four choices; try to get it down to two choices."
Teachers at Bibbs and Dixon, and the parents who spurned the vouchers, blame the F's largely on demographics: many of their families are headed by single mothers or grandmothers on welfare with little education; kindergartners arrive never having picked up a book, not knowing the alphabet.
"I have a bicycle, and the man next door has a Cadillac," said Georgia Smith, a kindergarten teacher at Bibbs. "If you're going to compare the distance I can travel with the man who has a Cadillac, well, let me swap vehicles with that man, and then see how far I can travel."
Indeed, across Florida, no school where less than 10 percent of the students qualify for free lunch scored below a C, and no school where more than 80 percent of the students qualify scored above a C.
Many Florida educators want the results to take account of socioeconomics, or focus on a school's improvement from year to year, rather than judging all schools on the same criteria.
Tom Gallagher, the state's education commissioner and the architect of the school-grading plan along with the governor, said improvement would help dictate school grades as soon as the assessment tests are old enough to track annual progress. But "our expectations are the same for a first grader in Coral Gables as it is for Bibbs or Dixon," he insisted. As for whether test preparation has squeezed out enrichment programs and even basics like science, Mr. Gallagher is not worried: Nobody can pass the test, he noted, without reading its directions.
"You can't operate in our society if you can't read, write and do math," he said. "You can operate in our society if you haven't been on a field trip, if you haven't had any art this year, if you haven't been to gym, and if you haven't had any science."
Though parochial students do not take the tests, those using vouchers must. So there were no signs of the test -- no posters in the hallways, no mention of multiple-choice bubble techniques -- at Little Flower, one of the five private schools, four of them Catholic, where former Bibbs and Dixon students have enrolled.
In classrooms arrayed around a central courtyard with a fountain, fifth graders were writing persuasive letters, while first graders put on a puppet show.
"Last year, it was nothing but work sheets," said Patricia White, whose daughter, Katrina English, took a voucher. "Now, homework every night, books, essays to write. We just finished a report with poster board and such -- we didn't even leave the house last Saturday!"
Teachers say they have tweaked the curriculum -- cutting spelling tests to 10 words a week from 20 for one boy -- but that the acculturation process was not much different than with other public-school transfers.
Many voucher families had always wanted to send their children to private school but could not afford it; some were just fed up with what they saw as behavior problems and low expectations at Bibbs and Dixon.
Andy Cameron, whose son, Ray, was repeating fourth grade this year at St. Michael's, called Dixon "a giant sewer" where "the academic atmosphere was nonexistent."
Ms. White said she volunteered in Katrina's class every day last year, and saw third graders still struggling to identify letters; even if vouchers are ruled illegal, she will keep Katrina in Catholic school.
"I got cable; it'll go," Ms. White said. "The telephone? That's a luxury. I will get a night job. I'll do what I have to do. She's getting a better education."
In this very enthusiasm over the children's progress lies a potential pitfall. Whether vouchers are targeted by income, as in Milwaukee or Cleveland, or by school performance, as here in Florida, they are typically seized by families with relatively more money and better educational backgrounds; the most disenfranchised of the disadvantaged groups stay behind, only making the educational challenge steeper.
As Bibbs and Dixon struggle to get off the "F" list, principals and teachers are working overtime, and children are focused as they study in small groups, aided by an influx of volunteers serving as mentors.
Evaluating their effectiveness is tricky. In the writing laboratory at Bibbs, fourth graders cheerily chant a rhyme about adverbs; but they cannot name any. They enthusiastically sing a song diagramming sentences, but when asked to define a "predicate," one of the items they have just identified, the children are at a loss.
At Dixon, a simple sign suggests the complexity of the challenge: "Teach half as much, twice as well."

There are nearly 64,000 children using vouchers to attend private schools, but that number could explode this spring when as many as 60,000 students in Florida alone may become eligible. Here is a look at programs across the country, including those in Florida, Cleveland and Milwaukee, which are paid for by taxes, and the Children's Scholarship Fund, which is one of several programs sponsored by private philanthropists:
 
Florida (Opportunity Scholarship)
Student Eligibility: Students assigned to a public school whose pupils fail standardized tests twice in four years.
Participation: No limit. Participation for this school year is 53. As many as 60,000 students could be eligible next year.
Voucher Amount: Distric;s cost per student, or the private school's tuition, whichever is less. Currently about $3,400.
 
Cleveland (Pilot Project Scholarship)
Student Eligibility: Priority to families with income below double the federal poverty level. Applicants selected by lottery.
Participation: Depends on funds allocated by the Ohio State Legislature. Participation for this school year is 3,484 students.
Voucher Amount: For those below twice the poverty level, 90 percent of the private school's tuition or $2,250, whichever is less. Other families get 75 percent of tuition or $2,250, whichever is less.
 
Milwaukee (Milwaukee Parental Choice)
Student Eligibility: Income may not be more than 75 percent above the poverty level. Applicants selected by lottery.
Participation: No more than 15 percent of the Milwaukee Public Schools' enrollment. Participation for this school year is 7,996 students.
Voucher Amount: For this school year, maximum of $5,106 per pupil or private school's cost of education, whichever is less.
 
Nationwide (Children's Scholarship Fund)
Student Eligibility: Families who earn up to 170 percent more than the poverty level; for a family of four, income must be below $44,415. Average income is $21,000.
Participation: 40,000 students in 48 states, concentrated in Chicago, Detroit, New York and Los Angeles. Selected by lottery from among 1.25 million applicants.
Voucher Amount: Varies, but average is about $1,000. Families must also contribute to tuition, typically about $1,000. Fund has awarded $160 million in scholarships since 1998. (Source: Institute for the Transformation of Learning)(pg. A20)
