HEADLINE: How Big a Part Of G.D.P. Are Office Pools? Make a Bet?

BYLINE: By JOBERT E. ABUEVA 

 BODY:
Don't try calling Jake Williams right now about his company's product line. Mr. Williams, a manager at Furnimex, a distributor of home textiles based in Dallas, is working furiously against a deadline of noon tomorrow to complete a special project.
Starting Monday morning, faxes began piling up on his desk, his voicemail light started blinking and messages began clogging his e-mail. As in years past, Mr. Williams is spending much of his workday confirming the orders pouring in and collecting cash from customers. 
 But not all of them are Furnimex customers. Mr. Williams organizes an office betting pool for the granddaddy event of them all: the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship playoffs, a.k.a. March Madness, with 64 of the nation's top men's teams battling it out throughout the next two and a half weeks.
And here is the twist: Mr. Williams says his role as numbers man is good for business, good for workplace morale and even good for his family life since he enlists the help of his wife and son in the tabulations.
"It gets everyone excited and talking around the water cooler, regardless of their function and position in the company," Mr. Williams said. It is also a lifeline to customers old and new, he said. When his previous employer moved him from New York to Dallas 12 years ago, he said, "Everyone identified me as the sports fan, and, as many colleagues remained in New York, they wanted to know whether the tradition would be maintained."
They did not have to worry. Even though he took a job with Furnimex six years ago, the office pool he organizes around March Madness gives him a chance to renew old contacts. "It's an annual high moment that so many busy partners and friends look forward to, year in and year out," he said.
It may sound crazy, but a lot of business consultants agree with him, and many corporate bosses have long tolerated office pools on sporting events and award shows as harmless diversions. But some say the pools are much more than that because they increase camaraderie and encourage interaction in the workplace.
"The betting pool, as a shared experience, gives co-workers an excuse to see each other face to face in a world where technology has put efficiency, but distance, in our work relationships," said Bob Nelson, a consultant and author of "1001 Ways to Take Initiative at Work" (Workman, 1999).
Matt Weinstein, founder of Playfair, a management consulting firm in Berkeley, Calif., and co-author of "Work Like Your Dog" (Villard, 1999), says betting pools can make the workplace more fun -- an important consideration for retaining employees in the current job market. They can also add a light touch to otherwise humdrum activities. "Pools run the gamut from what time the U.P.S. deliveryman will arrive to how many pie charts a vice president will use during his presentation," he said.
Mr. Williams's pools have sometimes produced results that warm the hearts of even the losers. Once, a secretary who was eight months pregnant took the top prize. Another year, it was a 15-year-old high school sophomore, the son of one of Mr. Williams's customers. And once it was a top industry executive who split the money among three clerks who had entered losing sheets.
For Peter Bielby, a design engineer in Ann Arbor, Mich., betting pools are just part of the work landscape. "Pools exist everywhere I've worked -- Texas, Georgia and now back in Michigan," he said. "People look forward to it. It acts as a morale booster."
From the opening tap at the N.C.A.A. tournament's first-round game tomorrow afternoon until the April 3 championship in Indianapolis, millions of workers with a stake in the outcome will be monitoring each game, rooting for the "right" team combination. As in years past, many will crowd into office conference rooms with television sets or flip on a radio on the factory floor to catch the action.
The entry fee of $10 a sheet for Mr. Williams's pool has not changed since its inception, he said. The number of participants has grown, though, to 450 last year. That is a pot of $4,500, with the top winner getting $3,000; the first runner-up, $900, and the second, $600. This is still small potatoes compared with Wall Street pots that investment bankers say can go to five or even six figures. In all, it has been estimated that $6 billion changes hands annually in office pools around the nation, led by the Super Bowl and March Madness in dollar volume.
The volume is big enough to support a few software packages and a growing number of Web sites. The March Madness Tournament Tracker, for example, which can be downloaded from sportsdatatech.com, can track and rank up to 1,000 entries, saving organizers endless paperwork -- an efficiency that the bosses of America no doubt appreciate. Mr. Williams, though, happily remains in the Dark Ages, keeping score by hand.
In addition, Web sites like Gamesville.com and Easypool.com are for an assortment of pools. And the N.C.A.A. Web site, ncaachampionships.com, offers printouts of team seeds and pairings as well as updates.
Before the Final Four games on April 1, Mr. Williams will work out all the possibilities and advise the front-runners of their chances of winning. "This is always fun because loyalties can change in an instant, even against one's alma mater," he said. It also becomes a chance for Mr. Williams to set up appointments with Furnimex customers in the pool once the tournament ends.
So, does he face an emotional letdown when the madness is over? Not really. He and other regulars in the N.C.A.A. pool are already preparing for the draft next month for fantasy, or Rotisserie, baseball.

HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE;
Dissonance At the Pump

BYLINE: By Neil Strauss 

 BODY:
The average price of gasoline has hit yet another record high, rising for the ninth week, to $1.53 a gallon. Such inflation is hard on commuters, trucking companies and owners of sport utility vehicles. But there is another vehicle-dependent class that may be among the hardest hit in the short term: rock bands and other touring musicians. For many fledgling acts crisscrossing the country on their own dime and performing low-paying gigs in hopes of building an audience, the surge in gas prices has been crippling.
"We have a diesel truck, and in some places the gas is over $2 a gallon," said Pete Donnelly, the bassist and singer with a New York City rock group, the Figgs. "So for a band like us, where we're not making a lot of money, the gas really affects us, especially when we get out to the Midwest and West Coast and have to drive eight hours between shows. We've had to cut all our extra costs, including our road manager." 
 Bands are affected not only by the extra costs but also by concerns that gas prices will deter fans from traveling long distances to get to their shows. "I just drove to Washington, D.C., this weekend for a show, and we spent more money on gas than we did on the tickets," said Ginger Nance, a senior at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, of a recent concert by the English rock band Gomez. "I'm in college, and I don't have much money. So if it's going to cost $40 to get to a show, on top of parking and ticket costs, I'll definitely reconsider going to so many shows."
Concert promoters said they had not yet seen a noticeable dip in ticket sales. But they worry that if gas prices continue to rise, that could have a significant impact on the summer music season, when the majority of big-name concerts take place.
This is particularly worrying because they also anticipate a rise in the price of concert tickets this summer and most summer amphitheaters are an hour or so outside major cities, making gas prices an even bigger factor. The combination of steep ticket prices, service charges, inflation in fuel prices, parking costs and all the other incidentals of concertgoing (not to mention the difficulty of getting tickets to an in-demand show) could make attending a concert daunting.
Others in the industry do not expect any major fallout, said Bob Grossweiner, a concert-business analyst, because in the elastic world of popular music "the higher the price of the ticket, the faster it sells." He did note, however, that if high gas prices continued to increase bands' touring expenses, a result could be even higher ticket prices.
Particularly affected by the gas gain may be so-called jam bands like Phish and Widespread Panic, whose devoted audiences often follow them from city to city. "I think the increase in gas prices most certainly weighs heavily on the minds of anyone hitting multiple shows in a row," said Andy Gadiel, who runs the Web site Jambase.com as well as a popular Phish fan site, though he added that it would take a lot more than expensive gasoline to keep a hard-core fan from attending a show.
Seymour Guenther, a booking agent at the Nancy Fly Agency in Austin, Tex., said the gasoline hike could make a difference in the way tours are routed. "I was thinking that we may have to look at getting more money for them out there," he said of his touring acts. "The sudden rise in prices really has changed the amount of money that they bring home. We have a guy out right now who bought an old van and thought he could get around cheaply. But it's only getting 12 miles to the gallon, and it's eating his lunch."
That is Slaid Cleaves, whose rootsy album is currently topping the Americana charts. "It's just one more challenge out there," Mr. Cleaves said from a tour stop in Kentucky. "When you have to shell out $45 to $50 a night for gas, it hurts. Right now we're doing a radio show that doesn't pay any money and was a day out of our way. And maybe we wouldn't have done that if we knew gas was $1.50 a gallon."
The Memphis band Those Bastard Souls could not pay for a hotel room one night after putting $50 into the gas tank. "It's like putting a hotel room into your gas tank," said David Shouse, the band's singer.
On its current tour the group became obsessed with filling stations and prices. "We keep track of gas prices every day in the news," Mr. Shouse said. "Then we play the gas game and try to discover gas stations we've never gone to before. We bought no brand-name gas at all on this tour. But it's almost like Russian roulette, because you wonder when you're going to get a tankful of water by going the cheap route."
Todd Herfindal, the singer and guitarist with the unsigned San Francisco band Blue Sky Roadster, said there was one advantage to the soaring prices. "We just did a stint down to Las Vegas, Los Angeles and back, and it was almost $300 in gas for a big van," he said. "Our bass player put it all on his Shell card, and we're all going to pay him back. But at least he gets miles on his air fare for it, and now he's going to Puerto Vallarta in May."

SECTION: Section C; Page 16; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 37 words

 BODY:

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: The Afterlife Of a Powerful Chief;
'I'm Actually Back Doing Things,' Says One Starting Anew

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: SANTA ROSA, Calif.

 BODY:
It was about noon on a Wednesday, and the retired Silicon Valley executive in a black V-neck sweater was considering a much more relaxed range of choices than he was accustomed to: Should he start with a merlot? Or perhaps a cabernet sauvignon? And should it be a recent vintage or an older, riskier one?
Eventually, he dived in, nose first, and, after a long sniff, took a generous sip of the 1988 merlot. Pronouncing it acceptable, he moved on to the 1990, 1991 and 1994 versions. Then came the cabernets and finally a single chardonnay to wrap up the tasting. 
 After each tilt of a glass, however, came a clue that this was not a typical northern California retiree: the man swished the wine around in his mouth and then spit it into a red plastic cup. It was still before lunch, after all, and the man, Lewis E. Platt, had hours more work in front of him.
Mr. Platt, it turns out, is retired only from Silicon Valley, not from the business world. In one of the more unusual corporate job changes in years, Mr. Platt, 58, left Hewlett-Packard last year after 33 years, including an up-and-down seven-year term as chief executive, and promptly took the top job at Kendall-Jackson Wine Estates.
It was quite a transition. Since December, he has moved from Palo Alto and a global company with 124,000 employees at the center of the new economy, to Wine Country and a private firm with 1,200 workers in one of the world's oldest industries.
When Mr. Platt accepted the Kendall-Jackson job late last year rather than take the more common path of sitting on corporate boards, teaching business school classes or leading a foundation, he generated a buzz among executives around the country. Gerard R. Roche, the headhunter who selected him, said he had since received calls from at least six "big-name C.E.O.'s" asking for help in finding similar posts when they retire.
One executive said, "Get me something like that! What a way to go out," according to Mr. Roche, the chairman of the search firm Heidrick & Struggles.
Mr. Platt's new job certainly seems romantic. A wine enthusiast with a 2,500-bottle cellar at home, he works in Kendall-Jackson's headquarters here, about 60 miles north of San Francisco, with a first-floor corner office that looks out on a vineyard and the mountains that separate Napa and Sonoma Counties. He has come to the industry in good times, when the long economic expansion has inspired many Americans to drink more expensive wine. Kendall-Jackson has been one of the main beneficiaries, becoming perhaps the biggest California success story of the last decade on the strength of its $10 chardonnay.
But Mr. Platt's switch has also brought a management problem the textbooks do not discuss: how does an executive who has already climbed his way to the top, and grown used to the trappings that come with one of corporate America's plum jobs, start anew? The question is particularly relevant because both the average age and the average tenure of chief executives at large companies are dropping. As the calls to Mr. Roche indicate, even those chiefs with sterling resumes and lots of energy will be pondering what to do in the coming years.
Mr. Platt's answer has been to sublimate his ego, forget about the trappings and pretend he is 20 years younger, running a division of Hewlett-Packard. He has thrown himself into the number crunching and small decisions that he once relegated to underlings. "I'm actually back doing things," the burly, mild-mannered Mr. Platt said with satisfaction.
In his previous life, he made millions, dined with President Clinton and swapped ideas with foreign leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Now, Mr. Platt says, he wants to turn his attention to one of his passions and get the satisfaction that comes from having direct responsibility for products.
In truth, he had plenty of reasons to take up fishing, one of his hobbies, after leaving Hewlett-Packard. Though the company flourished under him at first, profits slumped in his final years. Some employees and investors blamed his relaxed style, contrasting him with more aggressive corporate leaders who have remade hidebound companies. His successor, Carleton S. Fiorina, has even become the star of Hewlett-Packard's current advertising campaign, saying, "The original start-up will act like one again."
At Kendall-Jackson, Mr. Platt is at a company with a firebrand of its own. Jess Jackson, a San Francisco trial lawyer who founded the winery, and his former wife, Jane, were the only people ever to have run it, and he remains its chairman. "Jess Jackson took K. J. from a small, second-tier producer and placed it squarely among the top 10 premium producers in California," said David I. Freed, the chairman of Silverado Premium Properties, a company in Napa, Calif., that sells grapes to wineries. (Kendall is a family name of Mr. Jackson's former wife, who is no longer in management.)
Mr. Jackson has the strong entrepreneurial personality and will not have an easy time relinquishing control, say people who have worked with him. Mr. Platt, in other words, went from the undisputed head of a $50 billion company to one of two bosses at a $400 million concern.
All of which has led some industry analysts to speculate that Mr. Platt is mostly window-dressing to help Kendall-Jackson go public, a move that it has been considering for two years. Even some of his friends think his venture into the wine business is something of a lark, Mr. Platt says.
"I've had more trouble convincing my friends this is work -- they think I sit around and do tastings all day long," he said. Not so, he said: "This is a real job."
One of his first tasks has been to tinker with parts of his management style to fit his new job. Although Hewlett-Packard is a relatively flat organization where all executives work out of cubicles, Mr. Platt still relied on dozens of analysts to comb through information for him. Though he is known for his mild manners, he once stood up in front of a crowd of managers, told them they were falling down on the job, asked them for new ideas and then blasted those new ideas the next day.
At Kendall-Jackson, by contrast, he has stepped gingerly. He has told his new employees that he does not consider himself a wine industry expert simply because he is a collector. On a tour of Kendall-Jackson's storage rooms and bottling plant, for example, he met some employees for the first time and spoke to them as if he were a tourist visiting the winery, asking them about everything from the speed of a conveyer belt to the level of tannic acid in a wine. During the tasting of merlots and cabernets, he proclaimed his judgment of various vintages, but then turned to Kendall-Jackson's winemaster to see how close to the truth he was.
Only when Mr. Platt stepped into a laboratory and noticed a Hewlett-Packard chemicals machine did he try to show off some of his own knowledge. "I actually managed Hewlett-Packard's chemicals business for many years," he said, smiling, to the workers in the room.
He has brought a similar care to his relationship with Mr. Jackson. The two speak frequently, and Mr. Platt says he has been mindful of not grabbing the reins too quickly. "There are always some issues when the owner or founder is still involved," said Mr. Platt, who was Hewlett-Packard's chief when David Packard was still chairman. "You can't just storm in and take over."
Mr. Jackson said, "Lew has a selflessness about his leadership."
He also has the kind of corporate experience that almost every other professional oenophile lacks, and in a few ways he is trying to reshape Kendall-Jackson instead of himself. His laid-back approach, he hopes, will allow him to bring discipline to an enterprise that has sprouted some bureaucracy as it has grown.
When he arrived in January, Mr. Platt found an approval process for travel and other expenditures that often required five signatures for a single trip. Kendall-Jackson also had little in the way of a formal bonus plan, and employees say they received extra money largely at the whim of their bosses.
Now, all employees know their bonus depends on some combination of their year-end review, their department's performance and the company's profits. And managers receive a budget and can spend money on travel as they see fit. "As you start to give people a little more freedom," Mr. Platt said, "you can actually transfer a lot of responsibility."
(One byproduct of bureaucracy that Mr. Platt will not eliminate is the door to his office. This is the first time he has ever had one, he said.)
All the while, Mr. Platt says he has been enjoying taking more direct responsibility for the nuts-and-bolts decisions of running a company. He is studying Kendall-Jackson's vineyards to determine those that can be replanted to produce red wine, which became much more popular in the 1990's as some doctors credited moderate drinking of it with lowering the risk of heart disease. More than 70 percent of Kendall-Jackson's wine is now chardonnay.
Another priority is to sell more Kendall-Jackson wine overseas. Now, just 3 percent of its output leaves the United States.
In some ways, his current education resembles his intense introduction to wine in the 1980's. Shortly after moving to California for Hewlett-Packard, he immersed himself in the subject, buying books, attending tastings and pumping for information from his boss at the time, who was Hewlett-Packard's chief operating officer and a wine aficionado.
It was all a reaction to the first dinner parties he gave in his new state and the wine he served. "People made fun of me," he remembers, "and I didn't like that."

HEADLINE: Cohen Looks To Closer Ties With Vietnam

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, March 14

 BODY:
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today that his trip to Vietnam had sown the seeds for a relationship that one day might bloom as bright as Washington's ties to many other Asian nations.
Mr. Cohen said Communist Vietnam -- the victor in a war that cost 58,000 American lives -- can look to the examples of American relations with Japan, Australia, Thailand, the Philippines and other Asia-Pacific nations that form the foundation of stability in the region. 
 "By building confidence over a period of time, hopefully one day we'll have the same kind of relationship" with Vietnam, Mr. Cohen said, while stressing that progress will necessarily be gradual and uncertain.
Mr. Cohen is the first American defense secretary to come here since the war ended in 1975.
In a policy speech at the National Defense Academy in Hanoi earlier today, Mr. Cohen said the United States is ready to "step cautiously forward" in a relationship that has grown since diplomatic ties were established in 1995.
Elaborating later in remarks to reporters flying with him to Ho Chi Minh City -- the former Saigon -- Mr. Cohen said his two days in Hanoi convinced him that Vietnamese leaders are ready to put the war behind them and move toward closer ties -- not just economically and politically but also on the military front.
"Not one individual I met with during this entire time said anything about looking back into the past," Mr. Cohen said. "They're looking to the United States in a very positive way," not as former enemy.
President Tran Duc Luong offered encouraging words to Mr. Cohen at a reception in the presidential palace.
"I think that your visit to Vietnam will be a further contribution to the development of the relationship between the two countries," the president said.
Mr. Cohen came to Hanoi to advocate a gradual approach to building a military-to-military relationship. He suggested starting with studies of the environment, removal of old land mines and improvement in Vietnam's flood control.
He said he also raised the possibility of visits by United States Navy ships to Vietnamese ports.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
European Regulators Halt Truck and Aluminum Mergers

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 14

 BODY:
European antitrust regulators took some of their most strenuous action against big corporate mergers today, blocking a planned $7 billion purchase by Volvo of the rival Swedish truck maker Scania and forcing three large aluminum companies to withdraw their proposed $17 billion combination.
The moves by the European Union's competition commission are not expected to slow the pace of global consolidation in the automotive and aluminum industries. But they reflected the rigorous standards set by Mario Monti, the chief European antitrust regulator, who in his six months on the job has taken a far more aggressive position than his predecessors in examining the impact of mergers on competition. 
 In rejecting a combination of Volvo and Scania announced last year, Mr. Monti said such a merger would dominate the Scandinavian market and hold a virtual monopoly for heavy trucks in Sweden.
Leif Johansson, the Volvo chief executive, said the decision appeared to "go against the basic concept of the common market."
Fears about opposition from Mr. Monti also led two aluminum companies, Alcan Aluminium of Canada and Pechiney of France to withdraw a proposal for a three-way merger with the Alusuisse Lonza Group of Switzerland. The regulators said that they would accept a combination of just Alcan and Alusuisse, but that a three-way deal including Pechiney would have to be modified.
The three companies announced in August that they intended to create the world's leading aluminum company, challenging the market leader, Alcoa of the United States.
Mr. Johansson of Volvo said his company had no plans to sell the Scania shares it now owns. Volvo holds 45.5 percent of Scania, and the proposed merger would have created the world's second-largest manufacturer of buses and trucks, after DaimlerChrysler.
Investors bid up the shares of the losers in the regulatory process, apparently in the expectation that either Volvo or Pechiney, or both, could come into play as possible takeover targets. Volvo stock rose 7 percent in Stockholm after the announcement, to 236 kronor, or $27.20, and shares of Pechiney gained more than 10 percent in Paris, closing at 57 euros, or $55.
Last year, Volvo sold its car-building division to Ford to concentrate on heavy trucks, after rejecting a bid by Fiat to buy the whole company. Recently, Volvo executives are said to have made preliminary contacts with several other rivals, including Renault of France, about a possible combination. Fiat, which on Monday announced a wide-reaching cooperation agreement with General Motors in the car business, is known to be considering whether to make an offer for Volvo.
Last August, Volvo announced its intention to take full control of Scania, forming a union of the world's No. 2 and No. 3 truck makers. To overcome regulatory objections, Volvo agreed to open its dealer network to the trucks of its competitors and to set a ceiling on its market share in the Scandinavian countries. But regulators said that even with such changes, the proposed acquisition was unacceptable because it would "significantly change the market structure to the detriment of the customers."
Since taking office, Mr. Monti, an economics professor and former dean of Bocconi University, a prestigious Italian business school, has sought to shift the emphasis in European antitrust policy from the fulfillment of legal requirements to an examination of the consequences on commercial competition. The result has been far tougher standards than were common in the past.
Since the latest European antitrust regulations were enacted in 1990, only 11 proposed mergers have been blocked, while 11 others were withdrawn in the face of probable refusal. But the proposed mergers affected today were the second and third Mr. Monti has stopped since taking up his post in September.
And the regulators are relying on support of their strict interpretation by European courts. In 1996, the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg upheld one of the first major efforts by regulators to thwart a proposed merger on the basis of its consequences for commercial markets. It blocked a combination of two big platinum-dealing companies, Lonrho of Britain and Gencor of South Africa, declaring that the merged company would be able to effectively dictate platinum prices in Europe.
Similar concerns seem to have motivated the regulators' hard line on the proposed three-way aluminum deal. Mr. Monti appeared ready to allow a merger of Alcan and Alusuisse after those companies agreed to take steps to eliminate their dominant position in the market for aluminum trihydrate, a substance used for fireproofing and film manufacturing.
But he indicated that he would block a combination of Alcan and Pechiney because of its potentially dominant position in the European market for aluminum sheets used to make containers for food, drinks and sprays.
In similar statements, Alcan and Pechiney said today that they would resubmit their proposal for a merger. The companies are under particular pressure because of Alcoa's planned $6.3 billion acquisition of Reynolds Metals, which is under investigation by antitrust authorities both in Europe and the United States.

HEADLINE: As a Conflict Intensifies, It's India's Move

BYLINE: By Daniel Benjamin and Steven Simon; Daniel Benjamin is a fellow at the United States Institute of Peace in Washington. Steven Simon is assistant director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. Both served on the National Security Council staff from 1994 to 1999.

 BODY:
Although President Clinton's decision to visit Pakistan has received more attention, the most important hours of his Asia trip will be spent talking with India's leaders. South Asia is careening toward a crisis, and it may be that only an Indian initiative can avert disaster.
Two developments are hastening the crisis: the deteriorating relationship between India and Pakistan, and Pakistan's accelerating disintegration. Both countries have tested nuclear weapons, and last summer Pakistan-backed militants crossed into the Indian-held Kargil region of Kashmir, nearly sparking a full-fledged war. 
 In Pakistan, antipathy among ethnic groups and violence between Sunni and Shiite Muslims have been aggravated by economic decay and breathtaking misgovernment. Before he was deposed by the military last year, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif centralized power, undermining Pakistan's legislature, judiciary and provincial governments. His predecessor, Benazir Bhutto, effectively gutted public education, clearing the way for the growth of madrassahs, or Islamic schools, some of which are breeding grounds for soldiers of holy war.
These trends converge on a single spot on the map: Kashmir. The long-running conflict has changed dramatically in the last few years. The Pakistani government has sought to distract its citizens from mounting domestic problems by fostering grievances over Indian control of the region. Militant Muslims have been encouraged by the army to assert Pakistan's territorial claims and bleed Indian forces. For these zealots, Kashmir has become a holy land that they believe they must liberate.
Since 1994, the role of native Kashmiris in the insurgency has diminished as heavily armed outsiders from Pakistan and Afghanistan have stepped up the violence. Indian military observers and journalists in the area estimate that these outsiders now account for some 40 percent of the militants there and that almost two-thirds of them are recruited from madrassahs, including some schools linked to the Afghan Taliban.
Some of the outsiders are products of terrorist camps in Afghanistan. Press reports on the 1998 United States missile strike against Osama bin Laden's camps there indicated that a number of casualties were from groups active in Kashmir. In the camps, the fighters imbibe hopes of a glorious victory over India like that of the Afghans over the Soviet Union.
The Pakistani government is increasingly hard-pressed to control the radicals, who have made inroads in the army officer corps and have many sympathizers in the general populace and rich supporters in Saudi Arabia. Some militants have even declared their intent to establish a radical Islamic state in Pakistan.
Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani leader, has voiced concerns about religious extremism. But his failure to do anything about it, along with his lack of progress toward promised economic and government reforms, indicate real limits on his authority and perhaps weakness in the army's support for him. He is in no position to make bold moves.
Thus any first step at de-escalating the Kashmir conflict must come from India. Some Indian leaders may enjoy the prospect of an enemy in turmoil, but for India and the world there can be few prospects more alarming than Pakistan's becoming the first nuclear-armed failed state.
What can President Clinton do? Washington has long offered to mediate between India and Pakistan; while Pakistan has sought intervention, India, out of cold war-era doubts about American intentions and its own great-power pride, has steadfastly declined. Yet today India's willingness to engage with the United States has increased as its economy has strengthened and as China's power has grown. Thus India might be receptive if Mr. Clinton presses the case that an internationally brokered deal on Kashmir would be in its interest.
The president's trip has led to talk in India of a new strategic partnership. India should understand that this will not develop without de-escalation in Kashmir, because the United States cannot push a desperate Pakistan further into the wilderness. But if India softens its position, that could lead to increased military cooperation and the lifting of some American technology export restrictions. If President Clinton used his visit to talk specifically about deepening American-Indian cooperation, it would help give Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee the cover he would need to overcome military and public resistance to mediation in Kashmir.
There is no guarantee that Pakistan can or will negotiate productively. But more than ever before, India has reason to come to the table.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Remain Strong, Posting 1.1% Rise in February

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Soaring gasoline prices did little in February to deter consumers from spending money on other goods like cars, food and clothes, a government report showed today.
Retail sales rose 1.1 percent last month after rising 0.4 percent in January, the Commerce Department said. February's gain included the largest increase in the value of gas station sales in 10 months. Even when gasoline sales are excluded, sales rose 0.9 percent. 
 "For now the economy is just so strong, higher gasoline prices are just an annoyance for consumers," said Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
Last month's sales gain was paced by a 1.4 percent increase in car and truck sales, which followed a 3 percent rise in January. Sales also rose 1.8 percent at food stores, 1.1 percent at clothing stores, 0.7 percent at furniture retailers and 0.6 percent at department stores like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Federated Department Stores Inc.
The General Motors Corporation posted its best February sales in a dozen years, while the Ford Motor Company and DaimlerChrysler A.G. set records for the month.
Spending "should stay strong as long as the labor market remains tight, consumer confidence remains high and the stock market is relatively stable," said Marilyn Schaja, a money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York.
Today's report reaffirms views that the series of Federal Reserve rate increases have yet to slow consumer spending and the economy.
"This is the type of data that will encourage the Federal Reserve to raise its target at the next policy meeting," said William Sullivan, senior economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York. The Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee will meet on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
A Midtown hotel divides itself up like an airplane and migrates toward business and first class.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. Joe Sharkey's e-mail is jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE following is a typical conversation that Frank Banks says he used to have back in the early 1990's when trying to persuade a top corporate executive to stay at the Rihga Royal, the luxury hotel he runs in Midtown Manhattan:
"I always stay at the Marriott," the executive being wooed might say. 
 "Why? What's the rate you're paying over there?" Mr. Banks might ask.
"About $195 a night for a room."
"But that's the same rate we're charging here for a luxury suite."
"Yeah, but the Marriott looks better on paper to my board of directors."
Walking the quiet hallways of the Rihga Royal, nearly all of whose 500 rooms were occupied one day last week, Mr. Banks recalled those days with a shudder. The hotel was new. It was expensive, and in a then-questionable part of town for business travelers, just north of Times Square.
"This wasn't Park Avenue, after all," he said. "All I could think was, how am I going to fill 500 suites and make a profit?"
In the world of high-end corporate travel, decisions were being made by executives and boards still sensitive to the public outcry that had accompanied the horror stories of the corporate excesses of the late 1980's. It was a tough time to be going on line with a hotel meant largely to appeal to top-shelf tastes in both the corporate and the leisure trade.
"So I divided the hotel up like an airplane, with levels that corresponded to first class, business class and coach," Mr. Banks said. At first, only a single floor of the hotel's suites were in the top class.
Gradually, as the economy began booming and attitudes toward high-end corporate travel began to loosen across the board, more of the lower-priced suites were combined and redesigned for the higher level. Now, Mr. Banks said, the hotel has 100 Pinnacle Suites, which cost $625 for a one bedroom and $1,100 for two bedrooms. Other suites range up to $3,300 a night for the top-of-the-line Grand Royal Suites.
This is not the top price for a luxury hotel room in New York City, where some suites at better-known hotels can cost $9,000 a night. Instead, the Rihga Royal, which is owned by Royal Hotel Ltd., a Japanese company, is carefully positioned to appeal to the sort of corporate executives "who don't have to get two or three supervisors to approve their expenses," said Mr. Banks, who himself lives in the hotel on West 54th St.
"I say to corporate travel managers that I don't want big corporate volume. I want the two or three people in a company who are going to be able to avail themselves of our level of service. In effect, it's like selling more first-class and business-class seats," at a time when even airlines are reconfiguring planes to set aside more premium seats and take advantage of more relaxed business spending in a booming economy -- for the select few who qualify for top-dog travel.
Expense accounts from luxury hotels, of course, form only a tiny portion of the $175 billion that American companies spend a year on travel and entertainment. Most corporate travel departments -- and travelers -- are really struggling to deal with increases in costs, especially for airline travel. Yesterday, the Air Transport Association reported that with oil prices soaring, airline fuel prices are expected to rise 40 percent this year, suggesting that for air travel, "ticket prices could jump dramatically."
And mostly because of rising air fares, business travel expenses have already gone up 40 percent in recent years, even without inflation, said Kevin Mitchell, the chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, which lobbies for greater competition in the airline business and better cost controls for business travel across the board.
"We don't see the kinds of problems in the hotel industry that we have in the airlines industry," Mr. Mitchell said. "Hotels are a more classic model of a perfect market, where buyers and sellers both have really good information and there's unrestricted supply and access to the marketplace."
From the 54th floor of the Rihga Royal, looking out across a section of the city that now throbs with economic prosperity, Mr. Banks said things were looking good for businesses like his that served the well-heeled traveler willing to pay for space, convenience, service and in-room amenities like home-style comfort, plus private fax lines, personalized cell phones and video-phones.
"Over the years, we kept redesigning our suites upward to change the mix," said Mr. Banks, who ran his own hotel in Massachusetts and was a general manager of the St. Regis Hotel in New York before he took over at the Rihga in 1991, the year after it opened. "The demand for a higher lever of service keeps going up, just like on the airlines."
He thinks the high end of the market will hold its own for the foreseeable future. But there are no guarantees, of course.
"Obviously, if the economy goes south," he said, "we go south along with it."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Drop Longtime Ban On Luxuries From Iran

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
When moderates triumphed in parliamentary elections in Iran last month, they probably did not anticipate that their victories would resonate in the living rooms of wealthy Americans.
But the Clinton administration, eager to encourage moderation in the land where the United States has been reviled as the Great Satan, is about to ease some import bans on Iranian consumer goods: pistachios, caviar and carpets. 
 "This opens the door for trade in both directions and does it in a way that is purely commercial, and on a purely civilian basis," said Robert Pelletreau, the chairman of the American Iranian Council, an organization founded several years ago for discussion of issues involving the United States and Iran, and a former American envoy to Egypt.
The value of the pistachios, caviar and carpets may be relatively small in terms of Iran's overall trade but it is significant for the boost it can give to private Iranian entrepreneurs by pumping much-needed hard currency into their country, administration officials said.
The move may also affect another kind of currency, less definite but no less real, in the United States: the social cachet that comes from being able to buy things that have been largely forbidden since the shah of Iran was driven from the Peacock Throne in 1979.
Whether Persian rugs are better than those from, say, India or Pakistan may be debatable, just as it is debatable whether caviar from Iranian sturgeons is better than that from Russian sturgeons. But some merchants who deal in rugs and caviar predicted tonight that imports from Iran would become fashionable almost overnight.
Iranian caviar "is going to be very trendy," predicted Silverio Benitez, a sales associate at Petrossian's restaurant-boutique on West 58th Street in New York, which sold more caviar last year than ever before, partly because people wanted to put something special on their crackers to celebrate the arrival of 2000.
Mr. Benitez declined to say exactly how much caviar Petrossian sells (Tiffany doesn't boast of its sales in diamonds, after all), but he allowed that it sells about as much as any eatery on the planet. And no wonder: Petrossian will fix up a nice caviar picnic basket for a mere $75 or so.
"In general, this is going to open up the caviar market," Mr. Benitez said. But will prices go down, and if so for how long? Will the Iranian caviar be as good as the Russian caviar that Petrossian gets from the Caspian Sea by way of Paris? And will people who like caviar be able to tell the difference?
Mr. Benitez withheld predictions on those weighty issues. But he was sure that Iranian caviar will become popular "because it's available."
Like Cuban cigars? "Exactly." Well, not exactly.
As for Persian rugs (so-called because they have been around since long before Persia became Iran in 1935), two prominent Washington-area rug businessmen predicted that they will become the rage simply because they will become available.
James Keshishian, whose family business has been selling rugs in Washington and its suburbs for 70 years, said prices of Persian rugs might go up at first, then come down as the supply grows, then go up again as Iranian exporters get shrewder in the ways of the Western marketplace.
"They may sell very well," Mr. Keshishian said. "If they look right." His voice softened as he explained how Persian rug makers sometimes wash their creations gently in tea to soften the colors and texture.
Mr. Keshishian, who has taught college courses in rug appraisal, recalled the days before the shah was toppled, when 60 percent of the rugs his business sold were Persian and 40 percent were "everything else." Since then, he said, his business has sold "70 percent everything else and 30 percent Persian," with the bulk of the Persian rugs two decades or more old.
Another Washington-area rug seller, who asked not to be identified by name for fear of offending anyone, said he sells lots of Indian and Pakistani rugs but still welcomes the lifting of the import bans. "Persians make better rugs," he said. "They've been at it a long time. We'll sell quite a few."
The lifting of the import ban is likely to be announced here on Friday at a conference of the American Iranian Council, administration officials said.
The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said President Clinton has been looking at a variety of ways to "encourage a constructive dialogue" with Iran.
Meanwhile, the World Bank said today that it is considering loans to Iran, totaling $231 million, for the first time since 1994. So far, the United States opposes the loans, which would be used for sewerage and education. When it comes to easing world tensions, caviar and rugs go only so far.

HEADLINE: Effort to Curb Binge Drinking in College Falls Short

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
Despite a decade of aggressive prevention efforts, heavy drinking on college campuses did not diminish in the 1990's, according to a study released yesterday by the Harvard School of Public Health. But attitudes toward alcohol among students have become more polarized, with increases in abstainers and in frequent binge drinkers.
"It is disturbing that these findings show an increase in the most extreme and high-risk form of drinking," said Henry Wechsler, director of the College Alcohol Studies Program and the author of the study. "My disappointment is, given all the action on college campuses to deal with this problem, and given the attention that has been placed on it, the fact that it has stayed so remarkably stable shows what a difficult problem it is." 
 The survey of more than 14,000 students at 119 colleges in 39 states found 22.7 percent were "frequent binge drinkers," meaning they had consumed at least five drinks in a row for men, or four for women, at least three times in the two weeks before they had filled out the questionnaire. That is up from 19.8 percent in 1993, the first year of Dr. Wechsler's study, whose latest results appear in the current Journal of American College Health.
The percentage of occasional binge drinkers dropped to 21.4 last year from 24.7 in 1993, the survey found, and the percentage of non-binge drinkers -- students who had consumed alcohol in the past year but had not recently binged -- fell to 36.6 percent from 40.1 percent.
Abstainers -- students who had not drunk at all in the past year -- grew to 19.2 percent in 1999 from 15.4 percent in 1993. More students were choosing to live in alcohol-free dormitories, the survey found, and binge drinking dropped by almost 6 percent for students living on campus, while it rose a similar amount for those living off campus.
"Even at Florida State, the No. 1 party school in the nation, the majority of students do not binge drink," said Ed McGlothlin, 20, an abstainer and a junior at Florida State in Tallahassee. "But you're inundated by it. You have to go out of your way to avoid that kind of culture."
More than three-quarters of the students surveyed said they had experienced the second-hand effects of binge drinking, including being interrupted while studying or awakened (58 percent), having to take care of a drunken student (50 percent) or being insulted or humiliated (29 percent).
Dr. Wechsler examined the efforts that college administrators were making to curtail binge drinking, finding that 97 percent of the 734 institutions surveyed had alcohol education programs in place. Forty percent of the schools were working with groups in their communities to address under-age drinking, and 1 in 4 reported regular meetings on the issue with neighborhood groups.
Richard Yoast, director of a $10 million program financed by the Robert Wood Johnson foundation to address binge drinking on 10 campuses across the country, said the survey suggested that a serious commitment and coordinated efforts could have an impact on the problem. Though he was not allowed to release specific data from the 10 colleges, Dr. Yoast said the number of students who were abstaining on those campuses had almost doubled since 1993, while the rates of heavy drinkers were rising more slowly than that of the national average.
"Every campus needs to address the whole environment in which drinking occurs," Dr. Yoast said.
Mary Sue Coleman, president of the University of Iowa, one of the 10 campuses, said she had focused on the community's collective responsibility for solving the problem, with initiatives like removing alcohol from her own pre-football game brunches and urging local bar owners to buy scanners that highlight fake identification cards.
"Of course, students who drink too much must be responsible for the problems that they cause," Ms. Coleman said. "But students are not responsible for manufacturing and marketing alcoholic beverages. Students are not responsible for the excessive number of bars within walking distance of our campuses. Students are not responsible for the price specials that encourage drinking to get drunk."
Joel Wiegert, 22, a senior economics major at the University of Nebraska at Lincoln, said he had used a cost-benefit analysis to determine that he should stop binge drinking. Having accidentally broken a table, wasted untold quantities of money on beer and been rude to friends and strangers alike, Mr. Wiegert said he had "yet to come up with one benefit to high-risk drinking."

HEADLINE: Joseph Goldstein, Authority On Family Law, Is Dead at 76

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Joseph Goldstein, a longtime law professor at Yale who was widely known for his interdisciplinary approach to family law and other legal fields, died on Sunday at a hospital in New Haven. He was 76 and lived in Woodbridge, Conn.
The cause was a heart attack, the Yale Law School's director of public affairs, Elizabeth Stauderman, said. 
 Dr. Goldstein, who was also a psychoanalyst, was a co-author of three books that, as Martin Guggenheim, a professor of law at New York University, put it, became "required reading for judges and practitioners in the field of child custody and other legal issues relating to judicial decisions concerning a child's future."
The books are "Beyond the Best Interests of the Child" (1973), "Before the Best Interests of the Child" (1979) and "In the Best Interests of the Child" (1986). Dr. Goldstein wrote them with Anna Freud, the psychoanalyst and daughter of Sigmund Freud, and Albert J. Solnit, the director of the Yale Child Study Center. The 1986 book was also written with Dr. Goldstein's wife, Sonja.
Dr. Goldstein joined the law school's faculty in 1956 and retired in 1993. Then he became a professorial lecturer at the law school, and held that post at his death.
Alan M. Dershowitz, the Felix Frankfurter Professor of Law at Harvard Law School and a former student of Dr. Goldstein's, said Dr. Goldstein "introduced, probably more than anyone else, real interdisciplinary thinking in the law school and thus the legal world in general." His influence was widely felt, Professor Dershowitz said, through both his writing and his influential students.
Central to Dr. Goldstein's and his co-authors' thinking, Dr. Guggenheim said, was the idea "that courts should choose the alternative that was the least detrimental to the interest of the child."
That principle, in the authors' view, followed from an even more basic one: They were highly distrustful of the capacity of judges to make intelligent decisions about custody arrangements. And so, Dr. Guggenheim said, "they wanted courts to have very limited authority to intervene in a family."
The books also expressed the view that custody disputes should be looked at from the point of view of children, especially their perspective on time. For example, for very young children, six months might be 100 percent of their life, not six months in the life a 40-year-old.
In the foster-care side of family law, Dr. Guggenheim said, Dr. Goldstein's and his co-authors' views encouraged the acceleration of termination of parents rights in cases where children were in foster care.
"As a result of their work," Dr. Guggenheim said, "statutes were rewritten to shorten the length of time children should be in foster care before courts would terminate the right of the natural parents, freeing the children to become eligible to be adopted."
Dr. Goldstein's work involving family law, Professor Dershowitz said, was an application of his thinking about the interface between psychiatry and the law. Early in his career he began studying issues related to the insanity defense.
Dr. Goldstein went on to write "The Family and the Law" (1965) with Jay Katz, a Yale Law School professor and psychiatrist, and "Psychoanalysis, Psychiatry and the Law" (1966) with Professors Katz and Dershowitz. He finished his own psychoanalytic training in 1968 at the Western New England Psychoanalytic Institute.
"He changed both law and psychoanalysis" by bringing them together, Professor Dershowitz said. "In the world of law, he made us all think about the role of law as superego, how we internalize law, how we make it part of our personality. And then, I think, he used the concept of law to help broaden and make more meaningful concepts like the superego and psychoanalysis."
Joseph Goldstein was born in Springfield, Mass. He received a bachelor's degree from Dartmouth, a doctorate from the London School of Economics and a law degree from Yale. He was a law clerk for Judge David L. Bazelon of the United States Court of Appeals in Washington and taught briefly at Stanford Law School before returning to Yale as an associate professor of law.
He also was an author, co-author or editor of books on criminal law, on the My Lai massacre and on constitutional law.
He was an Army code-breaker in World War II.
Dr. Goldstein is survived by his wife and co-author, the former Sonja Lambek; three sons, Joshua, of Cambridge, Mass., Jeremiah, of Philadelphia, and Daniel, of Davis, Calif.; a daughter, Anne Goldstein of Hartford, Conn.; eight grandchildren; a brother, E. Ernest Goldstein, who lives in Texas, and a sister, Mariam Sommer of New Haven.

HEADLINE: Teacher Hiring Rule Relaxed, Opening Quick Jobs for Those Licensed Elsewhere

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
In a move to address a looming teacher shortage in New York City and across the state, education officials have decided to allow credentialed teachers from most other states to begin teaching here immediately rather than waiting until they pass New York's certification exams.
The state's Board of Regents quietly approved an emergency amendment to state education regulations March 7 giving the Education Department the ability to grant a two-year provisional certification to licensed teachers who move to New York from one of 39 other states or to those who have a national teaching certificate. 
 The measure was introduced to the Regents by Richard P. Mills, the education commissioner, at the request of Harold O. Levy, New York City's interim schools chancellor, who resigned from the Board of Regents earlier this year when he took charge of the city's school system.
New York City is facing a potentially crippling teacher shortage. A recent survey of its members by the United Federation of Teachers found that an estimated 14,000 of New York City's 78,000 public school teachers planed to retire over the next 18 months, a far faster pace than previously predicted. The Board of Education has said it expects its overall hiring needs, stemming from retirements, other turnover and the creation of new classes, to more than double for the 2001-2002 school year, to 19,000 new teachers.
"This is a deliberate response to New York City's need" for new teachers, Mr. Mills said of the new measure.
"This is an extraordinary moment, and it is in the widespread public interest for us to recruit more teachers," he added.
About 1,500 teachers from other states apply for certification in New York each year, a figure that Mr. Mills predicted could easily double under the new standard. "If we recruited hard and had some money behind that effort, we could be even more effective," he said.
Teachers hired under the new provision will have two years to complete the appropriate New York certification exams, which are administered quarterly. Until now, teachers from other states might have been discouraged from applying here, finding more lenient policies elsewhere, education officials said.
Although New York City has hired significant numbers of uncertified teachers in recent years, the new policy is expected to expand the number of applicants from other states because the city's Board of Education will give preference to candidates with certification, even from other states, over uncertified teachers.
Currently, about 10,000 New York City teachers, more than 10 percent of the total, are unlicensed. But state law will forbid the hiring of unlicensed teachers beginning in 2003. Moreover, the Education Department has proposed shortening the time it allows unlicensed teachers to work in a classroom before fulfilling their license requirements.
Gov. George E. Pataki and Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the State Senate, have proposed teacher recruitment packages that include salary bonuses, scholarships and other financial incentives. Teacher recruitment has also emerged as a central education issue in the Senate campaigns of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton.
The federal government also is making efforts to lure college students into teaching. Yesterday, the Department of Housing and Urban Development announced a plan to enable teachers to buy, at half price, homes owned by the department in economically distressed neighborhoods.
Previous efforts to allow out-of-state teachers to gain immediate teaching rights in New York have been opposed by politicians and education officials who first wanted other states to recognize New York's credentials, Mr. Levy said yesterday. But believing that the teacher shortage has become too dire to allow that requirement to remain, Mr. Levy asked Mr. Mills to take the new measure before the Regents.
"I don't want reciprocity," Mr. Levy said yesterday. "I want it very much one way. I want to take their teachers and make them unable to take our teachers."
The leader of New York City's teachers union cautioned that the new measure would not help New York City unless it raised the pay of its teachers to match the salaries of teachers in suburban areas.
"It might help open up the supply a bit, but it's a baby step," said Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers. "If their credentials are recognized and they can earn 20 percent more in the suburbs, it might very well push more people to the suburbs."
Mr. Levy has made teacher recruitment a focus of his tenure as interim chancellor. He and Mr. Mills recently met with the deans of 12 schools of education in New York State to discuss ways to draw more liberal arts students to a career in teaching.
This spring, the board is testing an online system known as Resumex, which allows prospective teachers from around the country to transmit resumes electronically to the board, creating a database that can be used by districts and schools for hiring.
New York City hires about 8,000 new teachers each year. The shortage could worsen starting July 2001 because of a salary provision in the teachers' contract that is expected to encourage retirements. The Board of Education anticipates needing 19,000 new teachers for the school year that begins in September 2001. Over the next five years, the United Federation of Teachers has said, the school system will need 54,000 new teachers.
The new measure to broaden hiring from out-of-state is restricted to teachers who are licensed by states and territories that have signed an interstate agreement that defines some of the qualifications that are necessary to obtain a teaching license. Forty states plus the District of Columbia, Guam and Puerto Rico are parties to the agreement. The 10 states that are not part of the interstate agreement are Alaska, Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, South Dakota, Wisconsin and Wyoming.
Alternatively, teachers who are licensed in any state and also have a certificate from the National Board of Professional Teaching Standards will be eligible for the New York program.

HEADLINE: School Vouchers Are Ruled Unconstitutional in Florida

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
A Florida judge ruled yesterday that the state's Constitution barred students from using taxpayer money for private school tuition, blocking Florida's eight-month-old voucher program, the nation's boldest experiment in using market forces to improve failing schools.
The decision, which the state says it will appeal, is the second major legal setback for voucher proponents in recent months, following a federal judge's ruling that Cleveland's program contravenes the First Amendment's separation of church and state. 
 Florida's is the first statewide voucher program and the first anywhere to tie voucher eligibility to schools' performance on standardized tests. It serves as a model for a national voucher plan proposed by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the expected Republican presidential nominee, and has been copied by several of the 25 state legislatures now considering new voucher initiatives.
"This ruling puts a stake in the heart of the voucher movement," said Bob Chase, president of the National Education Association, the teachers' union whose Florida affiliate was involved with the lawsuit challenging vouchers. "It sends a strong signal to states across the nation that vouchers are no substitute for a quality public education."
Under the ruling, the 53 children in Pensacola, Fla., who are now using vouchers to attend private schools will be allowed to finish out the semester, but the state will not pay their tuition next year. The ruling also stops the program's expansion to as many as 60,000 students in 78 schools who would have become eligible for vouchers in June if their schools were graded "F" for the second time in four years.
"It's a tragedy because this beacon of hope that has been offered to parents as a way for their children to get a better education has, at least temporarily, been snuffed out," said John F. Kirtley, a Tampa venture capitalist who is on the board of Floridians for School Choice, a pro-voucher group.
Mr. Kirtley and Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, the architect of the program, vowed to raise private donations to allow the Pensacola students using the vouchers to stay in the private schools, where their parents say they are thriving.
"This is about children -- it's not about the system, it's not about adults," Mr. Bush, the brother of the presidential candidate, said in an afternoon news conference at the Statehouse in Tallahassee. "I'm personally not going to let parents who have been given the assurance that their children can go to another school -- I'm not going to force them back to schools they don't want to go to."
The ruling by Judge L. Ralph Smith Jr. of the Circuit Court of Florida focuses on a provision of the Florida Constitution that declares education a "fundamental value" of the state and says it is a "paramount duty" to provide a "uniform, efficient, safe, secure and high quality system of free public schools."
The constitutional obligation to provide education, in Article IX, Section I, has existed for more than a century, but the specifics about how it should be provided were added by voters in November 1998 -- the same year Mr. Bush was elected governor on a platform that emphasized school accountability and school choice.
In defending against the lawsuit filed by groups of parents and teachers, voucher proponents argued that since the state already spent millions of dollars a year sending disabled and other students with special needs to private schools, it could also do so to help students escape low-performing schools.
But Judge Smith said that because the voucher program used private schools to provide the same services offered by public ones, it "supplants the system of free public schools mandated by the constitution."
While the ruling may be a catastrophic blow to Florida's program, its impact nationally is limited, since it turns on a narrow provision of the State Constitution. Virtually every state constitution has such a provision outlining the state's responsibility to provide public education, but judges in each state may interpret the language differently.
The broader question is whether vouchers, which are typically used at parochial schools, violate the federal Constitution's separation of church and state. Cleveland's voucher program, involving about 3,500 students, was declared illegal on those grounds in December, a decision that has been appealed and is expected to come before the United States Supreme Court soon.
Yesterday's ruling is likely to be appealed directly to the State Supreme Court in Florida.
"This is a blip in the voucher movement," said Clint Bolick, a lawyer for the Institute for Justice, a conservative group based in Washington that helped defend the lawsuit. "There has not been a single lawsuit yet where we have not had at least a momentary setback. We have developed some serious stamina. At the end of the day, we have not lost a single voucher program."
Vouchers were first proposed by the economist Milton Friedman in 1955 and are one of the most contentious issues in education and political circles today, a crucial point of disagreement between the likely Democratic and Republican presidential nominees. More than 25 state legislatures have voucher bills pending, and many major cities, including New York, are wrestling with the question of whether vouchers are a threat to the public school system or its savior.
The Florida decision is the latest in a string of legal victories for voucher opponents, a coalition of teachers' unions and civil liberties groups that have won court challenges against small programs in Maine, Pennsylvania and Vermont as well as Ohio. Milwaukee's voucher program, the nation's oldest and largest, with 8,000 low-income students enrolled this year, has been upheld by Wisconsin's highest court.
"The future will really very much be determined by what the U.S. Supreme Court does when it gets the question," said Joseph P. Viteritti, a professor at New York University who has written a book on school choice. "If the court says it's against the Constitution, these things can't really move. On the other hand, if the court did approve it, it doesn't necessarily mean you're going to have 50 states with voucher laws, either. The politics of many states are not friendly to vouchers."
Though Florida's was the first statewide voucher program and was likely to have become the nation's largest when school grades are released in June, it was confined this year to two schools in the most impoverished neighborhoods of Pensacola because they were the only ones with failing scores on standardized tests two consecutive years.
Tom Gallagher, the state's education commissioner, said he would continue to grade schools as planned this spring, and that students in schools with repeated F's would still be allowed to transfer to public schools with grades of C or higher.
 
What the Florida Constitution Says
Following is Article IX, Section 1 of the Florida Constitution on public education, which was cited as the reason for a judge's decision yesterday that the state's school voucher program is illegal. The provision has been on the books for more than a century although it was amended in 1998.
The education of children is a fundamental value of the people of the State of Florida. It is, therefore, a paramount duty of the state to make adequate provision for the education of all children residing within its borders. Adequate provision shall be made by law for a uniform, efficient, safe, secure and high quality system of free public schools that allows students to obtain a high quality education and for the establishment, maintenance and operation of institutions of higher learning and other public education programs that the needs of the people may require.

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
In the Midst of Upheaval, Yet Out of Public Sight: Horst Kohler

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 14

 BODY:
Horst Kohler, the veteran German banker now expected to run the International Monetary Fund, is not widely known, even in Germany. But he is no stranger to the kinds of seismic political and economic upheaval that come with the responsibility of managing a global lender to financially distressed nations.
Mr. Kohler was a financial engineer behind two of Europe's biggest transformations. The first was the reunification of Germany 10 years ago after the collapse of Communism. The second occurred relatively recently: the creation of the euro, the common currency that 11 European nations adopted more than a year ago. 
 People who know Mr. Kohler say that far from being a political or economic lightweight, as detractors have suggested, he has the toughness of someone who has endured baptisms by fire.
Perhaps more surprising, he could prove to be a tough-minded fiscal conservative in the political battle over the I.M.F.'s future mission and strategy.
Many of Mr. Kohler's mentors and longtime colleagues are top officials at the German central bank, people who have for years argued that the monetary fund should avoid big bailouts.
In that regard, Mr. Kohler may well echo those in Congress and the Clinton administration who want to curtail some of the lending institution's activity.
"He is a conservative -- by his background, his party affiliation and the jobs he has held," said Norbert Walter, chief economist at Deutsche Bank. "He is a hard-liner."
After two weeks of trans-Atlantic bickering, the United States reluctantly endorsed Mr. Kohler on Monday to become the next managing director of the I.M.F.
Washington's accession, following agreement by all 15 European Union countries, ended a spectacle stemming in large part from Germany's insistence that the job go to a German for the first time in the I.M.F.'s 37-year history. A week earlier, President Clinton defied the Germans' wishes by rejecting their first choice for the job, Deputy Finance Minister Caio Koch-Weser.
Mr. Kohler, who was on the way to I.M.F. headquarters in Washington today, declined to be interviewed. But he picked up more endorsements: from Russia and Japan, and from his prospective counterpart at the World Bank, James D. Wolfensohn, who said that the German would be "a very, very good person to run the I.M.F."
To most people, Mr. Kohler is an unknown quantity. Born on Feb. 22, 1943, in Skierbieszow, Poland, he is married with two children. He has spent most of his career in banking and finance -- for the last two years as president of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which lends money to projects in the former Soviet republics and Eastern Europe.
Despite his professional achievements, Mr. Kohler has worked largely outside public view. That could be one of his biggest problems.
American officials vetoed Mr. Koch-Weser partly on the grounds that, in their view, he lacked sufficient international stature to run the I.M.F., which provides emergency financing to developing and distressed countries.
But Mr. Kohler is hardly a neophyte. Now 57, he was a top economic adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl a decade ago, as the Berlin Wall was crumbling. Without warning, he found himself in the midst of changes of extraordinary sorts.
As Mr. Kohl's representative to the Group of Seven industrial nations, he led negotiations over the restructuring of billions of dollars worth of debt left by the collapsed Soviet Union.
Because Germany was and remains one of Russia's biggest sources of foreign lending, Mr. Kohler frequently sparred with the United States over how countries would divide the burden of refinancing or writing off old loans.
Mr. Kohler was also the financial architect of a far-reaching deal with Russia to evacuate its troops from the former East Germany. Under that deal, the Germans agreed to finance an enormous building program in Russia, which would provide homes for soldiers as well as a source of jobs.
One of his important legacies was his work in bringing about the economic unification of eastern Germany with the western areas.
He provided the blueprint for Germany's currency conversion in 1990, under which the former East Germans received one West German mark for every two of the nearly worthless Ostmarks.
The plan was harshly criticized by some economists and led to the resignation of Karl Otto Pohl as president of Germany's central bank. But Chancellor Kohl barreled over all objections on the ground that the political reality of German unification would allow nothing less.
Germany is still groaning under the consequences. Eastern unemployment remains nearly 20 percent, twice as high in the West, partly because prices and wages have soared to western levels without a comparable rise in productivity.
Mr. Kohler also played a big role in organizing the enormously expensive privatization of state businesses in the eastern areas. As a top official in the finance ministry, he organized the Treuhand, the agency charged with selling 11,000 rusting and moribund companies.
The Treuhand soon gained a reputation for catering to western German bargain hunters. It supplied tens of billions of dollars in taxpayer subsidies to industrial companies that either collapsed or eliminated most of their workers.
Many experts argue that the privatizations would have been messy under any circumstances, and the experience in some other former Communist countries was worse.
Even as Germany was coming to grips with reunification, Mr. Kohler was negotiating over plans for a common European currency. His job was to take the vaguely defined vision of a single currency and ensure that Germany's unflinching emphasis on price stability was dominant in all policy-making.
That meant forcing countries like France to accept German demands for fiscal austerity as well as an independent central bank.
"If you look at the structure of the European Central Bank, it is not far from the structure of the German Bundesbank," said Gert Haller, who worked closely with Mr. Kohler and succeeded him as top adviser to Chancellor Kohl."If we hadn't succeeded in making the central bank the way it is now, the whole thing could not have been sold in Germany."

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
After Injury, Added Insult Of Late Aid

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn.

 BODY:
THE horror began last Mother's Day. Sean Tobin, a young hospital corpsman at the Navy submarine base in Groton, told the police that he grew so frustrated with his 6-week-old son, who was crying and refusing a bottle, that he shook him until his "neck appeared very loose and his head was rolling around." Then he slammed the baby on the couch.
Doctors said the baby was unlikely to survive, and the family removed life supports. But the baby, Vincent Tobin, lived. Nearing his first birthday, he is almost totally blind, severely hearing-impaired and unable to crawl or sit up on his own. Cerebral palsy has been diagnosed. 
 The criminal case moved efficiently. Mr. Tobin, 20, pleaded guilty to assault. At an emotional hearing in Superior Court here earlier this month, a judge sentenced him to 18 years in state prison.
The disposition for Vincent Tobin has been anything but efficient. Born a healthy son of a Navy man, he is now the medically needy son of a convict. Along the way, he lost one thing he desperately needed, health insurance. A case that began with one man's rage became a parable for the chronic frustration of navigating the health insurance system.
At 19, Tina Riggio, Vincent's mother, was suddenly the unemployed mother of a baby who needed her constant attention as well as specialized medical care. She moved in with her parents near Orlando, Fla., and took her son to pediatricians, neurologists and eye doctors. He began physical and speech and occupational therapy five days a week.
"He will eventually be in a wheelchair," Ms. Riggio said. "If he doesn't learn to use his hands, he will have a feeding tube. He will never walk. He will never talk. He will actually get very stiff."
Then came the bills, many with notations like, "For us to continue providing medical services, you must pay outstanding balance immediately."
The Navy has a program to assist dependents of military personnel who leave the service due to domestic abuse, which is paying Ms. Riggio $1,078 a month for three years. The money helps, since she cannot both work and care for Vincent. (She worked at a Pizza Hut before he was injured.) But it doesn't begin to cover Vincent's medical care. Ms. Riggio applied many months ago for health insurance under the same program, and waited for the Navy to respond, with unpaid bills approaching $5,000 as of Monday.
Peggy Stellabotte, an administrative assistant at the Easter Seals clinic in Deltona, Fla., where Vincent received therapy, said Tricare, the military medical plan, returned his bills, saying without explanation that he was not covered. Medicaid, for which Ms. Riggio and Vincent qualified, also refused, saying Tricare was the primary insurer.
Ms. Stellabotte said that Easter Seals often treated uninsured children but that Ms. Riggio stopped taking her son for $55-a-day sessions in December, fearing it would only add to the stack of unpaid bills.
Ms. Riggio arrived at her husband's sentencing carrying their dark-haired, olive-skinned baby and a sheaf of his bills. But the hearing concerned the crime, not the aftermath.
Vincent Riggio, the baby's maternal grandfather and namesake, told the judge: "He has no idea who I am. He has no idea who my wife is." Mr. Tobin, he said, "destroyed my grandson."
MR. TOBIN'S mother, Renee, said, "My son's not a bad man, he's a good boy." She told the judge that "I am the product of physical abuse, sexual abuse, verbal abuse," and said that "as parents we don't recognize what we teach our children until it is too late."
Vincent, cradled in his mother's lap, let loose with a cry. Then his father was taken away to prison.
There he will have a full range of medical, mental health and dental services. For prisoners, at least, medical care is a right.
For Vincent, it was far more complicated. "I can really assure you that the Navy is working with this family to help them get any benefits, medical or monetary, that they are entitled to," was all Lt. Sandra Johnson, assistant legal counsel for Navy Personnel Command, would say about Vincent on Friday after several calls to the Navy.
That was news to Ms. Riggio, who felt alone against the Navy. Then, yesterday afternoon, a Navy official called Ms. Riggio to say she and Vincent would receive Tricare. "These things take some time," said Lt. Ingrid Mueller, a Navy spokeswoman.
In Vincent's case, it took nine months, or about three-quarters of his life.
