HEADLINE: High Tech Is the Art In San Francisco

BYLINE: By SALLY McGRANE 

 BODY:
CULTURAL sea change is nothing new to the Bay Area of San Francisco, and the city that spawned the beats and psychedelia now finds itself a few degrees north of the technology revolution's epicenter. But is there room for art in the no-nonsense commercialism of the tech world, where everybody has a business plan?
The answer, it turns out, is yes, with a twist. A number of Bay Area artists are taking the technology that is transforming the area and making art with and about it. 
 Several factors make the Bay Area a fertile region for technology-related art. Artists there are surrounded by technology as dot-com companies take over industrial neighborhoods that were once artists' haunts. Splashy Internet advertising plasters billboards and dominates radio spots. There are also last year's products, discarded by the tech industry but still useful to artists, as is technological know-how.
"Technology is in the atmosphere here," said Jim Campbell, a San Francisco-based technology artist. Mr. Campbell, who works in Silicon Valley as a hardware engineer three days a week, said that the Bay Area creates an environment in which technology and art feed off each other. He is working on a piece that explores compression technology and the impact it has on information and meaning -- because, he said, "I've been working with compression in my job, making 40 or 50 pixels represent something."
Ken Goldberg, a technology artist who is also an engineering professor at the University of California at Berkeley, said there was no question that the technology revolution was making itself felt in art circles. "In some way," he said, "all artists in the Bay Area are directly or indirectly responding to technology because it is so pervasive here."
Nonetheless, art and technology often have an uneasy relationship. Rebeca Bollinger, a San Francisco artist who uses the Internet in much of her work, said she was "equally disgusted with and passionately seduced by" technology. "I try hard to be on the outside of what's going on in the industry," she said. "I get so sick and tired of all the technology propaganda. I'm sick of all the marketing.
"We're so immersed in the economy of it. If you go to other parts of the country, you see that it's totally different. But what's happening here will happen there, eventually. We're living in this strange space of present-future."
In some cases, companies and organizations in the high-tech field have embraced -- and financed -- existing art groups. Survival Research Laboratories, for instance, a prominent feature of the alternative Bay Area landscape since Mark Pauline founded it in 1978, builds large robots and creates violent spectacles where machines wreak destruction on one another. More recently, the group integrated the Internet into its art, connecting laptops to the robots and allowing remote Internet users to aim and fire powerful machinery during shows.
"Probably since 1992 all of our shows have been affiliated with organizations related to technology," said Mr. Pauline, who has created events for clients like the publisher Miller Freeman, Wired magazine and Webzine99, a San Francisco conference for Internet-based alternative magazines.
But while the booming economy has brought in money that has benefited artists, it could also impose restraints. Eric Paulos, director of the Experimental Interaction Unit, an art group, pointed out that being employed in the technology sector could limit artistic freedom, especially if an artist's projects are critical of technology.
"It's hard to do anything too controversial if you're at a dot-com," he said. "This is an incredible time because you can do creative expression -- design work -- and get paid. But if what you're doing is driven by money, you're not really in control."
Mr. Paulos said he made a point of distancing his work -- which includes a vending machine that sells a mock lethal pathogen and tracks users' identities -- from his role as a graduate student at Berkeley's computer science department to maintain his artistic autonomy.
Ray Thomas, on the other hand, is firmly in the anti-tech camp. A spokesman for RTMark, a kind of cyberguerrilla group known for lampooning politicians and making mischief for corporations, Mr. Thomas pointed to escalating rents as a death knell for art. "Silicon Valley has basically destroyed the art scene in the Bay Area by bringing in so much money and so many people," he said.
Many of his artist friends are moving to cities like Los Angeles, where rents are lower. "It's basically so demoralizing, people don't even have energy to make art about it," Mr. Thomas said.
In a few cases, technology companies are looking to artists for new ideas that could lead to the development of new technology. Corporate research centers like the Interval Research Corporation and the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center are financing artists in residence. Michael Naimark, an artist at Interval, said: "It's a funny situation right now, because there really isn't an N.E.A. to support experimental work, and there's so much money and activity in high technology. The question is, how do artists fit in? Nobody really has the answer."
They do appear to fit in better in the Bay Area than down the road in Silicon Valley itself, which is generally acknowledged as not having much of an art scene (although a foundation for art and technology in the Valley is in the works). When asked about art in Silicon Valley, John Weber, a curator at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, said: "In Silicon Valley? They work. That's all they do. When they get interested in art, they move."

HEADLINE: SCREEN GRAB;
Sites Remember the Irish Potato Famine

BYLINE: By MICHAEL POLLAK 

 BODY:
IN May 1997, at a ceremony in Cork, Ireland, commemorating those who suffered and died in the great Irish famine, which began in 1845, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said: "That one million people should have died in what was then part of the richest and most powerful nation in the world is something that still causes pain as we reflect on it today. Those who governed in London at the time failed their people through standing by while a crop failure turned into a massive human tragedy. We must not forget such a dreadful event."
In the last few years, as Irish movies, dance, books and plays have enjoyed a surge of popularity in the United States, a number of Web sites have emerged to ensure that the famine, which Mr. Blair called "a defining event in the history of Ireland and of Britain," will not be forgotten. 
 Perhaps the most thorough treatment is a 117-page curriculum guide for teachers sponsored by the New Jersey Commission on Holocaust Education. It is available for downloading at www.nde.state.ne.us/SS /irish_famine.html, thanks to an Irish education coalition that persuaded the Nebraska Department of Education to put it online. The site is also linked or listed online by the education departments of Illinois, Massachusetts, Idaho and Colorado.
It was prepared by James V. Mullin of Moorestown, N.J., a former teacher and law librarian. In 1995, he began putting together a synopsis on the famine for the Holocaust Commission, which was assembling similar guides on the persecutions and mass deaths of Cambodians, Armenians, American Indians and African slaves. The online curriculum is free. (Another resource site about the famine is at www.people.Virginia .EDU/eas5e/Irish/biblio.html.)
Mr. Mullin, who was educated in parochial schools, said, "I was taught basically that the Irish only wanted to grow potatoes because they loved them so much, and then when the potato crop died, the Irish couldn't think of anything else to eat." He agreed with the historians he consulted that the famine could not be understood apart from British colonial misrule in Ireland.
But it was odd how little teaching existed about the famine and the policies that led to it and worsened it, he said. Jonathan Swift's "Modest Proposal," about eating Irish babies to reduce the surplus population, is routinely taught in English literature courses as a supreme example of irony, he noted, but it is less often taught in English history classes, where it would acquire a needed context.
The heavily footnoted and attributed guide takes Ireland from Neolithic times through the Viking and Norman invasions and into the era of colonial domination, British plantations and the absentee landlord system, laissez-faire economics, the poorhouses, the relief efforts and the anti-relief efforts, and the emigration in what were called coffin ships.
"Between 1845 and 1850, more than a million Irish people starved to death while massive quantities of food were being exported from their country," it begins.
The guide covers the English penal and administrative laws that reduced the native Irish to second-class citizens. A section on racism depicts some of the cartoons that helped foster Irish stereotypes. (The publication of Darwin's "On the Origin of the Species" in 1859 was soon followed by an upsurge in caricatures of Irishmen as monkeys.)
There are horrific depictions of beggars, of skeletal children, of a man staggering to the graveyard carrying his dead wife. Equally horrific are the quotes from Parliament on the folly of upsetting "natural law" by aiding the starving, and the economic wisdom of encouraging their eviction (in the dead of winter) and their emigration (in ships with mortality rates of more than 50 percent).
There is a discussion of genocide, and historians and political theorists are quoted on the differences between the planned extermination of a people or a culture and the prejudice and culpable neglect that produce the same result.
The curriculum has been revised to add a section on poetry of the famine and to remove a few lines that might unfairly characterize Britain today. But Mr. Mullin said he was disappointed at how many people assumed, wrongly, that the curriculum was anti-British or an Irish nationalist project.
"People are always saying we're comparing it to the Holocaust when we've never done that, and we never will do that," he said. "There is a passive genocide. You can allow people to die." Comparisons with famines in Ukraine, in China under the Great Leap Forward or among the Indians are always inexact, he said, "but the comparisons have to be made if we're going to learn anything."

HEADLINE: Site Sees a Sure Thing In Basketball Contest

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

 BODY:
IT seems like an audacious gamble for a small dot-com that lost more than $6 million last year.
Sandbox.com, one of the several thousand Internet start-ups in the Washington area scrabbling for attention and wealth, is putting on a rich sweepstakes based on the men's college basketball tournament that begins today, promising to pay $10 million to anyone who correctly chooses the winners of all 63 games. 
 So far about 600,000 contestants have filled out the brackets online, and Sandbox's 30-year-old president, Lawrence M. Cotter, said he expected the total to approach one million contestants before the contest, called It's Madness, closes at noon today.
But as with so many things in the new online economy, the risks for Mr. Cotter and his company are illusory. First, it is highly unlikely that anyone will win. Statisticians put the odds of selecting all 63 winners at something in the neighborhood of eight or nine quintillion (a quintillion has 18 zeros).
But then, most basketball fans think that they bring some knowledge and skill to the selections.
"So I think the odds are really in the neighborhood of one in five billion," Mr. Cotter said, "meaning that the chances are about 1 in 600 that a Sandbox member will win."
But a single upset in the tournament can cause turmoil.
Last year, when Sandbox offered a mere $1 million prize, every one of the 160,000 contestants was shut out in the very first round, after the highly ranked University of North Carolina lost to Weber State, a Cinderella team, by one point in the first game -- which almost nobody predicted. This year, another Web site, Predict It (sports .predictit.com), is offering a similar contest with a $1 million prize.
Mr. Cotter said he hoped that his contest would last longer this year. After all, the game for Sandbox.com is to gain national attention as well as new members for its online gaming business.
And at this point he has nothing to lose because if someone does win, Sandbox.com doesn't have to come up with the $10 million.
The company bought "hole in one" insurance, so named for the country-club practice of parking a Cadillac Coupe DeVille on the golf course, next to the 18th hole, and promising to give it to the member who can sink a hole in one.
An insurance examiner figured the odds for Sandbox.com's contest and assessed a fee of about 25 cents per player, or just $250,000 if one million people play.
Worried that the contest and resulting attention will shut down quickly again this year, Sandbox is also giving away other prizes, like a car and entertainment centers, for people who pick lots of game winners, if not all of them. The top scorer wins a Pontiac, donated by another Web site, AutoMall.com.
Sandbox also recruited several paying "sponsors," or advertisers, for the contest. The lead sponsor, whose banner advertisement appears at the top of the contest Web page, is another Internet start-up, PhoneFree.com.
Jan Horsfall, the company's president, said, "We are extremely stoked to be part of such great fun."
What's more, Sandbox is earning money from the entrants. Registration is free, but Sandbox presents about a dozen special offers -- trial magazine subscriptions, memberships at other Web sites -- on the registration page.
So many people are taking them up on the offers that on average, Sandbox is getting $3.50 in commissions and other fees as a result of each registration, the company said.
With all that, "everyone's a winner," Mr. Cotter said with a smile.
The contest almost did not get off the ground. The company ordered new server capacity to handle the surge in visitors to the site, but after weeks of promising, the contractor had not delivered by last Friday.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association was to post the game brackets on Sunday evening, and that is when Sandbox needed to have its contest up and running.
"We called all around the area, desparately looking for bandwidth," Mr. Cotter said. Finally a local company stepped in to help, and the higher-capacity servers were in place just in time on Sunday evening.
"We'd love to have someone win so we could march him around the country with a big $10 million check," Mr. Cotter said.
After a moment of thought, he added with a grin: "That's the second-best thing that could happen. The first-best thing would be for a hacker to shut down our site for two hours in the middle of the contest, and we'd be on the front pages of all the papers."
So far, a windfall like that has not arrived, so the company is already thinking about next year's contest.
Bill Carey, Sandbox's executive vice president, has said the company is thinking of offering $64 million in 2001. After all, what's to lose?

HEADLINE: MAKING BOOKS;
Black Reviews, Still a Secret

BYLINE: By Martin Arnold 

 BODY:
It matters that few people in book publishing seem aware of the existence of an ambitious, glossy bimonthly magazine devoted entirely to black literary culture, to books by or about blacks and to news about the few black people who work in publishing. The magazine, Black Issues Book Review, is a secret that doesn't want to be kept, and it matters that it is largely unknown in the industry because more books written by black authors are being published than ever before. Black Issues is trying, with some success, to reach African-Americans, particularly but not exclusively those on the high end socially and economically. In short, regular book customers.
To mainstream publishing, blacks are somewhat like a very welcome weekend guest that the host doesn't quite know how to entertain. Thus, for instance, Susan McHenry, editor of Black Issues, said that although the magazine is filled with book reviews, it still has difficulty getting on publishers' lists to receive galleys of new black books. It's not that publishers want to withhold them; it's just that they don't think black. Without such galleys, there can be no reviews, and without reviews no influence for the publication and no sales for the book. 
 Among other examples: in some book stores, the works of Toni Morrison are found on the racks identified as African-American literature, not general literature, where one would expect to find a Nobel laureate. (Sometimes, but not always, they are cross-indexed.) And there remains that old question: Where are the black editors? The answer is not that publishers don't want them but rather that they don't know how to attract them. This is not about prejudice as much as it is about a meandering lack of urgency.
Besides the growing number of books by and about blacks, in recent years black readers' groups have popped up all over. Publishers, with some exceptions, have been slow to respond to this expanding constituency. Doubleday Direct, the book club division of Bertelsmann, has Black Expressions, a club devoted to books by and about blacks, with its own online version, and Ballantine has its One World imprint, which publishes black writers. HarperCollins owns Amistad Press, devoted to work by and about African-Americans.
Still, there's a divide between what's being published and what's being publicized about black literature; to cross that divide there are black literary magazines, the newest among them Black Issues. Its latest issue, March-April 2000, celebrates the magazine's first anniversary. There are other magazines, like The Quarterly Black Review, founded in 1993, and Mosaic Literary Magazine, a quarterly founded two years ago as a showcase for new black literary writers.
Black Issues is a slick magazine, ambitious in scope, with crisp writing and quality production values. Its format is slightly larger than a news weekly, and it is divided into sections about literary subjects (the latest issue features poetry and the cover line is "Rap Is Poetry: Hip-Hop's Poet Ambassadors") and the business of book publishing. Between them are scattered 8 fiction reviews, 11 nonfiction reviews, 6 reviews of books of poetry and the usual magazine tchotchkes: shorts about deals, today's top 10 poetry CD's, a feature called Bookbytes etc.
Rone Shavers, the managing editor, said the magazine hoped to attract bookstores, libraries, agents, book publicists and art designers, "but the main mission is reaching regular book readers."
Ms. McHenry said: "There's no one place where someone can go and find out what's in the bookstores and libraries about people of African descent. A major national review may review a handful of black books a year. We do more than that in our latest issue."
"We want to have a national forum for the growing black book audience," she continued. "There's a community of lovers of black literature who are interested in contemporary black writers."
Black Issues was founded by a cultural entrepreneur, William E. Cox, who had started two other publications, Black Issues in Higher Education and Community College Week, a newspaper. Both are bimonthly.
"We ran book reviews in the higher education magazine," he said, "and we started to receive so many unsolicited book reviews back from readers there was no way we could publish them. First we did a special report twice a year. But there was this tremendous interest in books, we found, based on our feedback. Why starve an audience out there?"
The first issue of the book review was sent to colleges and universities. "But I wanted to cut across all areas, whether high school graduate or not, whether college graduate or not," Mr. Cox said. "I wanted a broad-based audience, yet I wanted to attack the high end economically and socially."
The magazine sells 40,000 copies of each issue, through subscriptions and newsstands, which includes bookstores, most but not all of which are black. The Borders chain is its largest advertiser and major supporter, and has been from the start. The magazine is advertising-driven, and Mr. Cox hopes to start making money on it in two years. Black Issues in Education also sells 40,000 copies each issue, but it has much more advertising and is a moneymaker, Mr. Cox said.
The latest issue of the book review has 74 pages, about its average size. Borders has its usual full-page ad inside the front cover and a second one for its Web site. Absolut vodka has the back cover. In between are but a few book publishing ads. Of the mainstream publishers, Doubleday has a full-page ad, and Penguin Putnam has an ad. There are also ads from Arabesque, Warner Aspect and the University of Indiana Press.
Book publishers, who often moan about their sales, should certainly be out there supporting anything that moves the product, which makes the ghostly absence of major publishing house ads all that more surprising.

HEADLINE: Growth in Industrial Sector Was Less Robust in February

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Industrial production grew more slowly than expected in February after surging in January, as carmakers scaled back their output of new cars and trucks, the Federal Reserve said today.
Production by the nation's factories, mines and utilities advanced 0.3 percent last month after a revised 1.1 percent jump in January, which was the strongest monthly increase in one and a half years. Wall Street economists had forecast a gain of 0.5 percent for last month. 
 Analysts said the report still showed that the industrial sector had ample momentum that would keep growth robust in the first quarter.
They said the report would play little part in the meeting Tuesday when Federal Reserve policy makers are widely expected to raise official interest rate targets again in an effort to curb booming consumer demand.
Businesses operated at 81.7 percent of their maximum capacity in February, the same as in January. Though it remained near a two-year high, the rate was below 85 percent, which might fan concern about production bottlenecks.
"The broader picture is that capacity utilization is a key to the inflation picture, and that figure continues to move higher," said Michael Niemira, an economist with Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. in New York.
"With labor pressures and energy prices moving up, it keeps alive the risk of higher inflation ahead," he added.
February registered the 14th consecutive monthly increase in industrial output, underlining the manufacturing sector's steady revival from a bout of weakness in 1998 caused by an Asian financial crisis. It also highlighted the sector's role in fostering the steady economic growth since the last recession ended in March 1991. The economy entered a record 108th month of unbroken growth in March.
Manufacturing raised its production by 0.3 percent last month after a rise of 1 percent in January. The Fed said motor vehicle producers slowed the rate at which they assembled new cars and trucks to 12.9 million a year from the January rate of 13.3 million.
Utility companies raised production a moderate 0.7 percent in February after a 2.7 percent jump in January, as milder weather placed less strain on electricity and natural gas producers. But mining companies reduced their production last month by 0.7 percent, reversing January's 0.6 percent gain.
A separate report on Tuesday from the Commerce Department showed businesses increased their inventories for the 13th consecutive month in January as strong sales to retailers, manufacturers and wholesalers left supplies at their lowest level on record.
The Commerce Department said total inventories rose 0.5 percent in January to a seasonally adjusted $1.150 trillion, matching the gain of 0.5 percent recorded in December.
The inventory-to-sales ratio, which measures how long it would take to fully deplete inventories at the current sales pace, fell to a record low of 1.31 months in January in a reflection of robust consumer demand.
In another report, the United States current account deficit, the broadest measure of foreign trade, widened to a record in the fourth quarter as imports outpaced exports, topping a year in which the deficit surged 53.7 percent.
The Commerce Department said the deficit swelled 12 percent, to $99.78 billion, in the fourth quarter, surpassing the record set in the third quarter, which was revised slightly lower to $89.09 billion.
The deficit on goods also hit a new record of $96.22 billion, up from $91.94 billion in the previous quarter, indicating that Americans' appetite for foreign products like cars and electronics remains insatiable.
For the complete year, the deficit hit a record $338.92 billion, up 53.7 percent from $220.56 billion for 1998.

HEADLINE: Paul Rudolph Jolles, Envoy Of the Atomic Age, Dies at 80

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Paul Rudolph Jolles, a Swiss diplomat who played a key role in promoting the peaceful use of atomic energy through the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna and later became chairman of Nestle, the Swiss food-products group, died on March 11 in Bern. He was 80.
At the end of his life, Mr. Jolles had the unusual experience of seeing the fruits of his earliest diplomatic labor blow up into a major political storm when the United States forced Switzerland's banks to return unclaimed Holocaust-era assets to descendants of the victims of Nazism. 
 In 1946, on his first foreign posting in Washington, Mr. Jolles served as secretary to the chief of the Swiss delegation that negotiated the so-called Washington Accord, in which the Swiss agreed to turn over much of the Nazi gold and other German assets Switzerland had amassed in its vaults.
The agreement was supposed to have settled Switzerland's postwar obligations toward the victorious Allies for good.
In a 1997 interview with the Swiss-German newspaper Der Bund, Mr. Jolles strongly defended Switzerland's economic conduct during the war, saying: "Switzerland never enriched itself, it simply traded according to market criteria. During the war Switzerland's national income increased only marginally -- by less than 1 percent a year."
Mr. Jolles had a lifelong passion for contemporary art and acquired a sizable personal collection. As chairman of Nestle from 1984 to 1990, he was particularly proud of his success in creating the Nestle Art Foundation, which has become a major force on the Swiss artistic scene.
After holding a number of positions in the Swiss administration, mainly concerned with foreign economic relations, Mr. Jolles became deeply involved in President Eisenhower's Atoms for Peace initiative, begun in December 1953. He served in 1957 as executive secretary of the preparatory commission planning the International Atomic Energy Agency.
After the creation of the agency later that year, Mr. Jolles was appointed a deputy directors general, with responsibility for administration, by the first director general, W. Sterling Cole, a former New York State Republican Congressman who had served as chairman of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy. The three other deputies came from France, the Soviet Union and Britain. Mr. Jolly left the atomic energy agency in 1961, returning to the Swiss administration.
"It was an important job and he did it well," said Sir Brian Urquhart, a former United Nations under secretary general for special political affairs, who worked with him on setting up the agency.
Born in Bern on Dec. 25, 1919, Mr. Jolles studied law at the Universities of Bern and Lausanne and in 1943 obtained a doctorate in political science at Harvard University.
In 1956 he married the former Erna Ryffel. He is survived by his wife, two sons and a daughter.

HEADLINE: The Tragedy of Myanmar

 BODY:
Few governments warrant isolation more than Myanmar's military junta, one of the most brutal and repressive regimes in the world. But the cruelty of Myanmar, formerly Burma, is increasingly a regional problem that threatens to destabilize its Southeast Asian neighbors with refugees, narcotics and now AIDS. Unfortunately, Myanmar has faded from attention at a time when the need for concerted action has never been greater.
The latest disturbing news is that Myanmar's booming heroin trade is contributing to the spread of AIDS in nearby countries, notably India, China and Vietnam. Myanmar is the world's second-largest source of opium and heroin, after Afghanistan. It also has its own exploding epidemics of drug use and AIDS. 
 The courageous opposition leader and 1991 Nobel peace laureate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, an advocate of nonviolent resistance, remains under strict government control in the capital, Yangon, formerly called Rangoon. The government continues with a campaign of harassment and imprisonment of her party, the National League for Democracy, which won 80 percent of the parliamentary seats in a 1990 election that the junta then annulled. In recent years South Korea, the Philippines and Thailand have replaced authoritarian regimes with fledgling democracies. Now Indonesia has done the same. The changes present a fresh opening for action on Myanmar, but the world has been slow to seize it. The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, has yet to appoint a new special envoy for Myanmar to coordinate international efforts to bring pressure on the junta.
The White House took the lead in isolating Myanmar, imposing sanctions on new investment there in 1997. But the problem has not been high on Washington's agenda for many months. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which includes Myanmar, will meet in July, and the Group of Eight leading industrial nations will gather in Japan the same month. Tokyo continues to do business with Myanmar's leaders. Washington should use the occasion of this summer's meetings to persuade its democratic friends in the region to shun Myanmar and make clear that normal trade and diplomatic relations cannot be sustained as long as the government abuses its people.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Riseon Hopes Of Slowdown

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday, as declines in the Nasdaq composite index fueled speculation that the economy might slow and prompted some investors to buy fixed-income securities.
Thirty-year Treasuries were also helped to a third consecutive day of gains, as Wall Street firms and investors prepared for a second round of Treasury Department bond buybacks today and as the price of crude oil dropped 3 percent. That drop reduced concern about faster inflation, analysts said. 
 There is "some shift out of equity investments into fixed income," said Zane Brown, who has loaded up on high-yield and municipal bonds for the $12 billion he oversees at Lord, Abbett & Company. A sustained drop in "the Nasdaq could cause some people to reassess expectations for stocks in general."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 8/32 , to 10215/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.07 percent from 6.09 percent Tuesday.
In afternoon trading, Treasury bonds eased a bit as the Dow Jones industrial average surged 3.3 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.6 percent.
Fed policy makers have cited gains in stocks as a pillar of the booming economy. Further losses in stocks, especially the Nasdaq index, which is up 12.6 percent this year and rose 86 percent in 1999, may cap consumer spending and limit interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve, investors said.
"A weak stock market is one harbinger of a softer economy," said Hal Woolley, who helps invest $5 billion in fixed income at Bessemer Trust Company. It's one change that "will make the Fed stop raising rates."

HEADLINE: Hylan G. Lewis, 88, Student of the Urban Poor

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Hylan Garnet Lewis, a sociologist and pioneer in the field of community studies who was active in public life and taught in New York for years, died on March 8 at a hospital in Versailles, France. He was 88, lived on Manhattan's Upper West Side and had been visiting France.
The death of Dr. Lewis, who was retired, was announced on Tuesday by the City University of New York Graduate Center, where he was a professor of sociology for two decades, beginning in 1977. 
 "Professor Lewis, in his research, teaching and leadership in public affairs, was a bright beacon that lit, and in a major way, helped to guide more than a half-century of American race relations," said Setsuko Matsunaga Nishi, a retired professor of sociology at Brooklyn College and the Graduate Center.
Dr. Lewis's 1955 book "Blackways of Kent" is a study of a black community in the industrializing South. It has been called an exemplary early product of community studies, which examines the role of factors like race, job and economic status and family in joining people together.
He went on to direct, from 1959 to 1964, a child-rearing study carried out by the Health and Welfare Council in Washington. A key finding of the study was that poor black mothers in Washington had aspirations of success for their children that were just as high as those of all middle-class mothers. But the study found that the poor black mothers also had a realistic understanding of the obstacles -- like racial prejudice, poverty and poor schools -- that their children would face.
These findings were important and influential, because it had been widely thought at the time that these children had not been succeeding in life because their families had not set high goals.
Later, Dr. Lewis held posts in New York in which he analyzed, and sought remedies for, the problems of the poor and unemployed. He also studied discrimination against members of minorities in corporate employment, foster care and schools.
He was a senior associate at Kenneth B. Clark & Associates, a consulting firm led by Dr. Clark, the noted psychologist and race-relations expert, which advised corporations, schools and other clients about racial integration.
After teaching at Howard University and in the South, Dr. Lewis was on the faculty of Brooklyn College from 1967 to 1977 and while teaching at the Graduate Center he also taught at Queens College from 1990 to 1992.
He was born in Washington, received a bachelor's degree in 1932 from Virginia Union University in Richmond, Va., and his doctorate in sociology in 1951 from the University of Chicago.
His 1935 marriage to Leighla Whipper ended in divorce.
He is survived by his companion, Francoise Burgess; his wife, the former Audrey Carter, from whom he had been separated for 26 years; a daughter, Carole Ione of Kingston, N.Y.; a son, Guy, of Yreka, Calif.; three grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren and two sisters, Kathryn Garner and Elsie Lewis, both of Washington.

HEADLINE: $500 Million Resort Planned on Concord Site in Catskills

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In the first major project since the bungalow colonies and hotels in the borscht belt fell on hard times 30 years ago, a developer plans to demolish the legendary Concord Hotel in the Catskills and build a $500 million resort, with a hotel and conference center, golf village, spa ranch, entertainment center and wilderness area.
Louis R. Cappelli, a Westchester developer who bought the Concord property on Kiamesha Lake a year ago, said he planned to begin construction by Labor Day on property of more than 1,600 acres -- twice the size of Central Park. He said that the complex, 90 miles northwest of New York City, would be a year-round attraction in an area where most of the old hotels have crumbled and many people work two and three jobs to make ends meet. 
 Economic pied pipers have appeared before in the Catskill Mountains with fanciful revival plans that quickly evaporated, but local political leaders have embraced Mr. Cappelli's proposal as a substantive development that could bring new life to the area.
"We're very excited to have him here," said Rusty Pomeroy, chairman of the Sullivan County Legislature. "Once in a while you get a project that can reposition the area all by itself. If he's able to do it, it would change the way people perceive Sullivan County. We're not the borscht belt anymore. We're not a dying, depressed county."
Mr. Cappelli presented his plans yesterday in Monticello a day after Gov. George E. Pataki seemed to dash longstanding hopes for another project, an Indian-run casino at the Monticello Raceway. Governor Pataki has long said that casinos would provide a much-needed boost for former resort areas like Monticello. But on Tuesday, he introduced a bill that would require the State Legislature to approve any Indian gambling initiative, which proponents say is unlikely to happen.
In recent months, Mr. Pataki had come under attack by casino operators from Atlantic City and anti-gambling groups in New York who opposed a planned $500 million casino in Monticello. Some unions have also criticized Indian-run casinos, which are not bound by labor or civil rights laws.
"In my opinion, the governor is bailing out because he has national aspirations," said Mr. Pomeroy, who had supported the casino. "He acceded to a campaign against him by the Atlantic City gaming interests. If this goes to the Legislature, the people speculating on a casino can pack it in. There's too much Donald Trump influence there."
The Federal Bureau of Indian Affairs and Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt are nearing a decision on the proposed casino, which would be owned by the St. Regis Mohawk tribe. The project also needs state approval.
Mr. Cappelli said his plans were not dependent on the casino, which had touched off a land boom in Sullivan County in the last two years. He said the Concord is only 90 minutes northwest of New York City and within a four-hour drive of 55 million people. The resort, he said, should attract conventions looking for an 1,100-room hotel in a rural setting, as well as families looking for a weekend getaway.
"It's going to be a world-class destination resort in one of the most beautiful and easily accessible areas in the nation," Mr. Cappelli said. "It's going to be like nothing else you've ever seen. I think it will also attract all those kids who used to enjoy the Catskills and are now grown up and looking for places to go."
Mr. Cappelli, and his partner, Reckson Strategic Venture Partners, bought the Concord and Grossinger's, perhaps the most famous of the old Catskill resorts, last year in bankruptcy court. Both properties were in disrepair, although the Monster golf course at the Concord, one of the longest in the country, and the Grossinger's golf course have remained open.
Mr. Cappelli has since hired an architect and hotel consultants to develop what he calls the Concord Resorts at Kiamesha Lake. He said Salomon Smith Barney, the investment bank, would offer $150 million in bonds on June 15 to finance the first of two phases.
In the first phase, Mr. Cappelli, who has built office buildings and retail complexes in Westchester, on Long Island and in Connecticut, said he would build the convention center, time-share apartments, the golf village and the spa ranch. The second, $200 million phase would include rental housing, an alpine village and a retail and entertainment complex. An internal tram system would transport visitors across the hilly property and around the golf courses at the center of the property.
The Concord was the largest of 500 hotels and scores of bungalow colonies that once dotted the wooded landscape of Sullivan County, providing a respite for vacationing, mostly Jewish, New Yorkers and a stage for entertainers like Milton Berle and Danny Kaye.
The Catskills evoke memories captured in books and movies like "A Walk on the Moon," and "Dirty Dancing." But with the advent of inexpensive air fares in the 1970's and competition from Europe and Florida, the area fell into decline. Many of the hotels and bungalows were abandoned and eventually demolished, leaving thousands of residents unemployed.
Local residents have heard promises of a revival for decades. "Most people are hopeful but skeptical," said John Conway, the county historian. "We've seen a lot of proposals for resurrecting these hotels come and go, but very few have been carried out. What is encouraging about Cappelli is that this man comes with visible means of support and a willingness to start from scratch."
There have been unsuccessful efforts to build casinos for almost 40 years. A recession cut short the boom in vacation homes in the late 1980's. Joshua Muss, a developer who bought land near Grossinger's, is still waiting to build. Soung Kiy Min bought Grossinger's in 1993 with plans for a redevelopment, only to see it sink back into bankruptcy court.
More recently, several developers bought a number of old resort properties in anticipation, at least in part, that the Mohawk casino would soon open. But since then, David Flaum, a developer from Rochester, has done nothing with the 336-acre Shawanga Lodge property he bought in nearby Wurtsboro last year. And developers are proceeding very slowly at the old Laurels resort on Sackett Lake.
Crescent Heights Investments, however, hopes to break ground in a month or two on a hotel and conference center and a golf community on an 800-acre parcel in Wurtsboro Hills. And Mr. Cappelli said he wants to move quickly.
"The Concord name is synonymous with Sullivan County," said Jonathan Drapkin, the county manager. "If Cappelli can rebuild the glory of that name, I think it'll mean a lot. It can have an impact well beyond the hotel property."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Thai Bankruptcy Decision Seen as a Victory for Creditors

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 15

 BODY:
In a landmark decision watched closely throughout Southeast Asia, Thailand's fledgling bankruptcy court declared Thai Petrochemical Industry, that country's largest corporate debtor, insolvent today.
Creditors regarded the decision as an important victory that could help them start to recover billions of dollars in unpaid loans left from the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis. 
 Thailand's Central Bankruptcy Court ruled that Thai Petrochemical, which defaulted on $3.5 billion in debt in 1997, had liabilities exceeding its assets and ordered the company to submit to court-supervised restructuring.
Thai Petrochemical's creditors, which include the International Finance Corporation, which is part of the World Bank, and the United States Export-Import Bank, filed court papers to have the company declared insolvent last month after more than two years of talks on how to get the company to begin repaying its debts broke down.
Thai Petrochemical's story is one that is being repeated in various forms around Southeast Asia, reflecting efforts to clean up the mess left by the financial crisis. Banks and other creditors have resorted to legal proceedings to uproot the entrenched family interests that continue to dominate much of the region's economy. In Indonesia, for example, efforts to sell assets repossessed by the government have been delayed by legal wrangling over the role still played by former owners connected to the fallen former President Suharto.
Creditors of Thai Petrochemical did not get everything they wanted. The bankruptcy court rejected their request to replace Thai Petrochemical's family-led management immediately, saying a meeting of all creditors and management must take place first. That means there could be more negotiations between the creditors and Prachai Leophairatana, Thai Petrochemical's founder and chief executive.
But Thai officials and analysts still called the ruling a victory in efforts by creditors to force the most stubborn debtors to negotiate in good faith.
"It's a rather good outcome for creditors," said Anthony J. Norman, managing director of Effective Planners Ltd., a unit of Ferrier Hodgson Ltd., the financial advisory firm that the creditor committee had put forward to take over management of Thai Petrochemical. Creditors were satisfied with the decision, Mr. Norman said, shrugging off the possible delay posed by further negotiations. "What does a few weeks matter when you've been waiting 30 months?"
Thai Petrochemical owes so much money that the successful restructuring of its debt would eliminate almost 7 percent of Thailand's outstanding bad loans. Foremost among the beneficiaries would be Bangkok Bank, Thailand's largest bank, which extended $600 million in credit to Thai Petrochemical and is the company's single largest lender.
Financial markets, which had rallied Tuesday in expectation of a ruling favorable to creditors, fell back on the news, with the benchmark index in Thailand falling 3.5 percent. Thailand's currency, the baht, was little changed against the dollar.
The ruling today appeared to stop short of setting what many bankers and lawyers had hoped would be a legal precedent on interpreting insolvency. Current Thai law, amended in 1998 and 1999 to give more power to lenders, defines insolvency as an excess of liabilities over assets, but it fails to include situations in which an otherwise healthy company is unable or unwilling to repay its debts. A report made in January by the Asian Development Bank, the International Finance Corporation and the World Bank to Thai officials identified this loophole as one of several shortcomings in the law.
The Thai bankruptcy court, established only nine months ago as a separate entity to expedite cases like this one, appeared to rely instead on technicalities in deciding in the creditors' favor. It rejected Thai Petrochemical's defense partly because the company's financial adviser who had testified about its debt problems was deemed by the court to be unqualified.
It remains unclear how long it would take to convene a meeting of Thai Petrochemical's nearly 150 creditors, which could give Mr. Prachai a new, if diminished, chance to retain control of the company he and his family founded in 1978. Thai Petrochemical officials did not return phone calls seeking a reaction to the court's decision.
Company officials had said they would resign if they lost the case, but there was no immediate sign that they would abide by that statement. Last week, the company appealed to nationalist sentiments, issuing a statement to the Thai stock exchange that accused creditors of trying to destroy the company and of planning to lay off most of its 20,000 employees.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
When Greenspan speaks and the stock market doesn't listen, the loss of credibility is dangerous.

BYLINE: By Jeff Madrick; This column appears here every Thursday. Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and adjunct professor of social sciences at Cooper Union. Four economic analysts -- Mr. Madrick, Virginia Postrel, Alan B. Krueger and J. Bradford DeLong -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
ALAN GREENSPAN is no longer taken as seriously on Wall Street as he once was. Why else did the strong warnings he made about the lofty levels of stock prices last month go unheeded by so many? His basic message was right: over-speculation can damage the economy. But while the Dow Jones industrials fell on his comments, if only moderately, investors defiantly sent the all-important Nasdaq to record highs.
Some still believe that the Nasdaq rose because the technology stocks that dominate it are relatively immune from any interest rate increases Mr. Greenspan might impose. But that's wishful thinking. The new economy is still dependent on the much larger old one. After all, what is going to be sold on the Internet? Even though Nasdaq gave plenty back this week, it is above the level that provoked Mr. Greenspan to issue his warnings. For that matter, the Dow industrial average, after yesterday's rise, made up all but a couple of percentage points of the ground it had lost. 
 For all his bluntness, Mr. Greenspan was simply not able to deflate stock portfolios with his warnings. The nation's mutual funds, for example, were so top-heavy with the high-technology Nasdaq leaders that they just kept rising in value. "Despite the bifurcation in the market, most investors are still up this year," says Michael Lipper, who monitors the funds. To some on Wall Street, Mr. Greenspan is becoming the chairman who talks loudly but carries a little stick.
The issue is moral hazard, a technical term that means investors take too much risk because they know that if all goes wrong, they will be protected by the central bank from having to absorb severe losses. Such aggressive investing can drive financial prices to insupportable levels.
Moral hazard is not the only factor that pushes asset prices to irrational heights -- greed has no small part. But many believe it contributed significantly to the Asian financial crisis of 1997. The bailouts came in the form of giant emergency loans.
To many Americans, moral hazard is something that only happens elsewhere. But consider our own bailouts. In 1987, Mr. Greenspan admirably engineered an infusion of money worldwide after the market crash. Stock prices came back and major economies avoided recession. In 1997, he supplied liquidity again to offset the escalating Asian financial crisis. Again, the West averted disaster.
Mr. Greenspan even injected funds late last year to forestall problems that some feared would result as computers and other electronic equipment crossed into 2000.
However necessary these were, many in the markets now seem to believe Mr. Greenspan will always save the day. Moreover, there is a suggestion in his public pronouncements that he is not sufficiently sensitive to this. He warns of irrational exuberance, on the one hand, only to present a case, on the other hand, that a new economy can continue to grow rapidly without inflation. Robert J. Shiller, a Yale economist, writes in his new book "Irrational Exuberance" (Princeton University Press) that cheering on investors while warning them not to speculate is no way to maintain credibility.
In his remarks before Congress last month, the Fed chairman cloaked his market concerns in terms of fighting inflation, but my guess is that he was really worried that a stock market flying so much higher than its historical norms is at risk of collapse. Mr. Greenspan knows that any such collapse could result in a recessionary reduction in spending by consumers.
Ultimately more dangerous, a fall in stock prices could induce a run on the United States dollar as foreign investors withdraw money and American investors seek greener pastures abroad. A falling dollar would then push up interest rates and import prices. To control inflation, the Fed might have to tighten further.
The virtuous circle of a high dollar, high stock prices, low inflation and low interest rates could suddenly slip into the vicious circle of a falling dollar, falling stock prices and rising inflation and interest rates. Recession would not be far behind.
Here is my pipe dream. The Fed chairman at last recognizes that he needs two weapons to fight on two fronts. To be sure, this would require Mr. Greenspan to break the self-imposed rules that restrict the Fed to monitoring inflation and economic growth. But some of history's most successful central bankers were at their best when they broke their own rules.
At next Tuesday's Fed policy meeting, Mr. Greenspan should consider raising interest rates no more than a quarter point, as expected, but he should also do the unexpected and raise the 50 percent margin requirement on stock purchases to stanch market speculation. Admittedly, there are plenty of ways around such margin requirements these days, which require investors to put up half the purchase price in cash. But if margin debt, now at record levels, is so meaningless, why are so many people resorting to it?
Raising margin requirements alone would not have much bite, but if margin requirements and interest rates were raised simultaneously, Mr. Greenspan could restore some credibility and send a strong message to the Street.
The Fed should also consider tightening its capital requirements on risky bank loans to big investors. Reducing speculation by restricting credit now would help Mr. Greenspan avoid larger and quite painful rate increases in the future.
The real fear is whether he has waited too long.

HEADLINE: F.T.C. Expected to File Complaints Over Generic Drug Delays

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
The Federal Trade Commission is expected to file complaints today contending that four drug companies harmed consumers when they made agreements that delayed the sale of low-cost generic drugs, according to lawyers and executives briefed on the matter.
The expected civil actions will be the first to come from a continuing investigation by the commission into the growing number of deals between companies that make brand-name drugs and competitors that are developing cheaper, generic forms of popular medications. Under the agreements, the brand-name company pays the generic company not to sell the lower-cost drug. As a result, consumers pay hundreds of millions of dollars more than they would if the cheaper drug were available. 
 The Andrx Corporation, a generic drug maker, said yesterday that the commission was expected to file a case against it and Aventis, created last year with the merger of Hoechst A.G. of Germany and Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France, over a 1997 agreement between Andrx and Hoechst. Under the agreement, Hoechst agreed to pay Andrx $100 million a year if Andrx kept its generic version of Cardizem CD, one of the nation's top-selling heart drugs, off pharmacy shelves. Cardizem had sales of $850 million in 1998, according to IMS Health, a market research firm.
The F.T.C. is also expected to settle charges with Abbott Laboratories and Geneva Pharmaceuticals, a generic drug company owned by Novartis, executives said. The charges result from a deal between the two companies involving Abbott's blood-pressure drug, Hytrin, which had sales of $610 million in 1998. Abbott agreed to pay Geneva millions of dollars a month to not sell its generic version of Hytrin.
Elliot Hahn, president of Andrx, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said yesterday that the company's agreement with Aventis did not harm consumers. Instead, Mr. Hahn said, details of the agreement and Aventis's payments helped the financially struggling Andrx get the generic drug on the market faster than would have otherwise been possible.
"We did everything we could to get this product out there," Mr. Hahn said.
A spokeswoman for Aventis also said that the agreement with Andrx did not harm consumers but was solely meant to protect the company's patent.
"We are aware that the commission is expecting to vote on this issue," she said. "We don't yet know the outcome of that vote."
Spokeswomen at Abbott, based in North Chicago, Ill., and Geneva, based in Broomfield, Colo., declined to comment yesterday.
Some of the companies are also facing class-action lawsuits filed by consumers and large purchasers of drugs, including insurance companies and pharmacies. Abbott disclosed in its annual 10-K report this week that Florida's attorney general was also demanding information about its agreement with Geneva and about a similar deal with another drug company, Zenith Laboratories.
The commission is investigating the generic drug deals at a time when many popular drugs are nearing the end of their patent protection. To protect revenues derived from those brand-name drugs, companies often quickly file lawsuits against any competitor that applies to the Food and Drug Administration to sell a generic form. The lawsuits argue that the generic drug company is infringing on the other company's patent.
A growing number of those lawsuits result in the kind of settlements the commission is now investigating.
Mr. Hahn said that Andrx had submitted applications to develop the generic form of 10 different brand-name drugs. So far, he said, Andrx has been sued by the manufacturer of the brand-name drug over nine of those applications. Just by filing the lawsuit, the company with the brand-name drug can often delay the introduction of the generic drug for many months.
"That is the game," Mr. Hahn said.
The commission is expected to file its case involving Aventis and Andrx before an administrative law judge rather than in federal court. The F.T.C. could only press for fines or other financial penalties if it filed the complaints in federal court.
In the case of Abbott and Geneva, the commission is expected to approve a consent order that would not involve financial penalties but would prohibit the companies from entering into similar agreements in the future.

HEADLINE: Ukraine Leader Cancels U.S. Visit Over I.M.F. Complaint

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN with TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
The prime minister of Ukraine canceled a visit to the United States earlier this week after the Clinton administration told him that he should come only after "cleaning up" his government, which was discovered to have abused a major international loan program.
Ukrainian officials said the prime minister, Viktor Yushchenko, postponed his trip on short notice because of a mining disaster at home, not because of a snub by the president. 
 Mr. Yushchenko, who was confirmed by Parliament as prime minister late last year and was planning to make his first official visit to Washington in that capacity, was told that he would not be able to meet with President Clinton during his stay, a senior administration official said.
The decision to discourage the visit came just before the Treasury Department and the International Monetary Fund revealed that the Ukrainian central bank had made a series of financial transactions designed to create the impression that it had more foreign currency than it did. The fund said that manipulation of exchange reserves was intended at least in part to mislead fund officials into disbursing hundreds of millions of dollars in loans that might otherwise have been withheld.
Mr. Yushchenko headed Ukraine's central bank before becoming prime minister. American officials consider him the leading reformer in a nation that has been rocked by corruption scandals for years. But revelations of mismanagement at the central bank while he served as its leader have undermined the prime minister early in his administration, analysts who follow Ukrainian politics said.
"There was the sense that they should go fix this and then talk about a visit," the senior administration official said. "They clearly have some business to do at home to clean up this problem."
The Washington-based International Monetary Fund, which coordinates its lending programs with the United States, its largest shareholder, said that Ukraine supplied false information about foreign reserves from 1996 to 1998. The country's central bank used nearly $1 billion in hard currency to conduct a series of banking transactions that allowed it to double-count its reserves. The transactions were designed to make it seem as if it was meeting I.M.F.-set goals for managing its economy when it actually might not have met those goals, the fund said this week.
During the period in question, the fund distributed $675 million in loans to Ukraine. Fund officials said today that they had yet to determine exactly how much of that amount would have been withheld if they had had an accurate picture of Ukraine's financial health.
The revelations raise questions about political and economic management in Ukraine, the former Soviet republic that has long been a high priority for the Clinton administration. Until recently, Kiev was the third largest recipient of foreign aid from the United States, after Israel and Egypt -- aid that was intended in part to support democracy and foster capitalism. Ukraine, along with Russia, has also been among the largest recipients of long-term lending from the fund.
The discovery of mismanagement in Ukraine is a blow to the monetary fund at a sensitive time. The fund came under pressure from Congress and the Clinton administration to strengthen its auditing procedures after Russia was found to have misused foreign exchange reserves, possibly including I.M.F. aid, in ways that resemble the problems in Ukraine.
When Congress agreed to devote $18 billion to support the fund in 1998, it set up a commission to investigate ways of streamlining its operations. The so-called Meltzer Commission last week issued a report that, among many recommendations, urged that the fund eliminate the types of long-term lending programs involved in loans to Ukraine.
Lawmakers who vote on United States contributions to the fund have also demanded that the fund do a better job of ensuring that the money it provides is used properly.
"It's going to be important to know who knew what and when at the I.M.F.," said Representative Jim Leach, who is chairman of the House Banking Committee. "There are also very serious questions about how deep the corruption goes in the former Soviet Union -- whether this is just endemic or whether there is still hope for reform."
The fund made a detailed statement about Ukraine's deception in response to questions from several news organizations, fund officials said today. The statement, issued late last night, said that Ukraine's central bank, at its request, hired the private accounting firm of PriceWaterhouseCoopers to audit it accounts. Fund officials said they hoped that the audit would reveal more information about how the currency reserves were inflated, how much money the fund disbursed to Ukraine that it otherwise might have withheld, and whether offshore banking transactions generated profits for Ukrainian officials.
The fund received indications of Ukraine's deception well before it said anything publicly about the matter.
The fund said this week that it had spotted problems with Ukraine's management of its foreign reserves as early as August 1998. In April of last year, legislators in Ukraine's Parliament sent a letter to the I.M.F. raising accusations that the central bank was "round-tripping" foreign reserves through offshore accounts to create a false picture of its total reserves.
The mismanagement, at least so far, has not resulted in any punishment for Ukraine. The nation currently has access to an I.M.F. loan program initiated in September of 1998, though the fund has not recently disbursed money because Ukraine has failed to meet conditions of the loan program.
Questions also have been raised about the role of Credit Suisse First Boston, the New York-based investment banking arm of Swiss financial services giant Credit Suisse Group. Credit Suisse helped transfer about $150 million in central bank funds, some of which might have been provided by the I.M.F., from Ukraine to Cyprus, a popular offshore haven for financial transactions in the former Soviet Union, government investigators said. The information about Credit Suisse's role was first reported by The Financial Times.
The fund said the money involved in that transaction was funneled back into Ukraine from Cyprus, invested in government securities and double-counted for purposes of tallying total foreign reserves.

HEADLINE: New York Planning Crackdown On Excessive Home Loan Fees

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Regulators in New York State, the nation's largest banking center and an industry pace setter, are devising new rules to crack down on lenders who impose exorbitant fees that force countless homeowners into foreclosure and bankruptcy.
The abuses at issue are the underbelly of the lucrative $280 billion national market in loans for people with limited income or poor credit histories, so-called subprime borrowers. Although such loans charge higher interest rates, they have been a godsend to many people who otherwise might not get financing. 
 But some unscrupulous operators seek out unsophisticated clients, typically elderly or minority homeowners or first-time buyers in poor areas. They talk the victims into refinancing or applying for other loans saddled with excessive interest and fees. The lenders and brokers collect their fees up front. If the borrower falls in arrears, the mortgage holder seizes the house.
With action on the issue apparently stalled in Congress, the New York State Banking Board is flexing its powers to license and oversee mortgage bankers and brokers.
Gov. George E. Pataki, who appoints the board, ordered it to take up the issue last year after an investigation of a major lender, Delta Funding, by Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer. Mr. Pataki was stung by Mr. Spitzer's suggestion that his regulators had gone easy on Delta.
The final regulations are expected to win the board's unanimous support in the next several weeks.
"I hope it will become a model for similar regulation and legislation in other states and on a nationwide basis," said Elizabeth McCaul, the acting superintendent of banks and the board's chairwoman. "We want to end abusive practices, but we don't want to inadvertently cut off access to credit in those communities where we are trying to create more access."
The regulations, drafted in recent months, would impose several new standards for high-cost loans.
*Such loans would be defined as those that charge interest more than eight percentage points above the comparable United States Treasury rate, or up-front fees greater than five points on a loan (a point is 1 percent of the total loan amount). For second mortgages and other home loans, the threshold would be nine percentage points.
*Lenders would be required to consider borrowers' ability to repay and notify them that impartial credit counseling is available.
*Negative amortization (in which the principal grows) would be banned, as would balloon payments before seven years and higher-interest penalties after a default.
*Certain fees and points would be limited to 5 percent of the loan.
*The "packing" of certain insurance and other costs into the loan would be prohibited, as would the "flipping" of loans by refinancing at excessively higher costs, the charging of bogus fees for services not rendered and unfair mandatory arbitration.
While Ms. McCaul said the proposals had broad support from the public and the lending industry, consumer groups say the plan does not go far enough. A joint statement from 70 groups and 12 elected officials last month said that the proposal "leaves serious and glaring loopholes what would allow creative lenders and brokers, in too many instances, to continue their predatory practices as usual."
Those endorsing the statement included AARP; New York Public Interest Research Group; Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, known as Acorn; Harlem Consumer Education Council; and Greater Rochester Community Reinvestment Coalition.
"All eyes are on the New York State Banking Department," said Sarah Ludwig, a leader of a statewide coalition of groups against predatory lending. "The whole country is watching. It's a huge problem, and they've got to get this right. What's clear is they're not really serious about putting the screws to this industry."
Lending-industry leaders, worried that a few disreputable lenders are tainting the rest, say they want the abuses stopped. But they caution that overly stringent rules would hamper legitimate lenders and curtail access to loans for people who need them.
"If there's one bad actor, it puts a black eye on the entire industry," said Robert S. Lotstein, counsel to the National Association of Mortgage Brokers, which has 12,000 members. "We are certainly against predatory lending, but if we need any additional safeguards, they should be narrowly tailored so that we don't throw the baby out with the bath water."
And Stephen A. O'Connor, director for residential financing for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, which has 3,000 members, said: "New York is a bellwether state. Whatever they do is often copied or emulated."
Other states are also considering action: bills have been filed this year in the Legislatures of California, Illinois, Maryland, Minnesota, Missouri and South Carolina. The industry warns that a state-by-state hodgepodge of 50 systems would hinder lenders and drive up costs. "We would much prefer uniformity to a patchwork," Mr. Lotstein said.
The subprime lending market exploded after Congress changed the banking laws in the 1980's in an effort to help the battered savings and loan industry. The pressure for new regulations stems from a surge of complaints about loan abuses by a number of lenders. One high-profile company, First Alliance, a national company with four offices in New York State, has been under investigation by the federal Justice Department and regulators in seven states, including New York. The New York banking board formulated its proposals before an article in The New York Times and a report on the ABC News program "20/20" yesterday about the practices of First Alliance.
The only state that has enacted rules against predatory lending is North Carolina, under a law passed last year in a compromise reached by consumer groups, some industry groups and government officials. Consumer advocates in New York say that North Carolina's version is a far stricter and better precedent than the proposal pending here.
North Carolina, a major banking state, is home to BankAmerica, First Union and Wachovia. Since the law is still being phased in, it is too early to judge the effect, although Alan S. Hirsch, a deputy to Attorney General Michael F. Easley, a leading proponent, said, "It's very plain to us that all the major lenders can live with this."
But Mr. Lotstein said, "We've had clients who have decided it's just not desirable to do business there anymore, and some have turned in their licenses."
In New York State, consumer groups say, the regulators have already yielded to industry criticism and have ignored the revisions they urged. Ms. Ludwig said the coalition wanted the rules to bar common devices like the financing of all points and fees, penalties for paying off a loan early, the financing of insurance charges paid years in advance, all balloon payments and all mandatory arbitration.
The critics also say that the regulations should require stricter review of a borrower's ability to repay and put greater limits on the frequency of refinancing and on the use of so-called discount points.
"The proposed regulations simply overlook too many victims of predatory lending," said an Acorn member, Gloria Waldron of East New York, Brooklyn. "Almost no cases we've seen would even fall under their definition of high-cost loans."
Abuses take many forms, beginning with deceptive advertising of "free money" and high-pressure sales pitches. In Brooklyn, for example, unethical brokers comb through court records to find homeowners already facing foreclosure. The brokers talk the owners into new loans that save their homes temporarily but sink them deeper into debt as the operators strip out the remaining equity to pay their excessive fees. Some lenders have even preyed on homeowners who have been declared mentally incompetent. Many of the loans start with shady home improvement contractors.
Acorn cited a couple in Port Jefferson Station on Long Island who missed a payment and found their interest rate jacked up, to 24 percent from 14. In Brooklyn, a woman told a lender she had lost her $8,000-a-year job as a home health aide, but it approved a loan anyway, falsely listing her with a $50,000 salary. Another woman learned too late that her $45,000 loan required monthly payments of $500 for 15 years -- $90,000 total -- yet left her owing a balloon payment of $41,000.
The problem is worst in minority neighborhoods that have been neglected by more traditional, lower-cost lenders, critics say. Subprime lenders fill that vacuum. In New York City, the legacy of predatory abuses has been a proliferation of foreclosures that community advocates say is devastating central Brooklyn and southeastern Queens.
Assemblywoman Barbara M. Clark, a Democrat of Queens, has proposed a bill that would create protections beyond the proposed banking board regulations.
"I've seen people losing their homes outright as a result of home improvement or debt consolidation loans," Mrs. Clark said. "They're putting their homes on the line and don't know what they're getting into, with fees and interest that are just off the scale."
Her bill would entitle homeowners to cite an improper loan as a legal defense to prevent foreclosure. It would also cap brokers' fees at 3 percent, require disclosure of finder's fees that lenders pay to home improvement contractors for recruiting borrowers, and hold bankers responsible for the brokers they deal with.
"Somebody needs to do something," said Brenda J. Thompson, a school teacher in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, who said she was victimized by a subprime lender.
After inheriting her mother's brownstone, which had a small mortgage with a monthly payment of $154, she talked to a contractor and lender about renovations. But she was upset when crews tore out walls without her approval or a loan's being issued.
So she went to another lender, who seemed sympathetic and referred her to a new contractor. He was charming but overcharged her with a $70,000 fee, took an additional $6,000 of her money and did incomplete and shabby work, she said.
She was left with a $105,000 loan at 10.9 percent with a $1,002 monthly payment and a balloon balance.
"They did a job on me, all right," Mrs. Johnson said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Four Drugmakers Expected To Face F.T.C. Complaints
The Federal Trade Commission is expected to file complaints today contending that four drug companies harmed consumers when they made agreements that delayed the sale of low-cost generic drugs, according to lawyers and executives briefed on the matter.
The civil actions would be the first to come from a continuing investigation into deals under which companies that make brand-name drugs pay rivals that are developing cheaper, generic forms not to sell the lower-cost drug. As a result, consumers pay hundreds of millions of dollars more than they would if the cheaper drugs were available. Page C8. 

Bear Stearns Profit Beats Forecast
Bear Stearns posted a 20 percent increase in its first-quarter profit, beating analysts' expectations, as rising investment banking fees offset a slump in bond trading. The securities firm had net income of $278.2 million, or $1.89 a diluted share, compared with $230.7 million, or $1.45 a share, in the period a year earlier. Shares of Bear Stearns rose $1.5625, to $41.50. C8.
 
Sears Chief Plans to Step Down
Arthur C. Martinez, the chairman and chief executive of Sears, Roebuck, who led a turnaround at the retailer in the mid-1990's, will retire at the end of the year. C14.
 
King's Popularity Extends to Web
Stephen King's latest novella, "Riding the Bullet," has proved so popular in two days of literary life on the Internet that several online booksellers could not meet the demand from people wanting to download digital copies. About 400,000 orders were received in the 24 hours after the book became available. A1.
 
Crackdown on Subprime Lenders
Regulators in New York State, the nation's largest banking center and an industry pace setter, are devising new rules to crack down on so-called subprime lenders that impose exorbitant fees that force countless homeowners into foreclosure and bankruptcy. A1.
 
Creditors Cheered by Thai Ruling
Thailand's bankruptcy court declared Thai Petrochemical Industry insolvent. Creditors regarded the decision as an important victory that could help them start to recover billions of dollars in unpaid loans left from the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis. But the court rejected a request to replace Thai Petrochemical's family-led management immediately, saying a meeting of all creditors and management must take place first. That means there could be more negotiations between the creditors and Prachai Leophairatana, the compa ny's founder and chief executive. C4.
 
European Exchanges Revamping
European stock exchanges began to position themselves for a shake-up in the way investors trade. In London, the 298 members of the London Stock Exchange ended almost two centuries of mutual ownership by converting their stakes into tradeable shares. And the Brussels, Paris and Amsterdam stock exchanges are in talks to merge or form an alliance. C4.
 
New Complaint Filed in Auction Case
The top executives of Sotheby's and Christie's, the two archrival auction giants under federal antitrust investigation for collusion, held secret discussions and meetings to fix prices, and Christie's maintained "a highly unusual, concealed separate filing system" to hide the conspiracy from shareholders and regulators, a new complaint contended. C12.
