LENGTH: 1448 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From Interview With Bush on Campaign Issues and Election Strategy

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., March 15

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview today with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, as recorded by The New York Times: 
 Q. What is your reaction to Al Gore's statement that he had asked the Democratic National Committee to refrain from running issue ads financed with soft money?
MR. BUSH: It's kind of a gimmick. He has no credibility, as far as I'm concerned. I don't trust him. I don't trust him. I don't trust him. He needs to stand up in front of the unions, to get all his friends not to run issue ads. I don't trust the man. . . .
Q. Why not call his bluff?
MR. BUSH: I'm running against a man that I believe will say anything to get elected. I believe that. And I am amazed. Last week, it was, we're going to ban all soft money. At the same time, in your newspaper, you reported that President Clinton was out raising soft money and Vice President Gore, the very same day or the next day, in your paper, accurately reported by you all, was getting ready to go raise $35 million and proud of it. So you can understand why I'm somewhat skeptical.
Q. As a politician/competitor, what do you think of him?
MR. BUSH: I believe he'll say anything to get elected, that's what I believe.
Q. If he's willing to say and do anything, how do you not end up having a whole bunch of the time in this campaign consumed by him doing and saying things and you responding?
MR. BUSH: It's very important for me to enunciate clearly where I want to lead the country. In order for me to win, I need to talk about my vision of reform and the ideas that are necessary to achieve reform. There's no question about that. I hope to be able to counterpunch quickly and move directly to where I want to lead America. That's what Americans want to hear. . . .
Q. Wasn't that lost in fighting over tactics during primaries? Can't that happen again if Gore acts as McCain did?
MR. BUSH: First of all, Al Gore is no John McCain. Please don't lump John into that category. Secondly, I think John McCain is a person that basically wanted to elevate the discourse and had a reason for running, rather than tearing somebody down.
I know everybody said this was a dirty campaign. Compared to many campaigns, it wasn't and the proof is that we had huge turnouts in our primaries, huge, much bigger than the Democrats and much bigger than the past. And the reason why was in spite of what the punditry said, people were hearing positive things. They were hearing positive things about education. They were hearing things about the military.
I know that some are saying that people aren't interested in tax relief. I happen to think they are. And even if they weren't, I'd still be talking about it, because I happen to think it's important for the economic growth.
Q. Polls say voters aren't demanding a huge tax cut and that they trust Al Gore more on the tax issue. Is that not like campaigning with weights around your ankles?
MR. BUSH: May I make something really clear to you, once again, and I hope this pleases you. I don't care what the polls say. I don't. . . . I think it's right for economic reasons. You've heard me talk about what's wrong with this tax code. It's wrong for people who are making $22,000 a year to pay a higher marginal rate on every dollar earned than someone making $200,000 a year. That's wrong. And I hope this doesn't sound blase: I don't care what the polls say. It's not going to change my opinion about what I think should happen. . . .
Q. How critical is your tax plan to winning this election?
MR. BUSH: It's a part of what's critical to my election. What's critical to my election is a lot of things. One, that people trust my judgment. Two, that people hear the call for reform. Three, that people know that I can renew what I call the spirit of America. Four, that people are comfortable with the types of people that I'll bring into my administration. Five, whether people are happy or not with the status quo. I readily concede that if people want four more years of Clinton-Gore, I've got a tough road. I do. I know what my position is. I'm the outsider, and I'm the challenger. I'm coming from outside Washington, and I'm the challenger candidate. People say, I hear them talking out of Washington, well, he doesn't have enough experience. As if being the governor of the second biggest state and having served as a C.E.O. in the private sector isn't experience. It's a Washington mentality. And I'm going to have to battle it. I'm fully aware of the odds I'm going to face.
It's a well thought-out plan. And I'm going to have to battle. I'm going to have battle with the polls. I'm going to have to battle with a president who wants to keep the money in Washington. I'm going to have to battle with a vice president who'll say risky this, risky that. I understand that. But I believed it when I laid it out and I believe it while I'm sitting right here today, after having won some primaries and lost some primaries. This is right for America.
Q. Has John McCain elevated your consciousness about reform? Has he changed your views?
MR. BUSH: No, he didn't change my views. He made me a better candidate. He forced me to play to my strengths better. I needed to make it more clear that I not only believe in reform, I've got the record as a chief executive of getting reform done. There's nothing like the humbling experience of getting whipped pretty bad in New Hampshire to cause a man to re-evaluate. And I re-evaluated my message and I re-evaluated how I was conducting myself as a candidate. I wasn't doing as good a job as I could have explaining where my strength is. And my strength is as somebody when, giving the chance to reform, like education, I brought both Republicans and Democrats together. That's what this country needs, when it comes to Social Security, for example.
When it's all said and done, I think America's going to turn to me. I've got a record of doing it. The vice president is extremely partisan. He's extremely partisan.
Q. Is there anything McCain brought to light for you or changed your opinion on in any way?
MR. BUSH: No, not really. We agreed more than we disagreed. That's the great irony. You know, primaries are struggles, arguments over shades of gray. And that's what makes primaries difficult. In my case, I've known John a long time. And battling with John wasn't all that pleasant, because I like him. . . .
Q. What about Al Gore's public life do you dislike so much?
MR. BUSH: I don't like the acrimony in Washington. I don't like the zero-sum politics. I don't like pitting one group of people against another. I don't like the way they've handled whether or not he knew about raising money from the White House -- you know, iced tea and all these kinds of excuses. . . .
Q. Do you regret the turn of the whole campaign?
MR. BUSH: I regret being called an anti-Catholic bigot. . . .
Q. How involved are you in the day-to-day decisions of the campaign?
MR. BUSH: This is important if you're trying to leap from here to the presidency. I know the difference between being somebody who sets the vision and sets the tone and enunciates the principles by which decisions are being made and someone who is a micro-manager. Being a candidate itself is a lot of work. I can't tell you all the times when I say I'm not going to give this speech. It happens a lot. I can be pretty stubborn.
People make suggestions on what to say all the time. I'll give you an example; I don't read what's handed to me. People say "Here, here's your speech, or here's an idea for a speech." They're changed. Trust me. Last night's a good example. We could have been a lot harsher in tone on Vice President Gore last night. I chose not to. What I think is important is not to get mired in a slugfest with this guy. That's what he wants. And last night one of the drafts I got was pretty tough. I said I'm not going to talk about him this way, because I wanted to talk about education.
Q. When you look at some of the situations where the United States is trying with mixed success to broker peace talks, do you have sympathy for what Clinton is trying to do or do you blame him?
MR. BUSH: Take Northern Ireland for example. I have been on the record applauding the efforts to use our prestige to bring people together. It's very important for Americans and elected officials to be patient with the peace process. To be diligent and patient. It's very important for a president not to impose a United States solution on the peace process. So to the president's credit, it seems to me on the Middle East he's working hard to bring people together.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS;
HIGHER CANADIAN INFLATION

BYLINE: By Timothy Pritchard 

 BODY:
Rising oil prices pushed Canada's annual inflation rate to a five-year high of 2.7 percent in February, up from 2.3 percent in January, Statistics Canada said. Gasoline prices were 31 percent higher than a year earlier. Excluding energy, the consumer price index rose by 1.6 percent last month, more than economists had expected after a 1.4 percent advance in January. With oil prices higher again this month, economists predict inflation for March will be close to 3 percent -- the maximum the Bank of Canada has said is acceptable. At the least, the central bank is expected to try to slow the economy by following any interest rate increases imposed by the Federal Reserve in the United States. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TEXAS GOVERNOR;
BUSH REBUFFS BID TO EMBRACE VIEWS PUSHED BY McCAIN

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE and FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., March 15

 BODY:
Rebuffing calls from prominent Republicans to reach out to Senator John McCain, Gov. George W. Bush insisted today that he had no intention of making concessions to his vanquished rival for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Mr. Bush passed up several opportunities to embrace Mr. McCain's remedy for overhauling the campaign finance system, the senator's signature issue. Mr. Bush said he had learned nothing new about reform from Mr. McCain, although he conceded that his challenger had forced him to be a more spirited competitor. And he was sparing in his praise of Mr. McCain, whose supporters Mr. Bush's campaign is counting on to help him win the general election. 
 "He didn't change my views," Mr. Bush said in an hourlong interview at the governor's mansion here on the day after he all but officially clinched his party's nomination.
Asked if Mr. McCain had illuminated any new ideas for him or affected his positions, he said, "No, not really." Excerpts, Page A20.
Reminded that Mr. McCain helped propel record turnouts in the primaries, Mr. Bush responded curtly, "Well, then, how come he didn't win?" The governor noted that in South Carolina his candidacy helped draw record numbers of Republicans to the polls.
Mr. Bush's comments were notable because they suggested that despite the bruising, bitter and sometimes humbling nature of his primary campaign against Mr. McCain, the governor emerged without any regrets about his campaign's conduct, any second thoughts about his strategy or any new resolves for the way he positions himself for the general election. His confidence, if anything, seemed fortified.
As with the overhaul of campaign finance laws, he did not cede ground on any of his positions. He said, for example, that he was not daunted by polls showing that his plan to cut taxes by $483 billion over five years had not caught on with voters. The proposal, he said, would be a pillar of his campaign.
"May I make something really clear to you, once again?" Mr. Bush asked. "I don't care what the polls say. I don't."
Insisting there was no reason to turn back, he explained, "It's a well thought out plan backed by numbers, backed by credible sources, and it's something I'm going to stay with, you bet."
The governor said he was not deterred -- or haunted -- by the memory that voters were never drawn to the ambitious tax-cut proposal of Bob Dole, the Republican presidential nominee four years ago.
"It's different because, one, I started early, and, two, there's a different budget projection," he said, drawing a contrast with the plan Mr. Dole put forth late in the campaign. "There's a different budget picture. I'm still going to have to fight the same thing he fought, with an administration that's desperate to keep the money in Washington."
Signs that the economy is getting a bit shakier are "all the more reason to provide tax relief," he said, explaining that his plan would not only jolt the economy but also provide insurance against any downturn.
To persuade Americans to back his plan, he said: "I'm going to have to battle. I'm going to have to battle with a vice president who'll say risky this, risky that."
But Mr. Bush said that in the end, voters would be less moved by whatever sniping occurred between him and Vice President Al Gore and would make their decisions based on a few overarching considerations.
"What's critical to my election is a lot of things," he said. "One, that people trust my judgment. Two, that people hear the call for reform. Three, that people know that I can renew what I call the spirit of America. Four, that people are comfortable with the types of people that I'll bring into my administration. Five, whether people are happy or not with the status quo.
"I readily concede that if people want four more years of Clinton-Gore, I've got a tough road. I do.
"I know what my position is. I'm the outside, and I'm the challenger. I'm coming from outside Washington, and I'm the challenger candidate. People say, I hear them talking out of Washington, well, he doesn't have enough experience. As if being the governor of the second biggest state and having served as a C.E.O. in the private sector isn't experience. It's a Washington mentality. And I'm going to have to battle it. I'm fully aware of the odds I'm going to face."
Mr. Bush's aggressiveness toward Mr. Gore was the latest reminder of how quickly the general election campaign had become ferocious. The governor made no effort to mask his animosity toward Mr. Gore.
With little prompting at the start of the interview, Mr. Bush said his Democratic rival was not to be trusted. Scoffing at an e-mail message Mr. Gore sent to him on Tuesday night calling for something of a disarmament on both sides' use of unregulated soft money, Mr. Bush said: "I don't trust the man. He has no credibility as far as I'm concerned about campaign funding reform."
Mr. Bush repeated six times that he did not trust Mr. Gore.
Specifically, Mr. Gore said in his message that he had instructed the Democratic National Committee not to spend a cent of soft money for issue commercials against the Republicans unless the Republicans did so first.
Christopher Lehane, Mr. Gore's spokesman, mocked the governor's comment that the vice president would do anything to win the White House. Mr. Lehane said: "If nothing else, the Republican primary proved one thing: George W. Bush will do anything to get elected, included embracing extreme right positions on choice, gun control, tolerance, the environment and, of course, the economy."
But if Mr. Bush's combative tone toward Mr. Gore was not surprising, his relatively complacent attitude about any remaining rift between him and Mr. McCain was.
It could simply be part of an effort to maintain a brave public face while the campaign's emissaries privately reach out to Mr. McCain. Even so, one of the few times Mr. Bush said something explicitly favorable about the senator was in the course of condemning Mr. Gore.
"First of all, Al Gore is no John McCain," Mr. Bush said. "Please don't lump John into that category. Secondly, I think John McCain is a person that basically wanted to elevate the discourse and had a reason for running, rather than tearing somebody down."
Asked, then, if Mr. Gore had a reason for running, Mr. Bush replied, "I'm sure he's got a reason, but their style, as we've seen from the last eight years, is to demean and degrade."
Mr. Bush's reluctance to reach out more to Mr. McCain, at least publicly, could be politically perilous for the governor. Mr. McCain has won enough delegates to have the leverage to embarrass Mr. Bush at the party's convention this summer.
Even Bush supporters on opposite ends of the Republican spectrum -- from Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York -- have called for a rapprochement between the two on reform issues.
Asked whether he needed to make any concessions to Mr. McCain, Mr. Bush said: "No. I think what I need to do is explain to John that we agree a lot more than we disagree. There's a lot of room for reform in Washington, D.C."
But in an interview last week, Mr. McCain said it would be "unacceptable" if Mr. Bush thought they could unite simply over their opposition to President Clinton and Mr. Gore.
Mr. Bush was also unrepentant about the pointed attacks that his campaign -- and supporters of his campaign -- waged on the senator.
Asked if there was anything in particular, he said: "Like what? Give me an example. What should I regret?" Pressed about the negative tone of the campaign, he said, "I didn't take the negative tone."
Mr. Bush was also unwilling to concede that his campaign squandered its record war chest of roughly $70 million to win the primaries. He said he had ordered no changes in his organization and was not worried about spending for the general election, when each campaign will get roughly $67 million in federal subsidies.
Mr. Bush talked about how he managed his campaign and, by extension, how he would function in the Oval Office.
"People make suggestions on what to say all the time," he said. "I'll give you an example: I don't read what's handed to me. People say, 'Here, here's your speech.' Or, 'Here's an idea for a speech.' They're changed. Trust me. Last night's a good example. We could have been a lot harsher in tone on Vice President Gore last night. I chose not to."
Mr. Bush also came to President Clinton's defense in his confrontation with the National Rifle Association, which had asserted that Mr. Clinton was content with a certain prevalence of gun deaths so he could keep gun control as an issue.
"By the way," he said, I didn't think the N.R.A. was right to characterize the president the way they did. I don't believe the president is anxious to use death to advance an agenda."
Nor did he criticize Mr. Clinton as failing to negotiate lasting peace agreements in several regions, from the Middle East to Northern Ireland to Kosovo.
"It's very important for Americans and elected officials to be patient with the peace process, to be diligent and patient," he said. "It's very important for the president not to impose a United States solution on the peace process. So to the president's credit, it seems to me on the Middle East he's working hard to bring people together."
It was not yet time, he said, to turn management of the warring factions in the Balkans over to the United Nations.
The interview closed as it began, with Mr. Bush's attention riveted toward his general election opponent. How fierce a competitor would Mr. Gore be?
"We're about to find out," Mr. Bush said.

HEADLINE: Municipal Workers Seek to Equal Transport Union Gains

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
District Council 37, New York City's largest union of municipal workers, kicked off negotiations yesterday with city officials and demanded many of the same things the transport workers gained in their recent contract battle.
Lee Saunders, the trustee running District Council 37, which represents 125,000 city employees, said his union wanted a wage increase substantially above the inflation rate, and a reduction in employee pension contributions like the one secured by the transport workers. 
 "Our members have sacrificed in terms of making the city healthy again," Mr. Saunders said. "We believe that, based on the city's economic health, its substantial budget surpluses and the productivity increases we're seeing with the reduction in the city's full-time work force, we deserve a fair contract with fair wages."
Because of its size, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees is expected to have a substantial influence on the new rounds of negotiations for the city's more than 100 unions, representing nearly 300,000 workers. The district council's present five-year contract expires on March 31, but union officials are now seeking a two-year pact, reasoning that, in a time of budget surpluses, large annual increases are more likely to be won in a short-term contract.
Under the current contract, the workers accepted a two-year pay freeze in the first two years and then received raises totaling 12 percent over the last three years. Mr. Saunders declined to say how large a wage increase he was seeking in the new contract, although some members of his union said they hoped for a raise of at least 5 percent a year over the life of any new pact.
The presidents of the district council's 56 union locals joined Mr. Saunders yesterday to present the union's demands to James F. Hanley, the city's labor commissioner.
"It was a standard first bargaining session," Mr. Hanley said. "Their demands were sufficiently vague. We hope to get further clarification as time goes on. We will have proposals for them when we next get together."
Mr. Saunders said the council's negotiations would be influenced by the transport workers' contract, which included a 12 percent wage increase over three years, and by the tentative agreement reached Monday between Gov. George E. Pataki and the Civil Service Employees Association, which represents 77,000 state employees. That contract includes a 13 percent wage increase over four years.
Both that agreement and the transport workers' accord reduce the employee pension contribution by 3 percent of their annual salary -- money that is left in the paychecks of workers.
"I wouldn't say those contracts are models, but they'll clearly have an impact," Mr. Saunders said. "We'll also have to deal with our own concerns."
Among those concerns, he said, were gaining a no-layoff clause, reducing the rising co-payments for prescription drugs and providing cost of living adjustments on pensions. Many retired city employees complain that their pensions have been frozen since 1995 despite continued inflation.
Leaders of District Council 37 say they will take a tougher negotiating line than the council's former executive director, Stanley Hill, who was close to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and accepted the two-year wage freeze. The district council's parent union pushed out Mr. Hill in November 1998, saying he had failed to stop widespread corruption at the council.
Mr. Saunders, the trustee who replaced Mr. Hill, has repeatedly talked tough about his bargaining goals and, unlike Mr. Hill, has often clashed with the mayor.
The council's tougher attitude was reflected in the actions of members yesterday, as they held demonstrations or gave out leaflets yesterday at more than 100 work sites around the city. The leaflets read: "Since taking office, Mayor Giuliani has given himself a 40 percent salary hike. Doesn't the average city worker deserve a reasonable increase?"
District Council 37 represents social workers, secretaries, librarians, cafeteria aides and thousands of other public employees. Mr. Saunders said 75 percent of the union's members are paid less than $35,000 a year -- from $15,000 for school crossing guards to $75,000 for municipal engineers.
About 200 district council members held a lunch-time protest in front of the Municipal Building yesterday, with placards that read, "We Deserve a Good Deal, Not a Raw Deal."
Vermell Jackson, a demonstrator who works as a $23,000-a-year secretary at Police Headquarters, criticized the mayor's call to replace across-the-board pay increases with merit pay that would be awarded only on an individual basis. "That is crazy," she said. "The only way you'd get a raise is if you're the boss's favorite."

HEADLINE: Republicans Can't Match Bush's Plan for Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
In taking their first step toward a federal budget for next year, House Republicans were left today in the awkward position of backing a smaller tax cut than their party's presumptive presidential nominee, Gov. George W. Bush.
The tax and spending blueprint, passed by the House Budget Committee on a near party-line vote of 23 to 18, would provide more money for the Pentagon and education, freeze or cut many other programs and set aside at least $150 billion and perhaps as much as $250 billion for tax cuts over five years starting in 2001. 
 Mr. Bush's plan calls for a tax cut of $483 billion over five years starting in 2002. His plan would require roughly $300 billion for the tax cuts over the period covered by the House Republican plan.
House Republicans insisted they had no disagreement with Mr. Bush over the size of the tax cut and said they were confident that with a Republican in the White House they could find the additional money needed to close the gap between their plans.
A Republican "with a reform agenda" like Mr. Bush could easily squeeze another $50 billion out of government spending over five years, said Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the budget committee.
"I'm not backing away from the Bush tax cut and neither are members of this committee," Mr. Kasich said.
But the difficulty that Republican leaders have had in coming up with a plan that would give Mr. Bush all that he wants highlighted their problems in translating their ideological penchant for smaller government into spending restraint that even a Republican-controlled Congress can swallow. And it gave the White House, Vice President Al Gore and Democrats in Congress a new opportunity to portray Mr. Bush's plan as excessive.
Democrats on the budget committee went so far as to tweak the Republicans today by offering an amendment to the budget plan calling for Mr. Bush's tax plan to be included. The amendment was defeated.
Gene Sperling, the director of the White House's National Economic Council, said that "if you were looking for a definition" of fiscal irresponsibility, "it would be a tax cut that was so excessive that even the House Republicans are basically forced to admit they couldn't afford it."
In a statement released tonight, President Clinton responded to the vote by calling the Republican budget plan "risky" and warning that it threatened fiscal discipline that has led to economic prosperity.
Mr. Bush's aides said the situation just helped to make his point that Congress, under pressure from President Clinton, has been far too willing to spend money and that the best remedy was to send as much of the government's revenue as possible back to the people who earned it, the taxpayers.
"The governor believes that money left in Washington is likely to be spent, and that covers both parties," said Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman. "It will take a new president to change the way Washington does business and turn things around."
The plan passed by the committee calls for an increase in overall government spending of 3 percent, to $1.85 trillion. About two-thirds of that amount would go to Social Security, Medicare, interest payments on the national debt and other commitments that Congress does not revisit each year.
The other third of the budget, which covers everything from the space program and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to Head Start and environmental programs, would rise by 3.16 percent under the Republican plan, to $596.5 billion.
But nearly all of that increase would go to the military, which would see its budget rise 6 percent next year, to $307.3 billion. The increase in nonmilitary programs would be held to three-tenths of 1 percent, well below the inflation rate, which is running between 2 percent and 3 percent a year.
The plan would set aside $40 billion over five years to finance a yet-to-be developed plan to add prescription drug coverage to Medicare, the health insurance system for the elderly.
The plan would reserve the portion of the surplus generated by excess Social Security revenues to pay down the national debt. It would also create a $60 billion reserve that Congress could use for further debt reduction or additional tax cuts. And it would reserve for tax cuts any surplus beyond what is currently projected by the Congressional Budget Office.
Mr. Kasich said it was not unrealistic to believe that the budget office will increase its surplus projection this year by $40 billion. That money, combined with the $60 billion reserve, would allow the $150 billion tax cut over five years to rise to as much as $250 billion, he said.
Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the budget committee, said the proposal would prove to be no more workable than the Republican budget plans of the last few years, which set spending at levels for most programs far below what Congress and Mr. Clinton ultimately agreed upon.
Even before Mr. Kasich had made the details of the Republican plan public, White House officials attacked it.
Jacob J. Lew, the director of the White House's Office of Management, called it "fundamentally flawed" and said it would gut a wide array of programs, from environmental cleanup to aid for poor women and children.

HEADLINE: Finding Camaraderie in the Music of Mah-Jongg Tiles

BYLINE: By SANDEE BRAWARSKY 

 BODY:
The men who play mah-jongg regularly at the Hok Shan Family Association's Chinatown headquarters have been playing the game since they were children. You can see it in their fingers. One man senses a tile as though reading Braille, running his fingers against the carved surface while flipping it over. Another gracefully lifts a horizontal line of 10 or so tiles, applying just enough pressure so that, miraculously, the middle tiles don't fall. These players are economical with their movements, their smiles and their Cantonese.
Elsewhere in Chinatown waiters are known to slip games in during off hours in restaurant kitchens. On the Upper West Side, a group of professional women in their 40's play on alternate Sundays with a set bought on eBay. The sounds of mah-jongg, an echo from a distant past, are alive as the game enjoys a modest resurgence throughout the New York metropolitan area, though in some precincts it never faded. The daughters of an earlier generation of players have reclaimed the game, the influx of Chinese immigrants has added vitality and expertise, and the Internet has expanded the possibilities of how the game is envisioned and played. 
 Many of New York's mah-jongg enthusiasts are Chinese or Jewish, although it is rare for the two groups to mix because they follow different rules and play in different places. In Chinese neighborhoods m.j., as it is often called, has long been popular with many age groups and with both sexes; families often play together. Now, among non-Chinese players, younger women are embracing the game their mothers and aunts played in the city's boroughs and suburbs. With cellular phones nearby, they plot strategy about dragons and winds, sliding faux-ivory tiles across a card table in search of a perfect hand.
Talk about mah-jongg, and the conversation keeps coming back to the tiles. The simple designs, including dots (small buttons), craks (Chinese characters) and bams (pieces of bamboo) -- represented on the tiles in different amounts, the way spades, hearts and clubs are pictured on playing cards -- have an elegance about them. The tiles are painted with thin lines of red, green, blue and black and polished smooth.
Push two together and there is an unmistakable click. Players find the clicks soothing, even when the shuffling of tiles between games sounds like a tap-dance convention. Some players mix with both hands as though kneading dough. Others nonchalantly dip one hand into the heap of tiles in the middle of the table or make vigorous swimminglike motions. (Some Chinese players call the game "table swimming.") Even the name evokes the din of the tiles: "mah" means flax plant, recalling the rustling of leaves, and "jongg" means sparrow.
For experienced players, mah-jongg is like a left-brain, right-brain symphony, with one side involved in analytical play, the other in affable talk. The object is to be the first player to complete a hand, accumulating set combinations of tiles. A 100-year-old man who plays at a Chinatown senior center said that the game kept his mind sharp.
For a Jewish group playing weekly in Hewlett on Long Island, mah-jongg is therapy. Surprisingly, amid the nonstop talk and howling laughter, none of the players seem to miss a beat in the game. Now in their 40's, they recount learning to play in their old Brooklyn neighborhoods or in Catskills bungalow colonies. One of the regulars says that the game got her through chemotherapy, taking her mind off the cancer she is fighting.
Growing up on Long Island, I heard a lot of tiles tapping. My mother played mah-jongg with the same group of women for more than 25 years, every Monday night. I loved the look of the tiles and would try to copy the designs with colored pencils. Although I pretended to play, devising games with other mah-jongg daughters, I never learned the rules. But I understood that this was much more of a ritual than a game.
When the women played in our house I loved to eavesdrop, unseen from the top of the stairs, as they told their stories. So on a recent visit with players in Fair Lawn, N.J., I felt as if I should have been hiding behind the kitchen door in pajamas, not seated. These five 40-something women, three of whom learned the game from their mothers, are passionate about their mah-jongg. If someone can't make the Wednesday game, they shift it to another night; if anyone needs a "fix," they'll schedule an "emergency game." When one player was out sick, they called and left the phone on the table so that she could hear the tiles.
The kibitzing begins as the group gathers, each player with a small purse for her winnings. (The most one could lose in an evening there was $5.) Play starts promptly as they follow the elaborate system of dividing up the wall of tiles and arranging the hands they are dealt on their racks; in each hand, one woman takes a turn sitting out of the game to serve as bettor. Players take turns selecting a tile from the wall and then call out what tile they are discarding. Their jokes and banter -- about their week, children and efforts to avoid the potato chips and pistachio nuts -- is punctuated with "four dot," "flower" and an occasional "I'll take that" when someone claims a discarded tile. The one who completes her hand first calls "Mah-jongg!" and shows her hand.
They pay up, passing quarters or dollars across the table, while displaying and commenting on the unlucky hands. They then push the tiles to the center and joyously shuffle, with their rings and bracelets adding to the racket on the laminated table, and begin again. About 10 minutes have passed, very quickly.
The men at the Hok Shan Family Association on Mott Street, ranging from their 40's to 70's, make the Fair Lawn five look as if they play in slow motion. The tiles have no identifying numbers or letters. There's little talk, no cake, no tile racks, no announcing of discarded tiles, no Monday-morning quarterbacking about the hands they almost had. One hand flows into the next. They'll play a full game, 16 hands, before one of the men lingering nearby might substitute.
Around the corner at the New York Senior Citizen Coalition Center, at the corner of Mulberry and Bayard Streets, many women apply the wisdom of their years to the game. Sitting in foursomes -- some are made up of both men and women, some are all men, but most are all women -- at long lunch tables with thermoses of tea nearby, the players approach the tiles with intensity and refinement. Between hands they exchange chips according to their modest stakes, and by the end of the week they have usually won back whatever they have lost. Several women pause during play to smile at a stranger.
According to a Chinese saying, you shouldn't let your daughter marry someone unless you have played mah-jongg with the family. Using the game as a character meter, you can learn about someone's temper, generosity and honesty. The game can get competitive. Once a man who was feeling the stress of his next move pressed his fingers to his forehead and pushed his head back, not realizing that the tile in his hand was leaving a distinct imprint on his forehead, revealing his strategy.
Many legends surround the Chinese origin of the game, which is said to date to the time of Confucius, or the fifth or sixth century B.C. When mah-jongg was introduced to the United States in the 1920's, it became a national craze, played in clubs and homes under varying rules. In the mid-1930's a group of German-Jewish mah-jongg enthusiasts placed an advertisement in The New York Times inviting interested players to a meeting at the Essex House. They founded the National Mah-Jongg League in 1937 to standardize the game, and every year since have issued a card with updated regulations and a new list of hands. In traditional Chinese mah-jongg, the hands are unchanging.
The new cards are a harbinger of spring, more eagerly awaited in some neighborhoods than the first buds. On or about April 1, about 200,000 laminated red-white-and-blue cards listing the year's official 52 standard hands and rules will arrive at members' homes in regular or optional large-print versions. Within days bags of mail will begin arriving at the league's 57th Street office with opinions about the 2000 edition. A woman distressed by the difficulties of a new card told the league's president, Ruth Unger, that if she were looking for frustration she would have stayed home with her husband.
To design the new card, Mrs. Unger, an associate and six volunteers play mah-jongg six hours a day, three days a week from August to Thanksgiving in the office. Like test drivers for General Motors, they try out 75 new hands, or variations on tile combinations, proposed by a brainstorming committee and select those that work best together. This year there is increased anticipation among players because of the date: the card always features year-related hands and 2000 presents a challenge because there are not many tiles that can represent zero.
Timed with the release of the new card, the National Mah-Jongg League is introducing an Internet game. Members can meet old friends on the league's Web site or play with strangers and, as long as they can type, they can talk. With other software now on the market, people can play American, Chinese and other styles of mah-jongg on the Internet; players can compete against the computer or join a game with other players anywhere in the world.
But whether the game is played Chinese or American style, it takes the same skills to excel, along with luck. In terms of complexity, mah-jongg is somewhere between rummy and bridge. Good players can infer what is concealed in others' hands and shift to another hand if the one they are playing "goes dead." Players must develop an instinct for what to keep and what to discard.
"You have to decide which tiles you're listening to," a Taiwanese-American accountant advises. He and a group of first-generation Taiwanese-American men and women in their 30's and 40's meet occasionally to play mah-jongg on Sundays in Wyckoff, N.J. Their children, munching on pizza bagels, come along to watch. The chatter is a cross between the talk in Hewlett and Chinatown: low-key but persistent, drifting from family news to stocks, from Mandarin to English.
The accountant graciously insists that I take his place, and I play my first hand of mah-jongg. The other players arrange their tiles in perfect walls; I'm trying to keep the top layer of mine from sliding off. When it's my turn, I pick and discard tiles, enjoying the pattern of play. Unlike my mother's tiles, these have no numbers, so I have to count the bams, craks and dots. My mah-jongg mates -- a banker, a graduate student and a computer specialist -- are patient. At the accountant's urging, I call "pung" and take a discarded tile to make a threesome.
I am admiring the way my sequences look, trying to join in the conversation about New York real estate, and relying on my coach to help me so I won't toss out the tile that will make someone else a winner. On the second hand, I have mah-jongg. That they let me win doesn't diminish my sense of small triumph.
Many mah-jongg players say they would play every day if they had time. It is as if sitting with friends face to face through three or more hours of mah-jongg produces something like a runner's high. For some it means entering a zone where the noise of the world is lowered, camaraderie is heightened and the soul is lifted. There is ceremony, mystery, nostalgia, hopefulness -- there's always the next game -- coffee and low-fat cake. Players have too much fun to be smug about it, but they do seem to know something others don't. "There's magic in the tiles," Mrs. Unger says.
Mah-jongg provides continuity and connectedness, but it is, after all, a game. I wonder at the serendipity that brought about this overlap in interests among Jewish and Chinese people. A group in Great Neck, N.Y., used to celebrate both cultures by marking birthdays with lunch and mah-jongg in a kosher Chinese restaurant; the waiters enjoyed watching.
My mother still plays mah-jongg. I no longer peek in, but I feel a sense of awe at her ongoing friendships as well as her dexterity with the tiles. I have her old set, but the case is locked, the key lost. It may be time to break it open.
 
Dragons and Dots, Flowers and Bams
The many versions of mah-jongg include Chinese Classical, Hong Kong Old Style, Shanghai New Style, American, Western, Taiwanese and Filipino, and there are variations within each. The four players agree on table rules before they begin. In American-style mah-jongg a fifth player, the bettor, can alternate in.
A mah-jongg set includes several types of illustrated tiles: four winds (north, east, west and south), three dragons (red, green and white) and flowers. Three suits (dots, bams and craks) are numbered from one to nine. Dots look like tiny buttons, bams are pieces of bamboo and craks are Chinese characters. In American-style mah-jongg only, eight jokers are also used.
As in a card game, the play involves developing a winning hand through rounds of selecting and discarding tiles. In American-style mah-jongg hands are selected from a card published annually. The other styles play with standard hands.
An American-style game begins with players' mixing the tiles, building double-tiered walls of tiles along their racks and then dividing them in a prescribed order. Each player has 13 tiles while the player in the East position has 14. In an exchange called the Charleston, players trade three unwanted tiles to other players in a set order, then make an optional pass to the player opposite. The player who is East then throws out an unwanted tile, face up. The next player, to the right of East, picks a tile from the wall and then throws one out. A player may call a discarded tile to complete a sequence of three (pung), four (kong), or five (quint) of a kind and exposes the matching tiles on the rack. Once a tile is claimed, play procedes with the player to the right of the claimant. This continues until a player completes a hand and calls "mah-jongg."
In the Chinese and other versions, there is no Charleston and different rules apply about claiming tiles and scoring.
For information about playing American-style mah-jongg, visit the Web site of the National Mah-Jongg League, www. nationalmahjonggleague.org. It publishes an introductory booklet, "Mah-Jongg Made Easy."
"Mah-Jongg: Basic Rules and Strategies" by Dieter Kohnen (Sterling Publications) introduces readers to the Classical Chinese style of the game.
Activision, which sells mah-jongg software, has a Web site that includes frequently asked questions about the various versions of the game, along with information about the company's products, at www. activision.com/games/shanghai.

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Images of a Burnished Utopia Born in a Bleak Reality

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
You might not think that February 1930 was the best time to start a magazine about business. But then you are not Henry Luce. He was already the co-founder of one profitable magazine, Time, seven years earlier. He believed, with President Herbert Hoover, that the stock market crash was one of those corrections that would right itself in a few months.
"Business is, essentially, our civilization," Luce said, "for it is the essential characteristic of our times." Something that central deserved to be honored, and Luce figured that a stock market in peril would stir up interest in it, so he didn't let a little financial earthquake stop his plans for a new magazine. That magazine was not only a financial success but also a gift to American photography and photojournalism. It was called Fortune. 
 The International Center of Photography uptown has a show of 154 original prints of photographs published in Fortune's early years, "Picturing Business: The Photography of Fortune, 1930-1965," organized by the center's associate curator, Ann Sass, in conjunction with Fortune's 70th anniversary. The magazine employed top photographers, from Margaret Bourke-White to Berenice Abbott, Walker Evans to Robert Frank, and it prepared the way for picture magazines like Luce's own pioneering example, Life.
The 130 black-and-white prints in this show are vintage work; the color, much of which is in bad shape or no longer exists as prints, has been digitized from the original transparencies and then printed. Fortune had good color from an early date, when color was still very difficult to print.
Luce said he meant to make "the most beautiful magazine yet attempted in this country," and if you except Alfred Stieglitz's Camera Work, he did. This was the old Fortune, with a larger format than the current magazine, heavy stock and gravure-printed photographs with elegant framing lines drawn around them in the early years. The New York Times said it was "sumptuous to the point of rivaling the pearly gates." The magazine was intended for the rich -- it cost $1 an issue, $10 a year -- and looked it. A copy on your coffee table was a sign of class and promised that you could have the time of your life with Fortune.
It is good to have so many images from the magazine, if only to make clear how important Fortune was to photography. It came closer to telling stories in pictures rather than merely illustrating the text, than any American magazine had before, and in its more formal and elegant way it laid the groundwork for Life. For some reason, the photographs on the museum wall often do not have the impact they had or might have had in print, although some are more beautiful than the magazine reproductions. This can happen to photojournalism; work that was meant for the page may well belong there.
Happily, "Picturing Business" puts a number of the actual magazines on display to show the quality of the reproductions, the brilliance of the magazine's design and layout and the way the photographs were integrated into the story. Fortune was stylistically unified to the nth degree. Everything, from the cover to the print font to the ads, which the art department frequently designed for good customers, had a Fortune look. There was even said to be a Fortune-type photograph, much as other magazines had identifying literary styles.
That photograph in the first decade or so was a kind of burnished, heroic industrial image typified by Bourke-White's gleaming dams and statuesque oil derricks. It showed up in other work, too, like Russell Aikins's photograph of Henry and Edsel Ford in front of the massive steel beams and luminous metal smokestacks of the River Rouge plant, or Arthur Gerlach's vision of brave construction workers high above the city. It carried a message Fortune's readers wanted to hear: that industry was beautiful in itself and thriving, no matter what was going on out on the streets, and that America had the might and the technology to overcome obstacles. The Fortune-type photograph was in effect an image of industrial utopianism.
But in 1931 and 32 Fortune also reported on the bleak side of America earlier and more accurately than many other publications, running articles on racial prejudice, unemployment, occupational disease and death and inadequate housing. Archibald MacLeish, the poet, who wrote for Fortune, said the magazine was a better social historian than The New Masses, a magazine with a more obvious interest in the working class. "Picturing Business" includes two pictures of migrant workers in California made by Horace Bristol while he was working with John Steinbeck, who based "The Grapes of Wrath" on his visits to the migrants' camps.
Fortune also featured small-camera, "candid" photojournalism early in the decade; this became the staple of picture magazines in the 1930's. Time Inc. invited the German photographer Dr. Erich Salomon to the United States, and Fortune made good use of him. Salomon's casual, unposed pictures of statesmen were already well known in Europe, where the new style originated. Images like his photograph of William Randolph Hearst at lunch with his guests, who could neither outshine nor outweigh the silver table fixtures, taught people to expect the inside picture.
The magazine maintained its strong reputation for photography in the 1940's and 50's with fine photographers including Bruce Davidson, Roy DeCarava, Arnold Newman, Gordon Parks and Dan Weiner. As Walker Evans was special photographic editor from the 1940's until 1965 -- his Fortune portfolios on various subjects are well represented in the show at the the center -- photography watchers paid attention to the magazine. Evans also brought in younger photographers, principally Robert Frank, whose 1955 essay on "The Congressional," a businessman's train, is evidence that Fortune admitted a fairly broad range of styles into its pages.
Between 1930 and 1965, as other magazines got into the photographic game, the notion of a Fortune-type photograph had faded. Styles changed after World War II, and so did ideas about the world, even about industry. Trust in an ordered world, a sense that the world could be rationally organized and understood by human minds, lingered in the formal certitudes of a good deal of 1930's photography but basically went up in smoke in World War II. And although that war was won in large measure by industrial might, it had also seen the principles of industry turned into assembly-line killing factories. Robust as American manufacturing was in the postwar years, the utopian faith in industry was fraying at the edges.
When Margaret Bourke-White photographed hog carcasses strung up at Swift & Company in 1933, she emphasized their bulk and the rhythm of their repetitive shapes, bestowing on them a kind of piggy grandeur. When Jerry Cooke photographed Harley-Davidson motorcycles in 1950, he saw them as jumbled, irregular shapes of blue and red that reduced a lone worker to insignificance in the middle of a cheerful, manufactured chaos. In 1950 industry was still king, but the time was not all that far off when the king must die.

HEADLINE: The Rules Nasdaq Forgot

BYLINE: By Robert H. Frank; Robert H. Frank, a professor of economics at Cornell University, is the author of "Luxury Fever" and co-author of "The Winner-Take-All Society."

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
The story is told of two economists on their way to lunch who spot what appears to be a $100 bill lying on the sidewalk. When the younger economist stoops to pick up the bill, his older colleague restrains him, saying, "That can't be a $100 dollar bill."
"Why not?" asks the younger colleague. 
 "If it were," comes the reply, "someone would have picked it up by now."
The older economist might have been wrong about that particular bill, of course. Yet his admonition embodies an important truth that Americans seem increasingly determined to ignore -- namely, that low-hanging fruit in public places gets picked very quickly. As in the past, the only way to make real money in the future will be through some combination of talent, thrift, hard work and luck.
Tens of millions of Americans, however, now seem to believe they can get rich in a hurry by simply transferring their money from old-economy stocks, like General Motors or Procter & Gamble, into Oracle, Cisco Systems and other high-tech stocks that have led the Nasdaq index.
So far that strategy has worked like a charm. Someone who invested $100,000 in the Nasdaq index in January 1992 is now holding shares that are worth more than $850,000, and that takes this week's ups and downs into account. Many bullish analysts insist that the ride is far from over, and no one can doubt that the new technologies have thus far generated only a tiny fraction of the gains in productivity they will ultimately produce. It may be no exaggeration, for example, to say that business-to-business e-commerce will reduce the operating costs of many companies by 30 percent or more.
The ultimate value of an e-commerce company, however, depends not on the gains made possible by its technology, but on how much profit it generates.
As in the past, new technologies will continue to generate a burst of new profits for companies that are relatively quick to adopt them. But the historical pattern has been that competition will award the long-run savings from these technologies to consumers in the form of lower prices.
Thus dairy farmers who were quick to adopt bovine somatotropin, the hormone that increases milk yields by as much as 20 percent, reaped a short-term windfall, but as use of the hormone spread, increased production pushed milk prices steadily downward, eroding profit margins.
A similar profit trajectory will characterize most Nasdaq purveyors of new technologies. Organizers of business-to-business e-commerce may indeed save manufacturers hundreds of billions of dollars. But because the new technology companies are no more insulated from competition than dairy farmers, most of those savings will take the form of lower product prices, not higher profits.
Armed with this simple insight, economists have long warned investors against betting their entire fortunes on new technology companies. Many sophisticated portfolio managers share these concerns.
The reality, however, is that investors who want to insulate themselves from risk have no safe haven in today's market.
The cautious investor's natural inclination is to focus on old-economy stocks that are not yet selling for astronomical multiples of their annual earnings. Yet investing in those companies entails another form of risk. If millions of additional Americans continue putting their money behind high-tech companies each month, someone who fails to buy Nasdaq stocks will continue missing out on the greatest financial bonanza in generations.
Thus far, the latter risk is the one people seem most intent on avoiding. The small handful of investment firms whose cautious managers built portfolios that were light on high-tech stocks in recent years have seen their clients depart in droves. For such firms, to continue advising against high-tech stocks is to risk extinction.

Earlier this week, the Nasdaq index plunged almost 9.3 percent from its peak of more than 5,000, set just last Friday. At the same time, the old-economy stocks of the Dow Jones industrials staged a modest rebound.
Is this the beginning of a major realignment, notwithstanding the index's gains yesterday? Someone who knew the answer to that question would not have to work for a living.
But the likely outcome is that the pattern of recent years will continue a while longer. After all, the Nasdaq has swooned many times during its protracted run-up, and each time investors have rushed in to buy tech stocks at the new "bargain" prices, as they seem to have done again yesterday.
If the Nasdaq's upward spiral resumes, still more investors will feel compelled to jump on board. In such an environment, the only thing certain is that a spectacular downturn lies out there somewhere.

HEADLINE: German Cleared to Head I.M.F. as Rivals Bow Out

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
The contentious five-month-long scramble to find a new leader for the International Monetary Fund came to a de facto conclusion today, as the Japanese and American rivals for the job formally withdrew their nominations and cleared the path for a German to take the post for the first time in the fund's history.
Fund officials said the election of the German, Horst Kohler, who heads the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, was now certain. An overwhelming majority of its 182 nations have signaled that they will back him. 
 A coalition of African and Arab countries that had backed Stanley Fischer, the American who serves as deputy managing director of the monetary fund, withdrew his candidacy today. And Japan said it would vote for Mr. Kohler and was no longer pushing the candidacy of Eisuke Sakakibara, former vice finance minister for international affairs.
Mr. Kohler, on a visit to Washington with Germany's finance minister, Hans Eichel, had breakfast with Mr. Fischer today and lunch with Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers. The Clinton administration tipped the scales in favor of Mr. Kohler this week when it agreed to support him. He also won the backing of the 15-nation European Union.
Mr. Fischer, a former Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor who is well regarded by fund members for his day-to-day stewardship, reaffirmed his intention of remaining in the No. 2 post.
"I had an excellent meeting this morning with Mr. Kohler, during which we discussed the challenges the fund faces," Mr. Fischer said in a statement. "I am confident that under his leadership, the fund will become an even more effective institution. I look forward to working closely with him."
The development ends the leadership struggle at the fund, which has been under intense pressure to streamline even with its increasing prominence as a sort of world central bank. The United States rejected Germany's first choice, arguing that the candidate, Caio Koch-Weser, a state secretary in the Finance Ministry, did not have the financial skills or leadership experience.
The rejection set off a feud of sorts with Germany, which had chanpioned Mr. Koch-Weser and lined up grudging acceptance from the European Union. After failing to win broad support for him in a round of voting at the fund, the Germans backed Mr. Kohler.
Neither man tops the lists of European financial officials. But Mr. Kohler gained relatively quick endorsement, at least in part because the European Union and the United States had no desire to pick another fight with Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who had vested prestige in winning the job for a German.
Mr. Kohler, 57, served as a top economic aide to Mr. Schroder's predecessor as chancellor, Helmut Kohl. Now, as head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, he helps finance development projects and back businesses in the former Soviet bloc.

HEADLINE: Group Wants Con Ed to Pay Failure Costs

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Citing a law that requires a utility to pay for its mistakes, a group of New York State legislators and customers petitioned the state Public Service Commission yesterday to prevent Consolidated Edison from passing on to customers costs associated with the shutdown of its Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant.
The petitioners said Con Ed should pay for electricity it is having to buy to make up for the temporary loss of power from its plant, because it knew for many years that four aging steam generators were increasingly prone to leaking and chose not to replace them. Con Ed has estimated the cost at $600,000 a day. 
 The emergency shutdown occurred on Feb. 15 when a corroded tube in one of the generators burst. Federal officials have said it will be at least several weeks before the plant is restarted.
Earlier this week, Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester county executive, proposed a lawsuit that had a similar goal but cited a different law. The county Board of Legislators is expected to consider approving the suit when it meets on March 27.
But Richard L. Brodsky, the chairman of the Assembly Committee on Environmental Conservation and a Westchester Democrat, said that he initiated the new action, called a prudency petition, because it had a better chance of succeeding and had been used before.
In 1982, Robert Abrams, the state attorney general, used the petition process to win a $33.7 million refund from Con Ed after the Public Service Commission ruled that a 59-day shutdown of Indian Point 2 caused by a different kind of leak was caused by "imprudent actions."
Mr. Brodsky said there were ample indications this time that the shutdown was an avoidable consequence of economic decisions by the company. "There is powerful evidence," he said, "that this company tried to squeeze every drop of juice from this lemon and failed to recognize repeated signs that these kinds of ruptures were inevitable."
Last night, a spokesman for Con Ed, Joseph Petta, said he could not discuss the move because the utility had not yet received a copy of the petition.
In recent public meetings, Con Ed officials and inspectors from the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission have said that Indian Point 2 was running well in the days before the emergency shutdown and that leakage rates -- until Feb. 15 -- were far below federal limits.
David Flanagan, a spokesman for the state commission, said the shutdown was already being investigated, adding that the commission could order refunds with or without a petition from customers.
"Obviously," he said, "we will give it a full review, and it's up to the commission to determine if we should initiate a proceeding."
Mr. Brodsky said that an added benefit of a prudency petition, if accepted by the commission, is that it would shift the burden of proof away from state officials and instead force Con Ed to prove that it had acted responsibly before the shutdown.
Finally, he said, the inquiry by the commission would take place in a series of public hearings, not in private discussions between state officials and the utility.
"It's easier for ratepayers to be treated fairly in an open public proceeding," Mr. Brodsky said.

HEADLINE: In New Jersey, Sprawl Keeps Outflanking Its Foes

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: HOPEWELL, N.J., March 16

 BODY:
Leslie Kramer and her husband moved into a big Victorian house in this rural township five years ago to get away from congestion in Westchester County. Carol Ferry and her husband moved here from Hamilton, on the other side of Trenton, for the same reason.
So have hundreds of their neighbors who thought that here, at last, they would be safe from sprawl. 
 After all, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had said that she would make New Jersey a national model for controlling growth in ways that would protect open space and direct growth back to urban areas. Governors across the country, including George E. Pataki of New York and John G. Rowland of Connecticut, have recently begun programs with similar goals.
But like forest creatures who are too slow to outrun a wildfire, the Kramers and the Ferrys have found that the crowded old neighborhoods they tried to flee are on their way to them, led by a giant new development that could produce more office space than a tower of the World Trade Center. And when new census figures this month showed formerly rural parts of New Jersey growing faster than any other place in the region, it was a reminder that stopping sprawl and talking about it are two very different things.
"I'll tell you what I believe -- you can't stop it," said Ms. Kramer, the leader of a failed effort to stop Merrill Lynch from building a project that starts at 3.5 million square feet and could grow to 5.5 million in an old cornfield here. "My husband hit me over the head with that fact all along and I didn't believe him. I kept saying, 'No, this is so wrong on so many levels -- look what it's doing to our community, look how it violates the state plan, look how it goes against everything the governor said she was going to do!' But you know, he was right. You can't stop it, not if the people with the money want it."
If anything, anti-sprawl measures like New Jersey's plan and the governor's fervent calls to protect open space may only deepen residents' sense of betrayal when a project like the one being built by Merrill Lynch here starts rising, in a neck of the state that looks more like Vermont than New Jersey.
The Hopewell project, which began construction about two years ago to replace leased back-office space for Merrill Lynch, also demonstrates anew how money and jobs -- in this case the threat to move 3,500 jobs to Pennsylvania -- can trump public land preservation policy.
So whether it is the project here, or the 1 million square feet of laboratories AT&T recently opened in Middletown, Monmouth County, or the plans to develop 2,000 acres of woods near Stewart Airport in Orange County in New York, sprawl continues to march on across the region.
Some figures from New Jersey: Of the 9.9 million square feet of office space authorized by local officials last year through November, nearly two-thirds is being built in an outer ring of largely rural counties of Morris, Somerset, Hunterdon, Monmouth, Mercer and Ocean.
Somerset, the fastest-growing county in the New York metropolitan region, added more than half a million square feet alone, while Mercer County, home of Princeton and Hopewell and two hours from Manhattan, leads the state with 2.1 million square feet of office space authorized last year, much of it from the Merrill Lynch project.
The Regional Planning Partnership, a nonprofit land-use planning group that studies growth in Mercer, Somerset and Middlesex Counties, forecasts a 40 percent population increase by 2020 there. Even more striking than population growth trends, however, are land-use trends.
Between 1986 and 1995, before the boom began in earnest, Somerset County ate up 10 percent of its open space. Monmouth developed 9.1 percent, Mercer 8.8.
Governor Whitman, in her 1998 inaugural address, announced a $1 billion open space preservation bond act, to buy 1 million acres, and declared, "We must do more to encourage intelligent, responsible growth for New Jersey's future, especially in our cities." Voters passed the bond act almost 2 to 1.
In January, Governor Pataki of New York created a Quality Communities Task Force to study how to direct growth in ways that emphasize redevelopment and reduce sprawl. In Connecticut, Governor Rowland has declared a goal of tripling the amount of land protected from sprawl in the next 25 years.
But the new pledges to stem sprawl have come too late for residents here, who failed to follow the local planning process until it was too late, said Samuel H. Hamill Jr., a former local planning board president and now senior consultant to New Jersey Future, a nonprofit land-use research group. That aloofness from the nitty-gritty of planning issues, he said, is now ending.
"Not only did the governor's bond act pass, but there were any number of local elections that turned on these very questions," Mr. Hamill said.
Merrill Lynch had one big factor in its favor: the land the company chose was zoned for a big project like the company's, however incongruous it might seem to someone driving slowly by on the rural lane that bordered the site. But if the state had any misgivings, they were erased when Merrill Lynch made plain that it was going to be Hopewell or another state, probably an equally rustic corner of Pennsylvania. Governor Whitman, concerned with the company's threat to pull 3,500 or more jobs from the state, gave the project political and financial support.
The state applied for and got $38.5 million in federal money to rebuild the interchange at Interstate 95 and Scotch Road, where the Merrill Lynch project is being built, and it has agreed to help the company avoid $13.5 million in sales taxes. In addition, the state said it would give the company $6.4 million to create at least 1,100 jobs at the site, which will eventually employ 3,500. Finally, Merrill Lynch, the country's largest brokerage house, will get $135 million more in grants for job creation at all 11 of its New Jersey sites.
Eileen McGinnis, the governor's chief policy adviser, lives in Hopewell and defends the project, even as she has her own personal misgivings about it. "I separate my personal feelings from my professional feelings," she said. "On a personal level I drive by it every day and I do wish the project wasn't there. But on a professional level I know that the state plan is not about no growth, it's about smart growth."
The State Development and Redevelopment Plan, adopted in 1992 as guidelines for directing growth to areas that are already built up or have transportation access, is often invoked by preservationists for its goal that the state should use its power to push some development toward the state's hollowed-out cities. But the plan's guidelines are advisory, not mandatory, and subject to economic and political pressures.
The Merrill Lynch site is designated for growth under the state plan as an area with retail stores or other public amenities. Critics point out, however, that there is no public component in the 3.5 million-square-foot first phase.
The site is also designated as a growth area under the plan because it is adjacent to an interstate highway. But Jeff Tittle, executive director of the New Jersey Sierra Club, maintains that by helping Merrill Lynch build on a pristine rural site, the state is working against its own aim of buying land for a public greenway trail from the Delaware River to Princeton through Hopewell, because all land in the area will now be made much more expensive by the immense development.
Yet building deep in the country makes perfect sense from the company's perspective, said Mr. Hamill, even though the state may have wished that the project had gone to a city like Trenton, which has acres of unused industrial space and which lies only a few miles from here.
"The cities in general, and Trenton is no exception, are much less certain than the suburbs as planning environments," Mr. Hamill said. "Things don't happen as quickly in the cities, building inspections aren't on time and policy plans are much more vague, so anyone going there has this uncertainty in the approval process."
In fact, when Merrill Lynch told the state that it would build in Hopewell or leave the state, state officials gingerly raised the idea of building in Trenton.
"Merrill Lynch officials said very clearly that they would not look at Trenton," said Tom Dalessio, Ms. McGinnis's assistant in the governor's policy office. "They wanted a suburban-style campus, so it was either here or Pennsylvania."
In Hopewell, Merrill Lynch found 450 acres of open farmland that had been owned, with development in mind, by Bristol-Myers Squibb, the pharmaceutical concern, from 1955.
It also found a five-member all-Republican town board with strong landowner sympathies that welcomed the prospect of millions of dollars in new taxes for sewers and schools. It did not hurt that the company also bought 440 acres across the road from the family of William E. Schluter, an influential state senator who sits on the Economic Growth, Agriculture and Tourism Committee.
Merrill Lynch has final approval to build 1.3 million square feet of office space on the land, and has preliminary approval to build 2.2 million more at the site. The adjacent 440 acres is zoned for 2 million square feet of commercial development, for a total of 5.5 million square feet of potential, and probable, construction on both sides of the road. One World Trade Center Tower contains 4 million square feet.
Local reaction followed the now-familiar arc from surprise to anger to despair. An anti-growth coalition swept the Republicans off the town board and replaced them with a 4-to-1 Democratic majority, which succeeded in stopping Merrill Lynch's preferred sewer option -- it has others -- but could not block the development.
To Harry J. Ferguson, Merrill Lynch's vice president for real estate operations, the level of anger here in the outer suburbs was new. "We have not run into it before." Mr. Ferguson said. "We typically try to make sure that we're doing what the community wanted us to do, and that's why we look for areas that are already zoned and preapproved. So we were caught a little off guard by the reaction to this."
Now Mrs. Ferry, an office worker, has to wonder if she and her husband, Dennis, a chemist, should think of moving again, to stay ahead of the wave.
When they moved from their starter home in Trenton to a house in Hamilton in 1978, they had fields behind them. When they left for Hopewell in 1985, Mrs. Ferry said, the fields in Hamilton were covered with houses, and a drive that once took 10 minutes took half an hour.
"Where do we go next?" Mrs. Ferry wondered. "There's really no place you can go to hide."
