HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Credit Suisse Under Scrutiny for Ukrainian I.M.F. Loans

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN with JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
Credit Suisse Group, the European banking giant, has long plied the unpredictable waters of overseas financial markets with elan, earning a reputation as a swashbuckler in corners of the globe as far afield as the former Soviet Union and East Asia.
The bank has made lush profits in many of those markets but has also suffered bruising losses when speculative fervor overseas turned against it in recent years. Still, Credit Suisse remains an important player in emerging markets, particularly in the former Soviet Union. 
 Now, Credit Suisse is on the hot seat. Allegations of improprieties in the way the Ukrainian central bank managed International Monetary Fund loans are raising serious questions about the bank's role in the matter.
The bank's chairman, Rainer E. Gut, has been asked to testify before the House Banking Committee next week at a hearing examining money laundering and the possible misuse or theft of I.M.F. money.
The I.M.F. disclosed this week that the Ukrainian central bank engineered a series of financial transactions -- some through Cyprus -- to inflate artificially its foreign currency reserves so that the country could obtain hundreds of millions of dollars in I.M.F. loans that otherwise might have been denied. Some of the transactions were conducted with the help of Credit Suisse's investment banking arm, Credit Suisse First Boston, according to government investigators in the United States.
The I.M.F. has retained the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers to audit the transactions for any evidence of wrongdoing and a report is expected by the end of the month. The Ukrainian government and Credit Suisse have repeatedly denied any wrongdoing.
"We've examined all the transactions in question and we've found nothing to cause us to believe that any of those transactions were inappropriate or illegal," a Credit Suisse spokesman said in an interview. Credit Suisse, citing bank secrecy laws in Cyprus, declined to comment about whether it knew that transactions it conducted for the Ukrainian central bank artificially increased reserve levels.
Credit Suisse was one of the first foreign companies to receive a commercial banking license from the Ukrainian government and the bank has conducted a wide variety of financial services for the government. Just this week, Credit Suisse was one of several banks that helped Ukraine repackage almost $3 billion in foreign debt to avoid a default.
Western financiers said that Alexander Bazarov, who runs Credit Suisse First Boston's Kiev office, has played a key role in winning business for Credit Suisse with the Ukrainian government. And the authorities in the United States said that Mr. Bazarov was the banker responsible for channeling the central bank funds in question through Cyprus. Mr. Bazarov could not be reached for comment, and Credit Suisse declined to comment on questions about him.
Mr. Bazarov, a Ukrainian citizen who once worked in the Ukrainian central bank, is said to be close to Viktor Yushchenko, Ukraine's prime minister. Mr. Yushchenko was formerly the head of Ukraine's central bank. Earlier this week, Mr. Yushchenko canceled a visit to the United States after the Clinton administration told him he should come only after "cleaning up his government." Ukrainian officials said the trip was canceled because of a mining disaster at home.
Mr. Yushchenko's visit was discouraged soon before the Treasury Department and the I.M.F. disclosed the Ukrainian central bank's financial maneuvers late Wednesday.
The I.M.F., a public agency financed by several Western governments, has been widely criticized for lax lending and oversight in the former Soviet Union. But it is the private and very profitable Western commercial and investment banks that have provided the financial plumbing underlying many of the transactions under investigation.
Interest in the role played by Western financial institutions in possibly aiding financial misdeeds in the former Soviet Union was heightened by last year's disclosure that $7 billion in suspect Russian money was funneled through the Bank of New York. The Bank of New York has not been charged with wrongdoing and is cooperating with the investigation.
The Financial Times was the first publication to report on Credit Suisse's involvement with the Ukrainian central bank. One of those cited by the paper as providing information about Credit Suisse was Joel Bartow, a former F.B.I. agent who once worked as a member of the legal defense team for Pavlo Lazarenko, a former Ukrainian prime minister. Mr. Bartow has been out of the country and did not return phone calls seeking comment.
Mr. Lazarenko is being detained by the federal authorities in California while they consider extradition requests from Switzerland and Ukraine on charges of embezzling state funds and money laundering. As prime minister, Mr. Lazarenko may have pocketed millions of dollars from state programs, according to Ukrainian, Swiss and United States authorities.
Mr. Lazarenko has a personal interest in any stories that impugn the integrity of Ukraine's government.
His wealth and power were growing so briskly during 1996 and 1997, his two years as prime minister, that the situation led to a rift with Ukraine's president, Leonid Kuchma, who dismissed Mr. Lazarenko from his influential post. Mr. Lazarenko subsequently formed an opposition party and planned to run for the presidency until he fled Ukraine in late 1998, just days before prosecutors there charged him with embezzling millions of dollars in government funds. Mr. Lazarenko has not been charged with any crime in the United States.
Michael Handwerker, a New York lawyer representing Mr. Lazarenko, said that charges against his client were politically motivated and noted that some of Mr. Lazarenko's reputed co-conspirators are now members of Mr. Kuchma's administration.
Mr. Handwerker would not comment on any of the issues involving the Ukrainian central bank and the I.M.F., other than to point out that Mr. Bartow is no longer a member of Mr. Lazarenko's legal team.
Problems with the management of central bank funds in Ukraine bear striking similarities to questions that were raised last year about the management of Russian central bank reserves. I.M.F.-sponsored audits of its lending to the Russian central bank, also conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers, found no evidence of any misappropriation, although the I.M.F. said that the central bank had misled it about the level of its foreign currency reserves.
Nonetheless, questions still linger about how Russian central bank funds were managed through an offshore entity known as Fimaco. Hefty interest payments earned on billions of dollars invested by Fimaco in high-yielding Russian debt still have not been entirely accounted for -- an issue also under scrutiny in the Ukrainian central bank matter.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE REFORM PARTY;
Buchanan Wraps Himself In McCain's Flag of Reform

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 16

 BODY:
Grafting onto the lesson of the presidential primary contests, Patrick J. Buchanan unveiled a retooled stump speech today for his lagging third-party candidacy, packing this year's politically magic phrase "campaign reform" into its every jot and tittle.
Conceding that the losing insurgent effort of Senator John McCain had made campaign reform "the only real issue" in this presidential year, Mr. Buchanan tailored his remarks to that cause as he took his quest for the Reform Party nomination to Harvard University and accused the two major parties of huge fund-raising abuses in "an incumbents protection racket." 
 "Both Beltway parties are chemically dependent on soft money," Mr. Buchanan told an overflow crowd of more than 300 at the John F. Kennedy School of Government in a speech starkly different from the "pitchfork brigade" appeals of past campaigns to voters aggrieved with a variety of economic and social complaints. "We get no soft money and we take no PAC money."
"Neither Beltway party is going to drain this swamp: it's a protected wetland; they breed in it, they spawn in it," Mr. Buchanan added, sparking general laughter and applause.
He even updated his stump graphics with a giant mock check at his side made out for hundreds of millions of dollars to the major parties and signed "Influence Peddlers."
With his candidacy in the doldrums for months, Mr. Buchanan, who left the Republican Party last October, clearly sought to tap into the public appetite for changes in campaign finance laws that Mr. McCain galvanized in his losing challenge to Gov. George W. Bush.
But during Mr. Buchanan's one-hour appearance, students accused him of exploiting some controversial racial and political views in his chronic presidential candidacy. One student accused him of "selling out" his one political virtue, consistency, in jumping to the Reform line. Another, identifying himself as a rare conservative Republican at the Kennedy school, caustically declared, "Thank you for leaving the party."
Mr. Buchanan gave as good as he got, at one point defending his accusation that Harvard employs elitist quotas favoring groups like Jewish- and Asian-American students at the expense of white Christians.
"Simply because you're at Harvard does not exempt you from the same kind of rules and regulations that Harvard lovingly imposes upon the rest of America," he shot back at one critic. "Pat Buchanan is not a beloved figure in America, but neither is Harvard."
To another questioner, Mr. Buchanan conceded the "risk" that he might ultimately succeed only in playing the spoiler's role and drain enough votes from the Republican line to help Vice President Al Gore be elected. In the view of some political specialists, Mr. Buchanan's current standing of about 6 percent in the polls might be enough in a close race to foil Governor Bush. The Reform line created by Ross Perot drew 19 percent of the vote in 1992 and saw President George Bush defeated by Bill Clinton by a plurality.
Throughout his remarks, Mr. Buchanan made clear his determination to stay in the race and fight for an equal spotlight in this fall's televised presidential debates if, as he expects, he wins the Reform nomination. He said that he expected the major parties to try to block this and that he was preparing a lawsuit to challenge for debating time.
"People have ruined the conservative cause," he declared in criticizing Republican leaders and rebutting a questioner who called him "a reactionary in reformer's clothing."
"For the last seven years they conflated the conservative cause with Clinton bashing," he added.
Framing his speech as a detailed cry for change, Mr. Buchanan called for a ban on unlimited contributions to political parties, or soft money, and the creation of a national initiative and referendum process to let voters directly change the system. He also urged the imposition of term limits on Congress, a body he described as so beholden to big-money donors that it had become a "bellhop stand for the business roundtable."
In sum, Mr. Buchanan brandished the same heady mix of political iconoclasm and personal controversy that was his stump signature in 1992 and 1996, when he drew early primary support but failed to win the Republican nomination. His quest this time, in which he has said he will fight Mr. Perot if the latter runs again, is complicated by the need to build political organizations in most of the 29 states where the Reform Party does not exist.
Students questioned how the Reform Party, which in the past shied from social and cultural issues, might ever embrace Mr. Buchanan, whose opposition to abortion has been his political keystone. The candidate replied that he had not altered his views but, rather than feature them in the Reform platform, he would "append" them to the platform as a personal statement.
Mr. Buchanan drew strong applause at the close of a performance in which he handled even a lampoon touch when a young man beamed and asked him out on a date.
"Shelly, would it be O.K.?" Mr. Buchanan asked, turning to his wife with a big grin. Then the candidate guffawed as he told the audience, "She said it would be O.K.!"

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Edge Up Slightly But Oil Remains Inflation Threat

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Inflation at the producer level was absent from the nation's economy last month with the exception of higher costs for oil and tobacco products, government figures showed today. Other reports showing gains in housing starts and manufacturing suggested that the economy was continuing its robust expansion.
The overall Producer Price Index rose 1 percent last month after being unchanged in January. But prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers, excluding food and energy costs -- the so-called core rate -- rose 0.3 percent in February after falling 0.2 percent in January, the Labor Department said. Without tobacco prices, February's core rate was unchanged. A surge in the cost of petroleum products last month more than offset declines in prices of autos, computers and drugs. 
 "The inflation problem is still an energy-price problem," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York. "The bottom line: There is still no real sign of inflation in core prices."
That will not deter Federal Reserve policy makers from raising interest rates again when they meet on Tuesday, analysts said, because they are still concerned that the economy is growing too fast and threatens to cause an acceleration in inflation. The Fed has raised the rate on overnight loans between banks a full percentage point since June.
Three other reports today reflected the economy's resilience. Starts of new housing rose 1.3 percent in February, led by a 19.2 percent increase in construction of multifamily homes. Starts of single-family houses fell 3.9 percent.
Business at Philadelphia-area factories expanded at an increased pace in March as new orders surged, a Fed report showed. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's general economic index rose to 25 from 13.3 in February, reaching its highest level since July 1996. Analysts had expected the index to slip to 13.2.
And the Labor Department said first-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell 19,000, to a seasonally adjusted 263,000 last week -- the lowest in 26 years. Claims rose 6,000, to 281,000, the previous week. The four-week average for claims fell to 271,750 -- also the lowest in 26 years -- from 277,500.
The rise in producer energy prices was the biggest increase since October 1990. Oil prices have tripled since December 1998. In New York, crude oil for April delivery rose 37 cents, or 1.2 percent, to $31.09 a barrel today.

HEADLINE: Morris Abram Is Dead at 81; Rights Advocate Led Brandeis

BYLINE: By WILLIAM HONAN 

 BODY:
Morris B. Abram, a small-town boy from Georgia who went on to play a role in the civil rights movement, become a leader of the American Jewish community, serve as president of Brandeis University and fill posts on a variety of commissions and panels under five presidents, died yesterday at a hospital in Geneva. He was 81.
The cause was a sudden viral infection, said Pranay Gupte, a family friend. 
 At his death Mr. Abram, who lived in Geneva, was chairman of U.N. Watch, an organization affiliated with the World Jewish Congress that he founded in 1993 with Edgar M. Bronfman, the businessman and philanthropist. Mr. Abram was also of counsel to the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, where he had been a partner for many years.
In 1973, Mr. Abram was told he had acute myelocytic leukemia. His fight against the disease impelled him to write an autobiography, "The Day is Short," in 1982.
Mr. Abram was a young lawyer in Atlanta specializing in railroad cases in 1949 when he began a 14-year struggle to overturn a Georgia electoral rule that gave disproportionate weight in primary elections to ballots cast in predominantly white rural areas at the expense of those cast by urban blacks. The rule perpetuated segregation in Georgia.
Mr. Abram felt the sting of the rule in 1953 when he sought the Democratic nomination for Congress from the Fifth District. He ran on a platform that urged the desegregation of schools and carried populous Fulton County, which includes Atlanta. But he lost two smaller rural counties that had disproportionate weight under the rule and lost the election.
Over the years Mr. Abram helped bring cases against the rule to the United States Supreme Court. On March 18, 1963, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, who had been briefed by Mr. Abram, argued the case before the Supreme Court. In a historic ruling, the court declared the rule unconstitutional because "within a given constituency there can be room for but one constitutional rule -- one voter, one vote."
It was the most notable of Mr. Abram's victories in the civil rights struggle. He also helped to start the first large, middle-income housing project open to black families in Atlanta. And defending civil rights workers in Georgia in 1963, he won decisions that helped overturn the state's insurrection and illegal assembly laws, which had been used against civil rights demonstrators.
Mr. Abram's career in public service began when President John F. Kennedy named him the first general counsel to the Peace Corps in 1961. President Lyndon B. Johnson made him United States representative to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, co-chairman of the Planning Committee of the White House Conference on Civil Rights and a member of the Committee on the Office of Economic Opportunity.
President Jimmy Carter appointed him chairman of the President's Commission for the Study of the Ethical Problems of Medicine. He also served President Ronald Reagan as vice-chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. President George Bush designated him United States Permanent Representative to the United Nations in Geneva.
Mr. Abram led the Moreland Act Commission, which in 1975 investigated corruption in the nursing home industry in New York. The commission's recommendations led to a number of changes, among them the closing of 68 nursing homes that did not comply with fire-safety codes.
Morris Berthold Abram was born on June 19, 1918, in Fitzgerald, Ga., a small railroad town founded by Northern veterans of the Civil War. He was one of four children born to Sam Abram, a harness maker and storekeeper born in Romania, and the former Irene Cohen, the daughter of a doctor and a granddaughter of Rabbi Elias Eppstein, one of the first Reform rabbis in the United States.
After graduating summa cum laude from the University of Georgia in 1938, Mr. Abram was chosen as a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford, but Britain entered World War II before he could attend. Instead, Mr. Abram entered the University of Chicago Law School, graduating in 1940.
After the war, in which he served as an Army Air Corps public relations officer, he attended Oxford, receiving a bachelor's degree in 1948 and a master's degree in 1953. In a summer recess at Oxford, a professor arranged for Mr. Abram to join the staff of prosecutors at the International Military Tribunal at Nuremberg.
Horrified by what he learned about the Holocaust, he regarded the experience as a turning point. He was national president of the American Jewish Committee from 1963 to 1968; chairman of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry from 1983 to 1988; and chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations from 1986 to 1989. He also helped to organize a demonstration of 200,000 people on the Mall in Washington protesting the refusal of the Soviet Union to permit Jews to emigrate to Israel and the West.
In 1963 he and his family moved to New York, where he joined the law firm of Paul, Weiss. Five years later he was named president of Brandeis, the nonsectarian university founded in 1948 under Jewish auspices in Waltham, Mass. He later wrote, "Part of me, it seemed, had done nothing for years except compile the right sort of resume for the job."
But two years later he resigned the post amid turmoil and bitterness.
His inauguration was attended by Coretta Scott King, Bayard Rustin and other figures from the civil rights movement. But soon after, many students and faculty members demanded that the university oppose the war in Vietnam and create housing for the poor, among other demands.
Mr. Abram would have none of it, insisting that "the university as an institution should stay out of politics."
He later acknowledged having made mistakes, like dismissing what he considered an insubstantial proposal for a black studies program with the insensitive remark, "I do not wish to preside over a university of superficialities."
On another occasion, when a group of students asked to be shown the university's investment portfolio to see whether it was "tainted," he said, jokingly, that Brandeis's endowment, compared with those of other major American universities, "taint enough."
The students were not amused. Soon, Mr. Abram recalled, they began to ignore his greetings and many on campus would go out of their way to avoid him.
In January 1969, 65 African-American students occupied Ford Hall. Unlike the administrators of Harvard and Columbia when faced with similar takeovers, Mr. Abram would not call in the police. After 11 days, the students drifted away, and Mr. Abram earned praise in some quarters for his restraint. But Mr. Abram lost whatever credit he earned among many on campus when he tried to punish those responsible for the takeover. This effort was thwarted by the Brandeis board, faculty and disciplinary committees.
Mr. Abram's presidency was fatally wounded. He resigned in 1970 and returned to Paul, Weiss. For the next nine years, he also was chairman of the United Negro College Fund, which raises money for predominantly black colleges and universities.
Mr. Abram's experience at Brandeis hardened his views, and he became a vigorous opponent of affirmative action. This came to the attention of President Reagan, and Mr. Abram was nominated to the United States Commission on Civil Rights in 1983. The nomination was opposed by some prominent blacks who considered him "not committed to equal opportunity," which pained Mr. Abram.
He wrote about it in his autobiography: "Liberalism for me means that, while men differ in their natural endowments, they must be treated as equal citizens in the eyes of the law; that they should possess equality of opportunity and be afforded some minimum of social benefits. These principles, which united American liberals for generations, now divide me from some who seek equality of result and who sanction the preferences imposed by government to attain it."
Mr. Abram, who once considered himself a liberal Democrat, said he never voted for a Democrat for president after Jimmy Carter.
During his career, he was president of the Field Foundation from 1965 to 1982; a board member of the Twentieth Century Fund from 1959 until his death; and a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
Mr. Abram's marriage to the former Jane Isabella Maguire ended in divorce in 1974 and a second marriage, to Carlyn Feldman Fisher, ended in divorce in 1987. He is survived by his wife, the former Bruna Molina, whom he married in 1990; two daughters, Ann Abram of Westport, Conn., and Ruth J. Abram of Manhattan, who is president of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum.
Also surviving are three sons, Morris Berthold Jr., of Los Angeles, J. Adam, of Chapel Hill, N.C., and Joshua A., of Manhattan; a stepson, Martin Molina of Zurich; a stepdaughter, Gabriela Molina of Cambridge, England; a sister, Ruthann Reis of Washington; a brother, Dr. Lewis Abram of Boca Raton, Fla., and nine grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Chief Says Suit Is Political And He'll Stay At Port Agency

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 16

 BODY:
Robert E. Boyle, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, vowed today to remain in his job, and Gov. George E. Pataki said he was welcome to stay, despite accusations by the state attorney general that Mr. Boyle had defrauded the hospital he once headed.
But Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, who has traditionally had veto power over the choice of executive director for the agency, was noncommittal, saying through a spokesman that she wanted to discuss Mr. Boyle's future with Mr. Pataki before commenting publicly. 
 Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York attorney general, filed a civil lawsuit against Mr. Boyle on Wednesday, charging that he had illegally profited from business deals with Hudson Valley Hospital Center in Peekskill when he was its chairman, in the early 1990's. The suit seeks more than $500,000 in restitution to the hospital.
Officials in the Pataki administration and the attorney general's office said earlier this week that they expected Mr. Boyle to leave the authority soon after the accusations were made public, either by resigning or by waiting until his term expires next month and not seeking reappointment. But Mr. Boyle said in a statement released today, "I have no intention of resigning my Port Authority post, and Governor Pataki has encouraged that decision and strongly endorsed my staying in place and fighting the Attorney General's political 'I gotcha' lawsuit."
At a news conference, Mr. Pataki said, "I have no reason to believe he should do anything but continue to serve the people of this state well." He added that he had not asked Mr. Boyle to explain his side of the accusations. And the governor, a Republican, declined to speculate on the motives of Mr. Spitzer, a Democrat, saying only that he was "a little shocked" at the suit.
But the tone from Mrs. Whitman's office was markedly different. "The allegations are of a serious nature, and it's one of a number of things she'd like to talk to Governor Pataki about," said Peter J. McDonough Jr., a spokesman for Mrs. Whitman. "There is some comfort taken in the fact that the allegations are not in any way related to Port Authority business, but before she says anything about his long-term future at the Port Authority, she needs to speak with Governor Pataki."
Officially, the Port Authority's 12-member board, appointed by the two governors, selects the executive director. But by longstanding tradition, the New York governor chooses the executive director and the New Jersey governor selects the board chairman, with each having veto power over the other's choices.
Lewis M. Eisenberg, chairman of the authority, would not comment today on Mr. Boyle. But some authority officials said today that while they considered Mr. Boyle a good manager, they had concerns about his ability to run the sprawling agency while fending off Mr. Spitzer's suit.
Mr. Boyle said the suit was based on "incomplete and inaccurate allegations that go back 10 years."
The officials who had predicted that Mr. Boyle would leave, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said today that they could only guess that he had changed his mind -- or that he might be postponing his departure for a face-saving interval, so that it would not appear that he was being forced out.
The Port Authority has been in turmoil recently, caught in a struggle between Mr. Pataki and Mrs. Whitman over how its spending should be divided between the two states. Because of that dispute, the agency has been unable to sign new contracts with the nation's two largest shipping companies, which have been threatening to move their operations to another port, a potential major loss to the region's economy.
Before taking over the Port Authority three years ago, Mr. Boyle was president of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where he won praise for eliminating organized crime influences, streamlining operations and bringing new business to a moribund center. Similarly, he was credited with reversing the fortunes of Hudson Valley, turning a small failing hospital into a much larger economic success story.
But news reports have long raised questions about some business practices at the hospital, in which some board members' private businesses had dealings with the hospital.
Mr. Spitzer's civil lawsuit, filed in state Supreme Court in Manhattan, contends that many of those transactions violated the state's laws on the conduct of nonprofit corporations, and that the hospital failed to comply with laws requiring disclosure of those relationships to the attorney general's office. Most of those accusations involve Mr. Boyle, but the attorney general also accused two other board members of similar wrongdoing.
The most serious charge made in the suit contends that Mr. Boyle committed fraud by disguising from the hospital his role in a real estate deal in the early 1990's. Mr. Spitzer contends that Mr. Boyle was a secret partner in a real estate company that leased a building to the hospital, then sold it to the hospital two years later, at a profit of $550,000.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Says Bush Plan Is 'Economic Snake Oil'

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Wasting no time in sharpening his knives against Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, Vice President Al Gore today ridiculed Mr. Bush for proposing an economic plan laced with "economic snake oil," a plan with a tax cut that Mr. Gore said was so reckless even the Republicans in Congress had better sense than consider it.
"Governor Bush's tax scheme is so risky, so reckless, that just yesterday the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, given an opportunity to vote for it, turned it down, turned the other way, said we don't want to even cast a vote on that thing," Mr. Gore said. "They came up with some gyrations to avoid having to vote on it." 
 In a day of campaigning around Washington, Mr. Gore also escalated the administration's battle with the National Rifle Association and what he described as the Republican "lackeys" in Congress who do its bidding. In a speech to the Consumer Federation of America -- an event that his office billed as official rather than political because Mr. Gore had been invited in his capacity as vice president -- Mr. Gore raised the issue of gun control.
Referring to earlier comments by Wayne LaPierre, the association's executive vice president, that President Clinton and Mr. Gore were willing to accept a certain level of killing to further their political agenda, Mr. Gore said, "Those kind of comments are shameful and they're wrong."
Noting that the Republican leadership had refused for eight months to allow a conference committee between the House and Senate to meet to discuss gun control proposed in one of the two chambers' juvenile crime bills, Mr. Gore added: "What we don't need is more violent rhetoric from those whose policies do nothing to stop gun violence and indeed are designed to paralyze efforts such as those as would take place in this conference committee if the N.R.A. would allow its legislative lackeys to meet, to permit the conference to meet."
Mr. Gore also leaped at the opportunity today to ridicule Mr. Bush for failing to heed any lessons from Senator John McCain, who has suspended his presidential campaign against Mr. Bush. In an appearance before about 50 members of the Amalgamated Transit Union, Mr. Gore cited a Bush interview and said of him, "He even said in this morning's New York Times that he didn't learn a thing from John McCain in the Republican primaries and wasn't going to change anything whatsoever in an effort to reach out to McCain or to accommodate whatever he could have learned from John McCain."
